Term.Title: Authentication
Term.Description: Verification of the genuineness of a document or signature, to make it effective or valid. (http://www.businessdictionary.com)

Term.Title: Authorisation
Term.Description: The process of delegating power to authorise an action and the seeking and granting permission to undertake a requested action.

Term.Title: Authorise
Term.Description: To officially empower someone to act.

Term.Title: Authority
Term.Description: Permission; a right coupled with the power to do an act or order others to act.

Term.Title: Autism
Term.Description: A pervasive developmental disorder of children, characterized by impaired communication, excessive rigidity, and emotional detachment.

Term.Title: Automated Boxing Scoring System
Term.Description: AIS created system that instroduces objectivity into the scoring of amateur boxing matches.

Term.Title: Automatic First Down
Term.Description: For several of the most severe fouls against the defensive team, a first down is awarded to the offensive team even if the result of the penalty does not advance the ball beyond the line to gain.

Term.Title: Avagoyermug
Term.Description: Have a go you mug - yelled to give encouragement.

Term.Title: Avalon Junior Rugby League Football Club Inc
Term.Description: http://www.avalonbulldogs.com.au/

Term.Title: Avast
Term.Description: Stop, cease or desist from whatever is being done.

Term.Title: Average Inventory
Term.Description: Average inventory is the beginning inventory for a period, plus the amount at the end of the same period, divided by two. It is most commonly used in situations where just using the period-end inventory yields highly variable results, due to significant ongoing changes in the inventory level.

Term.Title: Avoidable Cost
Term.Description: An avoidable cost is a cost that you can eliminate by not engaging in or no longer performing an activity.

Term.Title: Avoidable Hinder
Term.Description: When one player interferes with another and the interference was avoidable. The penalty is the loss of the rally.

Term.Title: Avoidant Personality Disorder
Term.Description: A condition characterised by a lifelong pattern of extreme shyness, feelings of inadequacy, and sensitivity to rejection.

Term.Title: Avulsion
Term.Description: A tearing away.

Term.Title: Award
Term.Description: An award is something given to a person or a group of people to recognize excellence in a certain field; a certificate of excellence.

Term.Title: Awasewaza
Term.Description: To score an Ippon by scoring two Waza-ari.

Term.Title: Awash
Term.Description: So low in the water that the water is constantly washing across the surface.

Term.Title: Away
Term.Description: When two or more players are playing a game, this refers to the ball that is furthest away from the hole. The away ball goes first.

Term.Title: Aweigh
Term.Description: Position of an anchor just clear of the bottom.

Term.Title: Axel Jump
Term.Description: The only jump counted as a jump element that starts from skating forward. An axel jump has an extra half rotation (180 degrees), and as all jumps is landed with the skater gliding backwards.

Term.Title: Axel Paulsen Jump
Term.Description: The Axel is a figure skating jump with a forward take off. It is named after Norwegian figure skater Axel Paulsen. Paulsen was the first skater to perform the jump in 1882. An Axel jump has an extra rotation in the air because of its forward take off. The jump takes off from the left forward outside edge and lands on the right back outside edge.

Term.Title: Axel to Axel Measure
Term.Description: The length between the two pivotal axels which hold the cams onto the limbs on a compound bow.

Term.Title: Axilla
Term.Description: The armpit, underarm, or oxter is the area on the human body directly under the joint where the arm connects to the shoulder.

Term.Title: Azerbaijan
Term.Description: Country code = AZ

Term.Title: B1 (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: From no light perception in either eye to light perception, but inability to recognise the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction.

Term.Title: B1 Class (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: From no light perception in either eye to light perception, but inability to recognise the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction.

Term.Title: B1 Class (Biathlon) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: From no light perception in either eye to light perception, but inability to recognise the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction.

Term.Title: B1 Class (Cross Country Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: From no light perception in either eye to light perception, but inability to recognise the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction.

Term.Title: B1 Vision Impaired Athlete
Term.Description: Athletes that have no ability to perceive light in either eye, or some ability to perceive light, but an inability to recognise the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction.

Term.Title: B2 (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Ability to recognise objects up to a distance of 2 metres i.e. below 2/60 and / or visual field of less than five degrees.

Term.Title: B2 Class (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Ability to recognise objects up to a distance of 2 metres i.e. below 2/60 and / or visual field of less than five degrees.

Term.Title: B2 Class (Biathlon) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Ability to recognise objects up to a distance of 2 metres i.e. below 2/60 and / or visual field of less than five degrees.

Term.Title: B2 Class (Cross Country Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Ability to recognise objects up to a distance of 2 metres i.e. below 2/60 and / or visual field of less than five degrees.

Term.Title: B2 Vision Impaired Athlete
Term.Description: Athletes that have no ability to perceive light in either eye, or some ability to perceive light, but an inability to recognise the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction.

Term.Title: B3 (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Can recognise contours between 2 and 6 metres away i.e. 2/60 - 6/60 and visual field of more than five degrees and less than twenty degrees.

Term.Title: B3 Class (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Can recognise contours between 2 and 6 metres away i.e. 2/60 - 6/60 and visual field of more than five degrees and less than twenty degrees.

Term.Title: B3 Class (Biathlon) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Can recognise contours between 2 and 6 metres away i.e. 2/60 - 6/60 and visual field of more than five degrees and less than twenty degrees.

Term.Title: B3 Class (Cross Country Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Can recognise contours between 2 and 6 metres away i.e. 2/60 - 6/60 and visual field of more than five degrees and less than twenty degrees.

Term.Title: B3 Vision Impaired Athlete
Term.Description: Athletes that has a standard of vision between 2/60 and 6/60 and / or a field of vision greater than 5 degrees and less than 20 degrees.

Term.Title: B4 (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: From visual acuity above 20/200 and up to a visual acuity of 20/70 with a visual field larger than twenty degrees. These athletes are ineligible for Paralympic competition.

Term.Title: Baby Giro
Term.Description: http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/

Term.Title: Back (Archery)
Term.Description: This is the side of the bow that is facing away from the archer.

Term.Title: Back (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: Generally, the backline consists of smaller and faster players.

Term.Title: Back Alley
Term.Description: When playing doubles this is the area between the back boundary line and the long service line.

Term.Title: Back and Fill
Term.Description: To use the advantage of the tide being with you when the wind is not.

Term.Title: Back Board
Term.Description: The border at the extreme ends of the sheet.

Term.Title: Back Bowl
Term.Description: A bowl that comes to rest beyond the Jack.

Term.Title: Back Crawl
Term.Description: A swimmer will lie on their back and their head will be raised. Their arms will be moving in clockwise direction and the legs will be raised vertically and they will be doing a flutter kick.

Term.Title: Back Door
Term.Description: When the ball goes around the lip of the cup and then does drop in from the back of the hole.

Term.Title: Back Flop
Term.Description: When a skier is able to first sit back and then lie back on their skies while still moving.

Term.Title: Back Foot Contact
Term.Description: Back foot contact is the position of the bowler at the instant when the back foot lands on the ground just prior to delivering the ball. For a right-handed bowler, the back foot is normally the right foot. An alternative name for back foot contact is coil.

Term.Title: Back Judge (Gridiron)
Term.Description: They are one of the referees. The back judge watches the wide receiver and the defender who are closest to them. They rule on if a catch was a legal catch, on fumbles and on penalties in the backfield. They are also in charge of keeping the time between plays.

Term.Title: Back Layout
Term.Description: When a skier does a single flip in a layout position.

Term.Title: Back Layout (Synchronised Swimming)
Term.Description: The swimmers body will be stationary with the swimmer lying on their back with the face, chest, thighs and feet on the surface of the water.

Term.Title: Back Line (Curling)
Term.Description: The line right behind the house. If a rock completely crosses the back line, it is removed from play.

Term.Title: Back line (Hockey)
Term.Description: The line signifying the end of the field. This is also called the goal line. When an offensive player knocks the ball out-of-bounds over the back line the defending team gets to put the ball back in play by taking the ball, up to about 16.4 yards (15 metres) parallel to the sideline from the spot where the ball went out.

Term.Title: Back Line (Netball)
Term.Description: The boundary lines at each end of the court.

Term.Title: Back Lip
Term.Description: The edge of a bunker or sand trap that's farthest from the green.

Term.Title: Back Nine
Term.Description: The final nine holes, 10-18, of an 18-hole golf course.

Term.Title: Back Pass
Term.Description: This is a defensive pass to pass the ball backwards to help the attacking team get their offense in place before moving forward to attack the defenders goal.

Term.Title: Back Row (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: Three forwards make up the back row of the scrum - two second-rowers and a loose forward.

Term.Title: Back Somersault
Term.Description: When a skier does one backflip.

Term.Title: Back Stick
Term.Description: This is when the ball hits the rounded face of the hickey stick. This is an illegal shot.

Term.Title: Back Swing
Term.Description: A golfer's back swing begins when he moves the club head away from the ball and it ends when he begins to move the club head toward the ball to hit it.

Term.Title: Back Tuck
Term.Description: A backflip that is done in a tuck position.

Term.Title: Back Walkover
Term.Description: The swimmer starts out lying flat on the surface of the water face up. The swimmer then moves into a back pike position and then the swimmer raises one leg and brings this leg completely over so the swimmer ends with their legs are doing a split, then the swimmer brings the other leg over to be next to the first leg while simultaneously bring their head and torso to the surface of the water so they are now lying face down in the water.

Term.Title: Backboards (Bocce)
Term.Description: The shorter court walls at each end of the court. Sometimes called endboards or backwalls.

Term.Title: Backbone
Term.Description: the largest cable or channel of a network or an Internet that carries the heaviest data traffic at highest possible speed, and which connects every main server and device on the network. (http://www.businessdictionary.com)

Term.Title: Backcheck
Term.Description: Rushing back to the defensive zone in response to an opposing team's attack.

Term.Title: Backcourt (Badminton)
Term.Description: The rear quarter area of the court.

Term.Title: Backcourt (Racquetball)
Term.Description: The rear quarter area of the court.

Term.Title: Backcourt (Volleyball)
Term.Description: The area from the endline to the attack line.

Term.Title: Backdoor
Term.Description: A backdoor play is when a player without the ball gets behind the defense and receives a pass for an easy score.

Term.Title: Backfield
Term.Description: The area of an American football field behind the line of scrimmage. The backfield or offensive backfield can also refer to members of offense who begin plays behind the line, typically including any backs on the field, such as the quarterback, running back and / or fullback.

Term.Title: Backflip (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: A reverse somersault in the air. They are banned in competition, but play a role in show skating and exhibitions.

Term.Title: Back-foot
Term.Description: The foot that is closest to the back of the snowboard.

Term.Title: Background Briefs
Term.Description: Background briefs are informal papers addressing a wide range of topics to include country profiles, military organizations, subject matter primers and history.

Term.Title: Backhand (Squash)
Term.Description: When a player hits the ball with their hand turned so the back of the hand is moving in the direction the ball is hit.

Term.Title: Backhand (Tennis)
Term.Description: When a player hits the ball with their hand turned so the back of the hand is moving in the direction the ball is hit.

Term.Title: Backhand Corner
Term.Description: An area of the court, where a side-wall and the back-wall meet on the same side as a player's backhand.

Term.Title: Backhand Draw
Term.Description: When the bowl is aimed to the left of the Jack, and curves to the right.

Term.Title: Backhand Push
Term.Description: A shot that is used to return short shots and shots that have a lot of backspin on them. The stroke on this shot is short and the paddle is held at a slight angle in order to try and put backspin on the ball.

Term.Title: Backhand Shot
Term.Description: The opposing team's end of the ice which extends from the blue line to the end boards.

Term.Title: Backhand Shot (Water Polo)
Term.Description: A pass or shot in which the ball carrier flips the ball directly behind him.

Term.Title: Backing on the Ball
Term.Description: Backing up from the sidewall, especially on service, to take a ball that is coming out far from the side and / or backwall.

Term.Title: Backlift
Term.Description: Backlift is the term used in cricket, describing how a batsman lifts his bat in preparation for hitting the ball.

Term.Title: Backmen
Term.Description: The 6 players who play defense and who stay in their teams defensive half of the field.

Term.Title: Back-Pike Position
Term.Description: A closed pike position. The swimmers body is bent at the waist. The legs are kept straight and close together and the torso is kept straight. The swimmers head and torso are underwater the legs are out of the water at a 45 degree angle. The swimmer takes on the appearance of a safety pin. The swimmers goal is to hold this position for an extended period of time.

Term.Title: Backscratcher
Term.Description: A maneuver when a skier touches their back with the tails of both skis with the skies being parallel and the tips pointing straight down.

Term.Title: Backscreen
Term.Description: An off the ball screen, usually done while the defender has his back to the screener.

Term.Title: Backside
Term.Description: Where the heels on a snowboard are. This is also the area behind the snowboarders back in the half-pipe or when a snowboarder is doing a trick off a wall. Also, any trick which gets air when done on the backside wall of the half-pipe.

Term.Title: Backside Hand Plant
Term.Description: A 180-degree hand-plant where the snowboarder has their back or rear hand or both hands placed on the lip of the wall and then does a backside rotation.

Term.Title: Backside Mechanics
Term.Description: The movements of the running form that take place behind the athlete's centre of mass.

Term.Title: Backside Rotation
Term.Description: A rotation in which the snowboarders back is the first thing to cross the line or direction they are traveling in.

Term.Title: Backside Turn
Term.Description: A heelside turn on the edge of the board. The rider's back will be uphill.

Term.Title: Backside Wall
Term.Description: The wall your back faces if you were to ride straight down the pipe.

Term.Title: Backspin (Racquetball)
Term.Description: Reverse rotation on the ball.

Term.Title: Backspin (Tennis)
Term.Description: Shot that rotates the ball backwards after it is hit.

Term.Title: Backsplash
Term.Description: Water thrown back toward the bow direction by the blade as it enters the water.

Term.Title: Backstay
Term.Description: A brace which is part of the rigger of sweep rowing boats, which extends toward the bow from the top of the pin.

Term.Title: Backstays
Term.Description: Long lines or cables, reaching from the stern of the vessel to the mast heads, used to support the mast.

Term.Title: Backstop
Term.Description: The stop mechanism on the seat slides which prevents the rower's seat from falling off the sliding tracks at the back end (towards the boat's bow) of the slide tracks.

Term.Title: Backstroke
Term.Description: The swimmer starts in the water, they are holding on to the backstroke starting grips and have their feet, that must be completely underwater, against the wall of the pool. When the starting signal goes off the swimmers push off the wall with their feet and simultaneously lets go of the starting grips.

Term.Title: Swimming for the Disabled terms and techniques
Backstroke Flags
Term.Description: These flags are 16 feet (5 metres) from the end of the pool and are 5 feet 9 inches (1.8 metres) high. They help to serve as a reference point for swimmers doing the backstroke, so they are able to tell how far away from the wall they are.

Term.Title: Backstroke Starting Grips
Term.Description: What Backstroke swimmers hold on to when they are starting a backstroke race.

Term.Title: Backswing (Tennis)
Term.Description: Portion of a swing where the racquet is swung backwards in preparation for the forward motion to hit the ball.

Term.Title: Backup Data
Term.Description: Duplicate copy of data saved during a backup session, and available as replacement of damaged or lost primary data.

Term.Title: Backwall Shot
Term.Description: When the ball is played off back-wall and driven to the front wall without the ball hitting the floor.

Term.Title: Backward Point
Term.Description: Behind square; further towards the end occupied by the batsman on strike and further away from the end occupied by the bowler.

Term.Title: Backward Pumping
Term.Description: A description of a skater using their outside leg to push off the ice while gliding along the ice on the outside edge of their inside skate.

Term.Title: Backward Snowplow
Term.Description: When a skier moves down the slope backward in a snowplow position with the tails of the skies together.

Term.Title: Backward Square Leg
Term.Description: This position is square of the wicket on the leg side, standing slightly behind the line of the wicket.

Term.Title: Backwater
Term.Description: To propel the shell backwards.

Term.Title: Bacon
Term.Description: Scabs on a rider's knees, elbows etc.

Term.Title: Bad Debt
Term.Description: An uncollectible debt.

Term.Title: Bad Faith
Term.Description: Intentional dishonest act by not fulfilling legal or contractual obligations, misleading another, entering into an agreement without the intention or means to fulfill it, or violating basic standards of honesty in dealing with others.

Term.Title: Bad Snap
Term.Description: A bad snap means that the center, whose job is to hike the ball, was not able to hand the ball to the quarterback and the ball drops to the ground and it ends up as a fumble. A bad snap can also happen on field goal and extra point attempts.

Term.Title: Badminton Australia
Term.Description: http://www.badminton.org.au/ Unit 15 8 Techno Park Drive Williamstown VICTORIA 3016

Term.Title: Badminton Court
Term.Description: The area where the game is played marked by the boundary lines, which are the sidelines and the baseline. The Court is 44 feet or 13.40 metres long. It is 20 feet or 6.10 metres wide for doubles play and 17 feet or 5.18 metres wide for singles play.

Term.Title: Badminton Horse Trials
Term.Description: http://www.badminton-horse.co.uk/

Term.Title: Badminton World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.bwfbadminton.org/

Term.Title: Badminton World Federation
Term.Description: BWF http://www.bwfbadminton.org/

Term.Title: Bag of...
Term.Description: The number of goals a player kicks in one game, e.g. a bag of six.

Term.Title: Baggy Green
Term.Description: The baggy green is a cricket cap of green colour, which has been worn by Australian Test cricketers since around the turn of the twentieth century. The cap was not originally baggy as evidenced by photographs of early players. The cap has long been a symbol of national pride in Australia, and was described by the chief executive of the MCC as the "most famous cricket cap in the world".

Term.Title: Baggywrinkle
Term.Description: A soft covering for cables (or any other obstructions) that prevents sail chafing from occurring.

Term.Title: Bahamas
Term.Description: Country code = BS

Term.Title: Bahrain
Term.Description: Country code = BH

Term.Title: Bail
Term.Description: A bail is one of the two smaller sticks placed on top of the three stumps to form a wicket. The bails are used to determine when the wicket is broken, which in turn is one of the critical factors in determining whether a batsman is out bowled, stumped, run out or hit wicket.

Term.Title: Bailiff
Term.Description: An officer of the District Court who serves process and executes judgments.

Term.Title: Balance (Strength & Conditioning)
Term.Description: The ability to maintain a stable and specific orientation in relation to the immediate environment

Term.Title: Balance Due
Term.Description: The amount of a debt still owed on an account or the principal owed on a promissory note.

Term.Title: Balance Sheet
Term.Description: A tabular statement of both sides of a set of accounts in which the debit and credit balances add up as equal.

Term.Title: Balanced Attack
Term.Description: A team is able to pass the ball and run the ball with success. Some teams might not have good running backs so they pass the ball a lot or other teams might run the ball a lot. These teams do not have a balanced attack.

Term.Title: Balestra
Term.Description: This is a short jump forward toward your rival.

Term.Title: Balk
Term.Description: Penalty for an illegal movement by the pitcher called by the umpire. The rule is designed to prevent pitchers from deliberately deceiving the runners. If called, baserunners advance one base.

Term.Title: Ball
Term.Description: A round or ovoid object, made of various materials and sizes, for use in games and sport.

Term.Title: Ball (Baseball Scoring)
Term.Description: A pitched ball in baseball which does not cross the plate between the batter's shoulders and knees is called a ball. Four called balls and the batter advances to first base.

Term.Title: Ball (Baseball)
Term.Description: The baseballs core is made of rubber and cork. Yarn is wound around the rubber and cork centre. Then 2 strips of white cowhide are sewn around the ball. Official baseballs must weigh 5 to 5 1/4 ounces and be 9 to 9 1/4 inches around.

Term.Title: Ball (Football 7 a Side) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The ball must be approved with the outer surface made of leather or other suitable material. The ball must have a circumference of between 68 to 70cm, weight between 410 to 450grams.

Term.Title: Ball (Football)
Term.Description: A spherical object made of leather or other suitable material. For official competition play the ball must be of a circumference of not more than 70 cm (28 ins) and not less than 68 cm (27 ins) in size. Weighing not more than 450 g (16 oz) and not less than 410 g (14 oz) in weight at the start of the match. Of a pressure equal to 0.6 1.1 atmosphere (600 1,100 g/cm2) at sea level (8.5 lbs/sq in 15.6 lbs/sq in).

Term.Title: Ball (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The ball used for goalball competition is made of rubber, weighs 1.25kg with a circumference of approximately 76cm. It has eight holes with noise bells inside. The ball must meet the specifications of the IBSA Sport Technical Committee.

Term.Title: Ball (Golf)
Term.Description: Golf balls are usually white, covered in dimples, and made of a variety of materials.

Term.Title: Ball (Hockey)
Term.Description: A field hockey ball is usually white, weighs about 5-? oz (156-163 grams) and is about 9 inches in diameter. The ball is made of hard plastic and may either be solid or hollow.

Term.Title: Ball (Lacrosse)
Term.Description: The ball is made out of rubber and is colored yellow, white or black. The ball should weigh 142-149 grams and be 20 to 20.3 centimetres in circumference. When dropped the ball should bounce 1.1 to 1.3 metres high.

Term.Title: Ball (Netball)
Term.Description: Netball ball weighs 14-16oz and has a circumference of 27-28 inchs and is made of rubber or leather.

Term.Title: Ball (Pitched Baseball)
Term.Description: A pitched ball in baseball which does not cross the plate between the batter's shoulders and knees is called a ball. Four called balls and the batter advances to first base.

Term.Title: Ball (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: The ball must be white or orange. It is made of plastic, weighs 2.5 grams and is 38.2 centimetres wide.

Term.Title: Ball (Table Tennis) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The ball has a 40mm diameter and weighs about 2.7 grams. It is made of celluloid or of similar plastic material. It is coloured white or mat orange.

Term.Title: Ball (Volleyball)
Term.Description: Volleyballs are made of leather and they are round, about 65-67 centimetres (about 28 inches) in circumference and weigh about 260-280 grams (9.5 ounces).

Term.Title: Ball (Water Polo)
Term.Description: A water polo ball is usually a bright yellow color with a gripable surface, allowing it to be held with one hand despite its large size. The cover is a buffed rubberized fabric over a wound nylon fiber base with an inflatable bladder. Ball weight is 400-450 grams (14-16 ounces) and inflated to approximately 90 kPa (13 PSI) of pressure. Water polo balls come in two main sizes: size 5 (0.7 meters or 28 inches in circumference), intended for use by men, and size 4 (0.65 meters or 26.5 inches in circumference), intended for women.

Term.Title: Ball (Wheelchair Basketball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The ball must be an approved single shade of orange with eight traditionally shaped panels and black seams. The outer surface is made of leather, synthetic leather, rubber or synthetic material. The ball may have a circumference of 74.9 to 78cm and weight between 567 to 650gr

Term.Title: Ball (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: An official size and weight volleyball is used for play. The ball must weight 280 grams and be white in colour.

Term.Title: Ball (Wheelchair Tennis) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: A ball is made of two elastic hemispheres joined together and covered by a layer of wool and synthetic threads. Its colour must be yellow or white.

Term.Title: Ball and All Tackle
Term.Description: A type of tackle that prevents the player being tackled being able to offload the ball to a team mate for them to carry on the attack before the tackle has been completed. This type of tackle involves preventing the player being tackled from being able to move their arms effectively.

Term.Title: Ball Back
Term.Description: If the ball enters touch, then play is restarted by a line-out at the point where the ball left the field of play. The exception to this is if the ball is kicked into touch on the full. In this case, a line-out is taken from the point from where the ball was kicked from, and not from where it entered touch. Ball back is waived in certain circumstances: If the kicking player is inside his own 22m line when he receives and then kicks the ball. If the player receives the ball outside the 22 then retreats back into the 22 and kicks into touch on the full it is a lineout at the nearest point on the touchline from where the ball was kicked. If a side elects to kick a penalty into touch.

Term.Title: Ball Back (Rugby League)
Term.Description: If the ball enters touch, then play is restarted by a scrum at the point where the ball left the field of play. However, if the ball is kicked into touch without first bouncing inside the field of play (on the full). In this case, the scrum is taken from level with the place from where the ball was kicked from. The ball is given back to the team who did not kick it out of bounds. Ball back is waived in certain circumstances, such as if a side elects to kick a penalty into touch, or Ii the kick took place from behind the 40m line and cleared the 2 m line before going out of play (the 40-20 rule).

Term.Title: Ball Boy / Ball Girl
Term.Description: Ball boys and girls are people, usually youths, who retrieve and supply balls for players or officials during sporting play. Their supply of balls back into play maintains the speed of the game and reduces the amount of inactive time.

Term.Title: Ball Carrier
Term.Description: The player in possession of the ball.

Term.Title: Ball Carrying Arm
Term.Description: An instance in which a tackle can be judged to be complete is when the attacking player's ball-carrying arm is touching the ground at the same time that a defending player is in contact with the attacker.

Term.Title: Ball Control
Term.Description: The ability to keep possession of the ball through the use of fancy moves, trapping, etc.

Term.Title: Ball in Dispute
Term.Description: Coaching term: refers to the fact that no one has clean possession of the ball.

Term.Title: Ball in Play
Term.Description: A ball is in play from the time a player begins his / her downswing in the teeing area and continues to be in play until the ball is either holed out, goes out of bounds, is lost or picked up.

Term.Title: Ball Mark
Term.Description: An indentation or kind of mark produced by the ball when it lands and the goes forward on a fairway or putting green.

Term.Title: Ball Marker
Term.Description: A marker that is used to mark a ball's position on the green. Once the ball is marked it can be picked up, cleaned, replaced or it might be marked because it is in the path of another players ball.

Term.Title: Ball Out
Term.Description: The referee calls for the ball to be thrown to him during a timeout or dead time.

Term.Title: Ball under
Term.Description: The player holding the ball, if it is forced under water as a result of contact with a defender, is charged with an ordinary foul, and loses possession.

Term.Title: Ball Up
Term.Description: When the umpire throws the ball in the air or bounces it after there has been a stalemated scrimmage.

Term.Title: Ball Washer
Term.Description: A machine, usually at each tee area, that is used to clean golf balls.

Term.Title: Ballcarrier
Term.Description: The player currently in possession of the football. If the ball is "loose", meaning nobody has possession, there is no ball carrier.

Term.Title: Ballet Leg Double
Term.Description: The swimmer is lying on their back they then bend both legs and bring the knees toward their chest, then they raise both legs and extended perpendicular to the surface of the water and the body is in a back layout position. The swimmer then lowers their legs back to a bent position and then back straight next to each other.

Term.Title: Ballet Leg Single
Term.Description: The swimmer is lying on their back they then bend one leg bring the knee toward their chest, then this one leg is extended perpendicular to the surface of the water and the body is in a back layout position. The swimmer then lowers the leg back to a bent position and then back straight next to their other leg.

Term.Title: Ballet Skiing
Term.Description: One of the three types of freestyle skiing the other two being Aerials and Moguls. Also called Acro Skiing.

Term.Title: Ballindenisk Horse Trials
Term.Description: http://www.eventingireland.com/

Term.Title: Ball-in-hand
Term.Description: Any ball that has to be moved, and is therefore lifted and replaced or given a fresh position on the court in accordance with the rules.

Term.Title: Ballistic
Term.Description: Dynamic muscular movements.

Term.Title: Balls (Bocce)
Term.Description: Eight larger balls about 4 1/4 inches (107 millimetres) in diameter that are rolled toward the pallino to score points. The balls are of 2 distinct colors, 4 each color.

Term.Title: Balls (Boccia) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Boccia balls are made of natural or synthetic leather and are slightly bigger than a tennis ball. Any ball will be accepted for play from any manufacturer providing they weigh 275gr (+/- 12gr) and measure 270mm in circumference (+/- 8mm). All balls will be checked at each competition. There are six red and six blue balls to indicate which team is playing and one white ball called the "jack".

Term.Title: Banana Ball
Term.Description: Hitting the ball so that it slices off to the side in the shape of a banana.

Term.Title: Banana Kick
Term.Description: A medium-range kick performed in general play that goes to off to the side of the kicker rather than in front, for chasers further afield. The aim of the banana kick is to be less predictable than conventional kicks and is named such thus as the rise and fall of the ball is in a curve like that of a banana.

Term.Title: Banding
Term.Description: Term describing strips which divide the court.

Term.Title: Bandwidth
Term.Description: Rate at which electronic signals can travel through a medium, such as a wire, cable, or channel.

Term.Title: Bandy
Term.Description: A winter team sport played on ice, in which players on skates use sticks to direct a ball into the opposing team's goal. The rules of the game originate in England, but variants are known throughout Northern Europe. The sport is generally percieved as a precursor to modern Ice Hockey. A Bandy team comprises 11 players and the field of play is an outdoor field of the same proportions of a football (soccer) field. Indoor Bandy is conducted on a smaller indoor ice rink.

Term.Title: Bangladesh
Term.Description: Country code = BD

Term.Title: Bank
Term.Description: A ball spiked very hard with a steep downward angle.

Term.Title: Bank Account
Term.Description: Balance standing to the credit of a depositor at a bank.

Term.Title: Bank Draft
Term.Description: A bank draft is a payment on behalf of the payer, which is guaranteed by the issuing bank. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Bank of the West Tennis Classic
Term.Description: http://www.bankofthewestclassic.com/

Term.Title: Bank Reconciliation
Term.Description: A bank reconciliation is a comparison between the cash position recorded on an entity's books and the position noted on the records of its bank, usually resulting in some changes to the book balance to account for transactions that are recorded on the bank's records but not the entity's, such as bank fees and interest income.

Term.Title: Bank Shot
Term.Description: A bank shot in basketball is a shot that relies on the ball bouncing off the backboard and into the basket.

Term.Title: Banked Slalom
Term.Description: A type of slalom racecourse where the all the gate turns are on snow banks.

Term.Title: Banking
Term.Description: Throwing the bocce ball such that it hits and bounces off the sideboards towards the pallino.

Term.Title: Bankruptcy
Term.Description: Bankruptcy is the legal process of liquidating an insolvent debtor's assets, distributing the proceeds to creditors, and relieving the debtor of any further liability.

Term.Title: Bankstown Sports Senior Athletics Club Inc
Term.Description: http://www.bankstownsportsathletics.org.au

Term.Title: Bantamweight Boxer
Term.Description: Bantamweight boxers weigh a maximum of 118lbs or 53.6kg.

Term.Title: Bar Association
Term.Description: An organization of lawyers.

Term.Title: Bar Examination
Term.Description: The examination given in each state by either the highest court o the state bar association for admission as an attorney.

Term.Title: Barbados
Term.Description: Country code = BB

Term.Title: Barbagallo Raceway
Term.Description: Wanneroo WA 6065

Term.Title: Barbell
Term.Description: A bar, from 4 feet to 7 feet long and one inch in diameter, often engraved with a knurled crasshatch pattern to help with the grip of both hand. Disc weights are slid onto the outer portions of the bar to obtain the desired total weight and secured with collars to prevent them from sliding off during the exercise.

Term.Title: Barcelona Olympic Sailing Week
Term.Description: http://www.sailing.org

Term.Title: Barclays Dubai Tennis Championships
Term.Description: http://www.dubaidutyfreetennischampionships.com/

Term.Title: Bargain
Term.Description: A mutual agreement or contract between two parties which is voluntary and involves the exchange of consideration.

Term.Title: Barrack
Term.Description: To support and cheer on for your favourite team.

Term.Title: Barrel
Term.Description: The part of a gun along which the bullet or pellet travels when fired.

Term.Title: Barrister
Term.Description: A lawyer entitled to practice as an advocate, particularly in the higher courts.

Term.Title: Barroca d'Alva Horse Trials
Term.Description: http://www.barrocadalva.com/index_en.htm

Term.Title: Barwon Heads Golf Club
Term.Description: Barwon Heads VIC 3227

Term.Title: Barwon Sports Academy
Term.Description: http://www.barwonsportsacademy.org.au/

Term.Title: Base (Racquetball)
Term.Description: The racquetball handle.

Term.Title: Base Currency
Term.Description: When comparing the price of one currency to another, the base currency is the unit of currency that does not fluctuate in amount. The U.S. Dollar is frequently used as the base currency. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Base Hit
Term.Description: A play in which the batter hits the ball in fair territory and reaches at least first base.

Term.Title: Base on Balls
Term.Description: Called a walk, four balls and the hitter advances to first base.

Term.Title: Baseball
Term.Description: Baseball is a bat-and-ball sport played between two teams of nine players. The aim is to score runs by hitting a thrown ball with a bat and touching a series of four bases arranged at the corners of a ninety-foot diamond. Players on the batting team take turns hitting against the pitcher of the fielding team, which tries to stop them from scoring runs by getting hitters out.

Term.Title: Baseball Claxton Shield
Term.Description: http://www.baseball.com.au/

Term.Title: Baseball Diamond
Term.Description: The infield playing surface.

Term.Title: Baseball Player
Term.Description: An athlete who plays Baseball.

Term.Title: Baseball World Classic
Term.Description: http://web.worldbaseballclassic.com/index.jsp

Term.Title: Baseball World Cup
Term.Description: http://baseballdeworld.com/

Term.Title: Baseless Bindings
Term.Description: Snowboard bindings that don't have a base plate.

Term.Title: Baseline (Badminton)
Term.Description: The back boundary line or the end line that marks the end of the court. It runs parallel to the net. Any shot hit over then baseline is out of bounds.

Term.Title: Bases Loaded
Term.Description: Runners at each base.

Term.Title: BASIC
Term.Description: Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code. BASIC is a computer programming language that was developed in the mid-1960s to provide a way for students to write simple computer programs.

Term.Title: Basic Drill
Term.Description: Basic Drill is an introductory drill-team routine for younger members and beginners.

Term.Title: Basil Sellers Art Prize
Term.Description: Biennial prize awared to encourage contemporary artists to develop their practice, to engage with the many themes within sport past and present, and to contribute to critical reflection on all forms of sport and sporting culture in Australia. http://www.sellersartprize.com.au/

Term.Title: Basis
Term.Description: The original cost of an asset to be used to determine the amount of capital gain tax upon its sale.

Term.Title: Basket (Skiing)
Term.Description: Flat, round attachment at the end of a ski pole that prevents it from sinking too deep into the snow.

Term.Title: Basketball Australia
Term.Description: http://www.basketball.net.au/

Term.Title: Bat (Baseball)
Term.Description: Instrument used by the hitter while batting. Bats made of aluminium or wood. The bat must be no longer than 42 inches and no wider then 2 3/4 inches. Players are allowed to cover the first 8 inches of the bats handle so they can grip it better.

Term.Title: Bat (Softball)
Term.Description: Instrument used by the hitter while batting. Bats made of aluminium or wood. The bat must be no longer than 42 inches and no wider then 2 3/4 inches. Players are allowed to cover the first 8 inches of the bats handle so they can grip it better.

Term.Title: Bat Pad
Term.Description: A fielder who is in position close to the batsman on the leg side to catch the ball if it hits the bat, then the pad, and rises to a catchable height. Also a defence against being given out lbw, that the ball may have hit the bat first, however indiscernible.

Term.Title: Baton
Term.Description: A baton is a hollow rod of wood, paper or plastic that is passed during a race from one member of a relay team to the next in a prescribed area.

Term.Title: Bats (Table Tennis) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Since the 1950s, rackets have been covered by a layer of sponge-like material, which sits between a racquet's rubber surface and the wood, creating a new type of rubber layer. Using this material, new techniques of hitting and spinning the ball were discovered and developed, making the game more dynamic.

Term.Title: Batsman's Paradise
Term.Description: Refers to a pitch that will clearly favour the batting side.

Term.Title: Batten
Term.Description: A stiff strip used to support the roach of a sail, enabling increased sail area.

Term.Title: Batten Down the Hatches
Term.Description: To prepare for inclement weather by securing the closed hatch covers with wooden battens so as to prevent water from entering from any angle.

Term.Title: Batter (Baseball)
Term.Description: An offensive player who takes their position in the batters box.

Term.Title: Batter (Softball Positions)
Term.Description: An offensive player who takes their position in the batters box.

Term.Title: Batter's Box
Term.Description: An area marked by white chalk lines on the left and right side of home plate in which a player must stand while batting.

Term.Title: Batting
Term.Description: Batting is the act or skill of hitting the cricket ball with a cricket bat to score runs or prevent the loss of one's wicket. A player who is currently batting is denoted as a batsman, while the act of hitting the ball is called a shot or stroke. The terms batsman or specialist batsman are also used generically to describe players who specialise in batting (as opposed to e.g. bowlers who would specialise in bowling).

Term.Title: Batting Average
Term.Description: Batting average is a statistic in both cricket and baseball measuring the performance of cricket batsmen and baseball hitters, respectively. The two statistics are related, in that baseball averages are directly descended from the concept of cricket averages.

Term.Title: Batting Crease
Term.Description: Also known as the Popping crease, this term refers to the line located 48 inches in front of the stumps and denotes the batsman's safe ground. If a batsman is within his batting crease, he cannot be stumped or run out.

Term.Title: Batting Order
Term.Description: The batting order is the sequence in which batsmen go to the crease to bat. All eleven players in a cricket side must bat in an unlimited overs match unless a declaration is made. The batting order is usually subdivided into: opening batsmen or openers (the two batsmen who start, or open, the innings), upper or top order (batsmen at positions three and four in the order), middle order (batsmen five to seven), lower order or tail (batsmen eight to eleven). The order in which the eleven players will bat is usually established prior to the commencement of a cricket match, but may be altered during play. The decision is based on factors such as each player's specialities, the position each batsman will feel most comfortable in, each player's skills and attributes as a batsman, possible combinations with other batsmen, and the game situation, for example requiring a more defensive or attacking player at that point in the game.

Term.Title: Baulk
Term.Description: Where a player either 'sells the dummy' in order to pass another, or shifts weight from foot to foot in order to wrong-foot an opponent into believing thay are trying to pass them on one side, but actually passes them on the other.

Term.Title: Baulk (AFL)
Term.Description: A manoeuvre where a player holds the ball out to the side in one hand, then runs in the other direction to evade a defender.

Term.Title: Bayern Rundfahrt
Term.Description: http://www.bayern-rundfahrt.com/

Term.Title: BB
Term.Description: A shot that hits the front wall and then hits off the back wall and then again hits the front wall, without ever having touched the floor.

Term.Title: BC 1 (Boccia) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players in this class have cerebral palsy with movement difficulties affecting the whole body. They are unable to propel a manual wheelchair, often have difficulty adjusting their sitting position, and generally have little functional use of their legs. Players may use their hands or feet to propel the ball into the playing area. BC 1 players may utilise an assistant on the court to help with their grasp of the ball before their shot.

Term.Title: BC 2 (Boccia) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: BC2 players have cerebral palsy with movement difficulties affecting the whole body. These athletes have more trunk control but have difficulties with consistent shoulder movement. Players are able to spread their fingers and thumb but not quickly, and are able to use their hand or foot to propel a manual wheelchair. The player might be able to take steps or perform a standing transfer. BC2 players use their hands to throw the ball into the playing area. They have much more functional ability that BC 1 players and therefore are not permitted to use an assistive device or an assistant. A BC2 player who uses their feet can play in the BC1 class.

Term.Title: BC 3 (Boccia) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players in this class have significant movement difficulties in all four limbs of Cerebral and Non-Cerebral Origin. BC 3 players have insufficient strength or coordination to grasp, throw or kick the ball into the playing area. These players are unable to grasp the ball or cannot propel the ball consistently and purposely beyond the V-line on the Boccia court and are allowed to use ramps and assistive devices to drive the ball into the playing zone. They may utilise an assistant to support the placement of the ball on the ramp.

Term.Title: BC 4 (Boccia) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players in this class have significant movement difficulties in all four limbs that is a degenerative or other (non cerebral) neurological disorder. Players have poor muscle strength, and co-ordination difficulties combined with poor trunk control. They may be able to push a manual chair. Athletes often use their arms or a head thrust to bring themselves to an upright sitting position after a throw. BC 4 players can grasp and throw a ball into the playing area. These players are not permitted to use an assistant or throwing chair.

Term.Title: Beach Football
Term.Description: A variant of association football played on a beach or some form of sand. Also known as beach soccer or beasal.

Term.Title: Beach Handball
Term.Description: A team sport where two teams of four players pass a ball with the aim of throwing it into the goal of the opposing team. The game is similar to Handball, but is played on sand.

Term.Title: Beach Volleyball
Term.Description: Beach volleyball is an Olympic team sport played on sand.

Term.Title: Beach Volleyball
Term.Description: Use with Men's or Women's

Term.Title: Beach Volleyball World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.fivb.org/

Term.Title: Beam
Term.Description: The balance beam is a piece of artistic gymnastics apparatus. The beam was originally a thin beam of wood, but may now be made from or covered with different materials. The beam is raised from the floor on a leg or stand at both ends.

Term.Title: Women's Artistic Gymnastics Commonwealth Games Events
Beam (Sailing)
Term.Description: The width of a vessel at the widest point, or a point alongside the ship at the midpoint of its length.

Term.Title: Beam Ends
Term.Description: The sides of a ship.

Term.Title: Beam Load Cells
Term.Description: A load cell is defined as a transducer that converts an input mechanical force into an electrical output signal.

Term.Title: Beamer
Term.Description: A bowling delivery aimed at the head of the batsman.

Term.Title: Beamer (Cricket)
Term.Description: A beamer (less commonly beam ball) is a type of delivery in which the ball bowled at a fast pace without bouncing, passes above the batsman's waist height. Such a ball is often dangerously close to the batsman's head, due to the lack of control a bowler has over high full tosses. Worse, the batsman is expecting the ball to pitch on the wicket and therefore may not pick up the flight of the ball and may be struck by it. This type of delivery can result in injuries to the batsman, and the penalty for this type of delivery is an immediate no-ball signal given by the umpire.

Term.Title: Bear Away
Term.Description: Turn away from the wind, often with reference to a transit.

Term.Title: Bearer
Term.Description: Anyone holding something, such as a check, promissory note, bank draft, or bond.

Term.Title: Bearing
Term.Description: The direction of travel as indicated by the compass.

Term.Title: Bearing (Sailing)
Term.Description: The horizontal direction of a line of sight between two objects on the surface of the earth.

Term.Title: Beat the Defense
Term.Description: To get by one or both of the defensemen.

Term.Title: Beat the Goalie
Term.Description: To score a goal past the goal keeper.

Term.Title: Beating
Term.Description: Sailing as close as possible towards the wind in a zig-zag course to attain an upwind direction to which it is impossible to sail directly.

Term.Title: Becalm
Term.Description: To cut off the wind from a sailing vessel, either by the proximity of land or by another vessel.

Term.Title: Becalmed
Term.Description: Unable to move due to lack of wind.

Term.Title: Behavioral Disorders
Term.Description: A disorder characterized by displayed behaviors over a long period of time which significantly deviate from socially acceptable norms.

Term.Title: Behaviour
Term.Description: The action, reaction, or functioning of a system, under normal or specified circumstances.

Term.Title: Behind
Term.Description: A score worth one point, earned by putting the ball between a goal post and a behind post, or by the ball hitting a goal post, or by the ball being touched prior to passing between the goalposts.

Term.Title: Behind Posts
Term.Description: The two smaller posts (smaller than the goalposts) that are 6.4 metres to the side of each of the goalposts. They are a minimum of 3 metres in height.

Term.Title: Behind the Back
Term.Description: Advanced dribbling technique involving dribbling the ball behind the back either once (as a form of crossover) or continuously.

Term.Title: Behind the Back Pass
Term.Description: Behind-the-back passes are passes dealt to a target behind the passer's back. Usually done to confuse the defender, behind the back passes can either be bounced off the floor or passed directly to a teammate's chest.

Term.Title: Behind the Net
Term.Description: The area of ice behind the goal cage is legal territory.

Term.Title: Behind the Stick
Term.Description: A behind.

Term.Title: Belarus
Term.Description: Country code = BY

Term.Title: Belay
Term.Description: To make fast a line around a fitting, usually a cleat or belaying pin; an order to halt a current activity or countermand an order prior to execution.

Term.Title: Belaying Pins
Term.Description: Short movable bars of iron or hard wood to which running rigging may be secured.

Term.Description: Oatley Court, Belconnen ACT 2616

Term.Title: Belgium

Term.Title: Belize

Term.Title: Bell Lap
Term.Description: The final lap of a multiple lap race, at the beginning of which a bell is rung. This signifies that the leader of the race has begun the final lap.

Term.Title: Bells Beach
Term.Description: Bells Beach VIC 3228

Term.Title: Bell's Palsy
Term.Description: Bell's Palsy is a form of facial paralysis resulting from damage to the 7th (facial) cranial nerve. It usually resolves itself within a few months.

Term.Title: Belly
Term.Description: This is the side of the bow that is facing toward the archer.
