Term.Title: Bench (Gridiron)
Term.Description: The place where players sit when they are not playing. Both teams have benches and they are on opposite sides of the field along the sidelines.

Term.Title: Bench (Powerlifting) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Athletes compete lying on a bench. The official bench is 2.1m long. The main part of the bench is 61cm wide. At the end of the bench and towards the head, the bench narrows down to 30cm. The height of the bench varies between 45 and 50cm from the ground.

Term.Title: Bench Rest
Term.Description: A form of shooting done with the gun supported in some way, either partly or wholly, on a bench rather than solely by the marksman.

Term.Title: Benched
Term.Description: When a player, who is usually a starter, either does not start the game or is taken out of the game and replaced by another player. Starting players who are benched are not happy people.

Term.Title: Benchmark
Term.Description: The performance of a predetermined set of securities, for comparison purposes.

Term.Title: Bend
Term.Description: A knot used to join two ropes or lines.

Term.Title: Bendigo Bank Academy of Sport
Term.Description: http://www.bbas.org.au/

Term.Title: Bendigo Madison Cycling
Term.Description: http://www.madison.org.au/cycling.asp

Term.Title: Bendigo Spirit
Term.Description: Women's National Basketball League Club Team

Term.Title: Bending
Term.Description: Term used to describe movement of player on a curving course.

Term.Title: Beneficiary
Term.Description: A broad definition for any person or entity (like a charity) who is to receive assets or profits from an estate, a trust, an insurance policy or any instrument in which there is distribution.

Term.Title: Benefits Accrual Accounting
Term.Description: The benefits accrual accounting is to create a journal entry whenever there are employee benefit expenses that have been incurred during the reporting period, but for which an associated supplier billing has not yet been received. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Benin
Term.Description: Country code = BJ

Term.Title: Bent Arm Attack
Term.Description: When the arm is bent when a fencer attacks. This is dangerous because it leaves the attacking fencer open to a counter-attack.

Term.Title: Bent Arm Stroke
Term.Description: The correct method of stroke because it results in faster movements than a straight-arm stroke.

Term.Title: Bent Knee Postition
Term.Description: When the swimmer is lying on their back and they have one leg bent at the knee so their foot is still on the surface of the water but the knee is brought toward their chest.

Term.Title: Bequeath
Term.Description: To give personal property under provisions of a will.

Term.Title: Bequest
Term.Description: The gift of personal property under the terms of a will.

Term.Title: Berm
Term.Description: An embankment on a track built up on the outside of a turn to create curve.

Term.Title: Bermuda
Term.Description: Country code = BM

Term.Title: Bermuda Grass
Term.Description: Thick and coarse grass that is hard to hit out of.

Term.Title: Berwick Miners Gridiron Club
Term.Description: Sometimes known as American Football Gridiron is an umbrella term for related codes of football primarily played in the United States and Canada.

Term.Title: Berwick Rugby League
Term.Description: http://www.berwickrugbyclub.co.uk/

Term.Title: Best Ball
Term.Description: A golf game which has two or more players on a team and whichever player on a team has the best score on a hole, then their score is marked on the scorecard.

Term.Title: Best Practice
Term.Description: A comprehensive, integrated and cooperative approach to the continuous improvement of all facets of an organisation's operations. It is a method by which leading-edge companies manage their businesses to achieve world-class standards of performance.

Term.Title: Best Shot
Term.Description: A team competition in which each player on a team plays a shot. Then it is determined which ball is the best hit and placed ball and all of other players, from the same team, hit their next shot from that same position.

Term.Title: Besti Squat
Term.Description: A spread-eagle like move where the skater glides on two outside edges with knees bent at right angles.

Term.Title: Betaine
Term.Description: A colorless, crystalline, water-soluble, sweet-tasting alkaloid, C 5 H 11 NO 2 , usually obtained from sugar beets or synthesized from glycine, used chiefly in medicine.

Term.Title: Betting operator
Term.Description: A person or business who is authorised under state or territory law to engage in or conduct the business of betting.

Term.Title: Betting Shirts
Term.Description: Crews sometimes bet their shirts on the race and the loser must render a racing shirt with their logo on it to the winner.

Term.Title: Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea
Term.Description: The devil was possibly a slang term for the garboard seam, hence "between the devil and the deep blue sea" being an allusion to keel hauling, but a more popular version seems to be the seam between the waterway and the stanchions which would be difficult to get at, requiring a cranked caulking iron, and a restricted swing of the caulking mallet.

Term.Title: Between the Legs
Term.Description: A commonly-used variation of the crossover in which the ballhandler bounces the ball off of the floor between his legs and catches it with the other hand on the opposite side of his body.

Term.Title: Bevel
Term.Description: The angle that a snowboard's edges are set at.

Term.Title: Bhutan
Term.Description: Country code = BT

Term.Title: Biacromial Breadth
Term.Description: The distance between the most lateral points of the two acromion processes in a subject standing upright with arms hanging loosely at the sides. It is a measure of shoulder width.

Term.Title: Bial Band Syndrome
Term.Description: Iliotibial band syndrome is often referred to by other names, most commonly, runners knee and Iliotibial band friction syndrome, sometimes shortened to ITBS or ITBFS. As the ITB passes over the lateral epicondyle of the femur (bony part on the outside of the knee) it is prone to friction. At an angle of approximately 20-30 degrees the IT band flicks across the lateral epicondyle. When the knee is being straightened it flicks in front of the epicondyle and when it is bent, it flicks back behind.

Term.Title: Bias (Bowls)
Term.Description: Weighted offset to make the bowl curve. The bias side of the bowl is noted by the smaller button. Bias is correct when the bowl curves towards the Jack.

Term.Title: Biathlete
Term.Description: An athlete who competes in a Biathlon.

Term.Title: Biathlon
Term.Description: Biathlon is any sporting event made up of two disciplines, but usually refers specifically to the winter sport that combines cross-country skiing and rifle shooting.

Term.Title: Biathlon (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Biathlon was introduced in Lillehammer in 1994. The competition is open to athletes with a physical disability and blindness / visual impairment. It consists of a 7.5km route divided into three 2.5km stages.Between the two stages athletes must hit two targets located at a distance of 10 metres. Each miss is penalised by an increase in the overall route time. The most important success factor lies in the capability of alternating the skills of physical endurance and shooting accuracy during the competition. Athletes with blindness/visual impairment are assisted by acoustic signals, which depending on signal intensity, indicate when the athlete is on target.

Term.Title: Bicarbonate
Term.Description: An acid carbonate.

Term.Title: Biceps
Term.Description: Flexes arm at shoulder, flexes forearm at elbow and supinates hand.

Term.Title: Biceps Femoris
Term.Description: Flex and laterally rotate leg at knee, extend thigh at hip.

Term.Title: Bicycle Motocross Australia
Term.Description: http://www.bmxaustralia.com.au/

Term.Title: Bid
Term.Description: An offer to purchase with a specific price stated.

Term.Title: Biellmann Spin
Term.Description: A catch-foot position where the free leg is pulled above the head from behind. Can be either a spin or a spiral position. By regulation, a spin becomes a Biellmann at the moment the skate passes over the level of the head. It is named after Denise Biellmann, who popularized the position.

Term.Title: Biffer
Term.Description: Biffer is a slang term for an attacking batsman. A biffer is the opposite of a blocker, being a defending player. In earlier times (particularly pre-World War II) cricketers were either amateur (Gentlemen) or professional (Players). Typically, but not universally, amateurs would be "biffers" and professionals "blockers".

Term.Title: Bifurcate
Term.Description: The order or ruling of a judge that one issue in a case can be tried to a conclusion or a judgment given on one phase of the case without trying all aspects of the matter.

Term.Title: Big Air
Term.Description: A competition where snowboarders are judged on how much air (height) they are able to achieve, the difficulty of the move they used to get the air, how they control themselves in the air and how clean their landing is.

Term.Title: Big Note
Term.Description: Brag or boast about your self.

Term.Title: Big Show
Term.Description: The major leagues.

Term.Title: Bilateral
Term.Description: A swimmer will take a breath every third arm stroke and the breath will be taken on alternating sides of the swimmers body.

Term.Title: Bilge
Term.Description: The compartment at the bottom of the hull of a ship or boat where water collects and must be pumped out of the vessel.

Term.Title: Bilge Keels
Term.Description: A pair of keels on either side of the hull, usually slanted outwards.

Term.Title: Biliac Width
Term.Description: An anatomical term referring to the widest measure of the pelvis between the outer edges of the upper iliac bones. Biiliac width has the following common synonyms: pelvic bone width, biiliac breadth, intercristal breadth / width, bi-iliac breadth / width and biiliocristal breadth / width.

Term.Title: Bill
Term.Description: What is commonly called a check by which the signer requires the bank to pay a third party a sum of money; a statement of what is owed; any paper money; a legislative proposal for enactment of a law. It is called a bill until it is passed and signed, at which time it is a law (statute) and is no longer referred to as a bill.

Term.Title: Bill of Lading
Term.Description: A document specifying the details of goods being shipped.

Term.Title: Bill of Sale
Term.Description: A written statement attesting to the transfer (sale) of goods, possessions, or a business to a buyer.

Term.Title: Bimini Top
Term.Description: Open-front canvas top for the cockpit of a boat, usually supported by a metal frame.

Term.Title: Binding
Term.Description: Legally enforceable.

Term.Title: Bindings (Ski Jumping)
Term.Description: The bindings are where the skier's feet are attached to the skis. On ski jumping skis the bindings can can't be more then 57 %, from the tip, then the ski's total length. The heel on the bindings also don't hold the skier's heel down but are loose, which allows the skier to lean forward during flight.

Term.Title: Binge Eating
Term.Description: Uncontrolled compulsive eating especially as a symptom of bulimia or binge eating disorder.

Term.Title: Bingham Cup
Term.Description: The Mark Kendall Bingham Memorial Tournament, known as the Bingham Cup is a biennial international, non-professional, gay and inclusive Rugby Union competition.

Term.Title: International Gay Rugby Association and Board
Binnacle
Term.Description: The stand on which the ship's compass is mounted.

Term.Title: Biochemistry
Term.Description: The science dealing with the chemistry of living matter.

Term.Title: Biomechanics
Term.Description: The mechanics of a living body, especially of the forces exerted by muscles and gravity on the skeletal structure.

Term.Title: PERFORMANCE TERMS (including Sports Science and Medicine)
Biophysics
Term.Description: The branch of biology that applies the methods of physics to the study of biological structures and processes.

Term.Title: PERFORMANCE TERMS (including Sports Science and Medicine)
Bipolar Disorder
Term.Description: An affective disorder characterized by periods of mania alternating with periods of depression, usually interspersed with relatively long intervals of normal mood.

Term.Title: Birani
Term.Description: A front flip that adds a half-twist.

Term.Title: Bird
Term.Description: The object that the players hit back and forth over the net. It is made of cork and goose feathers; it is also called a shuttlecock.

Term.Title: Birdie
Term.Description: A score of one under par on any given hole in the sport of golf.

Term.Title: Birth Leave
Term.Description: Maternity leave.

Term.Title: Bisque
Term.Description: A replayed shot or an additional shot given to a player. Bisques are determined by a players handicap and serve the purpose of equalizing a game between players of different levels of ability.

Term.Title: Biting
Term.Description: A reference to when a stone is touching the outside circle.

Term.Title: Bits and Pieces
Term.Description: Disability cycling National Team

Term.Title: Bitt
Term.Description: A post mounted on the ship's bow for fastening ropes or cables.

Term.Title: Black Card
Term.Description: A card given out by a referee, which ejects a fencer from the match.

Term.Title: Black Dot
Term.Description: The underside of the crossbar connecting the goal posts will have a marking on it in the centre, usually black in colour, that is referred to a the "black dot". The black dot can be used as an aid to kickers with their aiming. A player scoring a try in the centre of the goal line or in goal, that is beneath the posts, might be said to have scored "under the black dot".

Term.Title: Black Mountain Rowing Club
Term.Description: http://www.bmrc.org.au/

Term.Title: Black Rock Yacht Club
Term.Description: Black Rock North VIC 3193

Term.Title: Blackspot
Term.Description: An area with a high concentration of coastal / ocean incidents and a high probability / risk of ongoing reoccurrence.

Term.Title: Surf Life Saving terms and techniques
Blade
Term.Description: The spoon or hatchet/cleaver shaped end of the oar. Also used to refer to the entire oar.

Term.Title: Blade (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: The large oval shaped piece of a paddle with which the ball is hit.

Term.Title: Blades
Term.Description: The blades used in long track speed skating are usually between 16.5 - 18.1 inches (42-46 cm) long and .039 inches (1 mm) wide. Blades used in short track speed skating are usually around 18.1 (46 cm) in length and between .046 - .054 inches (1.2-1.4 mm) wide.

Term.Title: Blairgowrie Yacht Squadron
Term.Description: Blairgowrie VIC 3942

Term.Title: Blank End
Term.Description: An end in which no stones are touching the house, and thus no points are scored iIn regular play the team that has the hammer retains it for the next end. In skins games, the skin for a blanked end is carried over. To "blank an end" means to intentionally leave no stones in the house so as to retain the hammer.

Term.Title: Blank Endorsement
Term.Description: Endorsement of a check or other negotiable paper without naming the person to whom it would be paid.

Term.Title: Blash
Term.Description: When a ball is blocked and the ball travels faster from the blocker to the floor than the attacker to the block. Made famous by Cameron Billingham, the term comes from a combination of the words 'Block' and 'Smash'.

Term.Title: Bledisloe Cup
Term.Description: Rugby Union's Bledisloe Cup is contested by the Australia national rugby union team and New Zealand national rugby union team.

Term.Title: Blind Hole
Term.Description: When the golfer can't see the green when they are playing their approach shot.

Term.Title: Blind Pass
Term.Description: To pass the puck without looking at the intended target.

Term.Title: Blind Sporting Association Of New South Wales
Term.Description: http://www.blindsportsnsw.org.au/

Term.Title: Sport competitions for People with Disabilities
Blind Sports Australia
Term.Description: http://www.blindsports.com.au/

Term.Title: National Sporting Organisation for People with a Disability
Sport competitions for Visually Disabled People
Blindside
Term.Description: The narrow side of the pitch in relation to a scrum or a breakdown in play; it is the opposite of openside. The blindside flanker is expected to cover the opposing team blindside at scrum and breakdown.

Term.Title: Blindsided
Term.Description: When a player, usually a quarterback, is hit from behind or from the side, so he is not aware that he is about to be hit.

Term.Title: Blister
Term.Description: A thin vesicle on the skin, containing watery matter or serum, as from a burn or other injury.

Term.Title: Blitz
Term.Description: A defensive maneuver in which one or more linebackers or defensive backs, who normally remain behind the line of scrimmage, instead charge into the opponent's backfield.

Term.Title: Blitz Defence
Term.Description: The blitz defence is a defensive technique similar to the defence used in rugby league. It relies on the whole defensive line moving forward towards their marked man as one, as soon as the ball leaves the base of a ruck or maul. The charge is usually led by the inside centre. The idea of this technique is to prevent the attacking team gaining any ground by tackling them behind the gain line and forcing interceptions and charged down kicks. However, the defending team can be vulnerable to chip kicks and any player breaking the defensive line will have lots of space to play because the defence are running the other way and must stop, turn and chase.

Term.Title: Block (Basketball)
Term.Description: In basketball, a block (short for blocked shot), not to be confused with blocking, occurs when a defensive player legally deflects a field goal attempt from an offensive player.

Term.Title: Block (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: A defensive shot where the paddle does not move. The player is just trying to make contact with the ball, and the shot is used to return hard shots or to try and recover when caught out of position.

Term.Title: Block (Tennis)
Term.Description: Defensive shot with relatively little backswing and shortened action instead of a full swing, usually while returning a serve.

Term.Title: Block (Volleyball)
Term.Description: A defensive action played close to the net and above the height of the net with the intention of stopping the ball passing over the net.

Term.Title: Block Play
Term.Description: A tournament format in which players are assigned to blocks and play one game against each, or most, of the other players in their block. Some form of playoffs to determine the top finishing positions usually follows a round robin.

Term.Title: Blocked Kick
Term.Description: This is a punt or a field goal that the defense has been able to block. You can't block a kickoff or free kick.

Term.Title: Blocker
Term.Description: Blocker is a slang term for a defending batsman, the opposite of biffer. In earlier times (particularly pre-World War II) cricketers were either professional or amateur. Typically, but not universally, amateurs would be "biffers" and professionals "blockers".

Term.Title: Blocker (Bowls)
Term.Description: A bowl that blocks someone (usually an opponent) from reaching the desired target.

Term.Title: Blocker (Gridiron)
Term.Description: The players who are doing the blocking on the play, these are players who are playing on offensive and usually they are offensive linemen.

Term.Title: Blocking
Term.Description: A technique used in the throws which entails bracing one part of the body to efficiently transfer momentum to another part of the body.

Term.Title: Blocking (Cycling)
Term.Description: Riders of one team who set a relatively slow tempo at the front of a group to control the speed, often to the advantage of one of their teammates who may be in a break.

Term.Title: Blocks (Athletics)
Term.Description: An aid used at the start of events up to the 400 metre distance, including the hurdles.

Term.Title: Blocks (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: Lane markers in long track skating and they mark the shape of the track in short track skating. Skaters must stay on the outside of the markers. Skaters can move the lane markers, (in long track skating) as long as they don't interfere with the other skater or as long as this does not make their course shorter then it would have been if they had not moved the markers.

Term.Title: Blocks (Swimming)
Term.Description: The starting blocks are the small platforms that swimmers stand on before the race starts and from which they dive into the pool. Starting blocks are between 19-29 inches (50 and 75 centimetres) above the water they are covered with a non-slip material and must be at least 19 x 19 inches (50 x 50 centimetres).

Term.Title: Blog
Term.Description: A Blog is a personal journal published on the WWW consisting of discrete entries.

Term.Title: Blood
Term.Description: The red liquid that circulates in the arteries and veins of humans carrying oxygen to and carbon dioxide from the tissues of the body.

Term.Title: Blood Bin
Term.Description: It is also called blood replacement. A player who has a visible bleeding injury may be replaced for up to fifteen minutes (running time not game time), during which he or she may receive first-aid treatment to stop the flow of blood and dress the wound. The player may then to return to the pitch to continue playing.

Term.Title: Blood Circulation
Term.Description: An organ system that permits blood to circulate and transport nutrients (such as amino acids and electrolytes), oxygen, carbon dioxide, hormones, and blood cells to and from cells in the body to nourish it and help to fight diseases, stabilize body temperature and pH, and to maintain homeostasis.

Term.Title: Blood Flow
Term.Description: The continuous circulation of blood in the cardiovascular system.

Term.Title: Blood Gas
Term.Description: Blood gas is a laboratory test of blood where the purpose is primarily to measure ventilation and oxygenation.

Term.Title: Blood Glucose
Term.Description: Glucose in the bloodstream.

Term.Title: Blood Pressure
Term.Description: The pressure exerted by circulating blood upon the walls of blood vessels, and is one of the principal vital signs.

Term.Title: Blood Proteins
Term.Description: Also called serum proteins, are proteins found in blood plasma.

Term.Title: Blue
Term.Description: Fight or punch up.

Term.Title: Blue Lines
Term.Description: The lines separating the attacking/defending zones from the neutral zone.

Term.Title: Bluetongue Central Coast Stadium
Term.Description: Corner Dane Drive and Pacific Highway, Gosford NSW 2250

Term.Title: Bluetongue Stadium
Term.Description: Bluetongue Central Coast Stadium, Corner Dane Drive & Pacific Highway, East Gosford NSW 2250

Term.Title: Bluetooth
Term.Description: Non-proprietary (open) standard for wireless digital data communication over short distances.

Term.Title: Blunt
Term.Description: An unsharpened arrowhead used for targets and small game.

Term.Title: Blu-ray Disc
Term.Description: Blu-ray Disc (BD) is an optical disc storage medium designed to supersede the DVD format.

Term.Title: BMW Cup Golf International
Term.Description: http://www.bmw.com.au/com/en/insights/events_sponsorship/sporting_events/bmw_golf_cup.html

Term.Title: BMW Open Tennis
Term.Description: http://www.bmwopen.de/english/tournament/index.html

Term.Title: BMX National Championships
Term.Description: http://www.bmxaustralia.com.au/

Term.Title: BMX Probikx
Term.Description: http://www.bmxaustralia.com.au/

Term.Title: Board
Term.Description: Short for Snowboard.

Term.Title: Board Head
Term.Description: A slang term for Snowboarder.

Term.Title: Board Member
Term.Description: A member of a governing board.

Term.Title: Board of Directors
Term.Description: A body of elected or appointed members who jointly oversee the activities of a company or organisation.

Term.Title: Board Secretary
Term.Description: A Board Secretary supports the operations of the Board, and is usually an employee of the public entity.

Term.Title: Board Wall
Term.Description: A wooden or fiberglass wall 4 feet high which surrounds the rink to keep the puck and players from accidnetally leaving the rink. All rinks have shatterproof glass that rises above the boards to provide additional protection.

Term.Title: Boarder Cross competition
Term.Description: A race course where gates have been set up to form an obstacle course. There will be four to six snowboarders in each heat and they will race through jumps and turns with the top three advancing to the next round.

Term.Title: Boarding
Term.Description: Checking a defenseless player causing them to violently impact into the boards. This typically leads to the face / head of the unaware player to hit first causing greater chance of injury. Usually a penalty.

Term.Title: Boards (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: The vertical barrier between the ice and the ground at the point where the ice ends. In non-Olympic competitions, they are usually covered with advertisements for the sponsors. At the Olympics, they are usually covered by designs or the Olympic logo.

Term.Title: Boards (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: A wall that surrounds the playing surface.

Term.Title: Boat (Adaptive Rowing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The hull of the adaptive rowing boat is identical to able-bodied boats. Adaptive rowing boats are equipped with special seats, which vary according to the disability of the rower. To date, there are no other specifications on the seat apart from the following: the LTA4+ has a sliding seat; the other three boat classes have fixed seats. The TA 2x has a seat, which offers complimentary support. The AW1x and AM1x are equipped with a seat, which offers postural support to those individuals with compromised sitting balance (i.e. spinal cord injury, cerebral palsy). This ensures that the upper body is supported and kept in a fixed position. Smaller boats are equipped with buoyancy devices called pontoons, which act as stabilisers attached to the boats riggers, providing additional lateral balance.

Term.Title: Boat Classes
Term.Description: A group of ships of the same or similar design.

Term.Title: Bob Jane Stadium
Term.Description: Albert Park VIC 3206

Term.Title: Bobsled
Term.Description: Modern day sleds combine light metals, steel runners, and an aerodynamic composite body. Competition sleds must be a maximum of 3.80 m (12.5 ft) long (4-crew) or 2.70 m (8.9 ft) long (2-crew). The runners on both are set at 0.67 m (2.2 ft) gauge. Until the weight-limit rule was added in 1952, bobsleigh crews tended to be very heavy to ensure the greatest possible speed. Now, the maximum weight, including crew, is 630 kg (1,388.9 lbs) (4-man), 390 kg (859.8 lbs) (2-man), or 340 kg (749.6 lbs) (2-woman), which can be reached via the addition of metal weights.

Term.Title: Bobsleigh
Term.Description: Bobsleigh is a winter sport in which teams of two or four make timed runs down narrow, twisting, banked, iced tracks in a gravity-powered sled.

Term.Title: Bobsleigh, Luge and Skeleton Track
Term.Description: Competition ice tracks are made of concrete, coated with ice. They are required to have at least one straight section and one labyrinth (three turns in quick succession without a straight section). Ideally, a modern track should be 1200 to 1300 metres long and have at least fifteen curves

Term.Title: Bobsleigher
Term.Description: An athlete who competes in the Bobsleigh event.

Term.Title: Bobstay
Term.Description: A stay which holds the bowsprit downwards, counteracting the effect of the forestay.

Term.Title: Bocce
Term.Description: Bocce is a precision ball sport devloped in Italy, that is closely related to Boules and Bowls. The sport is traditionally played by individuals or teams on an outdoor court.

Term.Title: Bocce court
Term.Description: A usually outdoor court, comprising of a floor of crushed stone, grass, soil or asphalt measuring 27.5 metres (90 ft) in length and 2.5 to 4 metres (8.2 to 13.1 ft) wide.

Term.Title: Bocce Federation of Australia
Term.Description: http://www.bocce.net/ Bocce Federation of Australia Inc., P.O. Box 353, Kew East, Victoria 3102, AUSTRALIA

Term.Title: Bocce Player
Term.Description: An athlete who plays Bocce.

Term.Title: Boccia (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Making its debut as a Paralympic sport in 1992, boccia has ancient origins and tests each competitors degree of muscle control and accuracy. Competing in wheelchairs, cerebral palsy athletes throw, kick or use a chute device to propel leather balls as close as possible to a small white ball which serves as the jack (target). Players compete in team and individual events on an equal level.

Term.Title: Boccia Australia
Term.Description: Boccia Australia Incorporated (BA), formerly The Cerebral Palsy Boccia Australia Association Incorporated, was formed in 1993 to develop and manage the sport nationally. The association oversees the development and implementation of the national strategic direction for the sport, covering fundamental areas such as community engagement, grass roots participation, athlete development and high performance. http://www.boccia.com.au/

Term.Title: National Sporting Organisation for People with a Disability
Sport competitions for People with Disabilities
Bodkin Point
Term.Description: A sharp, pointed arrow head.

Term.Title: Body (Rowing Races)
Term.Description: The body of the race is carried out at a consistent rating, with power tens called as the coxswain deems necessary.

Term.Title: Body Angle
Term.Description: Amount of forward lean of rowers body from hips at the catch.

Term.Title: Body Check
Term.Description: Using the hip or body to knock an opponent against the boards or to the ice.

Term.Title: Body Corporate
Term.Description: An association, group of people or a person which by law is a single entity which may manage many things including the land and common property of a block of townhouses or units.

Term.Title: Body Dysmorphic Disorder
Term.Description: BDD; Abnormal obsession and negative feelings regarding one's own appearance.

Term.Title: Body Mass Index
Term.Description: A heuristic proxy for human body fat based on an individual's weight and height.

Term.Title: Body Position
Term.Description: The swimmer has their hips tucked up, they are underneath the water, the torso is straight and the head is above the water and steady with the eyes looking forward and the swimmer has a happy expression.

Term.Title: Body Press
Term.Description: When a wrestler is trying to use all of their body weight to pin another wrestler who is on their back on the mat.

Term.Title: Body Regions
Term.Description: Anatomical areas of the body.

Term.Title: Body Wire
Term.Description: This is the wire that connects the fencer to the electronic touch signaling system.

Term.Title: Bogey
Term.Description: A golf score of one stroke over par for a particular hole.

Term.Title: Bolandiol
Term.Description: A synthetic anabolic steroid. It is hypothesized by interaction with androgen receptors, estrogen receptors, and progestin receptors.

Term.Title: Bolasterone
Term.Description: A 17-alkylated anabolic steroid.

Term.Title: Boldenone
Term.Description: Also known under the trade names Equipoise, Ganabol, Equigan and Ultragan, is an anabolic steroid developed for veterinary use, mostly for treatment of horses. In the US it is not indicated for use in humans and is only available through veterinary clinics.

Term.Title: Bolo Punch
Term.Description: A bolo punch is a flashy wide sweeping uppercut that is more about showboating than power. The bolo punch might not even be thrown at all but rather used to distract the opponent so you can hit them with your other hand.

Term.Title: Bolt
Term.Description: A crossbow projectile. Also called a quarrel.

Term.Title: Bolt (Shooting)
Term.Description: A steel rod-like assembly which moves back and forth in the action when operated by the shooter's hand, seals the cartridge in the chamber during firing and extracts it afterwards.

Term.Title: Bomb
Term.Description: A long high kick.

Term.Title: Bomb (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A bomb is a very long pass.

Term.Title: Bomb (Kick)
Term.Description: A bomb or an up and under, is a high, but short-range punt onto or behind the defending team.

Term.Title: Bona Fide
Term.Description: Latin for "good faith," it signifies honesty, the "real thing" and, in the case of a party claiming title as bona fide purchaser or holder, it indicates innocence or lack of knowledge of any fact that would cast doubt on the right to hold title.

Term.Title: Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba
Term.Description: Country code = BQ

Term.Title: Bond
Term.Description: Written promise topay sum of money or do something at a future date.

Term.Title: Bond University, Institute for Sport
Term.Description: http://www.bond.edu.au/life-at-bond/facilities-services/sports-centre/index.htm

Term.Title: Bone Remodelling
Term.Description: The bodily process of replacing old bone with new bone tissue.

Term.Title: Bone Spur
Term.Description: Commonly referred to as bone spurs are bony projections that form along joint margins.

Term.Title: Bone Turnover
Term.Description: Replacing old bone with healthy new bone.

Term.Title: Boned
Term.Description: When a snowboarder has their leg straight when going over a jump.

Term.Title: Bonk
Term.Description: To completely run out of energy on a long ride.

Term.Title: Bonspiel
Term.Description: Curling tournament.

Term.Title: Bonus Points
Term.Description: Bonus points are a method of deciding table points from a rugby union match. It was implemented in order to encourage attacking play throughout a match, to discourage repetitive goal-kicking, and to reward teams for "coming close" in losing efforts. Under the standard system, 1 bonus point is awarded for scoring 4 (or more) tries and 1 bonus point for losing by 7 points (or fewer). The French professional league replaces the four-try bonus point with a point for a win in which the winning team scores at least 3 more tries than its opponent.

Term.Title: Bonzer
Term.Description: Great, terrific.

Term.Title: Book
Term.Description: A written or printed work usually on sheets of paper fastened or bound together within covers.

Term.Title: Book Value
Term.Description: A determination of the value of a corporation's stock by adding up the stated value of corporate assets as shown on the books of a corporation and deducting all the liabilities (debts) of the corporation.

Term.Title: Booking
Term.Description: A contract, engagement, or scheduled performance of a professional.

Term.Title: Boom
Term.Description: A spar attached to the foot of a fore-and-aft sail.

Term.Title: Boom Gallows
Term.Description: A raised crossmember that supports a boom when the sail is lowered.

Term.Title: Boom Vang
Term.Description: A sail control that lets one apply downward tension on a boom, countering the upward tension provided by the sail. The boom vang adds an element of control to sail shape when the sheet is let out enough that it no longer pulls the boom down. Boom vang tension helps control leech twist, a primary component of sail power.

Term.Title: Booms
Term.Description: Masts or yards lying on board in reserve.

Term.Title: Boost
Term.Description: To catch air off a jump.

Term.Title: Boot Leg
Term.Description: This is when a quarterback fakes a handoff to the running back who will be going in one direction and the quarterback keeps the ball and runs in the opposite direction and he can then run with the ball or throw it. It is a fake handoff.

Term.Title: Boots (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: Boots in speed skating are usually made of leather they do not have high tops, but give freedom of movement to a skater's ankle. They have skating blades attached to them.

Term.Title: Boots and Bindings (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Boots for Alpine Skiing events have a hard plastic exterior with extensive foot and ankle support. The heel height of boots is regulated, with a maximum distance of 50mm between the sole and the heel. Alpine skiers use bindings that attach at both the heel and toe.

Term.Title: Borderline Personality Disorder
Term.Description: A mental condition on the dividing line between a psychiatric disorder and normality characterized by impulsiveness, extreme mood swings, and often aggressiveness.

Term.Title: Borrowing Costs
Term.Description: Borrowing costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset form part of the cost of that asset. Other borrowing costs are recognised as an expense. May include interest on bank overdrafts, amortisation of discounts or premiums relating to borrowings, amortisation of ancillary costs incurred in connection with the arrangement of borrowings, finance changes or exchange differences arising from foreign currency borrowings.

Term.Title: Bosnia and Herzegovina
Term.Description: Country code = BA

Term.Title: Boss
Term.Description: A target, typically made from tightly compacted foam or straw.

Term.Title: Botswana
Term.Description: Country code = BW

Term.Title: Bottler
Term.Description: Something excellent.

Term.Title: Bottlescrew
Term.Description: A device for adjusting tension in stays, shrouds and similar lines.

Term.Title: Bottom Board
Term.Description: The lowest point on the front wall.

Term.Title: Boucles de la Mayenne
Term.Description: http://www.bouclesdelamayenne.fr/

Term.Title: Boucles de l'Artois
Term.Description: http://www.boucledelartois.fr/

Term.Title: Bounce
Term.Description: A ball spiked very hard with a steep downward angle.

Term.Title: Bounce Down
Term.Description: The act of a field umpire putting the ball back into play by bouncing the ball in such a way that it mimics a vertical throw.

Term.Title: Bounce Pass
Term.Description: The bounce pass is a fundamental and very effective passing technique. This pass consists of one player passing the ball to a teammate by bouncing the ball off the floor with great energy.

Term.Title: Bouncer
Term.Description: A bouncer (or bumper) is a type of delivery, usually bowled by a fast bowler. It is pitched short so that it bounces on the pitch well short of the batsman and rears up to chest or head height (or even higher) as it reaches the batsman.

Term.Title: Bound
Term.Description: The bound is a jump that allows the bowler to transition from the run-up to the back foot contact position. For a chest on bowler not much transition is needed. So, many chest on bowlers have a low, short bound. In contrast, side on bowlers need to rotate their bodies through ninety degrees and so tend to have a longer, higher bound. A high bound can lead to the knee on the back foot collapsing and so lose momentum.

Term.Title: Boundary
Term.Description: Boundary has two distinct meanings - the edge or boundary of the playing field and a manner of scoring runs.

Term.Title: Boundary Line
Term.Description: The line that marks the edge of the field. Outside of the boundary line the player is no longer in the field of play. For the ball to be out of play it must be completely over the boundary line.

Term.Title: Boundary Throw in
Term.Description: The act of throwing the ball back into play by the boundary umpire. The boundary umpire stands with his back to the arena and throws the ball backwards over his head. This is used to restart play from neutral situations whenever the ball goes out of bounds.

Term.Title: Bounding
Term.Description: A type of exercise in which the athlete runs with an exaggerated push off so that each step becomes a leap.

Term.Title: Bout (Boxing)
Term.Description: The individual event where one boxer competes against another. Within Olympic boxing a bout comprises three rounds of three minutes in men, and four rounds of two minutes in women, each with a one-minute interval between rounds.

Term.Title: Bout (Fencing)
Term.Description: The sporting event in which fencers compete. A bout is made up of 3, 3-minute segments with a 1-minute rest in-between each segment. The winner of the bout will be the first fencer to reach 15 hits or if the bout ends before either fencer has reached 15 hits, then the fencer with the most hits is declared the winner.

Term.Title: Bout (Wrestling)
Term.Description: A bout is the sporting event in which 2 wrestlers compete. In Olympic wrestling a bout is completed over two, three-minute periods with a 30-second break between periods.

Term.Title: Bow (Archery)
Term.Description: The device or weapon that an archer uses to shoot arrows. The bow consists of a riser and two limbs. Bows can be made of wood, metal or other materials. The weight and size of bows vary dependent on the competitor and the competition.

Term.Title: Bow (Luge)
Term.Description: Curve in the runner of the luge sled.

Term.Title: Bow (Rowing)
Term.Description: The front section of a shell; the first section of the shell to cross the finish line.

Term.Title: Bow (Sailing)
Term.Description: The front of a vessel.

Term.Title: Bow Ball
Term.Description: A small, soft ball no smaller than 4 cm diameter securely attached to a rowing or sculling boat's bow. Primarily intended for safety, but also used in deciding which boat crossed the finish line first in very close races.

Term.Title: Bow Number
Term.Description: A card displaying the lane number assigned to the boat for a race.

Term.Title: Bow Rigged
Term.Description: The person stroking the boat has their oar on the Bowside (Starboard or right side) rather than the typical Strokeside of the boat.

Term.Title: Bow Seat
Term.Description: The rower closest to the front or bow of a multi-person shell. In coxless boats, often the person who keeps an eye on the water behind them to avoid accidents.

Term.Title: Bow String
Term.Description: This is the string archer pull's back to propel the arrow forward. Bowstrings are usually made by weaving several strands of Kevlar or Dacron together to make a single cord.

Term.Title: Bow Thruster
Term.Description: A small propeller or water-jet at the bow used for manoeuvring larger vessels at slow speed.

Term.Title: Bow Wave
Term.Description: A wave that is created by the swimmer as they move rapidly through the water. The wave is created in front of the swimmers head.

Term.Title: Bowing
Term.Description: It is customary that when entering the Dojo or mat area a judoka should bow at the waist to the referee and to his opponent if this is a match situation or if this is a training situation bow to the instructor.

Term.Title: Bowl
Term.Description: To deliver the ball in a manner determined to be legal by the umpire.

Term.Title: Bowl Out
Term.Description: A bowl-out (sometimes termed a bowl-off) is used in various forms of limited overs cricket to decide a match that would otherwise end in a tie. The procedure is similar to a penalty shootout in association football. Five bowlers from each side deliver one or two balls each at an unguarded wicket (three stumps). If each team has hit the same number of wickets after the first five bowlers per side, the bowling continues and is decided by sudden death.

Term.Title: Bowled
Term.Description: Bowled is a method of dismissing a batsman in the sport of cricket. A batsman is out bowled if his wicket is put down by a ball delivered by the bowler. It is irrelevant as to whether the ball has touched the bat, glove, or any part of the batsman before going on to put down the wicket, though it may not touch another player or an umpire before doing so.

Term.Title: Bowler
Term.Description: A cricket player who propells the cricket ball toward the wicket defended by a batsman.

Term.Title: Bowline
Term.Description: A type of knot, producing a strong loop of a fixed size, topologically similar to a sheet bend.

Term.Title: Bowling
Term.Description: Bowling is the action of propelling the ball toward the wicket defended by a batsman. A player skilled at bowling is called a bowler.

Term.Title: Bowling Average
Term.Description: Bowling average is a statistic measuring the performance of bowlers.

Term.Title: Bowloader
Term.Description: A shell in which the coxswain seat is near the bow of the boat rather than its stern. The seat in a bow loader partially enclosed and is designed so that the coxswain is virtually lying down, in order to reduce wind resistance and distribute coxswains weight so as to create a lower centre of gravity.

Term.Title: Bowls
Term.Description: A game played with wooden balls on a level, closely mowed green having a slight bias, the object being to roll one's ball as near as possible to a smaller white ball at the other end of the green.

Term.Title: Bowls Australia
Term.Description: http://www.bowlsaustralia.com.au/ PO Box 52 Northcote, VIC 3070 03 9480 7100

Term.Title: Bowls Rink
Term.Description: The lane on the grass court playing surface. Often 15 feet wide from one end to the opposite end. Each Rink is defined by markers on the edge to clearly define the lane.

Term.Title: Bowls World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.bowlsaustralia.com.au/

Term.Title: Bowside
Term.Description: Any sweep rower who rows with the oar on the Bowside (usually, the right or starboard side) of the boat.

Term.Title: Bowsight
Term.Description: Usually made of carbon or aluminum, this is placed above the arrow rest and helps the archer aim at the target.

Term.Title: Bowsling
Term.Description: The Bowsling wraps around an archer's wrist and helps the archer keep his hand on the grip.

Term.Title: Bowsprit
Term.Description: A spar projecting from the bow used as an anchor for the forestay and other rigging.

Term.Title: Box
Term.Description: A trapezoidal indentation in the ground with a metal or fiberglass covering at the end of the runway in which vaulters "plant" their pole. The back wall of the box is nearly vertical and is approximately 8 inches in depth. The bottom of the box gradually slopes upward approximately 3-feet until it is level with the runway. The covering in the box ensures the pole will slide to the back of the box without catching on anything. The covering's lip overlaps onto the runway and ensures a smooth transition from all-weather surface so a pole being planted does not catch on the box.

Term.Title: Box (Luge)
Term.Description: This is the reinforced area of the cufin that the bridges (supports) are inserted into using gummies (rubber insert).

Term.Title: Box Kick
Term.Description: A kick taken from behind a scrum, normally by the scrum-half, in which they turn away from the scrum facing the touchline, and kick the ball back over the scrum into the clear "box" of space behind the opposition to allow their own team to chase through and regain the ball in undefended territory .

Term.Title: Box out
Term.Description: As a shot or pass is taken, a player moves quickly in front of the opponent to prevent the opponent from recovering the pass or rebound.

Term.Title: Boxing Australia
Term.Description: http://www.boxing.org.au/

Term.Title: Boxing gloves
Term.Description: Equipment to compete. Can be various sizes, but competition gloves are 10 oz.

Term.Title: Boycott
Term.Description: Organized refusal to purchase products or patronize a store to damage the producer or merchant monetarily, to influence its policy, and / or to attract attention to a social cause.

Term.Title: Brace (Archery)
Term.Description: The act of attaching a bow string to a bow.

Term.Title: Brace (Canoe / Kayak)
Term.Description: Face of blade facing the sky or river bed, shaft flat to water.

Term.Title: Brace a Box
Term.Description: To bring the foreyards flat aback to stop the ship.

Term.Title: Brachialis
Term.Description: Flexes forearm at elbow.

Term.Title: Brachioradialis
Term.Description: Flexes forearm at elbow.

Term.Title: Bracket Turn
Term.Description: A one-foot turn with a change of edge that results in a '}' shape traced on the ice.

Term.Title: Bragg Grating Sensors
Term.Description: A short length of optical fiber that filters out a particular wavelength. Periodically spaced zones in the fiber core are altered to have different refractive indexes slightly higher than the core. This structure selectively reflects a very narrow range of wavelengths while transmitting others. Fiber Bragg gratings are used to stabilize the output of a laser and to filter out wavelengths in a WDM system.

Term.Title: Brail
Term.Description: To furl or truss a sail by pulling it in towards the mast, or the ropes used to do so.

Term.Title: Brain Concussion
Term.Description: A clinical syndrome occurring as the result of trauma to the head and characterized by immediate and transient impairment of neural function, such as loss of consciousness.

Term.Title: Brain Injury
Term.Description: Any injury occurring in the brain of a living organism.

Term.Title: Brainstorming
Term.Description: A problem-solving method involving members of a group contributing ideas.

Term.Title: Brakeman
Term.Description: The last person to enter the sled at the start. Known as the brakeman because he or she is responsible for pulling the brake to stop the sled at the end of the run.

Term.Title: Branding
Term.Description: Trademarkin; characterising a product; logos.

Term.Title: Brasil Tennis Open
Term.Description: http://www.atpworldtour.com/Tennis/Tournaments/Costa-do-Sauipe.aspx

Term.Title: Brazil
Term.Description: Country code = BR

Term.Title: Breach
Term.Description: Literally, a break. A breach may be a failure to perform a contract (breaking its terms), failure to do one's duty (breach of duty, or breach of trust), causing a disturbance, threatening, or other violent acts which break public tranquility (breach of peace), illegally entering property (breach of close), not telling the truth-knowingly or innocently-about title to property (breach of warranty).

Term.Title: Breadbasket
Term.Description: Refers to the stomach of a player.

Term.Title: Break
Term.Description: A breach of the line of defenders by the player in possession of the ball on the attacking team.

Term.Title: Break (Croquet)
Term.Description: A series of wickets scored by a player in one turn using one other ball (two-ball break), two other balls (three-ball break) or with all balls in play (four-ball break).

Term.Title: Break (Golf)
Term.Description: The way that a ball will move when it is putted toward the hole.

Term.Title: Break Down
Term.Description: When a break or turn ends because no continuation or croquet shot is earned or a fault occurs.

Term.Title: Break Line
Term.Description: A specific mark on the track used only in certain races that are longer than one lap (such as the 800 metre or 4x400 metre relay). The break-line indicates the point at which runners may leave their assigned lane and move toward the inside lane of the track.

Term.Title: Breakaway (Football)
Term.Description: A situation where an attacking player has broken through the defensive line and is now entering a one on one challenge with the goal keeper.

Term.Title: Breakaway (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: When a player has possession of the puck and there are no defenders other than the goalie between them and the opposing goal.

Term.Title: Breakaway (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: A sprint used by a skater to breakaway from the rest of the skaters and is usually done in the final moments of a race in a sprint to the finish line.

Term.Title: Breakdown
Term.Description: The breakdown is a colloquial term for the period immediately after a tackle and the ensuing ruck. During this time teams compete for possession of the ball, initially with their hands and then using feet in the ruck. Most referees will call "ruck" or "hands away" as soon as a ruck is formed. Most infringements take place at the breakdown, owing to the greater variety of possible offences at a breakdown, for example handling in the ruck, killing the ball, offside at the ruck and so on.

Term.Title: Breakdown (Wrestling)
Term.Description: When a wrestler is able to put their opponent on their side or stomach by knocking their hand, elbow or knee away that is providing them support.

Term.Title: Breakfall
Term.Description: A method of falling that is taught to all people who learn judo.

Term.Title: Breaking Area
Term.Description: The breaking area is the area right after the K point on the ski jump.

Term.Title: Breaking Ball
Term.Description: An off-speed pitch that curves.

Term.Title: Breaking Pass
Term.Description: A pass to a teammate who is trying for a breakaway.

Term.Title: Breakout
Term.Description: Instantaneous velocity of vertex of head when hands part to commence stroke cycle.

Term.Title: Breakwater
Term.Description: A structure constructed on a coast as part of a coastal defense system or to protect an anchorage from the effects of weather and longshore drift.

Term.Title: Breaststroke
Term.Description: In the breaststroke the legs and arms must be synchronized. The arms are allowed to make three different moves. The first move is out away from the swimmers body, then the arms go down toward the bottom of the pool and then the arms are pulled together and are brought forward together from the breast and then the movements start over. The leg kick consists of keeping the legs together bending the knees thus bringing the feet forward and then kicking the feet back which straightens the legs.

Term.Title: Swimming for the Disabled terms and techniques
Breaststroke (Synchronised Swimming)
Term.Description: In the breaststroke the legs and arms must be synchronised. The arms are allowed to make three different moves. The first move is out away from the swimmers body, then the arms go down toward the bottom of the pool and then the arms are pulled together and are brought forward together from the breast and then the movements start over. The leg kick consists of keeping the legs together bending the knees thus bringing the feet forward and then kicking the feet back which straightens the legs. The breaststroke is the most complicated and physically demanding of all the different types of strokes.

Term.Title: Breech
Term.Description: The end part of the barrel nearest the shooter with the chamber into which the cartridge or projectile is loaded.

Term.Title: Brick
Term.Description: To miss a shot so badly it sound like somebody threw a brick at the rim instead of a basketball.

Term.Title: Bridge
Term.Description: Connecting two or more local area networks (LANs) together.

Term.Title: Bridge (Luge)
Term.Description: These are support legs of the sled that attach the seat to the cufin.

Term.Title: Bridge (Wrestling)
Term.Description: When a wrestler has their back to the mat and is bent over. The only way to keep their shoulders from touching the mat is to keep their legs bent at the knee holding their buttocks off the mat and using their elbows to keep their shoulders off the mat.

Term.Title: Bridle and Bit
Term.Description: The bridle and bit provides a means of contact and communication between horse and rider. Grade I and II athletes use a snaffle bit, while Grade III and IV athletes may use either a snaffle or a double bridle.

Term.Title: Brigadoon Horse Trials
Term.Description: http://www.equestrian.org.au/

Term.Title: Bring To
Term.Description: Cause a ship to be stationary by arranging the sails.

Term.Description: Australian Baseball League Club Team

Term.Title: Brisbane Broncos
Term.Description: National Rugby League Club Team

Term.Description: Melaleuca Drive, Boondall QLD 4034

Term.Title: Brisbane Equestrian competition
Term.Description: http://www.equestrian.org.au/

Term.Title: Brisbane Lions
Term.Description: Australian Football League Club Team.

Term.Title: Brisbane Roar
Term.Description: National A-League football club team.

Term.Title: Brisbane Roar W League
Term.Description: National A League Women's football club team.

Term.Title: Brisbane Tennis International
Term.Description: http://www.brisbaneinternational.com.au/ Formerly known as Modial Australian Women's Hardcourts

Term.Title: Brisbane to Gladstone Yacht Race
Term.Description: http://www.brisbanetogladstone.com.au/

Term.Title: British Open
Term.Description: One of the four major golf championships along with the US Open, Augusta: The Masters and the PGA Championship. It is played in Scotland at a course named St. Andrews.

Term.Title: British Open Squash
Term.Description: http://www.britishopensquash.com/

Term.Title: Broach
Term.Description: When a sailing vessel loses control of its motion and is forced into a sudden sharp turn, often heeling heavily and in smaller vessels sometimes leading to a capsize.

Term.Title: Broadband
Term.Description: A transmission technique using a wide range of frequencies that enables messages to be sent simultaneously, used in fast Internet connections.

Term.Title: Broadcasting
Term.Description: Communication or disseminating information or entertainment widely, by means of mass media.

Term.Title: Broadhead
Term.Description: A sharp-bladed hunting head.

Term.Title: Broadside
Term.Description: One side of a vessel above the waterline.

Term.Title: Brochure
Term.Description: A pamphlet or leaflet.

Term.Title: Broker
Term.Description: A person who arranges contracts between a buyer and seller for a commission.

Term.Title: Bronchitis
Term.Description: Acute or chronic inflammation of the membrane lining of the bronchial tubes.

Term.Title: Bronze Duck
Term.Description: When a batsman is dismissed by the third ball he faces without scoring.

Term.Title: Broom
Term.Description: An implement with which players sweep the ice to make a stone travel farther and curl less. Though brushes have almost completely replaced brooms, the traditional name remains.

Term.Title: Broomball
Term.Description: Broomball is a recreational ice game originating in Canada (also contested as being Swedish) and played in certain other countries. It is played in a hockey rink, either indoors or outdoors, depending on climate and location.

Term.Title: Brothers Junior Rugby League
Term.Description: http://www.brisbanebrothersjrlfc.org.au/

Term.Title: Brownlow Medal
Term.Description: The Chas Brownlow Trophy, better known as the Brownlow Medal (and informally as "Charlie"), is awarded to the "fairest and best" player in the Australian Football League (AFL) during the regular season (i.e., not including finals matches) as determined by votes cast by the officiating field umpires after each game.

Term.Title: Browser
Term.Description: A software program that allows the user to find and read encoded documents in a form suitable for display, especially such a program for use on the World Wide Web.

Term.Title: Bruce Weir
Term.Description: Bundaberg QLD 4670

Term.Title: Bruise
Term.Description: To injure by striking or pressing, without breaking the skin.

Term.Title: Bruised Heel
Term.Description: A bruised heel can be caused by either a sudden impact (such as landing heavily) or repetitive pounding.

Term.Title: Brumbies
Term.Description: U17 Men's baseball team

Term.Title: Brunei Darussalam
Term.Description: Country code = BN

Term.Title: Brutality Foul
Term.Description: A violent foul with intention to harm. The fouling player is ejected from the game without substitution. The opponents are awarded a penalty shot and the ejected player's team plays one man down for the next four minutes of game time.

Term.Title: Bruxism
Term.Description: Bruxism: Involuntarily grinding or clenching of the teeth while sleeping.

Term.Title: Bucket
Term.Description: A completed shot.

Term.Title: Bucket of Balls
Term.Description: At a driving range you rent a large amount of golf balls to practice with and they are usually put in metal baskets.

Term.Title: Buckley's
Term.Description: No chance, no hope at all.

Term.Title: Budget
Term.Description: An estimate, often itemized, of expected income and expense for a given period in the future.

Term.Title: Budget Variance
Term.Description: A budget variance is the difference between the budgeted or baseline amount of expense or revenue, and the actual amount. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Budgeted Income Statement
Term.Description: The budgeted income statement contains all of the line items found in a normal income statement, except that it is a projection of what the income statement will look like during future budget periods. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Bulgaria
Term.Description: Country code = BG

Term.Title: Bulimia
Term.Description: A habitual disturbance in eating behavior mostly affecting young women of normal weight, characterized by frequent episodes of grossly excessive food intake followed by self-induced vomiting to avert weight gain.

Term.Title: Bulkhead
Term.Description: An upright wall within the hull of a ship. Particularly a watertight, load-bearing wall.

Term.Title: Bull
Term.Description: The centre of a target.

Term.Title: Bulleen Boomers
Term.Description: Women's National Basketball League Club Team

Term.Title: Buller Cup
Term.Description: http://www.mtbuller.com.au

Term.Title: Bullet
Term.Description: The name given to the single projectile that comes out of the barrel of a gun.

Term.Title: Bullpen
Term.Description: Area designated for pitchers to warm-up. Generally consists of two mounds and two home plates.

Term.Title: Bully
Term.Description: A Bully is used to restart a game. A player from each team stands facing a sideline with the goal line to their right. The referee places the ball on the ground, where play was stopped. The two opposing players then tap each others stick on the ground and then they tap them above the ball and then bring their sticks to the ground and tap the ground again. This is done three times and on the third time, when the sticks have been touched above the ball, then each player will try to hit the ball.

Term.Title: Bullying
Term.Description: Bullying is the use of force, threat, or coercion to abuse, intimidate, or aggressively impose domination over others.

Term.Title: Bulwark
Term.Description: The extension of the ship's side above the level of the weather deck.

Term.Title: Bumetanide
Term.Description: A loop diuretic of the sulfamyl category.

Term.Title: Bump
Term.Description: When one player uses their hip or shoulder to force an opposing player out of position. A bump can't be in the back or above the shoulders and it must take place within 5 metres of the ball.

Term.Title: Bump (Volleyball)
Term.Description: The type of hit that is both a defensive and offensive hit. Both hands are used in a bump and when used for defensive purposes it is to keep the ball from hitting the ground. On defense this technique is used for receiving a service. On the offensive it is used to pass to a teammate so they can set up another teammate for a spike or smash.

Term.Title: Bump and Run
Term.Description: This is when a defensive player, who is guarding a offensive wide receiver, blocks or bumps the receiver at the line of scrimmage and then runs and guards them as they run down the field. A defensive player can only block an offensive wide within 5 yards of the line of scrimmage.

Term.Title: Bump Pass
Term.Description: The use of joined forearms to pass or set a ball in an underhand manner.

Term.Title: Bumper Guard
Term.Description: A protective covering, which is attached along the rim of the racquet head.

Term.Title: Bunbury Rowing Club
Term.Description: http://www.rowingwa.asn.au

Term.Title: Bundaberg Rum Series
Term.Description: Rugby Union. The Bundaberg Rum Rugby Series is the premier national competition played in Australia each year between the Qantas Wallabies and senior national representative teams from other countries. The Tri Nations tournament and Bledisloe Cup are also part of the Bundaberg Rum Rugby Series and involve matches between the Wallabies against their southern rivals New Zealand and South Africa.

Term.Title: Bunions
Term.Description: A bunion is a painful swelling of the soft tissue, and bone enlargement over the inside of the ball of the big toe.

Term.Title: Bunker
Term.Description: This is usually a large hole that is filled with sand that can be situated in the fairway or around the greens. It is an obstacle golfers try to avoid. If you do find yourself in a bunker, it is against the rules to take a practice swing or put you club on the sand.

Term.Title: Bunny
Term.Description: A goal scored on a power shot close to the goalkeepers head.

Term.Title: Bunt
Term.Description: Short hit that is executed by letting the ball hit the bat (not swinging). Used to advance a runner.

Term.Title: Buntline
Term.Description: One of the lines tied to the bottom of a square sail and used to haul it up to the yard when furling.

Term.Title: Buoy
Term.Description: A floating object of defined shape and color, which is anchored at a given position and serves as an aid to navigation.

Term.Title: Buoyancy
Term.Description: The power of supporting a body so that it floats; upward pressure exerted by the fluid in which a body is immersed.

Term.Title: Burden
Term.Description: Anything that results in a restrictive load upon something; any matter which limits, restricts or is onerous.

Term.Title: Burden of Proof
Term.Description: The requirement that the plaintiff (the party bringing a civil lawsuit) show by a "preponderance of evidence" or "weight of evidence" that all the facts necessary to win a judgment are presented and are probably true.

Term.Title: Burger Flip
Term.Description: A half-pipe trick where the rider will go into the backside wall riding fakie, then they will rotate 180 degrees in the air, and then they re-enter the pipe doing a McTwist.

Term.Title: Burghley Horse Trials
Term.Description: http://www.burghley-horse.co.uk/

Term.Title: Burkina Faso
Term.Description: Country code = BF

Term.Title: Burma (Myanmar)

Term.Title: Burn

Term.Title: Canoe (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Canoe was introduced as a Paralympic sport at the 2016 Rio Paralympic Games. In the Paralympic Games there is only the sprint discipline. The Olympic and Paralympic versions have similar rules, with the fastest canoeist winning. The competition format features direct classification to the finals and repechage heats to decide which athletes will take part in the final race, in which medals are won. In the Paralympic Games, only kayaks, identified by the letter K, are used. Each boat is adapted according to the functional abilities of its crew members. Athletes with any type of physical-motor disability may participate in competitions. There are three functional classes: LTA, where athletes use their legs, trunk and arms to help rowing; TA, in which athletes use only their trunk and arms; and A, in which athletes only use their arms. Events are always held along straight line courses marked by buoys, 200 metres long. There are both mens and womens races, with events for individuals.

Term.Description: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve in the wrist; a narrowing of the space through which the median nerve passes. The cause may be structural such as with a fracture or congenital cases, or due to swelling, inflammation or fluid retention.

Term.Title: Carry (Badminton)

Term.Description: The term carry the bat (or carry one's bat) refers to an opening batsman who is not dismissed ("not out") when the team innings is closed. The term is usually used only when the innings is closed as a result of all other 10 players being dismissed ("out"), not when an opening batsman remains "in" when the team's innings is declared closed, or the game ends when the batting team wins, or the match is drawn because time runs out.

Term.Title: Carryforward
Term.Description: A carryforward is the application of a tax loss or tax credit from the most recent tax reporting period to a future year.

Term.Title: Carrying Amount
Term.Description: The carrying amount is an asset's carrying amount is the recorded amount of the asset, net of any accumulated depreciation or accumulated impairment losses. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Carve

Term.Description: A skier will use the edge of their skies through turns down and when going down a ski slope to order to control their speed.

Term.Title: Castle Position

Term.Description: Water that is on the course but that is not a water hazard, like puddles caused by the sprinkling system. You can move your ball if it lands in casual water.

Term.Title: Casualty
Term.Description: The loss, as of life, from such an unavoidable accident.

Term.Title: Catalina
Term.Description: The swimmer starts by lying on their back. They move into a bent knee figure, into a ballet leg, they then twist their torso and move into a position where their torso is under water and one leg is horizontal to the water the other is vertical and out of the water. Then the swimmer brings their legs together and slowly descends under the water, keeping in the vertical position.

Term.Title: Catch
Term.Description: The part of the stroke at which the oar blade enters the water and the drive begins. Rowers conceptualize the oar blade as 'catching' or grabbing hold of the water.

Term.Title: Catch Point
Term.Description: Where the blade enters the water.

Term.Title: Catch Up
Term.Description: When one of the swimmers arms pauses so that the other arm can catch up to it.

Term.Title: Catcher
Term.Description: When a batter takes their turn to hit, the catcher crouches behind home plate, in front of the umpire, and receives the ball from the pitcher.

Term.Title: Catcher (Baseball)
Term.Description: When a batter takes their turn to hit, the catcher crouches behind home plate, in front of the umpire, and receives the ball from the pitcher.

Term.Title: Catcher (Softball Player)
Term.Description: When a batter takes their turn to hit, the catcher crouches behind home plate, in front of the umpire, and receives the ball from the pitcher.

Term.Title: Catcher (Softball Positions)
Term.Description: When a batter takes their turn to hit, the catcher crouches behind home plate, in front of the umpire, and receives the ball from the pitcher.

Term.Title: Catch-Foot
Term.Description: A spin or spiral position in which the free leg is held by one or both hands. The most notable catch-foot position is the Biellmann.

Term.Title: Catching Feature
Term.Description: A three-sided marker (usually orange and white) placed at features on an orienteering course. It usually has a punch or other marking device attached to mark a control card as proof that you visited the control.

Term.Title: Catharpin
Term.Description: A short rope or iron clamp used to brace in the shrouds toward the masts so as to give a freer sweep to the yards.

Term.Title: Caught
Term.Description: Caught is a method of dismissing a batsman in the sport of cricket. Being caught out is the most common method of dismissal. This method of dismissal is covered by Law 32 of the Laws of cricket which reads: A batsman is out caught if a fielder catches the ball fully within the field of play without it bouncing once the ball has touched the striker's bat or glove holding the bat. If a batsman could be given out caught or by any other method except bowled, 'caught' takes precedence.

Term.Title: Causa Mortis
Term.Description: Latin for 'incase of death'.

Term.Title: Caution
Term.Description: A player who deliberately or repeatedly infringes the laws is cautioned, and shown a yellow card. A cautioned player is suspended from playing for ten minutes.

Term.Title: Center (Gridiron)
Term.Description: The center is the player who begins the play from scrimmage by snapping the ball to the Quarterback.

Term.Title: Center (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: A forward position whose primary zone of play is the middle of the ice.

Term.Title: Center Face Off Circle
Term.Description: The circle in the middle of the ice where the game begins with the opening face off. The game will also restart here after a goal has been scored.

Term.Title: Center Fielder
Term.Description: Outfielder is term applied to each of the people playing in the three defensive positions in baseball farthest from the batter.

Term.Title: Center Ice
Term.Description: The area between the two blue lines, also called the neutral zone.

Term.Title: Center Line
Term.Description: A red 12-inch wide line across the ice midway between the two goals.

Term.Title: Centered
Term.Description: A spin that that stays in one spot on the ice. The opposite of traveling.

Term.Title: Centered Stance
Term.Description: When the bindings on a snowboard are mounted so the distance between the back binding and the tail is the same as the distance front binding and the nose. This gives equal backwards and forwards control to the snowboarder.

Term.Title: Centering Pass
Term.Description: A pass from an attacking player towards the middle of the ice to a teammate with a better angle at the goal.

Term.Description: Country code = CF

Term.Title: Central Coast Academy of Sport (Mingara)
Term.Description: http://www.thinksport.com.au/

Term.Title: Central Coast Mariners
Term.Description: National A-League football club team.

Term.Title: Central District Basketball Club
