Term.Title: Central Nervous System
Term.Description: Including the brain and spinal cord, this is the control centre which is responsible for interpreting information and making decisions about appropriate responses and movements.

Term.Title: Central Processing Unit
Term.Description: The part of a computer that interprets and carries out instructions provided by the software. It tests and manipulates data, and transfers information to and from other components, such as the working memory, disk drive, monitor, and keyboard. The central processing units of personal computers are generally implemented on a single chip, called a microprocessor.

Term.Title: Central Queensland University
Term.Description: http://www.cqu.edu.au/

Term.Title: Centre
Term.Description: They are the players wearing shirts numbers 12 & 13. They are divided into inside and outside centre.

Term.Title: Centre (AFL Player)
Term.Description: The center is the link between the offense and defense of his team. He tries to anticipate where the play is going and help either the defensive or offensive players on his team to make the play they need to make.

Term.Title: Centre (Netball)
Term.Description: The centre (C) is the link player from the defence third to the goal third and plays an important role in both attack and defence. They are allowed to move over the whole court, except the goal circles.

Term.Title: Centre Bounce
Term.Description: A field umpire will bounce the ball in the centre circle after a goal has been scored and at the beginning of each quarter. This is the way that play is resumed. If the field is too wet the umpire will throw the ball in the air. Players are not allowed in the centre circle until the umpire has bounced or thrown the ball.

Term.Title: Centre Circle (Football)
Term.Description: The 10-yard radius circle around the centre spot.

Term.Title: Centre Circle (Wrestling)
Term.Description: A small circle inside the wrestling area circle that is 1 metre in diameter.

Term.Title: Centre Court
Term.Description: The middle third of the court.

Term.Title: Centre Field
Term.Description: Outfielder is term applied to each of the people playing in the three defensive positions in baseball farthest from the batter.

Term.Title: Centre Forward (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: The center player in the forward line who usually leads his teams attack when they are trying to score a goal. He takes part in most of the face-offs and he controls the puck and tries to score or pass it to a teammate who is in a better position to score a goal.

Term.Title: Centre Forward (Water Polo)
Term.Description: This position is the primary attacking player who is positioned in front of the opposing teams goal. They usually triy to position themself between the two-metre and four-metre lines. They are the player who will take the most shots on goal. On defense they guard the opposing teams center guard.

Term.Title: Centre Half Back
Term.Description: The Halfbacks job is to get the ball and get it back to the Center or Wings.

Term.Title: Centre Half Forward
Term.Description: Half Forward players attack the ball, meaning that they try and get the ball away from the other team. They also try to keep the ball in their team's offensive zone. They try to set up scoring shots and they can also attempt to score themselves.

Term.Title: Centre Line
Term.Description: This is a line that divides the field in half. The field is 100 yards (91.4 metres) long so this is the 50-yard (45.7 metre) line.

Term.Title: Centre Line (Badminton)
Term.Description: A line that runs perpendicular to the net and separates the left and right service courts.

Term.Title: Centre Line (Curling)
Term.Description: A line running lengthwise down the centre of the ice, used as a visual aid.

Term.Title: Centre Line (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: The line which runs long ways down the table and it divides the tabletop into half-courts. It is only used in doubles matches when a serve must be made diagonally.

Term.Title: Centre Mark
Term.Description: This is a spot in the middle of the field or pitch where the ball is put down to start a half or after a goal has been scored.

Term.Title: Centre of Gravity
Term.Description: The point through which the resultant of the gravitational forces on a body always acts.

Term.Title: Centre Pass (Hockey)
Term.Description: A pass used to begin the game or the second half, or to restart action following a goal. The ball is placed in the centre of the field, where the centre forward passes the ball at least one metre backwards to a teammate.

Term.Title: Centre Pass (Netball)
Term.Description: Name of pass used to start or restart game from centre circle.

Term.Title: Centre Square
Term.Description: The center square is a 45 metre square that is in the center of the field. The center circle is inside the center square and only 4 players from each team are allowed to be in the center square when a center bounce is taking place.

Term.Title: Centreline
Term.Description: An imaginary line down the center of a vessel lengthwise.

Term.Title: Century
Term.Description: A batsman reaches their century when they score 100 or more runs in an innings. The term is also included in 'century partnership' which occurs when two batsmen add 100 runs to the team total when they are batting together. A century is regarded as a landmark score for batsmen and a player's number of centuries is generally recorded in his career statistics. Scoring a century is loosely equated in terms of merit to a bowler taking five wickets in an innings.

Term.Title: CEO
Term.Description: Chief Executive Officer is the highest ranking corporate officer in charge of total management of an organisation.

Term.Title: Cerebral Edema
Term.Description: Swelling of the brain due to the uptake of water in the neuropile and white matter.

Term.Title: Cerebral Palsy International Sport and Recreation Association
Term.Description: http://www.cpisra.org/

Term.Title: International Sporting Organisation for People with a Disability
Certificate of Title
Term.Description: The document of title to a piece of land.

Term.Title: Certified Cheque
Term.Description: A cheque issued by a bank which certifies that the maker of the cheque has enough money in his / her account to cover the amount to be paid.

Term.Title: Certified Public Accountant
Term.Description: A certified public accountant is an accountant who has passed all parts of the CPA examination.

Term.Title: Cestui Que Trust
Term.Description: A trust beneficiary.

Term.Title: CFO
Term.Description: Chief Financial Officer - person in charge of a finance department of a company.

Term.Title: Chad
Term.Description: Country code = TD

Term.Title: Chafing
Term.Description: Wear on line or sail caused by constant rubbing against another surface.

Term.Title: Chafing Gear
Term.Description: Material applied to a line or spar to prevent or reduce chafing.

Term.Title: Chain Slap
Term.Description: Annoying slapping of the bike's chain against the chainstays while riding over rough terrain.

Term.Title: Chain Suck
Term.Description: The tendency of a chain to stick to chain rings and be sucked up into the bike instead of coming off the chainring. Primarily caused by worn chainrings and rust on small chain rings, under high loads, and in dirty conditions.

Term.Title: Chains
Term.Description: A measuring device. In order to keep track of where a team begins first down and how far they have to go to make a first down, the officials have two poles and running between these two poles is a length of chain 10 yards long. So this device has become know as the chains.

Term.Title: Chair (Board of Directors)
Term.Description: The Chair is the highest officer of a Board of Directors or any other organized group.

Term.Title: Chair umpire
Term.Description: The Chair Umpire has the final word on all issues relating to on-court activities, for example whether a ball is in or out, if a player has a foot fault, a service touches the net, etc. In matches where line umpires are assigned, the chair umpire has the duty to over-rule any clear mistake made by a line umpire. In matches where electronic review is in use, this can over-rule a Line Umpires and/or Chair Umpires decision (following a challenge) and cannot be appealed. The Chair Umpires duty is also to control the match and enforce the Code of Conduct whenever required.

Term.Title: Chamber
Term.Description: The part of a firearm containing the cartridge.

Term.Title: Chamber Magistrate
Term.Description: A qualified officer of the Attorney Generals department who is able to give free legal advice to members of the public eligible for that service.

Term.Title: Chambers
Term.Description: The private office of a judge.

Term.Title: Champerty
Term.Description: An agreement made illegally where a person agrees to pay someone elses legal fees in return for a share of the proceeds.

Term.Title: Champion Lakes Boat Club
Term.Description: http://www.rowingwa.asn.au

Term.Title: Change in Track
Term.Description: In Olympic skating, skaters must change the lanes of the track that they started in. The skater who begins the race in the inside lane of the track moves to the outside lane when they reach the crossing straight and the other skater does the same. It is the responsibility of the skater that is moving from the inside lane to the outside not to touch the other skater.

Term.Title: Change of Pace Serve
Term.Description: A slow, off-speed serve, which is used to try and change the tempo of the game.

Term.Title: Change of Possession
Term.Description: When one team has to give the ball to the other team. Change of possession on downs is when a team had a 4th down, tried to get a 1st down and did not make it. Another way to have a change of possession is to have on team kick or punt the ball to the other team.

Term.Title: Change of Service
Term.Description: After 5 points have been scored the player who had been the receiver now becomes the server. This continues until the end of the game.

Term.Title: Changeover
Term.Description: The exchange of the baton from one runner to the next during a relay race.

Term.Title: Changeup
Term.Description: The changeup is the staple off-speed pitch, usually thrown to look like a fastball but arriving much slower to the plate.

Term.Title: Chappell Hadlee Series
Term.Description: Cricket Australia vs New Zealand

Term.Title: Commonwealth Bank International One Day Cricket Series
Chappell Hadlee Trophy
Term.Description: Cricket http://cricket.com.au/

Term.Title: Character Encoding
Term.Description: A mapping of binary values to code positions and back. Generally a 1:1 ( bijective) mapping.

Term.Title: Charcoal Platform
Term.Description: Seen on a number of maps in the U.S., particularly in the northeast states, this terrain feature is generally circular and flat with different vegetation than the surrounding area. The "platforms" provided a level surface to transform logs into charcoal.

Term.Title: Orienteering Land Forms and Map Symbols
Charge Down
Term.Description: The blocking of an attacker's kick as it rises from the foot. Done with outstretched arms and hands, this is not a knock-on.

Term.Title: Charging (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: The act of taking more than three strides while delivering a body check or leaving their feet to deliver a hit. A penalty.

Term.Title: Charging (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: A foul and it happens when one skater is trying to pass another skater on the inside and touches the skater they are trying to pass.

Term.Title: Charitable Contribution
Term.Description: A contribution to an organisation which is officially created for charitable, religious, educational, scientific, artistic, literary, or other good works. Such contributions are deductible from gross income, and thus lower the taxes paid.

Term.Title: Charles Darwin University Sport
Term.Description: http://www.cdu.edu.au/

Term.Title: Charlie
Term.Description: The Brownlow Medal.

Term.Title: Charlotte Spiral
Term.Description: The skater bends forward and glides on one leg with the other one lifted into the air. The skater's torso is upright, but during the charlotte, the skater's torso is as close to the grounded foot as possible. When performed well, the skater's legs are almost in a straight vertical split position.

Term.Title: Chase
Term.Description: A group of one or more riders who are ahead of the peloton trying to join the race or stage leader(s). There may be none, one, or many chases at any given point in a race.

Term.Title: Chasers
Term.Description: These are skaters who are trying to catch up to or go in front of the other skaters.

Term.Title: Chasse
Term.Description: An ice dancing step that can be a simple chasse, a crossed chasse, or a slide chasse.

Term.Title: Chatsworth Horse Trials
Term.Description: http://www.chatsworth.org/horsetrials

Term.Title: Chattels
Term.Description: Property which is not freehold land; divided into two- categories: chattels real: interests in land other than freehold; chattels personal: movable and tangible personal property.

Term.Title: Chatter
Term.Description: The vibration a snowboard will experience at high speeds and during turns.

Term.Title: Cheated
Term.Description: A jump that was not fully rotated in midair, with either the first rotation starting on the ice or the final rotation finishing after the landing.

Term.Title: Check (Curling)
Term.Description: To get a stone close to another stone.

Term.Title: Check (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: Stopping the rotation of a jump or a spin.

Term.Title: Check (Rowing)
Term.Description: The amount of interruption of the forward movement. Usually occurs at the catch and sometimes at the release.

Term.Title: Check Mark
Term.Description: A mark on the runway used to aid the athlete in staying consistent during the approach of a jumping event or the javelin throw. It might indicate where to start, where to change the phase of the approach, where to take off, or where to throw.

Term.Title: Checked Swing
Term.Description: A partial swing. If the swing has gone more than halfway around, the umpire can rule it a full swing, or strike.

Term.Title: Checking
Term.Description: The act of hitting an opponent.

Term.Title: Checking (AFL)
Term.Description: A player with the ball can be tackled from the shoulder down or above the knees. If a player tackles a player with the ball above the shoulders (including the top of the shoulders) or below the knees a free kick is awarded. A player who does not have the ball can be pushed in the chest or from the side as long as the ball is within 5 meters of the player.

Term.Title: Checkside
Term.Description: A kick that is kicked with great spin causing a curved trajectory through the air such that it gradually shifts from its initial flight path or direction in flight to another.

Term.Title: Cheddar Biscuits
Term.Description: A perfect set.

Term.Title: Cheeks
Term.Description: Wooden blocks at the side of a spar.

Term.Title: Chemical
Term.Description: A substance produced by or used in a chemical process.

Term.Title: Chemistry
Term.Description: The science that deals with the composition and properties of substances and various elementary forms of matter.

Term.Title: Cheque
Term.Description: A written order, usually on a standard printed form, directing a bank to pay money.

Term.Title: Cherry
Term.Description: Refers to a new ball because it is bright red cherry coloured appearance.

Term.Title: Cherry Pick
Term.Description: To stay on your side of the court when the other team has the ball. You basically don't play defense, so that if the other team misses, you are all by yourself for an easy lay-up. Needles to say, you won't make many friends if cherry picking is a part of your arsenal.

Term.Title: Cherry Picking
Term.Description: A player stays on his offensive end of the pool when the rest of his team is defending waiting for a turnover often resulting in a long pass and uncontested goal.

Term.Title: Chest On
Term.Description: Chest on describes the position of a bowler or batsman. The term is used interchangeably with front on.

Term.Title: Chest Pass
Term.Description: This pass is performed best by stepping towards your target with one foot, then throwing the ball out towards their chest with two hands while turning the hands over, ending with the thumbs pointing down.

Term.Title: Chicago Marathon
Term.Description: http://www.chicagomarathon.com/cms400min/chicago_marathon/

Term.Title: Chicane
Term.Description: A sequence of tight turns, often s-shaped, usually most important near the finish of a road-race or during a criterium.

Term.Title: Chicken Salad Grab
Term.Description: The snowboarder with their rear hand will reach between their legs and grab the heel edge between the bindings, and their front leg will be boned. The snowboarders wrist will be rotated inward to complete the grab.

Term.Title: Chicken Wing
Term.Description: Used to describe a tackle where one or both arms are pinned and the player is then usually thrown to the ground, unable to break their fall.

Term.Title: Chickenpox
Term.Description: Chickenpox (also called varicella) is a common and extremely infectious childhood disease that also affects adults on occasion. It produces an itchy, blistery rash that typically lasts about a week and is sometimes accompanied by a fever or other symptoms.

Term.Title: Chief Justice
Term.Description: The presiding judge of the Supreme Court.

Term.Title: Chief Referee (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: The lead official and the one who listens to and makes the final ruling or decision on any protests that are lodged during a race. Only coaches are permitted to speak to the Chief Referee.

Term.Title: Chief Umpire (Tennis)
Term.Description: The Chief Umpire is a liaison officer between the officials and the tournament staff and/or Referee. They coordinate the officials, assign the Chair Umpires and line umpires and deal with officiating problems or requests from officials. Chief umpires are not required at every event.

Term.Title: Child Protection
Term.Description: Organisations and activities to protect children and young people from abuse or discrimination.

Term.Title: Child Protection Legislation
Term.Description: www.ausport.gov.au/supporting/ethics Most of the legistlation has a similar framework and involves checking someone's suitabillity to work with children.

Term.Title: Chile
Term.Description: Country code = CL

Term.Title: Chin Music
Term.Description: Chin music is a term for a bowling strategy where bouncers are aimed at the batsman's throat or chin. Rising rapidly off the pitch, the ball is difficult to play unless the batsman has quick footwork. Better left alone, it yields a ballooned return catch to the bowler or to close-in fielders. This is a difficult ball to bowl, since a few inches on either side would present the batsman with a short ball that can be easily put away on either side of the pitch. It is not illegal in cricket, but the number of short deliveries allowed in an over is usually restricted, and bowlers who exceed this may get a warning from the umpire. This tactic was made famous by the England team in the controversial 'Bodyline' Ashes series in 1932.

Term.Title: China Australia Softball Challenge
Term.Description: http://www.ausport.gov.au/ais/sports/softball/home

Term.Title: China Sport Information Center
Term.Description: Chinese government sport information collecting and dissemination agency.

Term.Title: China Tennis Open
Term.Description: http://www.atpworldtour.com/Tennis/Tournaments/Beijing.aspx

Term.Title: Chine
Term.Description: A line formed where the sides of a boat meet the bottom.

Term.Title: Chip
Term.Description: A shot that is hit just far enough in the air to land the ball on the green and get it to roll to the hole.

Term.Title: Chip Pass
Term.Description: A pass intended to go over a defender's head where the ball is snapped up with a quick ankle motion.

Term.Title: Chip Shot
Term.Description: A chip that has some spin on the ball.

Term.Title: Chipping Iron
Term.Description: A iron club, used in chipping, either on to the green or perhaps to hit out of the rough when there is no other way to get the ball back into the fairway.

Term.Title: Chloride
Term.Description: A salt of hydrochloric acid consisting of two elements, one of which is chlorine, as sodium chloride, NaCl.

Term.Title: Chlorodehydromethyltestosterone
Term.Description: Sold under the brand name Oral Turinabol, is an anabolic steroid. It is a chlor-substituted version of methandrostenolone.

Term.Title: Chlortalidone
Term.Description: A diuretic drug.

Term.Title: Chock
Term.Description: Hole or ring attached to the hull to guide a line via that point.

Term.Title: Choctaw Turn
Term.Description: A two foot turn with a change of edge that results in a change of lobe.

Term.Title: Choke Hold
Term.Description: The goal of the Choke Hold is to cut off your rivals breathing. This is accomplished when one of the combatants is able to get his forearm around his rival's neck and compress the trachea or the carotid arteries. This is also called a Strangle Hold.

Term.Title: Choke Up
Term.Description: A player will move their hand up the racquet handle to better hit a certain kind of shot.

Term.Title: Chongming Island Cycling Time Trial
Term.Description: http://www.cycling.org.au

Term.Title: Choose in Action
Term.Description: Personal property that is intangible such as a right to be paid a debt.

Term.Title: Chop
Term.Description: A shot hit in a downward motion, the aim of which is to try to get the opposing player to hit their return into the net.

Term.Title: Chorionic Gonadotropin
Term.Description: A hormone produced by the syncytiotrophoblast, a component of the fertilized egg, after conception.

Term.Title: Chose in Possession
Term.Description: Personal property that is tangible, goods or chattels.

Term.Title: Chowder
Term.Description: A badly mangled set.

Term.Title: Christie Turn
Term.Description: A turn where the skis will skid and both skis will skid on the same edges.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Chronic Fatigue
Term.Description: Chronic fatigue syndrome is a condition of prolonged and severe tiredness or weariness (fatigue) that is not relieved by rest and is not directly caused by other conditions.

Term.Title: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
Term.Description: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) is an illness which causes long-lasting physical and mental fatigue.

Term.Title: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease
Term.Description: COPD; a progressive lung disorder, developed due to the inflammation and blockage of the airways and air sacs.

Term.Description: http://www.cyclingfever.com/editie.html?editie_id=21625

Term.Description: http://www.chronodesnations.com/

Term.Title: Chronometer
Term.Description: A timekeeper accurate enough to be used to determine longitude by means of celestial navigation.

Term.Title: Chui
Term.Description: This is a penalty given to one of the combatants, the opponent gains five points or the same number of points as a Yuko.

Term.Description: Natural gullies that snowboarders will ride through.

Term.Description: A type of interval training in which strength exercises are combined with endurance / aerobic exercises, combining the benefits of both a cardiovascular and strength training workout.

Term.Title: Circuito Montanes
Term.Description: http://www.circuitomontanes.com/

Term.Title: Circulatory system
Term.Description: The system that circulates blood and lymph through the body, consisting of the heart, blood vessels, blood, lymph, and the lymphatic vessels and glands.

Term.Title: Circumduction
Term.Description: Moving a limb so that the end of the limb draws a circle.

Term.Title: Citation
Term.Description: A notice to appear in court due to the probable commission of a minor crime.

Term.Title: Citizen
Term.Description: A person who by place of birth, nationality of one or both parents, or by going through the naturalization process has sworn loyalty to a nation.

Term.Title: Civil
Term.Description: That part of the law that encompasses business, contracts, estates, domestic (family) relations, accidents, negligence and everything related to legal issues, statutes and lawsuits, that is not criminal law.

Term.Title: Civil law
Term.Description: Laws regulating the behaviour of individuals; a form of private law.

Term.Title: Claim
Term.Description: To make a demand for money, for property, or for enforcement of a right provided by law; the making of a demand for money due, for property, from damages or for enforcement of a right.

Term.Title: Clamp
Term.Description: A maneuver done during a face-off where a player will push the back of their stick on top of the ball.

Term.Title: Clap Skate
Term.Description: This is the type of skate that is used in long track sped skating. The skating blade on the clap skate detaches from the heel of the boot and this allows the blade of the skate to stay on the ice longer. This is also where the skate gets its name.
