Term.Description: Clarendon NSW 2756

Term.Title: Clasica Alcobendas
Term.Description: http://www.euro-ace.eu/

Term.Title: Clasica de Almeria
Term.Description: http://www.clasicadealmeria.com/

Term.Title: Class
Term.Description: In legal terms all those persons in the same category, level of rights or who have suffered from the same incident.

Term.Title: Class 0.5 (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Main role is as blocker, not a major ball handler because of extensive proximal shoulder weakness and lack of triceps function forward head bob present when pushing. Because of lack of triceps, pulls on back part of the wheel for push stroke using biceps by bending elbows. Elbows are also out to side when pushing (called an unopposed biceps push). Because of wrist extensor weakness and lack of other wrist and hand function, may use forearm on wheel for starts, turns and stops because of proximal shoulder weakness, arm and wrist weakness, traps direct passes on lap or bats it in from limited range . Bats ball using underhand volleyball pass for longer range pass or for shorter range pass uses scoop pass with the ball forward to the side uses a two-hand toss.

Term.Title: Class 1 (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Complete Quadriplegic, Double Through Shoulder Amputation.

Term.Title: Class 1.0 (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Blocker may in-bound ball. Not a major ball handler because of proximal shoulder weakness and triceps weakness. May have slight head bob when pushing, but has a longer push on wheel (combination of push and pull on back part of wheel). Because of increased strength in upper chest and shoulders, multidirectional start, stop and turn (Can turn in all directions without stopping easier and faster turning than 0.5 athlete but because of triceps and wrist weakness, 1.0 athlete may still use forearm) Forearm or wrist catch. Weak chest pass or forearm pass.

Term.Title: Class 1.5 (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Excellent blocker and also may be occasional ball handler. Increased shoulder strength and stability allows for more effective and efficient pushing ball handling skills. Increased shoulder strength and stability allows for some distance and consistency to chest pass. Typically has wrist imbalance that causes limited ball security when passing. May have asymmetry present in arms. If so, predominantly uses the stronger arm for chair and ball skills.

Term.Title: Class 2 (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Double Above Elbow Amputation, Single Above Elbow Amputation and Single Below Elbow Amputation.

Term.Title: Class 2.0 (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Increasing role on court as ball handler. Typically has very strong and stable shoulder that allows for good pushing speed on court. Effective chest pass with control over moderate distance. Due to a lack of finger flexion, there is limited ball security.

Term.Title: Class 2.5 (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Ball handler and fairly fast playmaker. Because of excellent shoulder strength and stability will see good pushing speed on court. Functional grip is used to advantage on the pushrim when challenged. May have some trunk control giving better stability in the chair. Reasonably balanced finger flexion and extension without true grasp and release. Dribbles the ball safely, but supinates forearm to scoop the ball onto the lap. Due to finger flexion strength capable of performing one-handed overhead pass, but limited accuracy and distance because of imbalance in finger strength. Safe two handed catching of passes, usually scooping ball to lap. May catch passes single handed and scoop to lap or chest. Improved ball security compared to 2.0 hand due to improved ability to isolate wrist / finger function. May have asymmetrical arm or hand function, noticeable with chair and ball handling skills.

Term.Title: Class 3 (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Single Above Knee Amputation, Single Above Elbow Amputation and Double Below Elbow Amputation.

Term.Title: Class 3.0 (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Very good ball handler and fast playmaker. Because of balanced finger function, athlete can grip wheelchair rim increasing pushing speed. May have some trunk control giving better stability in the chair. Because of function in fingers, can control ball in varying planes of movement for passing, dribbling, catching and protecting ball during these activities. Can dribble and pass ball well with one hand. Multiple dribble. Stabilizes with the opposite arm to allow greater reach (if the athlete has no trunk function)one handed with control.

Term.Title: Class 3.5 (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Major ball handler and very fast playmaker. Often primary ball handler and playmaker on team. Has some trunk function, therefore very stable in wheelchair and able to use trunk for ball and chair skills. Because of combination of hand and trunk function, usually has excellent ball control with controlled one hand passing for distance and excellent ball security during passing and receiving. May have asymmetrical arm or hand function, noticeable with chair and ball handling skills.

Term.Title: Class 4 (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Single Through Shoulder Amputation, Double Above Knee Amputation, Double Below Knee Amputation without Prostheses, Single Above Knee and Single Below Knee Amputation without Prostheses.

Term.Title: Class 5 (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Single Above Elbow Amputation, Single Above Knee Amputation and Single Below Knee Amputation with Prostheses.

Term.Title: Class 6 (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Double Below Knee Amputation with Prostheses and Single Below Elbow Amputation.

Term.Title: Class 7 (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Single Above Knee Amputation and Single Below Knee Amputation without Prosthesis (excluding Symes Amputation or equivalent).

Term.Title: Class Action
Term.Description: A lawsuit filed by one or more people on behalf of themselves and a larger group of people who are similarly situated.

Term.Title: Class B1 Visual (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: No light perception in either eye, up to light perception but inability to recognize the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction. The competitor cannot make use of any visual clues to assist in sailing.

Term.Title: Class B2 Visual (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: From the ability to recognize the shape of a hand up to visual acuity of 2/60 and / or visual field of less than 5 degrees radius.

Term.Title: Class B3 Visual (Sailing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: A visual acuity at or below 6/60 or the visual field is less than 20 degrees.

Term.Title: Classic Championships Horse Show, Burbank USA
Term.Description: http://www.horseshowcentral.com

Term.Title: Classic de l'Indre
Term.Description: http://www.classicdelindre.com/

Term.Title: Classic technique (Cross Country Skiing)
Term.Description: A basic ski racing technique. Skiers use a diagonal stride with the skis staying parallel to each other. The left arm would be moved forward with the right leg and the right arm with the left leg. This is called a kick and glide movement.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Classification
Term.Description: One of the groups or classes into which things may be or have been arranged or organized according to rank.

Term.Title: Classification Points
Term.Description: Points that are awarded at the end of each tournament or match and are used as a way to rank wrestlers. These are not the same as the points a contestant gets during a match.

Term.Title: Clean and jerk
Term.Description: The clean and jerk is a Weightlifting lift that contains two movements: the clean and the jerk. The clean consists of the lifter raising a weighted barbell from the floor to a position across the deltoids and clavicles. The jerk involves lifting the weight above the head until the arms are straight and the bar is stationary.

Term.Title: Clean Bowled
Term.Description: When a batsman is beaten by a ball and subsequently dismissed through the stumps being broken.

Term.Title: Clean Program
Term.Description: A skating program without falls, hands on the ground in jumps and spins, or illegal use of toe picks in edge jumps that can all result in point deductions.

Term.Title: Clean-up Hitter
Term.Description: Player who hits fourth in the batting order.

Term.Title: Clear (Badminton)
Term.Description: A shot hit deep to the opponent's back boundary line. There are two types of clear shots; the high clear is a defensive shot, the flat attacking clear is an offensive shot.

Term.Title: Clear (Hockey)
Term.Description: A defensive tactic used to dribble or hit the ball out of the 25-yard area.

Term.Title: Clear (Luge)
Term.Description: That part of the track where the competitor begins his or her run.

Term.Title: Clear Title
Term.Description: Holding ownership of real property without any claims by others on the owner's title and no history of past claims which might affect the ownership.

Term.Title: Clearing (Netball)
Term.Description: A player moves to clear space for another player to move into.

Term.Title: Clearing the Puck
Term.Description: Getting the puck out of your defensive zone, so the other team can't take a shot on goal.

Term.Title: Clearing the Zone
Term.Description: When a defensemen moves the puck out of the defending zone before it can be shot on goal.

Term.Title: Clearinghouse
Term.Description: A central institution or agency for the collection, maintenance, and distribution of materials, information, etc.

Term.Title: Clearinghouse for Sport
Term.Description: The Clearinghouse for Sport (Clearinghouse) is an Australian sport sector information and knowledge sharing initiative developed and led by the National Sport Information Centre. https://secure.ausport.gov.au/clearinghouse

Term.Title: Cleat (Sailing)
Term.Description: A stationary device used to secure a rope aboard a vessel.

Term.Title: Cleaver Blade
Term.Description: Modern oar blades that have a more rectangular hatchet-shape.

Term.Title: Clenbuterol
Term.Description: A sympathomimetic amine.

Term.Title: Clerk of the Court
Term.Description: Person who files legal documents, issues summonds and subpoenas and has access to al court records.

Term.Title: Clew
Term.Description: The lower corners of square sails or the corner of a triangular sail at the end of the boom.

Term.Title: Clew-lines
Term.Description: Used to truss up the clews, the lower corners of square sails.

Term.Title: Click
Term.Description: The name given to the smallest adjustment of a sight.

Term.Title: Clicker
Term.Description: A device used to indicate an archer's optimum draw length.

Term.Title: Cliff Drops
Term.Description: When a snowboarder deliberately rides their snowboard off a cliff to become airborne.

Term.Title: Clincher
Term.Description: A type of tire that uses a bead around the edge of the tire to attach to the rim of the wheel when inflated. The inner tube is separate.

Term.Title: Clip
Term.Description: The name given to a device to hold a group of cartridges together prior to loading them into the gun's magazine.

Term.Title: Clip Art
Term.Description: Drawings or illustrations available for easy insertion into other material.

Term.Title: Clipboard
Term.Description: A temporary storage area in desktop publishing where text or graphics are held after the cut command or the copy command.

Term.Title: Clipping
Term.Description: An illegal block in which the victim is blocked from the back and at or below the waist incuring a 15 yard penalty.

Term.Title: Clips
Term.Description: Colored clips, one for each ball, which are placed on wickets to show which ball is going for which wicket and in what direction. Clips on top indicate the first six wickets and clips on the side indicate the second six wickets.

Term.Title: Clipsal Stadium
Term.Description: Adelaide SA 5000

Term.Title: Clock
Term.Description: When the skier starts their run they push a bar that moves straight out and out of the skier's way, kind of like a turnstile, and when this bar is touched it triggers the clock to start timing the run.

Term.Title: Clock Someone
Term.Description: To hit someone.

Term.Title: Clomifene
Term.Description: A selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that increases production of gonadotropins by inhibiting negative feedback on the hypothalamus.

Term.Title: Close Line Play
Term.Description: The area between the offensive tackles, and this extends three yards on each side of the line of scrimmage.

Term.Title: Closed Face
Term.Description: When the face of the racquet is at such an angle that it is slanted either toward the floor or toward the front wall side of the player.

Term.Title: Closed Gate
Term.Description: A single gate (a gate in slalom consists of two poles) that must be approached at an angle because the poles are placed in the fall line and the poles run in an almost vertical line.

Term.Title: Closed Stance
Term.Description: This involves the front foot being nearer the ball when preparing to hit the shot. This stance will help to hook the ball or to keep from slicing the ball.

Term.Title: Closer
Term.Description: Relief pitcher who specialises in pitching the last few outs of a game. General used to hold a lead in the late innings of a game.

Term.Title: Closing the Block
Term.Description: The responsibility of the assisting blocker(s) to join the primary blocker and create an impenetrable block in which a ball cannot fit between the two individual blockers.

Term.Title: Clostebol
Term.Description: Ester clostebol acetate or clostebol enanthate, is a synthetic anabolic androgenic steroid. Clostebol is the 4-chloro derivative of the natural hormone testosterone.

Term.Title: Clothing (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Alpine ski racers wear lightweight, form-fitting clothing (all in one suit) to minimise air resistance. Slalom skiers frequently wear pads to protect from injury.

Term.Title: Clothing (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: In Olympic figure skating, skaters wear costumes that are supposed to match the mood of their music and style of their programs. Women must wear skirts and men must wear full-length pants.

Term.Title: Clothing (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Teams must wear matching jerseys, pants and socks with a number clearly visible on the front and back of each player.

Term.Title: Cloud Computing
Term.Description: Cloud computing is the delivery of computing as a service rather than a product, whereby shared resources, software and information are provided to computers and other devices as a utility (like the electricity grid) over a network (typically the Internet).

Term.Title: Cloud Database
Term.Description: A Cloud database is a database that rely on cloud technology.

Term.Title: Club
Term.Description: An organisation constituted to provide teams or athletes to enter competitions in a particular sport or sports. Clubs contain an adminsitrative layer, members, players or athletes and technical officials, they may also manage their own sport facilties. All clubs have rules of membership and may be constituted as various types of organisation including; an incorporated business or an association.

Term.Title: Club (Golf)
Term.Description: An implement used by a player to hit a golf ball. A player is allowed to carry up to fourteen clubs during a round of golf.

Term.Title: Clubhouse
Term.Description: The administration centre of a golf club.

Term.Title: CMAS
Term.Description: Confederation Mondiale des Activites Subaquatiques (World Underwater Federation) www.cmas.org

Term.Title: Co trustee
Term.Description: A trustee of a trust when there is more than one trustee serving at the same time, usually with the same powers and obligations.

Term.Title: Coach
Term.Description: A person employed in the direction, instruction and training of the operations of a sports team or of individual athlete.

Term.Title: Coaching
Term.Description: To give instruction or advice to in the capacity of a coach; instruct; to mentor.

Term.Title: PERFORMANCE TERMS (including Sports Science and Medicine)
Coach's Code of Behaviour
Term.Description: The coach's code of behaviour is a positive document for all coaches. It affirms a coach's support for the concepts of responsibility, trust, competence, respect, safety, honesty, professionalism, equity and sportsmanship. The code also provides a reference point for clubs, parents, athletes, schools and employers to expect that a coach will demonstrate appropriate standards of behaviour. http://www.ausport.gov.au/participating/coachofficial/Guidelines/policy/coachbehaviour

Term.Title: Coaming
Term.Description: The curved lip around its edge, used to secure a spray skirt, is the coaming.

Term.Title: Coathanger
Term.Description: Dangerous high tackle with a forceful straight arm to the opponents neck or head.

Term.Title: Coburg Harriers Athletics Club Inc
Term.Description: http://www.coburgharriers.org.au

Term.Title: Cock
Term.Description: To set the action into position for firing.

Term.Title: Cocked Wrist Position
Term.Description: The wrist position when the racquet is pulled back to its set position.

Term.Title: Cockpit (Canoe / Kayak)
Term.Description: The opening in the deck of a kayak or closed canoe where the paddler sits.

Term.Title: Code
Term.Description: A collection of written laws gathered together, usually covering specific subject matter.

Term.Title: Code of Practice
Term.Description: A set of industry-specific guidelines, usually developed by an industry body, created to guide the conduct of industry members in the absence of binding legislation.

Term.Title: Codec
Term.Description: A set of equipment that encodes an analogue speech or video signal into digital form for transmission purposes and at the receiving end decodes the digital signal into a form close to its original; coder or decoder.

Term.Title: Codical
Term.Description: An amendment to a will which changes or explains some part of it. It must be signed with the same legal requirements of the will itself.

Term.Title: Codify
Term.Description: To arrange and label a system of laws.

Term.Title: Cohabitation
Term.Description: Living together in the same residence.

Term.Title: Collaboration
Term.Description: Working together.

Term.Title: Collar (Rowing)
Term.Description: A wide plastic ring placed around the sleeve of an oar.

Term.Title: Collars (Powerlifting) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: A collar weighing 2.5kg must be worn by all athletes in competition.

Term.Title: Collateral
Term.Description: Property pledged to secure a loan or debt, usually funds or personal property as distinguished from real property.

Term.Title: Collection
Term.Description: A group of objects or works.

Term.Title: Collingwood Magpies
Term.Description: Australian Football League Club Team

Term.Title: Colliwobbles
Term.Description: Term coined to describe Collingwood's failure in finals between 1958 and 1990, including eight grand final losses and one draw.

Term.Title: Collusion
Term.Description: Where two persons enter into a deceitful agreement, usually secret, to defraud and / or gain an unfair advantage over a third party, competitors, consumers or those with whom they are negotiating.

Term.Title: Colombia
Term.Description: Country code = CO

Term.Title: Colts
Term.Description: U19 Men's Baseball

Term.Title: Comb
Term.Description: The upper part of the stock where the shooter's cheek rests during aiming.

Term.Title: Combination (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: Two or more elements (jumps, spin positions) performed in succession.

Term.Title: Combination Gates
Term.Description: Gates that are put into some sort of combination, which can include 2 or 3 gates together or even groups of 4 or more.

Term.Title: Combination Paddle
Term.Description: A paddle that has different surfaces on each side of the blade of the paddle.

Term.Title: Combined Event
Term.Description: A combined event means that a skier will make runs in the downhill, slalom and giant slalom events.

Term.Title: Combined Spin
Term.Description: A swimmer will do a spin descending in the water and the spin must be at least 360 degrees, then without stopping, the swimmer will be ascending in the water and do a spin in the same direction.

Term.Title: ComCover
Term.Description: Comcover is the Australian Government's general insurance fund.

Term.Title: Come Out Swinging
Term.Description: To go immediately on the offensive.

Term.Title: Commercial Law
Term.Description: All the law which applies to the rights, relations and conduct of persons and businesses engaged in commerce, merchandising, trade and sales.

Term.Title: Comminuted Fracture
Term.Description: A fracture of a bone in which the separated parts are splintered or fragmented.

Term.Title: Commissaire
Term.Description: A race judge, in road-racing they are usually based in a car following the event.

Term.Title: Commission
Term.Description: A fee paid based on a percentage of the sale made by an employee or agent, as distinguished from regular payments of wages or salary; a group appointed pursuant to law to conduct certain government business.

Term.Title: Commitment
Term.Description: An agreement to perform a particular activity at a certain time in the future under certain circumstances.

Term.Title: Committee of Australian Sport and Recreation Officials
Term.Description: The Committee of Australian Sport and Recreation Officials (CASRO), is made up of the CEOs or equivalent of each state and territory department of sport and recreation, as well as the ASC and Federal Government Office for Sport. It has carriage of the implementation and monitoring of the National Sport and Active Recreation Policy Framework.

Term.Title: Common Law
Term.Description: Case law developed in common courts. This term is sometimes used to describe all case law or judge-made law.

Term.Title: Common Wrist Extensor
Term.Description: Extend and either adduct or abduct hand at wrist (extensor carpi) muscles.

Term.Title: Common Wrist Flexor
Term.Description: Flexes and either abduct or adduct hand at wrist (flexor carpi) muscles.

Term.Title: Commonwealth Amateur Boxing Championships
Term.Description: http://www.boxing.org.au/

Term.Title: Commonwealth Authorities and Corporations (CAC) Act 1997
Term.Description: The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act outline the principles of conduct and general duties, such as Good faith, use of position and use of information. An officer or employee of an authority who misapplies, improperly disposes of, or improperly uses Commonwealth information may be in breach of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act (s. 26)

Term.Title: Commonwealth Bank International One Day Cricket Series
Term.Description: http://cricket.com.au/commonwealthbankseries2010-11

Term.Title: Commonwealth Games
Term.Description: The Commonwealth Games is a multi-sport event involving elite athletes from member nations within the Commonwealth. The first Games were held in Hamilton, Canada in 1930. The Games have been held every four years (except for the years between 1938 and 1950). The Games were originally known as the British Empire Games in 1930. The name changed to British Empire and Commonwealth Games in 1954, and to the British Commonwealth Games in 1970. The Games assumed the current name of the Commonwealth Games in 1978. http://www.commonwealthgames.org.au/

Term.Title: Commonwealth Games Federation
Term.Description: http://www.thecgf.com/

Term.Title: Commonwealth Games Federation
Term.Description: The Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) is the organisation that is responsible for the direction and control of the Commonwealth Games and Commonwealth Youth Games.

Term.Title: Commonwealth Golf Club
Term.Description: Oakleigh South VIC 3167

Term.Title: Commonwealth Golf Trophy
Term.Description: http://www.commonwealthgolf.com.au

Term.Title: Commonwealth Powerlifting Championships
Term.Description: http://commonwealthpf.homestead.com/

Term.Title: Commonwealth Regatta
Term.Description: Held every four years and coincides with the Commonwealth Games.

Term.Title: Commonwealth Rowing Regatta
Term.Description: http://www.rowingaustralia.com.au/

Term.Title: Commonwealth Table Tennis Championships
Term.Description: http://www.tabletennis.org.au/

Term.Title: Commonwealth Weightlifting Championships
Term.Description: http://www.commonwealthweightlifting.com/

Term.Title: Commonwealth Youth Games
Term.Description: The Commonwealth Youth Games is a multi sport event for athletes of an age minimum of 14 and maximum of 18 in the year of competition from nations within the Commonwealth Games Association. The first Commonwealth Youth Games was held in Edinburgh, Scotland in August 2000. In 2011, the Games dates were re-organised so that it no longer occurs in Olympic years, and a further subsequent re-adjustment has Games held in 2015 and 2017 and every four years hence.

Term.Title: Communications
Term.Description: The imparting or interchange of thoughts, opinions, or information by speech, writing, or signs.

Term.Title: Community
Term.Description: A social group of any size whose members reside in a specific locality, share government, and often have a common cultural and historical heritage.

Term.Title: Community Coach
Term.Description: An AASC community coach delivers structured physical activity sessions to primary school-aged children in the after-school timeslot during the school term.

Term.Title: Community Coach Training Program
Term.Description: An Australian Sports Commission developed Community Coach Training Program (CCTP) for community coaches of the AASC program.

Term.Title: Comoros
Term.Description: Country code = KM

Term.Title: Company
Term.Description: A business owned by a group of people called shareholders, which has its own legal identity separate from its owners.

Term.Title: Company Title
Term.Description: An arrangement where a company owns a block of houses, land or other property where individuals own shares n that property.

Term.Title: Compassionate Leave
Term.Description: Compassionate leave is paid leave for the purposes of spending time with a person who is a member of the employees immediate family or household and has a personal illness, or injury, that poses a serious threat to his or her life, or after the death of a member of the employees immediate family or a member of the employees household.

Term.Title: Compensation
Term.Description: Payment for work performed, by salary, wages, commission or otherwise; the amount received to make one whole after an injury or loss, particularly that paid by an insurance company either of the party causing the damage or by one's own insurer.

Term.Title: Compensation Aids (Equestrian) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Riders have an IPEC/FEI ID card, which state their grade and the compensating aids that they may use, such as a whip instead of a leg, ladder reins, elastic bands, special stirrups, etc. A small amount of velcro may be used. Any compensating aid used must allow the rider to fall free of the horse if necessary.

Term.Title: Compensatory Damages
Term.Description: Damages recovered in payment for actual injury or economic loss, which does not include punitive damages.

Term.Title: Competent
Term.Description: Able to act in the circumstances, including the ability to perform a job or occupation, or to reason or make decisions.

Term.Title: Competition Leave
Term.Description: National Teams. The Chief Executive Officer may grant leave with pay plus reasonable travelling time to an employee who is required to attend an approved event relevant to the ASC.

Term.Title: Competition Measure
Term.Description: A measuring device that is used to determine which stone is closer to the tee when the two stones are each very close.

Term.Title: Competition Sparring
Term.Description: Training where the athlete boxes like they are in a competition but the event is not officially recorded. There may or may not be referee/judges in attendance

Term.Title: Competitions
Term.Description: A contest for some prize, honour, or advantage.

Term.Title: Competitor
Term.Description: An athlete or team competing in a sporting event.

Term.Title: Compile
Term.Description: To translate a computer program from a high-level language into another language, usually machine language, using a compiler.

Term.Title: Complainant
Term.Description: A person or entity who begins a lawsuit by filing a complaint and is usually called the plaintiff, or in some cases the petitioner.

Term.Title: Complaint
Term.Description: The first document filed with the court by a person or entity claiming legal rights against another.

Term.Title: Complaint Management
Term.Description: Procedures and proceesses in place for managing and dealing with complaints and grievances about discrimination, harassment, child protection issues and other breaches of their sport's policies, rules and Code of Behaviour. These processes must be fair and transparent and apply to all roles and across all levels of the sport.

Term.Title: Complete Fracture
Term.Description: A bone fracture in which the bone is split completely across.

Term.Title: Completed Pass
Term.Description: A pass that has been caught. Usually between the quarterback and receiver and usually just called a completion.

Term.Title: Compliance
Term.Description: Steps taken to ensure that your business is operating in accordance with all applicable legislation, regulations, standards, codes of practice and contractual requirements. Compliance can also include conformity to internal policies and procedures. (http://www.smallbiz.nsw.gov.au)

Term.Title: Composite Bow
Term.Description: A bow that is constructed using different types of materials, which could include, fiberglass, plastic and metal alloys.

Term.Title: Composition Mark
Term.Description: These are the first two sets of scores or marks that are awarded in original dance. The judges take into consideration the skaters use of the ice surface, how difficult the routine was, originality, and the confidence of the skater and how well they performed the routine.

Term.Title: Compound Attack
Term.Description: A way of attacking that uses two different movements with the use of feints.

Term.Title: Compound Bow
Term.Description: This type of bow uses cams or pulleys that are on the tips of the limps along with cables when combined makes the holding weight much less then the draw weight. Which means that the arrow is fired with more power then the archer needs to hold and pull.

Term.Title: Compound Fracture
Term.Description: A fracture in which the broken bone is exposed through a wound in the skin.

Term.Title: Compound Interest
Term.Description: Payment of interest upon principal and previously accumulated interest, which increases the amount paid for money use above simple interest.

Term.Title: Compound Riposte
Term.Description: This is a riposte that uses, at the minimum, one feint.

Term.Title: Compulsive Gambling
Term.Description: An obsessive need to play at any game of chance for money or other stakes.

Term.Title: Compulsory Figures
Term.Description: These include edges, steps and turns that are performed at specific points on the skating surface.

Term.Title: Computer Case
Term.Description: The enclosure that contains most of the components of a computer.

Term.Title: Computer Hardware
Term.Description: The mechanical, magnetic, electronic and electrical components making up a computer system.

Term.Title: Computer Keyboard
Term.Description: A keyboard is a typewriter keyboard, which uses an arrangement of buttons or keys, to act as mechanical levers or electronic switches.

Term.Title: Computer Mouse
Term.Description: A mouse is a pointing device that functions by detecting two-dimensional motion relative to its supporting surface.

Term.Title: Computer Software
Term.Description: General term for various kinds ofprograms that are used to operate computers and related devices.

Term.Title: Computer Speakers
Term.Description: Speakers external to a computer, that disable the lower fidelity built-in speaker.

Term.Title: Computers
Term.Description: A programmable machine that receives input, stores and manipulates data and provides output in a useful format.

Term.Title: Concentric muscle action
Term.Description: Muscle shortening under tension with the external resistance forces acting in the opposite direction from the motion.

Term.Title: Concept 2
Term.Description: http://www.concept2.com.au/

Term.Title: Concept II Rowing Ergometer
Term.Description: http://www.concept2.com.au/

Term.Title: Conciliation
Term.Description: Resolving of a dispute by way of negotiation without the need of a final order by a court.

Term.Title: Condition
Term.Description: A term or requirement stated in a contract, which must be met for the other party to have the duty to fulfill his / her obligations.

Term.Title: Conditional Sale
Term.Description: A sale of property or goods which will be completed if certain conditions are met (as agreed) by one or both parties to the transaction.

Term.Title: Conditioning
Term.Description: The process of training or changing behaviour by association and reinforcement.

Term.Title: Conditions
Term.Description: The environmental factors within which an athletic performance is completed. Conditions can be affected or determined by factors including geo-political location, altitude, weather (wind, temperature, humidity), air quality and sporting surface or facility.

Term.Title: Condonation
Term.Description: To forgive or pardon an offence or a civil wrong by way of acting as if it had never taken place.

Term.Title: Conduct
Term.Description: Values and standards of behaviour or actions required of employees in their employment

Term.Title: Conference
Term.Description: A meeting for consultation or discussion.

Term.Title: Confiscate
Term.Description: To take one's goods or property without legal right, although there may appear to be some lawful basis.

Term.Title: Conflict
Term.Description: Discord of action, feeling, or effect; antagonism or opposition, as of interests or principles; incompatibility or interference, as of one idea, desire, event, or activity with another.

Term.Title: Conflict of Interest
Term.Description: A situation in which a person has a duty to more than one person or organization, but cannot do justice to the actual or potentially adverse interests of both parties.

Term.Title: Conformity
Term.Description: Action in accord with prevailing social standards, attitudes, practices, etc.

Term.Title: Congestive Heart Failure
Term.Description: Heart failure in which the heart is unable to maintain adequate circulation of blood in the tissues of the body or to pump out the venous blood returned to it by the venous circulation.

Term.Title: Congo
Term.Description: Country code = CG

Term.Title: Congress
Term.Description: A formal meeting or assembly of representatives for the discussion, arrangement, or promotion of some matter of common interest.

Term.Title: Conjunctivitis
Term.Description: inflammation of the conjunctiva - the mucous membrane that lines the exposed portion of the eyeball and inner surface of the eyelids.

Term.Title: Consanguinity
Term.Description: Kinship or blood relationship. Connection between persons with the same ancestor.

Term.Title: Consequential Damages
Term.Description: Damage, injury or losses which are not caused directly by an act but as a result of that act.

Term.Title: Consideration
Term.Description: A recompense or payment.

Term.Title: Consignment
Term.Description: Sending of goods to another party to be sold by them.

Term.Title: Consortium
Term.Description: A group of separate businesses or business people joining together and cooperating to complete a project, work together to perform a contract or conduct an on-going business.

Term.Title: Constitution
Term.Description: Regulations governing the relationships between the shareholders and directors of the company.

Term.Title: Constitutional Law
Term.Description: All rules of law which directly or indirectly effect the distribution of the sovereign power, that is law relating to the legislature or the judiciary.

Term.Title: Consultant (Finance)
Term.Description: A person who gives professional or expert advice.

Term.Title: Consumables
Term.Description: Items that may be depleted or worn out by use.

Term.Title: Consumer Protection Laws
Term.Description: Laws to protect the consumer from inferior, adulterated, hazardous or deceptively advertised products, and deceptive or fraudulent sales practices.

Term.Title: Contact
Term.Description: The establishment of communication (with). Someone with whom one is in communication.

Term.Title: Contact (Wrestling)
Term.Description: When the referee commands a wrestler to put both of his hands on the back of his opponent, who is knelling with his hands and knees touching the ground. Wrestlers in the standing position put their hands on the opponent's shoulder blades.

Term.Title: Contact Point
Term.Description: That part of the snowboard that is in contact with the snow.

Term.Title: Contact Sport
Term.Description: Any sport in which physical contact between players is an integral part of the game.

Term.Title: Contest Area
Term.Description: The 8 to 10 metre square area of the mat where the contest takes place. The entire mat is called the competition area and is 14 to 16 metres square.

Term.Title: Continental Grip
Term.Description: A way or method of holding the racquetball racquet. The hand position is between that of a forehand grip and a backhand grip.

Term.Title: Contingency
Term.Description: An event that might not occur.

Term.Title: Contingency Plan
Term.Description: A plan devised for a specific situation when things could go wrong.

Term.Title: Contingency Planning
Term.Description: The part of risk management that aims to ensure that swift and appropriate action is taken when an undesirable outcome, particularly an emergency situation, arises. It has two broad aspects: development of crisis management plans aimed at maximising safety for people and minimising damage and disruption during a crisis and, development of business resumption plans or continuity plans aimed at ensuring business functions are recovered as quickly as possible after a crisis. (http://www.smallbiz.nsw.gov.au)

Term.Title: Contingent
Term.Description: Dependent upon something.

Term.Title: Continuance
Term.Description: A postponement of a date.

Term.Title: Continuation Bisque
Term.Description: In handicap play a shot taken as an additional shot from where the striker ball stopped.

Term.Title: Continuous Spin
Term.Description: A descending spin with a rotation of at least 720 degrees. The spin is done quickly.

Term.Title: Contour
Term.Description: A solid brown line on a topographical map connecting points of equal elevation. Index contours (usually every fifth contour) are shown with a darker line.

Term.Title: Orienteering Land Forms and Map Symbols
Contra Proferentum
Term.Description: Against the person who alleges it.

Term.Title: Contract
Term.Description: An agreement between two or more parties for the delivery of a product, provision of a service, or management of a resource.

Term.Title: Contractor (Finance)
Term.Description: A person who contracts to perform work at a certain price or rate.

Term.Title: Contributed Equity
Term.Description: Amount invested in property.

Term.Title: Control
Term.Description: A checkpoint on an orienteering course that a competitor must visit to complete the course.

Term.Title: Control and Stability
Term.Description: The ability to control and stabilise the muscles and joints during movement, and limit unwarranted movement

Term.Title: Control Card
Term.Description: Also known as a Punch Card, a paper card carried by the competition to mark at each checkpoint / control if manual punching is used.

Term.Title: Control Circle
Term.Description: A circle drawn around a feature on the map to indicate the location of a control marker. The feature should be in the exact centre of the circle.

Term.Title: Control Code
Term.Description: Numbers on a control marker that enable participants to verify that it is the correct one.

Term.Title: Control Descriptions
Term.Description: A list given to each participant that briefly describes each control features in order. It also gives the control code.

Term.Title: Control Feature
Term.Description: A natural or man-made feature on or next to which the control is hung.

Term.Title: Control Gates
Term.Description: Gates that run down the centre of a mogul run they are 8-15 metres (26- 49 feet) wide.

Term.Title: Control Marker
Term.Description: A three-sided marker (usually orange and white) placed at features on an orienteering course. It usually has a punch or other marking device attached to mark a control card as proof that you visited the control.

Term.Title: Control Number
Term.Description: A number drawn beside each control circle on a map. On a cross-country course, they indicate the order in which the controls must be visited. The top of the number points to Magnetic North.

Term.Title: Control Player
Term.Description: A description of a player who relies on placing their shots rather than on the power of their shots.

Term.Title: Control Steel
Term.Description: This is a piece of steel that is mounted somewhere on the track that measure the control temperature of each sled.

Term.Title: Contusion
Term.Description: An injury, as from a blow with a blunt instrument, in which the subsurface tissue is injured but the skin is not broken; bruise.

Term.Title: Conversion
Term.Description: If a team scores a try, they have an opportunity to "convert" it for two further points by kicking the ball between the posts and above the crossbar - that is, through the goal. The kick is taken at any point on the field of play in line with the point that the ball was grounded for the try parallel to the touch-lines. So it is advatageous to score a try nearer to the posts as it is easier to convert it. The kick can be either a drop kick or a place kick in the 15-man game. However, in sevens, all conversions must be drop kicks.

Term.Title: Conversion (Assets)
Term.Description: Process of changing a facility from an existing use to a new use.

Term.Title: Conversion (Finance)
Term.Description: The process of converting a convertible security, such as a bond or preferred stock, into common stock.

Term.Title: Convey
Term.Description: To transfer ownership.

Term.Title: Conveyance
Term.Description: A generic term for any written document which transfers (conveys) real property or real property interests from one party to another.

Term.Title: Cook Islands
Term.Description: Country code = CK

Term.Title: Coolangatta Gold (Surf Life Saving)
Term.Description: http://www.sls.com.au/coolangattagold

Term.Title: Cooling Off Period
Term.Description: A time of inaction to reconsider.

Term.Title: Cooling System
Term.Description: Required to remove the waste heat produced by computer components, to keep components within their safe operating temperature limits.

Term.Title: Coolum Beach
Term.Description: Coolum Beach QLD 4573

Term.Title: Cooperation
Term.Description: Cooperation involves individuals or groups working together for the achievement of their individual or collective goals.

Term.Title: Coping
Term.Description: The top rim of a half-pipe wall.

Term.Title: Coppa Citta di Asti
Term.Description: http://www.cycle-racing.com/

Term.Title: Coppa Colli Briantei
Term.Description: http://www.cycle-racing.com/

Term.Title: Coppa della Pace
Term.Description: Cycling

Term.Title: Copyright
Term.Description: A type of property right which protects the expression of ideas such as literary or dramatic works, television productions, drawings and the like, from being used for commercial gain without permission of the copyright owner. Registration is not a prerequisite for protection.

Term.Title: Copyright Exceptions
Term.Description: Situations in which people can use copyright material without permission.

Term.Title: Copyright Infingement
Term.Description: Using copyright material in one of the ways exclusively reserved to the copyright owner without permission.

Term.Title: Core Stability
Term.Description: stabilisation of the trunk and pelvis necessary to perform movements of the extremities

Term.Title: CorelDRAW
Term.Description: Similar to Adobe Illustrator, it is another vector graphic manipulation tool.

Term.Title: Corio Gen Eclipse
Term.Description: A high performance scan converter with Genlock and Overlay capability.

Term.Title: Corkscrew
Term.Description: While either free-riding or in the half-pipe this is a fast and tight rotation.

Term.Title: Corner Hit
Term.Description: When the ball goes over the back line by being hit out by the defending team, the attacking team gets to take the ball out of bounds on the back line. The ball is hit back in bounds within 5 yards (4.57 metres) of the nearest corner flag where the ball was hit out of bounds. The player who hits the ball back in can't touch the ball again until another player touches the ball.

Term.Title: Corner Judges (Judo)
Term.Description: The 8 to 10 metre square area of the mat where the contest takes place. The entire mat is called the competition area and is 14 to 16 metres square.

Term.Title: Corner Kick
Term.Description: A free kick awarded to an attacking team when a defender plays the ball across the goal line (not between the goal posts).

Term.Title: Corner Kill Shot
Term.Description: A kill shot that hits first the side-wall and then the front wall.

Term.Title: Corner Throw
Term.Description: A corner throw is given to the offensive team when the last person to touch the ball before it went out of bounds was a defensive player. The offensive player who was nearest to the place where the ball went out of bounds throws the ball back into play from the sidewall at the 2 metre line.

Term.Title: Cornerback
Term.Description: Two players who primarily cover the wide receivers. Cornerbacks attempt to prevent successful quarterback passes by either swatting the airborne ball away from the receiver or by catching the pass themselves.

Term.Title: Corporate Communications
Term.Description: The communication division of a corporate organisation, body, or institute that issues communications to its staff, partners and the public.

Term.Title: Corporation
Term.Description: An organisation formed with governmental approval.

Term.Title: Corps-a-Corps
Term.Description: A move in which there is body contact, however neither fencer is able to use their weapon, they are too close to each other.

Term.Title: Corpus Delicti
Term.Description: Latin for the substantial fact that a crime has been committed.

Term.Title: Corpus Juris
Term.Description: The body of the law, meaning a compendium of all laws, cases and the varied interpretations of them.

Term.Title: Correct Hold
Term.Description: A correct throw used by a wrestler but it does not produce a takedown.

Term.Title: Corridor
Term.Description: The centre of the field, and therefore the most direct way to the goals.

Term.Title: Corticosteroid
Term.Description: Any of a class of steroids, as aldosterone, hydrocortisone, or cortisone, occurring in nature, especially as a product of the adrenal cortex, or synthesized.

Term.Title: Corticotrophin
Term.Description: A polypeptide tropic hormone produced and secreted by the anterior pituitary gland.

Term.Title: Cortisol
Term.Description: One of the corticosteriods secreted by the adrenal cortex in response to stress.

Term.Title: Cortisone
Term.Description: A steroid hormone of the adrenal cortex, C 21 H 28 O 5 , active in carbohydrate and protein metabolism.

Term.Title: Cosign
Term.Description: To sign a promissory note or other obligation in order to share liability for the obligation.

Term.Title: Cost
Term.Description: Valuation in terms of money, effort, material, resources, time and utilities consumed, risks incurred, and opportunity forgone in production and delivery of a good or service.

Term.Title: Cost Benefit Analysis
Term.Description: A method of evaluating projects or investments by comparing the present value or annual value of expected benefits to costs.

Term.Title: Cost Centre
Term.Description: Defined company department to whom direct and indirect costs are allocated.

Term.Title: Cost Centre (Assets)
Term.Description: A unit, such as a department of a company, to which costs may be allocated for cost accounting purposes.

Term.Title: Cost of injuries
Term.Description: Missed games or competition and missed training days are important as they establish the burden of the injury or illness as highlighted in first steps of the van Mechelen et al. (1992) and the Finch (2006) methods for injury prevention. The National Injury and Illness Database will collect both parameters.

Term.Title: Data dictionary for the National Injury and Illness Database
Costa Rica
Term.Description: Country code = CR

Term.Title: Costochondritis
Term.Description: Costochondritis occurs at the joints between the ribs and the sternum (breast bone). The condition is sometimes also known as Tietze's syndrome. It is an inflammatory condition, thought to be caused by overuse, resulting in repetitive micro-trauma. The two bones themselves are cushioned by cartilage inside the joint. It is this cartilage which is damaged and results in inflammation.

Term.Title: Cote d'Ivoire
Term.Description: Country code = CI

Term.Title: Cottesloe Golf Club
Term.Description: Swanbourne WA 6010

Term.Title: Couble Clutch
Term.Description: A double clutch is a move associate with a layup or a dunk, it is a change of ball position in mid-air (similar to the "up and under" move, but perform while the player is in the air). It is effectively used by many players especially those who are more athletic.

Term.Title: Coule
Term.Description: A thrust that goes straight down an opposing fencers blade.

Term.Title: Counsel
Term.Description: A barrister.

Term.Title: Count
Term.Description: The number of called balls and strikes on a hitter.

Term.Title: Count Back
Term.Description: The system used to break a tie between two or more competitors with the same total score.

Term.Title: Counter
Term.Description: Any stone that is inside or is touching the house.

Term.Title: Counter Rucking
Term.Description: If a team (usually the team that took the ball into contact) has secured the ball at a ruck, and the other team manage to force them off the ball and secure possession themselves, the defending team are said to have "counter-rucked".

Term.Title: Counter Turn
Term.Description: A one-foot turn on the same edge but results in a change of lobe with the rotation outside the original lobe.

Term.Title: Counterattack (Water Polo)
Term.Description: Transition when the defensive team regains control of the ball, advances the ball and sets up offense in front of the opponents goal.

Term.Title: Counter-Parry
Term.Description: A defensive tactic where by a fencer uses a circular motion with his weapon to move the opponent's blade thus counter his offensive move.

Term.Title: Counterpart
Term.Description: A true copy.

Term.Title: Country of birth
Term.Description: The country in which the person was born, as represented by a code.

Term.Title: Country of representation
Term.Description: The country which an athlete represents. To represent a country an athlete must be a citizen, whether by birth or naturalisation, of the country they represent, they may also have had to complete a period of time as a naturalised citizen prior to becoming eligible for international competition. Athletes, who have more than one nationality may only represent one country.

Term.Title: Country v City
Term.Description: http://www.nswrl.com.au

Term.Title: Country versus City
Term.Description: http://www.nswrl.com.au

Term.Title: Coupe
Term.Description: A movement where one fencer is able to attack by getting the tip of their sword underneath of their opponent's blade and lift while moving forward to attack.

Term.Title: Courses
Term.Description: A prescribed number of lessons, lectures, etc, in an educational curriculum and the material covered in such a curriculum.

Term.Title: Court (Boccia) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The boccia court measures 12.5 x 6m with 2m of free space around it. The surface of the court is flat and smooth. The throwing area is divided into six rectangular throwing boxes. On the court is a V-shaped line over which balls must cross for the throw to be valid. A cross marks the position where the jack must be placed if it touches or crosses the boundary line or in the case of a tie break.

Term.Title: Court (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The court used for goalball is a rectangle 18 x 9m. Starting from the final lines, where the goalposts are placed, a 9 x 3m team area and a 9 x 3m landing area for each team is marked. The remaining 9 x 6m area, between the two landing areas, is called the neutral area, which is divided in two parts by the centre line. With the exception of the final lines, all markings are tactile to enable the players' orientation. This includes the players' position and orientation lines in each team area. Goalposts have a height and length of 1.3m and 9m respectively. The court markings are clearly visible and tactile to help players orientate themselves on court.

Term.Title: Court (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: One half of the table that is separated from the other half by the net.

Term.Title: Court (Wheelchair Basketball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The field of play intended for wheelchair basketball matches has no differences compared to that of Olympic basketball. It is a rectangular hard surface 28 metres long and 15 metres wide. For official national and international matches, a wooden floor is required.

Term.Title: Court (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Wheelchair rugby is played indoors on a regulation-sized basketball court. The basketball key area is replaced by a wheelchair rugby key 8 metres wide and 1.75 metres deep. The part of the end line within the key is called the goal line, and it is marked with one pylon at each end.

Term.Title: Court (Wheelchair Tennis) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The court is a 23.77m x 8.23m rectangle for singles and a 23.77m x 10.97m rectangle for doubles. The same court can be marked for both singles and doubles. The court is divided into two halves by a net, which extends at a height of 0.914m at its centre and 1.07m at its sides. There are four types of courts clay, grass, hard and carpet.

Term.Title: Court Linkage
Term.Description: Linking of players with passes to exploit space of court with passes.

Term.Title: Court of Appeals
Term.Description: Any court (state or federal) which hears appeals from judgments and rulings of trial courts or lower appeals courts.

Term.Title: Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS)
Term.Description: The CAS (Tribunal Arbitral du Sport or TAS) is an international arbitration body set up to settle disputes related to sport.

Term.Title: International Council of Arbitration for Sport (ICAS)
Court of Arbitration for Sport (Oceania Registry)
Term.Description: The CAS (Tribunal Arbitral du Sport or TAS) is an international arbitration body set up to settle disputes related to sport.

Term.Title: International Council of Arbitration for Sport (ICAS)
Covenant
Term.Description: A promise in a written contract or a deed of real property.

Term.Title: Cover (Hockey)
Term.Description: A tactic used by defenders to protect their goal by staying within a close distance of an opposing attacker.

Term.Title: Cover (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: When a defensive player guards an offensive player very closely, so closely that the offensive player is not able to take part in the play of the game. However, if this guarding is done too aggressively it can result in an interference penalty.

Term.Title: Cover (Rowing)
Term.Description: The distance between one set of puddles and the next set of puddles.

Term.Title: Cover Defence
Term.Description: The attempt to tackle an attacker who has breached the main line of defenders.

Term.Title: Cover Point
Term.Description: The cover area runs from point all the way round to mid-off.

Term.Title: Cox Box
Term.Description: Portable voice amplifier; may also optionally incorporate digital readouts displaying stroke rate, boat speed and times.

Term.Title: Coxmate
Term.Description: A portable amplification device, similar to a coxbox, incorporating a digital readout. Higher models may also have a built in radio and speed sensor.

Term.Title: Coxswain
Term.Description: The oar-less crew-member, usually included, who is responsible for steering and race strategy. The coxswain either sits in the stern or lies in the bow of the boat.

Term.Title: Crab (Rowing)
Term.Description: A rowing error where the rower is unable to timely remove or release the oar blade from the water and the oar blade acts as a brake on the boat until it is removed from the water. This results in slowing the boat down.

Term.Title: Crab Defence
Term.Description: When a player is serving the opposing three passers shuffle side to side and pinch their hands like crabs to distract the server.

Term.Title: Crabs
Term.Description: Sitting Volleyball Men's National Team

Term.Title: Crack
Term.Description: When a cyclist runs out of strength or energy, they are said to have cracked.

Term.Title: Crack Ball
Term.Description: A shot that strikes the intersection of the side or rear wall and the floor. The ball will most likely not be able to be returned.

Term.Title: Cradle
Term.Description: A move whereby one wrestler places one arm around their opponent's neck, and then the other around the back or underside of their opponent's knee. The wrestlet then attempts to lock their hands together to force the opponents knee toward their face.

Term.Title: Cradling
Term.Description: When a player is trying to keep control of the ball when running up the field, they will cradle the ball in the stick pocket.

Term.Title: Cramps
Term.Description: A sudden, involuntary, spasmodic contraction of a muscle or group of muscles, especially of the extremities, sometimes with severe pain.

Term.Title: Crank Shot
Term.Description: When taking a shot on goal a player will take a back-swing with their stick and shoot the ball underhand or sidearm at the goal.

Term.Title: Crash Back
Term.Description: All six defensive field players swim back rapidly to the center of their end as soon as the other team recovers possession, to counter the offensive counterattack.

Term.Title: Crash Ball
Term.Description: It is an attacking tactic where a player receives a pass at pace and runs directly at the opposition's defensive line. The crash ball runner attempts to commit two or more opposing players to the tackle, then attempts to make the ball available to team-mates by off-loading in the tackle or recycling the ball quickly from the ruck.

Term.Title: Crater
Term.Description: When a snowboarder crashes or falls.

Term.Title: Crawl
Term.Description: The arms, alternating, move through the water pulling the swimmer forward. The arms go over the swimmers head and then back to their side and then are brought back over the head. The legs kick in a flutter kick, meaning they do not have to move together but also alternate, one moving up while the other moves down.

Term.Title: Crease
Term.Description: The crease is the area demarcated by white lines painted or chalked on the field of play. The term crease is also used to refer to the lines themselves (but only the back edge of the line, i.e. the edge nearest to the wicket at that end, as this is the actual crease), particularly the popping crease. Law 9 of the Laws of Cricket governs the size and position of the crease markings. Four creases (one popping crease, one bowling crease, and two return creases) are drawn at each end of the pitch, around the two sets of stumps. The batsmen generally play in and run between the areas defined by the creases at each end of the pitch.

Term.Title: Crease Lines
Term.Description: The red lines that form the semi-circular area with a 6-foot radius in front of the goal called the goal crease

Term.Title: Create a Leave
Term.Description: The process of placing balls during a turn so as to leave the partner ball a good playing opportunity and the opponent a bad one.

Term.Title: Creatine
Term.Description: An amino acid, C 4 H 9 N 3 O 2 , that is a constituent of the muscles of vertebrates and is phosphorylated to store energy used for muscular contraction.

Term.Title: Creatine Kinase
Term.Description: An isoenzyme (an enzyme that appears in multiple forms) found in high concentrations in heart and skeletal muscles, and, in smaller amounts, in brain tissue.

Term.Title: Creatine Phosphokinase
Term.Description: A muscle enzyme often measured s an indicator of cell damage.

Term.Title: Creatinine
Term.Description: A crystalline end product of creatine metabolism, C 4 H 7 N 3 O, occurring in urine, muscle, and blood.

Term.Title: Creative Disposal
Term.Description: An awkward handpass which is technically illegal, but never penalised.

Term.Title: Credit
Term.Description: A credit is an accounting entry that either increases a liability or equity account, or decreases an asset or expense account. It is positioned to the right in an accounting entry.

Term.Title: Creditor
Term.Description: A creditor is an individual or entity that extends credit to others, and which is owed money by them.

Term.Title: Crest
Term.Description: These are colored marks that are in front of the index feathers on an arrow used to identify the arrow.

Term.Title: Cricket Australia
Term.Description: http://cricket.com.au/

Term.Title: Cricket Australia Cup
Term.Description: Cricket Australia Cup

Term.Title: Cricket Emerging Players Tournament
Term.Description: http://cricket.com.au/

Term.Title: Cricket pitch
Term.Description: A cricket pitch is the central strip of the cricket field between the wickets. The pitch is 1 chain or 22 yards (20.12 m) long and 10 feet (3 m) wide. The surface is very flat and normally covered with extremely short grass though this grass is soon removed by wear at the ends of the pitch.

Term.Title: Cricket World Cup
Term.Description: http://cricket.com.au/

Term.Title: Crimes Act 1914
Term.Description: The Crimes Act outlines crimes against the Commonwealth. Several parts of the Act relate to records. For example, section 70 prohibits public servants (or anyone working for the Australian Government including contractors and consultants) publishing or communicating facts, documents, or information which they gain access to through their work, unless they have permission to do so. This includes taking or selling records which should be destroyed. This Act also makes it an offence for someone to intentionally destroy documents that they know may be required as evidence in a judicial proceeding.

Term.Title: Crimp
Term.Description: The inward folding of a cartridge case used to retain the projectile.

Term.Title: Cringle
Term.Description: A rope loop, usually at the corners of a sail, for fixing the sail to a spar.

Term.Title: Crippler
Term.Description: A half-pipe inverted aerial. The snowboarder will do a 180-degree flip and then go into a forward half-pipe, grabbing air and rotating 90 degrees then flipping over in the air, then rotating another 90 degrees and then lands riding forward.

Term.Title: Criterium Cycling Race
Term.Description: A bike race held on a short course (usually less than 5 km), often run on closed-off city centre streets.

Term.Title: Criterium International
Term.Description: http://www.letour.fr/

Term.Title: Critical Analysis
Term.Description: An appraisal based on careful analytical evaluation.

Term.Title: Critical Scoring Area
Term.Description: CSA. This is the part of the field where the attacking team is shooting for the goal. The CSA is approximately 15 metres in front of the goal circle to 9 metres behind the goal circle. It also measures 15 metres out to each side of the goal circle.

Term.Title: Croatia
Term.Description: Country code = HR

Term.Title: Crocs Tour Australia (Beach Volleyball)
Term.Description: http://www.beachvolleyballtour.com.au/

Term.Title: Crohn's Disease
Term.Description: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that causes scarring and thickening of the intestinal walls and frequently leads to obstruction.

Term.Title: Cronulla Sharks
Term.Description: National Rugby League Club Team

Term.Title: Crooked Cop
Term.Description: A free-riding version of the mosquito air trick.

Term.Title: Croquet Australia
Term.Description: http://www.croquet-australia.com.au/

Term.Title: Croquet Player
Term.Description: An athlete who competes in Croquet games.

Term.Title: Croquet Shot
Term.Description: The first of two shots earned by the striker for making a roquet.

Term.Title: Croquet World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.wcfcroquet.org/

Term.Title: Croquet World Series
Term.Description: http://www.wcfcroquet.org/

Term.Title: Cross (Football)
Term.Description: The delivery of the ball into the penalty area by the attacking team, usually from the area between the penalty box and the touchline.

Term.Title: Cross Bar
Term.Description: The horizontal bar that connects the top of the two goalposts.

Term.Title: Cross Checking
Term.Description: A check using both hands on the stick, and extending the arms, while the check is being delivered. A minor or major penalty, at the discretion of the Referee, shall be imposed on a player who crosschecks an opponent. If a major penalty is assessed for crosschecking, an automatic game misconduct penalty will be imposed and it will cost the player a one hundred dollar automatic fine.

Term.Title: Cross Country Eliminator - XCE (Men)
Term.Description: Mountain bike competition race

Term.Title: Cross Country Eliminator - XCE (Women)
Term.Description: Mountain bike competition race

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Cross Country Skiing appeared for the first time at the 1976 Winter Games in Ornskeldsvik, Sweden. The competition is open to athletes with a physical disability and blindness / visual impairment. Depending on functional disability, a competitor with little or no leg functionality uses a sit-ski, a chair equipped with a pair of skis. Athletes with blindness visual impairment compete in the event with a sighted guide. Male and female athletes compete in short distance, middle distance and long distance (ranging from 2.5km to 20km) or participate in a team relay using classical or free techniques.

Term.Title: Cross Country Turn
Term.Description: A skier will push out on their outer ski and transfer their weight to the inner ski.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Cross Court Drive Return
Term.Description: A hard hit service return that will hit the front wall and then go pass the server on the opposite side from where the server hit the shot.

Term.Title: Cross Court Pass
Term.Description: An offensive shot that is hit diagonally so the ball goes from one side of the court to the other side.

Term.Title: Cross Court Shot
Term.Description: An individual attack directed at an angle from one end of the offensive team's side of the net to the opposite sideline of the defensive team's court.

Term.Title: Cross Stroke
Term.Description: In ice dancing, a step that is begun with the feet crossed, the legs crossing above the knee, so the motion is begun by the outside edge of the free foot.

Term.Title: Cross Wire
Term.Description: Positioning the opponents balls on opposite sides of a wicket or the stake, thus preventing them from hitting each other.

Term.Title: Crossbar
Term.Description: The bar that a high jumper or pole vaulter must clear.

Term.Title: Crossbone Method
Term.Description: The snowboarder uses their front hand to grab the snowboards heel edge, their legs are boned, and then the board is pulled to level of the snowboarders head.

Term.Title: Cross-buttock
Term.Description: When a wrestler is able to execute a standing throw where their opponent is thrown over their hips or across their back.

Term.Title: Crosse (Stick)
Term.Description: The long stick that players use to throw, catch and carry the ball. In Women's Lacrosse the Crosse can be anywhere from 91-112 centimetres long and the width of the head can be 18-23 centimetres wide. In Men's Lacrosse the Crosse can be anywhere from 101-183 centimetres long and the width of the head can be 18-23 centimetres wide. However, a goalkeeper's stick can be up to 38 centimetres wide. Crosse can be made out of wood, plastic or fiberglass with the head being made out of leather or nylon.

Term.Title: Crosse Checking
Term.Description: When one player uses their Crosse to try and take the ball out of an opposing player's Crosse.

Term.Title: Crossing Straight
Term.Description: On a long track skating oval one of the straightaways has a place where skaters can change lanes and this is called the crossing straight.

Term.Title: Crossover (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: This is a skating technique where the skater pushes one leg behind the other so that they are able to take turns swiftly and also to be able to gather speed while turning. It also helps the skater to counter centrifugal force.

Term.Title: Crossover Dribble
Term.Description: The ballhandler changes the ball from one hand to the other via a dribble.

Term.Title: Crossover Kick
Term.Description: This is when on leg kicks over or across the other leg.

Term.Title: Crossover Turns
Term.Description: When a skier lifts one ski over the other.

Term.Title: Crossovers
Term.Description: Crossing one foot over the other as a way of gaining speed and turning corners.

Term.Title: Cross-Tracking
Term.Description: When a skater incorrectly crosses the track.

Term.Title: Crosstrees
Term.Description: Two horizontal struts at the upper ends of the topmasts of sailboats, used to anchor the shrouds from the topgallant mast.

Term.Title: Crotch Ball
Term.Description: A ball that hits the place where two playing surfaces meet, such as the corner where two walls come together or where the ceiling and wall meet.

Term.Title: Crotch Lift
Term.Description: When a wrestler puts their arms around the opponents upper thigh and lifts.

Term.Title: Crouch
Term.Description: A two-foot skating move in which the skater's legs are both bent at least 90-degree's.

Term.Title: Crouch Start
Term.Description: A common starting position used by sprinters in the absence of blocks. The crouch start utilizes four points of body-ground contact and positions for both the 'On your marks' and 'Set' commands.

Term.Title: Crow Hop
Term.Description: A technique used in fast-pitch softball where a pitcher will step off or hop off the front of the pitchers plate, then will replant their pivot foot and then throw the ball.

Term.Title: Crowder
Term.Description: A type of player who will get too close to his opponent to try and restrict the other players stroke and follow through. This is against the rules.

Term.Title: Crowdsourcing
Term.Description: Crowdsourcing is the practice of obtaining needed services, ideas, or content by soliciting contributions from a large group of people, and especially from an online community, rather than from traditional employees or suppliers.

Term.Title: Crown Prosecutor
Term.Description: Legal representative of the Crown who institutes criminal proceedings against the accused.

Term.Title: Crud
Term.Description: A negative term used to describe heavy, thick snow that is uneven in consistency and depth which makes for difficult maneuvering.

Term.Title: Cruiser Run
Term.Description: An easy or a fast run on a smooth slope.

Term.Title: Crumber
Term.Description: Small player or rover best at picking the ball up off the ground after a contest.

Term.Title: Crumble
Term.Description: Refers to the state of the pitch, usually late in a game after experiencing considerable wear. A crumbling pitch is often favoured by a spin bowler, as it will allow the ball more bite and turn.

Term.Title: Crush Shot
Term.Description: A fault committed when, during the striking period, the strikers mallet is in contact with the striker ball at the same time the ball is in contact with a wicket or the stake and the striker is not swinging the mallet in a direction away from the wicket or stake.

Term.Title: Crust
Term.Description: A hard layer of snow that is on top of soft snow.

Term.Title: CUA Stadium
Term.Description: Penrith NSW 2750

Term.Title: Cuba
Term.Description: Country code = CU

Term.Title: Cufin
Term.Description: The runners on the bottom of the sled. They are made of fiberglass and this is what the steel runners attach to.

Term.Title: Culture
Term.Description: The behaviors and beliefs characteristic of a particular group: the sport culture.

Term.Title: Cup (Golf)
Term.Description: The hole that is in the green, which holds the flag and flagstick, where the player is attempting to put the ball in the fewest possible strokes.

Term.Title: Curacao
Term.Description: Country code = CW

Term.Title: Curl
Term.Description: The curving motion that a stone follows as it moves down the ice.

Term.Title: Curl (Football)
Term.Description: A skill attribute in which players strike the ball in a manner that applies spin, resulting in the flight of the ball curving, or bending, in mid-air. Players who are especially adept at achieving this will often be their team's designated free kick taker, as they are able to bend the ball around walls while taking shots at goal. The phrase "bend it like Beckham" stems from English player David Beckham's ability in this regard.

Term.Title: Curling
Term.Description: Curling is a sport played between two teams of four players. The teams take turns sliding stones down a rectangular area of ice (known as the curling sheet) towards a marked target area.

Term.Title: Curling Player
Term.Description: An athlete who competes in Curling.

Term.Title: Curling Rock
Term.Description: The device thrown by curlers during the game. It is made of granite and has a standard weight of 19.6 kg (44 lb).

Term.Title: Curling Sheet
Term.Description: The area of ice measuring 146 to 150 feet (45 to 46 m) in length by 14.5 to 16.5 feet (4.4 to 5.0 m) in width on which curling is played.

Term.Title: Curling World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.worldcurling.org/

Term.Title: Currency
Term.Description: Something that is used as a medium of exchange - money.

Term.Title: Current Assets
Term.Description: Assets that are readily convertible into cash without loss in value.

Term.Title: Current Liabilities
Term.Description: Indebtedness maturing within one year.

Term.Title: Curtin University Boat Club
Term.Description: http://www.rowingwa.asn.au

Term.Title: Curve Ball
Term.Description: Pitch that moves down, across, or down and across, depending upon the rotation of the ball.

Term.Title: Custody
Term.Description: Holding property under one's control.

Term.Title: Custom
Term.Description: A group pattern of habitual activity usually transmitted from one generation to another.

Term.Title: Customary Law
Term.Description: The way people live and their rules including ceremonies, songs, stories; a way of life governed by a system of beliefs.

Term.Title: Customer
Term.Description: A customer is an entity that buys goods or services from other third parties.

Term.Title: Customer Profile
Term.Description: Information accumulated about customers which may include details about management structures and decision making.

Term.Title: Cut
Term.Description: Hitting the ball so that it moves outside of your stance. Also when a players score is not good enough to move on to the next round of competition he is said to have cut. Players either make the cut or don't make the cut.

Term.Title: Cut Off Shot
Term.Description: A shot that is hit before it bounces. It is also called a fly shot or a volley.

Term.Title: Cut Out Pass
Term.Description: Sometimes referred to as a cut out ball, the ball is passed by an attacking player across the front of one of their team mates and caught by a team mate positioned further away. This pass may be used to move the ball more speedily away from defenders who are closing in and likely to be focussing on the player who is "cut out".

Term.Title: Cut Rush
Term.Description: When a striker roquets a ball off-center to make it, the rushed ball, travel at a desired angle to a pre-selected position.

Term.Title: Cutthroat
Term.Description: A game where three players play against each other.

Term.Title: Cutting
Term.Description: When an attacking player who does not have the ball "cuts" around a defender in order to get pass from one of their teammates to take a shot on goal.

Term.Title: Cycle (C Classes) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: There are 5 sub classes in this category. Riders are assigned a class according to their level of ability. Riders in class 1 have less ability than riders in classes 2-5 with class 5 being the most able class.

Term.Title: Cycles (Paralympic Sport)

Term.Title: Cycling (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Paralympic Cycling is divided into track and road events. Athletes with cerebral palsy ride standard racing bikes competing in track and road - and, in some classes, tricycles competing only in road events. Visually impaired athletes compete on tandem bicycles with a sighted team mate (pilot), and they participate in the track and road events. Amputees and cyclists with permanent locomotor deficiencies compete in track and road events using bicycles specially modified for their requirements.

Term.Title: dAIS grant
Term.Description: The dAIS scheme provides an opportunity for athletes in Olympic, Paralympic and Commonwealth Games sports to receive a direct cash grant from the Australian Government. Athletes may be nominated by their National Sporting Organisation (NSO) to receive a dAIS grant if they: achieved a podium result at a recent world championship level event and are expected to maintain that level of performance; or demonstrate potential to achieve a podium result at a future world championship level event, and meet certain other eligibility criteria as set out in the dAIS guidelines. The dAIS scheme supersedes the previous Direct Athlete Support scheme and is administered by the AIS.

Danseuse
Term.Description: Riding out of the saddle, standing up, usually in a taller gear than normal, and rocking side to side for leverage. The phrase dancing on the pedals is related.

Term.Title: DAQ Board
Term.Description: The process of sampling signals that measure real world physical conditions and converting the resulting samples into digital numeric values that can be manipulated by a computer. Data acquisition systems (abbreviated with the acronym DAS or DAQ) typically convert analog waveforms into digital values for processing.

Term.Title: Darbepoetin
