Term.Title: Dart
Term.Description: Modern darts are made up of four parts: a point, a barrel, a shaft and a flight. Darts are made from a range of materials and can of varying sizes and weights.

Term.Title: Dartboard
Term.Description: A standard competition dartboard is made from Sisal fibres and is 17 34 inches (451 mm) in diameter and is divided into 20 radial sections. There are also two narrow rings traversing the dartboard in a circular pattern. The outer ring counts the number double score and the inner ring counts the number triple score. In the centre there are two sections; an outer ring which serves as a single bulls-eye and an the inner ring which counts as a double bull and scores 50 points. Dartboards are attached to a wall for play at a height of 5'8" (1.72m) measured from the inner bullseye to the floor.

Term.Title: Darts
Term.Description: Darts is a target sport which comprises a competitor throwing a small projectile (dart) with accuracy at a designated target (dartboard).

Term.Title: Darwin Airport Resort Territory Pearls

Term.Title: Dashes
Term.Description: The term commonly used to describe races up to the 800 metre distance. For example, the 100 metre dash.

Term.Title: Data Access
Term.Description: Software and activities related to storing, retrieving, or acting on data housed in a database or other repository.

Term.Title: Data AcQuisition card
Term.Description: DAQ cards contain multiple components - multiplexers, ADCs, DAC, TTO-IOs, high speed timers and RAM.

Term.Title: Data Analysis
Term.Description: A process of inspecting, cleaning, transforming, and modeling data with the goal of highlighting useful information, suggesting conclusions, and supporting decision making.

Term.Title: Data Architecture
Term.Description: The design of data for use in defining the target state and the subsequent planning needed to achieve the target state.

Term.Title: Data Cleansing
Term.Description: The process of detecting and correcting (or removing) corrupt or inaccurate records from a record set, table, or database.

Term.Title: Data Communications
Term.Description: High speed data exchange between computers and / or other electronic devices via cable or wireless. .

Term.Title: Data Dictionary
Term.Description: Dictionary of data elements within systems and their defining characteristics, eg. size of field, length of field, character-based or non-character based.

Term.Title: Data Erasure
Term.Description: A software-based method of overwriting data that completely destroys all electronic data residing on a hard disk drive or other digital media.

Term.Title: Data Governance
Term.Description: The discipline that embodies a convergence of data quality, data management, data policies, business process management, and risk management surrounding the handling of data in an organization.

Term.Title: Data Integration
Term.Description: Involves combining data residing in different sources and providing users with a unified view of these data.

Term.Title: Data Integrity
Term.Description: Accuracy and consistency of stored data, indicated by an absence of any alteration in data between two updates of a data record.

Term.Title: Data Maintenance
Term.Description: Data maintenance is the adding, deleting, changing and updating of binary and high level files, and the real world data associated with those files.

Term.Title: Data Management
Term.Description: Administrative process by which the required data is acquired, validated, stored, protected, and processed, and by which its accessibility, reliability, and timeliness is ensured to satisfy the needs of the data users.

Term.Title: Data Mart
Term.Description: Scaled-down and simplified version of a data warehouse.

Term.Title: Data Masking
Term.Description: The process of obscuring (masking) specific data within a database table or cell to ensure that data security is maintained and sensitive information is not exposed to unauthorized personnel.

Term.Title: Data Modelling
Term.Description: Defining a data set in terms of the attributes of and relationships among data items.

Term.Title: Data Privacy
Term.Description: The relationship between collection and dissemination of data, technology, the public expectation of privacy, and the legal and political issues surrounding them.

Term.Title: Data Processing
Term.Description: Manipulation of data by a computer. It includes the conversion of raw data to machine-readable form, flow of data through the CPU and memory to output devices, and formatting or transformation of output.

Term.Title: Data Quality Assurance
Term.Description: The process of profiling the data to discover inconsistencies, and other anomalies in the data and performing data cleansing activities to improve the data quality .

Term.Title: Data Security
Term.Description: The means of ensuring that data is kept safe from corruption and that access to it is suitably controlled.

Term.Title: Data Steward
Term.Description: A data steward is a person that is responsible for maintaining a data element in a metadata registry.

Term.Title: Data Warehouse
Term.Description: Any system for storing, retrieving and managing large amounts of data. Data warehouse software often includes sophisticated compression and hashing techniques for fast searches, as well as advanced filtering. A data warehouse is often a relational database containing a recent snapshot of corporate data and optimised for searching. Planners and researchers can use this database without worrying about slowing down day-to-day operations of the production database. The latter can be optimised for transaction processing (inserts and updates).

Term.Title: Database
Term.Description: Integrated data files organized and stored electronically in a uniform file structure that allows data elements to be manipulated, correlated, or extracted to satisfy diverse analytical and reporting needs.

Term.Title: Database Management System
Term.Description: DBMS; System for quick search and retrieval of information from a database.

Term.Title: Dataset
Term.Description: Structured information encoded in lists, tables, databases, etc, which will normally be in a format available for direct machine processing (eg spreadsheets, databases, GIS data, MIDI data), data may be numeric, spatial, spectral, statistical or structured text (including bibliographic data and database reports)

Term.Title: Date of acquisition
Term.Description: The date that depreciation of the asset begins.

Term.Title: Date of birth
Term.Description: The date of birth of a person, expressed as DDMMYYYY

Term.Title: De Jure
Term.Description: Latin for 'by law' or 'by right' legitimate or legal.

Term.Title: De Novo
Term.Description: Fresh; starting again.

Term.Title: de Quervains Tenosynovitis
Term.Description: Tenosynovitis is inflammation of the sheath that surrounds a tendon as opposed to inflammation of the actual tendon itself (tendinitis or tendonitis). de Quervain's Tenosynovitis is inflammation of the synovium of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus muscles as they pass through the wrist (on the thumb side of the wrist).

Term.Title: Dead Ball
Term.Description: A dead ball is a particular state of play in which the players may not perform any of the active aspects of the game. In other words, batsmen may not score runs and fielders may not attempt to get batsmen out. The ball, referring to the cricket ball, becomes live when the bowler begins his run up in preparation to bowling at the batsman. In the live state, play occurs with the batsmen able to score runs and get out. The ball then becomes dead when any of the following situations occur. The umpire is satisfied that, with adequate reason, the batsman is not ready for the delivery of the ball. The ball passes the batsman, is gathered by the wicket-keeper, and the batsmen obviously decline to attempt to take runs. The ball is finally settled in the hands of the wicket-keeper or the bowler, and the batsmen obviously decline to attempt to take any more runs. The umpire feels that both the fielding team and the batsmen consider the ball no longer to be in play. The ball reaches the boundary and four runs or six runs are scored. Either batsman is out. The ball lodges in the clothing or equipment of a batsman or umpire. The ball lodges in a protective helmet worn by a fielder. The batsmen attempt to run leg byes, and, in the umpire's opinion, no attempt was made either to hit the ball with the bat or to evade it. This nullifies the leg byes. The umpire intervenes in the occurrence of injury or unfair play.

Term.Title: Dead Ball (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A ball which is no longer in play.

Term.Title: Dead Ball Container (Boccia) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Placed at the end of the court. A ball is 'dead' if it is thrown after the time limit, if it is thrown out of the competition court or if, during a throw, an athlete makes a rule violation.

Term.Title: Dead Ball Hinder
Term.Description: When a player unintentional hinders another player that results in a replay of the point.

Term.Title: Dead Ball Line
Term.Description: A boundary located at each end of the playing field. The dead ball line is out of play.

Term.Title: Dead Ball Situation
Term.Description: When play is stopped and then begun again with throw-in, centre pass, or free pass.

Term.Title: Dead Bowl
Term.Description: When a bowl either goes in the ditch or rests outside the rink field of play.

Term.Title: Dead End
Term.Description: When the Jack has been knocked out of bounds. The end is not counted and is played again.

Term.Title: Dead Puck
Term.Description: When the puck can't be played which could be because of any number of reasons. The result will probably be a face-off.

Term.Title: Deadeye
Term.Description: A wooden block with holes (but no pulleys) which is spliced to a shroud.

Term.Title: Deadlift
Term.Description: Deadlift is a Powerlifting lift which involves an athlete raising a weighted barbell off the ground to a standing position with straightened lowered arms, then lowering the barbell back down to the ground.

Term.Title: Deadrise
Term.Description: The design angle between the keel and horizontal.

Term.Title: Decathlon (Men)
Term.Description: An athletic contest usually limited to men in Olympic competition in which each contestant participates in 10 track and field events: 100-metres, 400-metres, 1,500-metres, 110-metre high hurdles, discus, javelin, shot put, pole vault, high jump, and long jump.

Deceleration

Term.Title: Decision
Term.Description: The passing of judgment on an issue under consideration; The act of reaching a conclusion or making up one's mind; A conclusion or judgment reached or pronounced; a verdict.

Term.Title: Deck (Canoe / Kayak)
Term.Description: Closed-in area over the bow and / or stern of a canoe or kayak. Sheds water and, on a canoe, adds strength to the gunwales.

Term.Title: Deck Work
Term.Description: Swimmers perform on the deck before they enter the water. When the music starts swimmers try and set the mood for the routine they will be doing in the water. However, only ten seconds of deck work is permitted.

Term.Title: Deckhead
Term.Description: The under-side of the deck above.

Term.Title: Declarant

Term.Title: Decommission
Term.Description: To remove or retire from active service.

Term.Title: Decoy

Term.Title: Deed

Term.Title: Deep

Term.Title: Deep Set

Term.Title: Deep Vein Thrombosis
Term.Description: DVT; a condition marked by the formation of a thrombus within a deep vein (as of the leg or pelvis) that may be asymptomatic or be accompanied by symptoms (as swelling and pain) and that is potentially life threatening if dislodgment of the thrombus results in pulmonary embolism.

Term.Title: Defamation
Term.Description: The act of making untrue statements about another which damages his / her reputation.

Term.Title: Default
Term.Description: Default is the failure by a debtor to make a principal or interest payment in a timely manner, or to comply with other terms of a debt agreement. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Defence Reservist Leave
Term.Description: Employees engaged by the Department of Defence in Defence Reservist peacetime training and deployment activities are entitled to a specific amount of paid leave.

Term.Title: Defendant
Term.Description: The party sued in a civil lawsuit or the party charged with a crime in a criminal prosecution.

Term.Title: Defense (Gridiron)
Term.Description: The team that does not have the ball and is trying to stop the offense, which does have the ball, from making any kind of a score.

Term.Title: Defensemen (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: This is a player whose purpose is to concentrate on defense. They do not care about scoring themself, but want to keep the other team from scoring. There are usually two defense players on the ice for each team.

Term.Title: Defensive End
Term.Description: The two defensive ends play next to the defensive tackles, at the edges of the defensive line. Their function is to attack the passer or stop offensive runs to the outer edges of the line of scrimmage.

Term.Title: Defensive Line
Term.Description: These are the people who play against the offensive line and line up on the line of scrimmage. These players consist of the defensive tackles, the nose guard and the defensive ends.

Term.Title: Defensive Position
Term.Description: The back portion of the racquetball court. It is the area where a player will stand in order to have a better chance of returning an opponent's serve or shot.

Term.Title: Defensive Shot
Term.Description: A shot that is hit just to keep the ball in play and will allow the player hitting it time to get back to centre court to get ready to hit their next shot.

Term.Title: Defensive Tackle
Term.Description: Sometimes called a defensive guard, defensive tackles play at the centre of the defensive line. Their function is to rush the passer (if they can get past the offensive linemen blocking them), and stop running plays directed at the middle of the line of scrimmage.

Term.Title: Defensive Team
Term.Description: The team that begins a play from scrimmage not in possession of the ball.

Term.Title: Defensive Zone (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: Is that portion of the ice rink where the goal is located, and so each team's defending zone is the area in front of the goal they are defending.

Term.Title: Deferred Cost
Term.Description: A cost that you have already incurred, but which you will not charge to expense until a later reporting period.

Term.Title: Deferred Tax Asset
Term.Description: A deferred tax asset is income taxes recoverable in a future period.

Term.Title: Deferred Tax Liability
Term.Description: A deferred tax liabiity is income taxes payable in a future period.

Term.Title: Deficit
Term.Description: The amount by which expenditures or liabilities exceed income or assets. (http://dictionary.reference.com/)

Term.Title: Deflection
Term.Description: A shot or pass that hits some object such as a stick or skate and goes into the net for a score or when a goalie hits the puck away.

Term.Title: Degree of Difficulty
Term.Description: A scoring methodology that gives weighting to particular positions and movements and these are used in judging technical merit of a routine.

Term.Title: Dehydration
Term.Description: An abnormal loss of water from the body, especially from illness or physical exertion.

Term.Title: Dehydroepiandrosterone

Term.Title: Deke
Term.Description: This is when a player who has the puck tries to fake out the opposition.

Term.Title: Delay of Game (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A foul which occurs when the offensive team does not put the ball in play before the play clock runs out. There are also less common occurrences which result in a delay of game foul, such as a defensive player holding an offensive player on the ground to prevent them from lining up during a two-minute drill. Penalty: 5 yards.

Term.Title: Delayed Call (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: When an official raises their arm but does not blow their whistle, waiting to see the outcome of a play before calling a penalty. This is done so as not to penalize the non-offending team by stopping its momentum.

Term.Title: Delayed onset muscle soreness
Term.Description: The pain or discomfort often felt 24 to 72 hours after exercising and subsides generally within 2 to 3 days.

Term.Title: Delayed Penalty (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: When the play of the game continues until the team that had been penalized gets control of the puck.

Term.Title: Deliberation

Term.Title: Delinquency

Term.Title: Delivery (Athletics)

Term.Title: Delivery Cost
Term.Description: The amount of money it takes for a company to manufacture and deliver a product

Term.Title: Department of Defence
Term.Description: The Australian Government Department of Defence aims to promote the security of Australia, and to protect its people and its national interests.

Term.Title: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade
Term.Description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is responsible for the Australian Government's international relations, trade and development assistance programs through its headquarters in Canberra and Embassies, High Commissions and Consulates throughout the world.

Term.Title: Department of Health

Term.Title: Department of Treasury

Term.Title: Depreciation

Term.Title: Depreciation (Assets)

Term.Title: Depreciation Schedule

Term.Title: Depression (Movement)

Term.Title: Depression (Orienteering)
Term.Description: An indentation in the earth, generally rounded at the bottom. Smaller depressions are mapped with a 'u' symbol. Larger ones use contour (or form) lines with tag lines pointing into the depression.

Term.Title: Orienteering Land Forms and Map Symbols
Depth of Glide
Term.Description: Lowest vertical position of centre of mass during glide.

Term.Title: Depth of Hold
Term.Description: The height from the lowest part of the hull inside the ship, at its midpoint, to the ceiling that is made up of the uppermost full length deck.

Term.Title: Deputy
Term.Description: This is a player who is on the team defending their goal who may go into and stay in the goal circle when their team is in possession of the ball or when their teams goalkeeper is outside of the goal circle.

Term.Title: Deputy Chair
Term.Description: The Deputy Chair is subordinate only to the Chair of the Board of Directors and acts to serve as Chair in the absence of the appointed Chair or when a motion involving the Chair is being discussed.

Term.Title: Derecognition
Term.Description: Derecognition is the removal of a previously recognized financial asset or liability from an entity's balance sheet. (http://www.accountingtools.com)

Term.Title: Derelict
Term.Description: Something or someone who is abandoned.

Term.Title: Derivative
Term.Description: A derivative is a financial instrument whose value changes in relation to changes in a variable, such as an interest rate, commodity price, credit rating, or foreign exchange rate.

Term.Title: Derwent Entertainment Centre
Term.Description: Glenorchy TAS 7010

Term.Title: Descending Spin
Term.Description: A spin, of either 180 or 360 degrees, that starts in a vertical position and is finished when the swimmer's heels reach the surface of the water.

Term.Title: Designated Hitter
Term.Description: Player who bats in the pitchers spot in the line-up. The DH does not have a fielding position.

Term.Title: Desktop
Term.Description: The primary display screen of a graphical user interface, on which various icons represent files, groups of files, and programs.

Term.Title: Desktop Computer
Term.Description: A computer that is designed to stay in a single location.

Term.Title: Desktop Publishing
Term.Description: The design and production of publications by means of specialized software enabling a microcomputer to generate typeset-quality text and graphics.

Term.Title: Desmopressin
Term.Description: A synthetic replacement for vasopressin, the hormone that reduces urine production.

Term.Title: Desoxymethyltestosterone
Term.Description: An anabolic steroid. It was one of the first designer steroids to be marketed as a performance-enhancing drug to athletes and bodybuilders.

Term.Title: Determinable
Term.Description: Defining something which may be terminated upon the occurrence of a particular event.

Term.Title: Determination
Term.Description: The act of coming to a decision or of fixing or settling a purpose.

Term.Title: Determination of Fact
Term.Description: The court's role to discover the truth.

Term.Title: De-tuning
Term.Description: When a snowboarder dulls the edges on their snowboard so they won't catch in the snow.

Term.Title: Deuce
Term.Description: The curveball, usually signaled from a catcher to a pitcher by holding down two fingers.

Term.Title: Deuce (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: A time in the game where the score is tied, and one of the players must get two consecutive points to win the game. The next point won will give that player the advantage.

Term.Title: Deutschland Tour

Term.Title: Developing International Athlete
Term.Description: Athlete with the capability to achieve at least International Class Athlete status within 1-3 years.

Term.Title: Developmental Disorders
Term.Description: Disorders that occur at some stage in human development, often retarding the development.

Term.Title: Devonport Golf Club
Term.Description: Devonport TAS 7310

Term.Title: DEXA
Term.Description: Dual Energy Xray absorptiometry - a method of body composition monitoring.

Term.Title: Diabetes
Term.Description: A disorder of carbohydrate metabolism, usually occurring in genetically predisposed individuals, characterized by inadequate production or utilization of insulin and resulting in excessive amounts of glucose in the blood and urine, excessive thirst, weight loss, and in some cases progressive destruction of small blood vessels leading to such complications as infections and gangrene of the limbs or blindness.

Term.Title: Diagonal Formation
Term.Description: Used in doubles play where responsibility for covering a portion of the court is allocated by dividing the court diagonally from the left front corner to the right rear corner.

Term.Title: Diagonal Kill Shot
Term.Description: A ball that is hit diagonally into the opposite front corner. If hit right it will usually be a winning shot. If it is not hit right then the ball could come back to center court for an easy ball for the opposing player to hit.

Term.Title: Diamond Duck
Term.Description: A batsman who is dismissed without facing a ball (most usually run out from the non-striker's end, but alternatively stumped or run out off a wide delivery).

Term.Title: Diamond Paste
Term.Description: This is a special type of cream that has microscopic particles of diamonds and it is used to polish the runners to help reduce the friction between the runners and the ice.

Term.Title: Diamonds
Term.Description: Senior Women's Netball Team

Term.Title: Diarrhea
Term.Description: An intestinal disorder characterized by abnormal frequency and fluidity of fecal evacuations.

Term.Title: Dictum
Term.Description: Latin for "remark," a comment by a judge in a decision or ruling which is not required to reach the decision, but may state a related legal principle as the judge understands it.

Term.Title: Die
Term.Description: When the ball does not bounce high enough to be returned.

Term.Title: Dietetics
Term.Description: The branch of knowledge concerned with the diet and its effects on health, especially with the practical application of a scientific understanding of nutrition.

Term.Title: Diffusion
Term.Description: The borrowing of cultural elements from other societies in contrast to their independent invention within a host society.

Term.Title: Dig (Racquetball)
Term.Description: When the ball does not bounce high enough to be returned.

Term.Title: Dig (Volleyball)
Term.Description: Defensive contact following an opponents attack resulting in a playable ball.

Term.Title: Dig In

Term.Title: Digital Camera
Term.Description: A camera that captures images digitally.

Term.Title: Digital Video Disc (DVD)
Term.Description: Digital Video Disc is an optical disc used to store audio, video and computer data.

Term.Title: Digitorum Longus
Term.Description: Extends toes and dorsiflexes foot; flexes toes and plantar flexes foot.

Term.Title: Diligence
Term.Description: Reasonable care or attention to a matter, which is good enough to avoid a claim of negligence, or is a fair attempt.

Term.Title: Dime
Term.Description: A perfect pass.

Term.Title: Ding
Term.Description: A scratch or small hole in the bottom of a snowboard.

Term.Title: Dingos
Term.Description: Senior Men's Baseball team

Term.Title: Dink
Term.Description: A legal push of the ball around or over blockers.

Term.Title: Dinner Plain
Term.Description: Dinner Plain VIC 3898

Term.Title: Dinosaur
Term.Description: Refers to tall players or ruckmen.

Term.Title: Direct Cost
Term.Description: A direct cost is a cost that can be clearly associated with specific activities or products.

Term.Title: Direct Costs
Term.Description: The costs incurred, in addition to fixed costs, as a result of manufacturing a product or providing a service. Direct costs are made up of direct material, direct labour and direct manufacturing or servicing costs. (http://www.smallbiz.nsw.gov.au)

Term.Title: Direct Deposti
Term.Description: Direct deposit is a payment of an account payable, wages, or taxes directly into a bank account.

Term.Title: Direct Thrust
Term.Description: A direct attack at an opponent.

Term.Title: Direction Flags
Term.Description: Direction flags are placed along each side of the ski course: green flags are put along the right side and red flags along the left side.

Term.Title: Directional Stance
Term.Description: When the stance on a snowboard causes the snowboarder to ride differently when going in different directions.

Term.Title: Director
Term.Description: An individual who is elected by shareholders or members to oversee the strategy of the business; the senior manager of an organisation, company, or corporation.

Term.Title: Directory
Term.Description: A list of names, addresses etc., of specific classes of people or organisations, often in alphabetical order or in some other classification.

Term.Title: Disability Discrimination Act 1992
Term.Description: The Act is essentially in place to ensure equal opportunity, whether or not the discrimination is intentional or not.

Term.Title: Disability Sports Australia
Term.Description: Established at the request of the Australian Sports Commission in April 2003 as Australian Athletes With a Disability, the organisation changed its name to Disability Sports Australia in 2013. Disability Sports Australia performs the role of national coordinating body, providing a single point of contact between partner organisations (e.g. National Sports Organisations, Australian Sports Commission and Australian Paralympic Committee) and State and Territory members. DSA administers the Wheelchair Rugby and Wheelchair Basketball national leagues, and the Lawn Bowls Multi-Disability National Championships, providing opportunities for the development of athletes at a national level and supporting elite pathways.

Term.Title: National Sporting Organisation for People with a Disability
Disabled Surfers Association of Aust. Inc. (NSW)
Term.Description: http://disabledsurfers.org/

Term.Title: Sport competitions for People with Disabilities
Disabled Wintersport Australia
Term.Description: Disabled Wintersport Australia http://www.disabledwintersport.com.au/

Term.Title: Alpine Skiing for Athletes with Disabilities organisations
National Sporting Organisation for People with a Disability
Disadvantaged
Term.Description: Lacking the normal or usual necessities and comforts of life; absence or deprivation of advantage or equality.

Term.Title: Disaster
Term.Description: A half-pipe lip trick but the snowboarder lands with the coping (top rim of a half-pipe wall) perpendicular to the snowboard.

Term.Title: Disc Golf
Term.Description: Disc golf, also known as Frolf, Folf, Frisbee disc or frisbee golf, is a flying disc game, as well as a precision and accuracy sport, in which individual players throw a flying disc at a target

Term.Title: Disclosure
Term.Description: A disclosure is additional information attached to an entity's financial statements, usually as explanation for activities which have significantly influenced the entity's financial results.

Term.Title: Discretion
Term.Description: The ability to choose whether to, or whether not to, proceed with a decision.

Term.Title: Discretionary
Term.Description: When the decision is made on what seems fit for the circumstances.

Term.Title: Discretionary Leave
Term.Description: At the discretion of the Chief Executive Officer leave with or without pay may be approved where it is not appropriate that annual leave or other forms of leave be used.

Term.Title: Discrimination
Term.Description: Treatment or consideration based on class or category rather than individual merit.

Term.Title: Discrimination Act 1991
Term.Description: Under anti-discrimination legislation you must not discriminate or harass others on the grounds of race, colour or nationality, sex or gender, sexual or transgender orientation, pregnancy, marital or parental status, religious or politacal beliefs, social origin, age, or physical, mental or psychological disability. You must be sensitive to how your behaviour is or might be received by others.

Term.Title: Discs (Powerlifting) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: To have IPC Powerlifting approval, discs must conform as follows: All discs used in competition must weigh within 0.25% of their correct face value. The size of the hole in the middle of the disc may not exceed 53 mm or be less than 52mm. Discs must be within the following range: 1.25kg, 2.5kg, 5kg, 10kg, 15kg, 20kg and 25kg. For record purposes, lighter discs may be used to achieve a weight of a least 500 gr. more than the existing record. Discs must conform to the following colour code: 25kg = red, 20kg = blue, 15kg = yellow, 10kg and under = any colour. All discs must be clearly marked with their weight and loaded in the sequence of heavier discs innermost with the smaller discs in descending weight arranged so that the referees can read the weight on each disc. The first and heaviest disc loaded on the bar must be loaded face in, with the rest of the discs loaded face out. The diameter of the largest disc shall not be more than 450mm.

Term.Title: Discus
Term.Description: A discus is a circular disk more than 7 inches (18 cm) in diameter and 1 kg in weight usually wooden with a metal rim and thicker in the centre than at the edge, for throwing for distance in athletic competition.

Term.Title: Discus (Athletics equipment)
Term.Description: A cylindrical object thrown in a competition.

Term.Title: Disease
Term.Description: A disordered or incorrectly functioning organ, part, structure, or system of the body resulting from the effect of genetic or developmental errors, infection, poisons, nutritional deficiency or imbalance, toxicity, or unfavorable environmental factors.

Term.Title: Disk Drive
Term.Description: A device that reads and / or writes data to a disk.

Term.Title: Disk Encryption
Term.Description: Encryption technology that encrypts data on a hard disk drive.

Term.Title: Dislocation
Term.Description: An act or instance of dislocating; to put out of place; put out of proper relative position; displace.

Term.Title: Dismissal
Term.Description: A dismissal occurs when the batsman is out (also known as the fielding side taking a wicket and / or the batting side losing a wicket). At this point a batsman must discontinue batting and leave the field permanently for the innings.

Term.Title: Disorderly Conduct
Term.Description: Actions that disturb others; minor criminal offenses, such as public drunkenness, loitering, disturbing the peace, and loud threats or parties.

Term.Title: Disposal
Term.Description: A disposing or allotting of, as by gift or sale; bestowal or assignment.

Term.Title: Disposal (Assets)
Term.Description: The acting of getting rid of an asset.

Term.Title: Disposal Authorities
Term.Description: Policy for disposal of assets.

Term.Title: Disputed Transaction

Term.Title: Disqualification
Term.Description: The Athlete's results in a particular Competition or Event are invalidated, with all resulting consequences, including forfeiture of any medals, points and prizes as a result of an anti-doping rule violation.

Term.Title: Dissent
Term.Description: To differ in opinion.

Term.Title: Distal
Term.Description: Furthest from the point of attachment to the body.

Term.Title: Diuresis
Term.Description: Increased discharge of urine.

Term.Title: Diuretics
Term.Description: Any substance that promotes the production of urine.

Term.Title: Dive (Volleyball)
Term.Description: A defensive move made to keep the ball off the sand. Airborne and aiming to position the body near horizontal to reach the ball. The athlete lands on their knees or torso.

Term.Description: A catch made by a receiver where the receiver has to dive to catch the ball.

Term.Description: http://www.fina.org/

Term.Description: Grass turf displaced by the head of your club during a swing.

Term.Title: DLW
Term.Description: Doubly-labeled water is water in which both the hydrogen and the oxygen has been partly or completely replaced for tracing purposes (i.e., labeled) with an uncommon isotope of these elements to generate a particular type of measurement of metabolic rate.

Term.Title: Document
Term.Description: A written or printed paper furnishing information or evidence; a computer data file.

Term.Title: Documentation
Term.Description: Process by which documents are made availabelc and treated collectiviely.

Term.Title: Dodgy
Term.Description: Something suspicious and underhanded going on.

Term.Title: Dogleg
Term.Description: A description of a hole where the fairway goes either to the left or right and prevents the golfer from being able to see the green from the tee area.

Term.Title: Dog-leg
Term.Description: Positioning of a control which favors approaching and leaving a control by the same route, thereby leading other competitors to the control. Course design which results in a dog-leg should be avoided.

Term.Title: Dojo
Term.Description: This is the room or area where judo is learned and practiced.

Term.Title: Dolphin Bent Knee
Term.Description: The swimmer starts on their back moves into a bent knee position and then keeping this position swims in a circle under water.

Term.Title: Dolphin Kick
Term.Description: When the legs are kept together and the move up and down in the water in unison. It gets its name because the legs resemble a move like a dolphins tail.

Term.Title: Dolphins
Term.Description: Swimming National Team

Term.Title: Domain Names
Term.Description: A series of alphanumeric strings separated by periods, such as www.oup-usa.org, serving as an address for a computer network connection and identifying the owner of the address.

Term.Title: Domestic Testing Pool
Term.Description: The pool of Athletes established by ASADA who are not part of ASADAs Registered Testing Pool but who are subject to both In-Competition and Out-of-Competition Testing as part of ASADAs test distribution plan.

Term.Title: Dominant Eye
Term.Description: The stronger or 'master' eye.

Term.Title: Dominant Tackle
Term.Description: A referee may call "Dominant!" as a player is tackled to indicate the dominance of the defender over the attacking player in possession during the contact between them at the tackle. A dominant tackle is judged to be when the defender makes contact and drives the attacker back in one movement. The dominant tackle call rewards good technique and allows the defender extra time before the attacker must be released to be allowed to play-the-ball.

Term.Title: Dominica
Term.Description: Country code = DM

Term.Title: Dominican Republic
Term.Description: Country code = DO

Term.Title: Donation
Term.Description: A gift made by an individual or an organisation.

Term.Title: Donations
Term.Description: Acts or instances of presenting something as a gift, grant, or contribution.

Term.Title: Dongle
Term.Description: An electronic device that must be attached to a computer in order for it to use protected software.

Term.Title: Doping
Term.Description: The occurrence of one or more of the eight anti-doping rule violations specified in the World Anti-Doping Code - NISU definition

Term.Title: Doping Control
Term.Description: All steps and processes from test distribution planning through to ultimate disposition of any appeal including all steps and processes in between, such as provision of whereabouts information, sample collection and handling, laboratory analysis, TUEs, results management and hearings.

Term.Title: Dorsal
Term.Description: On the top surface of the foot; on the back of the hand.

Term.Title: Dorsiflexion
Term.Description: Movement which decreases the angle between the foot and the leg, so that the toes are brought closer to the shin.

Term.Title: Double (Baseball)
Term.Description: A hit that enables a batter to reach second base.

Term.Title: Double (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: A jump with two full rotations (720 degrees) in the air (two and a half rotations for double Axel).

Term.Title: Double (Softball)
Term.Description: A hit that enables a batter to reach second base.

Term.Title: Double Axel
Term.Description: When a skater does 2 1/2 revolutions.

Term.Title: Double Ballet Leg Position
Term.Description: A position in which the legs are together and extended perpendicular to the surface of the water and the swimmer's face is at the surface of the water.

Term.Title: Double Block
Term.Description: Two players working in unison to deflect an attacked ball at the net back to the hitters side.

Term.Title: Double Bogey
Term.Description: Two strokes over par for a particular hole.

Term.Title: Double Circle Routine
Term.Description: A routine performed by 12 swimmers on the surface of the water using a double circle formation.

Term.Title: Double Coverage
Term.Description: Refers to, two defensive players guarding one offensive player.

Term.Title: Double Eagle
Term.Description: This is three-strokes under par for a particular hole.

Term.Title: Double Foul
Term.Description: A foul by each team during the same down.

Term.Title: Double Full
Term.Description: A layout flip that has two twists with it.

Term.Title: Double Full Full Full
Term.Description: The skier does three flips with four twists. Two of the twists are done on the first flip, when the skier comes off the jump.

Term.Title: Double Grab
Term.Description: The snowboarder goes off of a jump and they grab the snowboard one way, then they grab it in another way, then they land.

Term.Title: Double Helicopter
Term.Description: When a skier does a 360-degree aerial turn, twice.

Term.Title: Double Hit
Term.Description: Successive hits or contacts by the same player. This is illegal.

Term.Title: Double Layout
Term.Description: In a layout position the skier does two flips.

Term.Title: Double Leg Tackle
Term.Description: When a wrestler drops to one knee and grabs the opponent's legs, they then begin to lift and by dropping to both knees to gain leverage lift the opponent over their shoulder and ultimately pins the opponent.

Term.Title: Double Marking
Term.Description: When two players mark a single opposing player.

Term.Title: Double Minor
Term.Description: A type of minor penalty given for certain accidental infractions that result in an injury to another player or for certain deliberate attempts to injure an opponent that are unsuccessful. Penalty time of 4 minutes is served, double the time of a normal minor penalty.

Term.Title: Double Movement
Term.Description: An illegal movement in the attempt to score a try. An attacking player whose momentum does not allow the ball to reach the try-line or in-goal after their ball-carrying arm touches the ground may not reach out to score if a defender is in contact with them. This is disallowed by interpretation as a double movement.

Term.Title: Double Play
Term.Description: Any defensive play that results in two base runners being called out.

Term.Title: Double Poling
Term.Description: When skiers use both poles at the same time to move themselves forward.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Double Quick
Term.Description: Two hitters approaching the setter for a quick inside hit.

Term.Title: Double Somersault
Term.Description: A skier performs two flips.

Term.Title: Double Support (Hammer Throw)
Term.Description: Phase of hammer throw when the thrower has both feet in contact with the ground.

Term.Title: Double Takeout
Term.Description: When one stone is able to knock two opponents stones out of the house.

Term.Title: Double Touch
Term.Description: This is when both fencers have a touch against them at the same time. Both fencers score a hit at the same time.

Term.Title: Double-Handed Grab
Term.Description: The snowboarder grabs the snowboard with both hands at the same time while in the air.

Term.Title: Doubleheader
Term.Description: Two games played back to back by the same teams.

Term.Title: Down (Bowls)
Term.Description: When your team does not have the Shot Bowl, you are considered to be Down. You may be down by one or more points.

Term.Title: Down (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A unit of the game that starts with a legal snap or legal free kick after the ball is ready for play and ends when the ball next becomes dead. First down is the first of the plays; fourth is the last down in American (third in Canadian) football. A first down occurs after a change of possession of the ball, after advancing the ball 10 yards following a previous first down or after certain penalties.

Term.Title: Down and Out
Term.Description: A boxer who is down has been knocked to the canvas, and one who is also out is unconscious or unable to resume the fight thus a down-and-out boxer is utterly defeated.

Term.Title: Down Ball
Term.Description: A ball the blockers elect not to attempt to block because it has been set too far from the net or the hitter is not under control. A down ball is hit overhand and driven over the net with topspin while the player remains standing. "Down Ball" is usually called aloud by the defense when it becomes apparent the attacker has no chance of hitting a powerful spike.

Term.Title: Down for the Count
Term.Description: Refers to a boxer being knocked down; the referee will count off ten seconds, the time allotted for the boxer to regain their feet or lose the fight.

Term.Title: Down the Wall
Term.Description: A shot that is hit parallel to and very near the one of the side-walls. This is also called a wallpaper shot or a down the line shot. Almost impossible to return or get a good shot on the ball.

Term.Title: Downhill
Term.Description: High-speed alpine ski racing with tight turns and jumps. Speeds can be in excess of 60 mph. Also, the common term used for alpine skiing.

Term.Title: Alpine Skiing for Athletes with Disabilities terms and techniques
Downhill - DH (Men)
Term.Description: Mountain Bike competition race

Term.Title: Downhill - DH (Women)
Term.Description: Mountain Bike competition race

Term.Title: Downhill (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Skiers are timed as they race down a long, steep course that may include turns and jumps. They must pass through a relatively few number of gates that are used as checkpoints. The penalty for missing a gate is disqualification. One run determines the finishing order the shortest time wins.

Term.Title: Downhill Lie
Term.Description: The ball is on the down slope of hill and this makes for a difficult shot.

Term.Title: Downhill Skiing
Term.Description: High-speed alpine ski racing with tight turns and jumps. Speeds can be in excess of 60 mph. Also, the common term used for alpine skiing.

Term.Title: Downswing
Term.Description: When a golfer is bringing his club down toward the ball.

Term.Title: Downtown
Term.Description: The area behind the three point line.

Term.Description: http://www.gymnastics.org.au/

Term.Title: Draft
Term.Description: Draught - The depth of a ship's keel below the waterline.

Term.Title: Draft (Gridiron)
Term.Description: This is the term used when professional teams are able to pick college football players to join their professional team.

Term.Title: Drafting
Term.Description: To ride closely behind another rider to make maximum use of their slipstream, reducing wind resistance and effort required to ride at the same speed.

Term.Title: Drafting (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: When a skater skates close behind another skater to lessen the wind resistance on them so they do not have to skate as hard as the lead skater.

Term.Title: Drag
Term.Description: Drag (sometimes called air resistance or fluid resistance) refers to forces that oppose the relative motion of an object through a fluid (a liquid or gas).

Term.Title: Drag Flick (Hockey)
Term.Description: A move used by advanced players to take a legal lifted shot on goal during a penalty corner.

Term.Title: Dragged
Term.Description: When a player is moved from field to interchange during game for poor form or conduct (ie. giving away a fifty or making a stupid mistake).

Term.Title: Dragons Rowing Club
Term.Description: http://www.dragonsrowing.com.au/

Term.Title: Draw (Canoe / Kayak)
Term.Description: Blade facing inwards, parallel to boat (more open).

Term.Title: Draw (Curling)
Term.Description: A scoring shot. It is meant to stop right inside and in front of the house.

Term.Title: Draw Length
Term.Description: The length or distance an arrow will be pulled or drawn back before it is released.

Term.Title: Draw Play
Term.Description: A draw play is a running play where the quarterback first fakes like he is going to pass the ball and then hands the ball off to the running back, and hopefully, many of the defensive players are out of position to stop a running play and the running back can gain many yards.

Term.Title: Draw Weight
Term.Description: The number of pounds of force required to draw a bow twenty-eight (28) inches

Term.Title: Drawing
Term.Description: The archer is pulling the bowstring into the shooting position along with the proper anchor.

Term.Title: Drentse 8 van Dwingeloo
Term.Description: http://www.rondevandrenthe.nl/

Term.Title: Dribble (Hockey)
Term.Description: A player is moving while at the same time controlling the ball with his / her stick.

Term.Title: Dribble Drive Attack Offence
Term.Description: Dribble drive motion is a "four-out" offense - that is, only one post player (generally the center) plays near the basket, while the other four players play on the perimeter, around the three-point line.

Term.Title: Dribbling (Water Polo)
Term.Description: The technique of moving the ball while swimming forward propelled ahead of the player with the wake created by alternating armstrokes. Since ball contact is minimal, this creates advantage for the ball carrier advancing the ball.

Term.Title: Drie Zustersteden
Term.Description: ttp://www.dedriezustersteden.iplsoft.com/

Term.Title: Drifting
Term.Description: When a skater moves into a lane they should not be in or if a skater changes lanes and interferes with another skater. This is a foul.

Term.Title: DrillDance
Term.Description: DrillDance is a non-contact team sport for male and female athletes. DrillDance teams perform drill routines in categories such as Basic, Thematic Dance, Prop and Technical Drill to music.

Term.Title: Drills
Term.Description: Disciplined, repetitious exercise as a means of teaching and perfecting a skill or procedure.

Term.Title: Drive (Bowls)
Term.Description: This involves bowling with considerable force with the aim of knocking either the Jack or a specific bowl out of play.

Term.Title: Drive (Golf)
Term.Description: The shot that is taken from the tee area. The first shot you take on each hole.

Term.Title: Drive (Gridiron)
Term.Description: When a team is able to run a number of plays and move the ball down the field gaining many yards.

Term.Title: Drive (Hockey)

Term.Title: Drive (Rowing)
Term.Description: The propulsive portion of the stroke from the time the oar blade enters the water ('catch') until it is removed from the water ('release').

Term.Title: Drive Serve
Term.Description: A serve that is low and hard.

Term.Title: Drive Serve Lines
Term.Description: Lines that are 3 feet from each side-wall, run parallel to each side-wall and are inside the service zone area. These lines delineate a 17-foot drive serve zone.

Term.Title: Drive Shot
Term.Description: A ball that is hit very hard.

Term.Title: Driver (Motor Sport)
Term.Description: Operator of a motor vehicle.

Term.Title: Driver (Sailing)
Term.Description: The large sail flown from the mizzen gaff.

Term.Title: Driving Iron
Term.Description: An iron that can be used to drive the ball. Sometimes called a long iron this would be called a #1 or #2 Iron. It can produce long drives while providing the golfer with more control as compared to a wood driver.

Term.Title: Driving Range
Term.Description: A place to practice hitting golf balls.

Term.Title: Drop
Term.Description: The distance that a projectile falls at any given distance from the gun.

Term.Title: Drop Ball
Term.Description: A method of restarting play after a technical foul.

Term.Title: Drop Goal
Term.Description: A drop goal is scored when a player kicks the ball from hand through the opposition's goal, but the ball must touch the ground between being dropped and kicked. It is worth three points. The team awarded a free kick cannot score a dropped goal until the ball next becomes dead, or until an opponent has played or touched it, or has tackled the ball carrier. This restriction applies also to a scrum taken instead of a free kick.

Term.Title: Drop Kick
Term.Description: A drop kick is when a player kicks the ball from hand and the ball touches the ground between being dropped and kicked. If a drop kick goes through a goal then it results in a drop goal.

Term.Title: Drop Kick (AFL)
Term.Description: A kick that is executed in such a way that the foot contacts the ball at the same time as, or immediately after, it has been dropped to the ground on its end.

Term.Title: Drop Pass
Term.Description: When a player leaves the puck behind them for a teammate to pick up as they move forward.

Term.Title: Drop Punt
Term.Description: The most common method of kicking the ball. Foot contacts the ball sililarly to the drop kick but before it reaches the ground. Ball spins end under end.

Term.Title: Drop Punt (AFL)
Term.Description: A kick that is executed by contacting the ball on its end so that it rotates around its mid-point end over end. Usually considered the most accurate of kicks and is by far the most commonly used kicking style in Australian rules football.

Term.Title: Drop Shot (Racquetball)
Term.Description: A shot that has very little speed or power behind it and is meant to barely make contact with the front wall to make it a difficult shot to return.

Term.Title: Dropball
Term.Description: In fast-pitch softball this is a pitch that drops just before it gets to home plate.

Term.Title: Dropout
Term.Description: The slot, of various sizes and orientations, in the frame that the axles of the wheels attach to.

Term.Title: Dropped
Term.Description: A player is moved to the reserves after a poor performance.

Term.Title: Drostanolone
Term.Description: Also known as Dromostanolone or Drolban, marketed as Masteron, an anabolic steroid. Part of the dihydrotestosterone (DHT) family. Its main medical uses include lowering cholesterol levels and as an antineoplastic agent.

Term.Title: Drowning
Term.Description: To die under water or other liquid of suffocation.

Term.Title: Drug Abuse
Term.Description: Addiction to drugs.

Term.Title: Drug Addiction
Term.Description: A condition characterized by an overwhelming desire to continue taking a drug to which one has become habituated through repeated consumption.

Term.Title: Drummoyne Olympic Pool
Term.Description: Henley Marine Drive, Drummoyne NSW 2047

Term.Title: Drummoyne Oval
Term.Description: Drummoyne NSW 2047

Term.Title: Drunken Octopus
Term.Description: The poor technique evident when an Eight is rowed with no two oars moving in the same time or position in the stroke.

Term.Title: Dry Pass
Term.Description: A pass made so the ball does not touch the water but is caught.

Term.Title: Dry Slope
Term.Description: A ski slope that is made out of a plastic material called Dendex.

Term.Title: Dual Alley Start
Term.Description: A type of start commonly used in large distance races where there are two waterfall starts: One standard, and a second farther down the track that is spread over the outside half of the lanes. Runners in the outside alley may break only to the middle of the track, designated by cones, until completing the first turn, at which time the runners on the outside may break toward the inside lanes where the runners who started from the full waterfall have already moved.

Term.Title: Dual Slalom
Term.Description: When two snowboarders race against each other on a slalom course.

Term.Title: Duck
Term.Description: A duck refers to a batsman's dismissal for a score of zero.

Term.Title: Duck Foot
Term.Description: A stance where the snowboarders toes are pointing outward like a duck.

Term.Title: Duck Under
Term.Description: When a wrestler is able to slip their head under their rivals arm and come up behind them in a position to take them down.

Term.Title: Ducks
Term.Description: Australian Women's Sitting Volleyball Team

Term.Title: Duckworth / Lewis Method
Term.Description: The Duckworth / Lewis method (D/L method) is a mathematical way to calculate the target score for the team batting second in a one-day cricket or Twenty20 cricket match interrupted by weather or other circumstance. It is generally accepted to be a fair and accurate method of setting a target score, but as it attempts to predict what would have happened had the game come to its natural conclusion, it generates some controversy. The D/L method was devised by two English statisticians, Frank Duckworth and Tony Lewis.

Term.Title: Duel in the pool
Term.Description: Swimming http://www.duelinthepool.com/

Term.Title: Dukes
Term.Description: Refers to the outstreched arms of a player, usually when taking or spoiling a mark.

Term.Title: Dumbbell
Term.Description: small weight of fixed resistance, usually held with one hand

Term.Title: Dummy
Term.Description: A type of baulk where a player tricks an opposition player into believing they are about to do something they are not.

Term.Title: Dummy Half
Term.Description: The dummy half is the player who stands behind the play-the-ball and collects the ball, before passing or running with the ball.

Term.Title: Dummy pass
Term.Description: An offensive ruse, where the ball carrier moves as if to pass the ball to a team-mate, but then continues to run with the ball themself. The objective is to trick defenders into marking the would-be pass receiver creating a gap for the ball carrier to run into.

Term.Title: Dummy Run
Term.Description: A player moves into a space as though preparing to receive the ball, without intending to receive it.

Term.Title: Dummy Runner
Term.Description: An offensive tactic. A player on the attacking team runs towards the opposition as if running onto a pass only for the ball to be passed to another player, carried on by the ball carrier or kicked forwards. As with a dummy pass, this tactic draws defenders away from the ball and creates space for the attacking team.

Term.Title: Dump
Term.Description: A surprise attack usually executed by a front row setter to catch the defense off guard.

Term.Title: Dump tackle
Term.Description: It is a tackling technique. The tackler wraps their arms around the ball carrier's thighs and lifts them a short distance in the air before forcibly driving them to the ground. The tackler must go to ground with the ball carrier for the tackle to be legal. This technique is useful to completely stop the opponent in their tracks. A dump tackle which drops the ball carrier on their head or neck is known as a spear tackle, and will almost invariably concede a penalty and possibly result in a caution for the tackler.

Term.Title: Dumping
Term.Description: To get rid of or discard.

Term.Title: Dunes Medal, The
Term.Description: http://www.thedunes.com.au

Term.Title: Dunk
Term.Description: A slam dunk is a type of basketball shot that is performed when a player jumps in the air and manually powers the ball downward through the basket with one or both hands over the rim.

Term.Title: Dutch Food Valley Classic
Term.Description: http://www.dutchfoodvalleyclassic.nl/

Term.Title: DVD

Term.Title: DVD Player
Term.Description: A DVD player is a device that plays Digital Video Discs.

Term.Title: DVD Recorder
Term.Description: A DVD, also known as a DVDR, is an optical disc recorder that uses optialc disc recording technologies to digitally record analog signal onto blank writable DVD media.

Term.Title: Dwars door Vlaanderen
Term.Description: http://www.dwarsdoorvlaanderen.be/

Term.Title: Dynamic Host configuration Protocol
Term.Description: A network configuration protocol for hosts on Internet Protocol (IP) networks.

Term.Title: Earned Run
Term.Description: A run scored on a hit, walk or steal, without benefit from a defensive error on the play.

Term.Title: Ears On

Term.Title: Easement

Term.Description: The East Asian Games is a multi-sport event organised by East Asian Games Association (EAGA) and held every four years since 1993 among athletes from East Asian countries. http://www.enecotour.com/ All EAGA's members able to take part in the Games, they are: People's Republic of China Guam Hong Kong, China Japan DPR Korea (North Korea) Republic of Korea (South Korea) Macau, China Mongolia Republic of China (Taiwan), (compete as Chinese Taipei

Term.Description: An eating disorder is characterised when eating, exercise and body weight / shape become an unhealthy pre-occupation of someone's life.

Term.Title: Eccentric contraction
Term.Description: An increase in muscle length, with muscle force resisting the lengthening of the muscle by external forces.

Term.Title: Eczema
Term.Description: Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is a skin condition that usually appears in early childhood and affects people with a genetic susceptibility.

Term.Title: Edge
Term.Description: Can refer either to part of the skate blade, or the result of skating on that part. Can be either inside (towards the body) or outside (away from the body), and forward or backward, for a total for four different edges. A "deep edge" is a deep lean on the edge of the skate.

Term.Title: Edge Angle
Term.Description: The amount of angle between the snow and the edge of the ski.

Term.Title: Edge Jump
Term.Description: A general term to refer to any of the three jumps that take off from an edge.

Term.Title: Edge Set
Term.Description: When the skier puts equal edging to both skies, with the result that they will either stop or dramatically slow their progress.

Term.Title: Edging
Term.Description: The amount of ski edge angle in combination with the position of the skier's body which will determine how much skidding the skis do when the skier is turning.

Term.Title: Edith Cowan Univeristy Sports
Term.Description: http://www.ecu.edu.au/

Term.Title: Educate
Term.Description: To develop the innate capacities of, especially by schooling or instruction.

Term.Title: Effective Edge
Term.Description: The amount of snowboard edge that is in contact with the snow and the amount of edge that is used to make a turn.

Term.Title: Efficacy
Term.Description: The ability to produce a desired or intended result.

Term.Title: Egg Beater
Term.Description: A race where the crews are drawn randomly from a hat, so that boats are made up of members from different teams and often the lineups include coxswains as rowers and vice versa.

Term.Title: Egg Flip
Term.Description: A trick where the snowboarder flips over as opposed to rotating 180 degrees to reenter the pipe.

Term.Title: Egg Position
Term.Description: When taking off from a ski jump, skiers will get in an egg position to lower their wind resistance. An egg position is when the skier gets in a crouching position, legs bent at the knees and they are also bending at the waist so their head is lower than their back and their arms are held in close to the side of their body. After take-off the skier will come out of this position into a standing position.

Term.Title: Eggbeater
Term.Description: The legs move in a rotary movement and are used to support and boost the upper body into an upright position, so the swimmer is able to stay in one place in the water and use their arms to perform artistic movements.

Term.Title: Egg-Beater (Water Polo)
Term.Description: A form of treading water, named because the circular movement of the legs resembles the motion of an egg-beater. This kick allows the player to maintain a constant position to the water level. Also by kicking faster for a brief period the player can get high out of the water for a block, pass, or shot.

Term.Title: Eggplant
Term.Description: A 180-degree backside rotated invert with the snowboarder places their front-hand on the lip of the half-pipe wall.

Term.Title: Egypt
Term.Description: Country code = EG

Term.Title: Eight Foot Ring
Term.Description: The 8-foot-diameter (2.4 m) circle in the house. It is used as a visual aid only - there is no extra score for placing a stone within it. It appears as the empty space between the 12-foot and 4-foot rings.

Term.Title: Eight Metre Arc
Term.Description: The Eight Metre Arc is an arc that is 8-metres in front of the goal circle. There are certain rules that apply when fouls are committed in this area.

Term.Title: Eights
Term.Description: A boat for eight sweep rowers.

Term.Title: Ejector
Term.Description: The mechanism which expels the cartridge or case from the breech of the gun.

Term.Title: El Salvador
Term.Description: Country code = SV

Term.Title: Elbow Hyperextension Injury
Term.Description: An elbow hyperextension injury occurs when the elbow is bent back the wrong way. This type of injury will occur more frequently in contact sports. The elbow pain is caused when the elbow is forced to bend the wrong way or hyperextend causing damage to the ligaments and structures of the elbow.

Term.Title: Elbowing
Term.Description: Elbowing is when a player uses an extended elbow in a manner that may or may not cause injury.

Term.Title: Electrogoniometry
Term.Description: The science of measuring angles and the changes in them used in the study of gait.

Term.Title: Electrolyte
Term.Description: Ions, primarily sodium, potassium and chloride that play an important part in water balance.

Term.Title: Electromyography
Term.Description: Electromyography (EMG) is an electrical recording of muscle activity that aids in the diagnosis of neuromuscular disease.

Term.Title: Electronic Funds Transfer
Term.Description: EFT - the use of telecommunications networks to transfer funds from one financial institution, as a bank, to another, or to withdraw funds from one's own account to deposit in a creditor's.

Term.Title: Electronic Scoring Device
Term.Description: The machine the records the location and number of touches landed by a fencer. The body wire connects the fencer to the electronic scoring device. When a valid touch is made a green or red light comes on, for an invalid touch a white lamp comes on.

Term.Title: Electronic Touch Pads
Term.Description: These are electronic pads that are at the end of each lane and they are connected to the timing system so when the pad is touched the timer records that time.

Term.Title: Electronic Transactions Act 1999
Term.Description: The Electronic Transactions Act encourages online business by ensuring that electronic evidence of transactions is not invalidated because of its format. Generally speaking, documents which are not originals can now be presented in court as evidence and treated as true and correct unless proven otherwise.

Term.Title: Electronic Whiteboard
Term.Description: A panel covered with white, glossy plastic for writing on with erasable markers.

Term.Title: Element
Term.Description: An identifiable component of a program. Includes spins, spirals, jumps, footwork, lifts, etc.

Term.Title: Elevation
Term.Description: Moving a body part upwards.

Term.Title: Elgeurial
Term.Description: An invert where the halfpipe wall is approached fakie, the rear hand is planted and a 360-degree backside rotation is executed and the rider lands going forward.

Term.Title: Elimination System
Term.Description: A type of race where there is a maximum of eight skaters and after 4 laps the skater in last position drops out of the race. Thereafter every two laps the last skater in the race drops out of the race until there is only one skater remaining and they are the winner.

Term.Title: Elite
Term.Description: Athletes that turn 17 - 34 in the year the event is held.

Term.Title: Elite Athlete
Term.Description: An athlete who is qualified to compete at a state, national or international level and is identified by an offically recognised sporting organisation.

Term.Title: Elite Indigenous Travel and Accommodation Assistance Program
Term.Description: Elite Indigenous Travel and Accommodation Assistance Program (EITAAP) is for Indigenous sportspeople who have been selected for a state team to compete at national championships or an Australian team to compete at an international event. The program assists with travel and accommodation expenses only.

Term.Title: Elphin Sports Centre

Term.Title: Emerging
Term.Description: Sports likely to achieve a top eight finish and have an outside medal chance at the next Olympic Games, or likely to achieve a medal at the next Paralympic Games. These sports have longer term potential.

Term.Title: Emerging International Athlete
Term.Description: Athlete with the capability to achieve at least international class athlete status within 1-3 years. Athletes who are considered (based on specific criteria) capable of making the national senior team within an Olympic cycle (high performance system major multi-sport benchmark event). Prognostic period is a rolling term (not link directly to current Olympic cycle).

Term.Title: Emphysema
Term.Description: Emphysema is a type of lung disease characterised by shortness of breath.

Term.Title: Empirical Investigation
Term.Description: Depending upon experience or observation alone, without using scientific method or theory, especially as in medicine.

Term.Title: Employee Benefits
Term.Description: Indirect and non-cash compensation paid to an employee.

Term.Title: Empowerment
Term.Description: Increasing the spiritual, political, social, or economic strength of individuals.

Term.Title: Empty Net Goal
Term.Description: A goal scored against a team that has pulled the goalie.

Term.Title: Emus

Term.Title: En Garde

Term.Title: Encroachment
Term.Description: This is when a team is offsides and moves before the snap of the ball. This is a five-yard penalty.

Term.Title: Encumber
Term.Description: To charge or mortgage; to create a burden on land such as an easement.

Term.Title: End (Archery)
Term.Description: A round of arrows shot during an archery event (rarely more than six arrows).

Term.Title: End (Bowls)
Term.Description: Means playing of the Jack and all bowls of both opponents in the same direction on a Rink. Bowling to the Jack is called one end. The number of ends played is decided by club rules. A typical game has 14 ends in social games and 18 in tournaments.

Term.Title: End (Curling)
Term.Description: In an end, each team throws 8 rocks, 2 per player in alternating fashion. Tournament style games usually run for 10 ends. Games played at the club level usually run for 8 ends.

Term.Title: End Line
Term.Description: The white line that runs along both ends of the table. Important for determining if a ball is in or out of bounds.

Term.Title: End of an Innings
Term.Description: A team's innings ends in one of the following ways. In cases 1 and 2, the team are said to be all out. All but one of the batsmen are out (dismissed). The batting side only has one not-out batsman who is still able to bat (the others are incapacitated through injury, illness or absence). The team batting last scores the required number of runs to win. The game runs out of time and so finishes as a draw. The set number of overs have been bowled (in limited overs cricket). The team's captain declares the innings closed. The Match Referee decides that one team has forfeited the game.

Term.Title: End of Financial Year
Term.Description: June 30th.

Term.Title: End Shot
Term.Description: The paddle speed is at its maximum when it hits the ball. The player tries to hit the ball right at the top of the balls bounce. This attempts to be a point, game or match ending shot.

Term.Title: End to End Footy
Term.Description: Game / activity where two groups indiscriminantly kick the ball back and forth between them and compete for possession of the ball on an individual basis.

Term.Title: End Zone

Term.Title: Endboards (Ice Hockey)

Term.Title: Endogenous

Term.Title: Endomorph

Term.Description: The capacity to perform work for an extended time, ability to bear fatigue.

Term.Description: The middle rowers in the boat. In an 8-person shell, these are generally seats 6, 5, 4 and 3. They are generally the biggest and strongest rowers, who provide most of the power to the boat.

Ensign

Term.Title: Equestrian (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Although used for many years for rehabilitation and recreation, equestrian as a sport was included in the program of the Paralympic Games for the first time in Atlanta in 1996. Equestrian is a multi-disability sport open to athletes with a physical disability or a visual impairment. Events are mixed and grouped according to their functional profiles. Riders compete in two Dressage events, a Championship Test of set movements and a Freestyle Test to music. There is also a Team test for three to four riders per team. Competitors are judged on their display of horsemanship skills as they ride their horse using a series of commands for walk, trot and canter. Riders may use permitted assistive devices such as dressage crops, a connecting rein bar, rubber bands or other aids. Since 2006, the International Equestrian Federation is the governing body for equestrian.

Term.Title: Erythropoiesis
Term.Description: The process by which red blood cells (erythrocytes) are produced. It is stimulated by decreased O2 in circulation, which is detected by the kidneys, which then secrete the hormone erythropoietin. This hormone stimulates proliferation and differentiation of red cell precursors, which activates increased erythropoiesis in the hemopoietic tissues, ultimately producing red blood cells.

Term.Title: Erythropoietin

Term.Title: Escape
Term.Description: The wrestler who was on the bottom is able to escape and get to his feet and face his rival.

Term.Title: Escape Point
Term.Description: When a wrestler is able to get out from a bottom position and stand and face the other wrestler. You get points for this because it should be hard to do.

Term.Description: Ethylestrenol (Maxibolin, Orabolin) is an anabolic steroid with some progesterone-like activity, and little androgenic activity. It is a nandrolone derivative and lacks the 3-keto functional group.

Term.Title: eTID
Term.Description: eTID is an online electronic talent identification tool that is simple to use, free and allows anyone (aged 12-29) to assess their sporting potential. eTID is the brainchild of the Australian Sports Commission's successful National Talent Identification and Development (NTID) program which seeks to identify and develop Australia's future sporting talent. This interactive website allows users to enter in results for a series of simple 'home based' performance tests and measurements which can be used to help identify athletes for selection in NTID development programs. Accessible to anyone, anywhere, anytime, eTID provides opportunities for aspiring or current athletes and even former elite athletes looking to start a new sport. The General Tests section caters for would-be champions aged 12-25 whilst the Sport Specific and Elite Athlete sections will consider athletic hopefuls up to the age of 29. If your results are identified as above average you will be encouraged to visit a Talent Assessment Centre (TAC) to have your results verified. After assessment, you may then be able to enter the elite sporting system, where you could be supported with coaching, equipment and travel.

Term.Title: Etihad Stadium
Term.Description: Docklands VIC 3008

Term.Title: Etoile de Besseges
Term.Description: http://www.etoiledebesseges.com/

Term.Title: Euhydration
Term.Description: Normal state of body water content.

Eurosport
