Term.Title: Event
Term.Description: A particular game, meet or bout that takes place within a sporting competition.

Term.Title: Events Queensland
Term.Description: Events Queensland attracts, supports, grows and promotes successful events in Queensland, Australia.

Term.Title: Eversion
Term.Description: Rotation of the foot to turn the sole outwards.

Term.Title: Every Inch
Term.Description: The sweepers should be sweeping hard all the way down the ice. This is an order given by the Skip.

Term.Title: Evidence Act 1995
Term.Description: The Evidence Act defines what records can be used as evidence in a Commonwealth court. It was revised in1995 to include the legal use of electronic records as evidence in a court of law.

Term.Title: Evidentiary
Term.Description: Having the quality of proof or evidence.

Term.Title: Ex Gratia
Term.Description: Without legal obligation.

Term.Title: Ex Parte
Term.Description: An application to a court made in the absence of the other party.

Term.Title: Ex Parte Order
Term.Description: An order made by the court on behalf of one party without hearing and / or prior notification to the other party involved.

Term.Title: Ex Post Facto
Term.Description: Retrospectively.

Term.Title: Examinations
Term.Description: The act or process of testing pupils.

Term.Title: Excel
Term.Description: Software developed and manufactured by Microsoft Corporation that allows users to organize, format, and calculate data with formulas using a spreadsheet system broken up by rows and columns. Microsoft Excel usually comes bundled with Microsoft Office and is compatible with other applications offered in the suite of products. The first software program similar to Excel was released in 1982 and was called Multiplan.

Term.Title: Exchange (Racquetball)
Term.Description: When players are returning each other shots.

Term.Title: Exchange Rate
Term.Description: The ratio at which a unit of the currency of one country can be exchanged for that of another country.

Term.Title: Exchange Zone
Term.Description: The 20 metre section of a track inside which the baton must be passed from one runner to another during a relay race.

Term.Title: Executive
Term.Description: A person or group of persons having administrative or supervisory authority in an organisation.

Term.Title: Executive Director
Term.Description: A working director of an organization who is usually also its full-time employee, and has a specified decision making role.

Term.Title: Exemestane
Term.Description: An aromatase inhibitors.

Term.Title: Exercise
Term.Description: Something physical done or performed as a means of practice or training.

Term.Title: Exercise Bout
Term.Description: Period of exercise in one session.

Term.Title: Exercise Prescription
Term.Description: Exercise prescription is the referral of patients to exercise programmes. The term is also used to describe the development of exercise programs.

Term.Title: Exercise, Recreation and Sport Survey
Term.Description: See ABS reports 4156. and 4177. for information post 2010. Joint statistical initiative of the Australian Sports Commission and State and Territory Departments of Sport and Recreation, which was first conducted in 2001 and ceased in 2010. The ERASS collected information on the frequency, nature and type of activities of persons aged 15 years and over for exercise, recreation and sport during the 12 months prior to interview. Participation means active playing participation and does not include coaching, refereeing and spectating or activities related to work or household chores. http://www.ausport.gov.au/information/casro/ERASS

Term.Title: Australian government sport reports, policies and studies
4156.0 Sports and Physical Recreation a Statistical Overview, Australia
4177.0 Participation in Sport and Physical Recreation, Australia
Exhibition (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: Non-competition skating or a show. Exhibitions often feature elements banned in competition as well as spotlights and show lighting. Also the gala after a competition in which the highest placing skaters perform a show program.

Term.Title: Exhibition Drill
Term.Description: Exhibition Drill links compulsory and free choice movements to create an exciting drill-team performance.

Term.Title: Exhibitions
Term.Description: A public display of works, products, skills or objects of general interest.

Term.Title: Exogenous
Term.Description: Refers to a substance which is not ordinarily produced by the body naturally.

Term.Title: Expedite System
Term.Description: The Expedite System comes into effect if a game is unfinished after 15 minutes, unless both players and / or pairs of players have scored at least 19 points.

Term.Title: Expenditure
Term.Description: The act of disbursing something, especially funds. (http://dictionary.reference.com/)

Term.Title: Expense
Term.Description: Cost or charge.

Term.Title: Explosive strength
Term.Description: The ability to exert maximal forces in minimal time.

Term.Title: Exposure measures
Term.Description: The National Injury and Illness Database includes are wide variety of sports ranging from on-water sports (rowing, sailing, canoe/kayak) to in-water sports (diving, swimming, water polo) to athletics, cycling, field team sports (rugby 7s and hockey) and gymnastics. We propose the per available training days as the most pragmatic definition. Similarly to clinical epidemiological studies, this exposure should be normalised to a set amount of days. Therefore, we propose the exposure be reported in per 100 athlete training days as this is easily interpreted by a range of backgrounds from governing bodies personnel to coaches. For example, a coach with 10 athletes and an incidence rate of 0.5 shoulder injuries per 100 days can expect to see 5 shoulder injuries per 100 days of training. The per 1000 hours method, the accepted gold standard in the literature, requires further calculations for the coach estimation example. Furthermore, sports such as equestrian who are spread across 4 continents and train on multiple horses each day may not be able to provide the data in the same level as a swimming group using the same pool each day.

Term.Title: Data dictionary for the National Injury and Illness Database
Express
Term.Description: Direct, written or spoken.

Term.Title: Expunge
Term.Description: To totally destroy or erase something.

Term.Title: Extending
Term.Description: When the arm holding the weapon is straightened toward the target.

Term.Title: Extension (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: The way a body part is held in a stretched position.

Term.Title: Extension (Strength & Conditioning)
Term.Description: Straightening of a joint: a movement that returns a body segment to the anatomical position from a flexed position.

Term.Title: Extensor
Term.Description: Muscle that extends a limb or increases the joint angle.

Term.Title: Extensor Digitorum Muscles
Term.Description: Extends phalanges of each finger.

Term.Title: Extensor Hallicus
Term.Description: Extends toes and dorsiflexes foot.

Term.Title: External Oblique
Term.Description: Flex spine and / or compress abdomen, involved in activities such as abdominal curl exercises.

Term.Title: Extinguish
Term.Description: To wipe out, make non-existent.

Term.Title: Extra
Term.Description: An extra (sometimes called a sundry) is a run scored by a means other than a batsman hitting the ball. Other than runs scored off the bat from a no ball, a batsman is not given credit for extras and the extras are tallied separately on the scorecard and count only towards the team's score. A game with many extras is often considered as untidy bowling. Cconversely, a game having few extras is seen as tidy bowling.

Term.Title: Extra Ends
Term.Description: In the event of a tie after the prescribed number of ends, extra ends are played until the tie is broken.

Term.Title: Extra Man Offense
Term.Description: EMO. This is a man advantage that results when a player from the other team is in the penalty box.

Term.Title: Extra Point
Term.Description: A single point scored in a conversion attempt by making what would be a field goal during general play.

Term.Title: Extranet
Term.Description: Restricted network of computers that allows controlled access to a firm's internal information to authorized outsiders by connecting them (usually via Internet) to the firm's intranet.

Term.Title: Extreme sport
Term.Description: A general term for sports that are considered more dangerous due to equipment, speed, location, height, or level of skill or physical exertion required. Some sports are considered extreme purely in relation to the level of injury expected by a failure of the participant to correctly execute elements of the sport.

Term.Title: Eye Splice
Term.Description: A closed loop or eye at the end a line, rope, or cable.

Term.Title: Eyeshades (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: All competitors must wear eyeshades at all times on the court. At all major competitions, all players have their eyes covered by gauze patches under the supervision of the IBSA Goalball Technical Delegate. Penalties are given if a player touches the eyeshade during play. This ensures that the level of all players is equal.

Term.Title: Eyre Peninsula Sports Academy
Term.Description: http://www.plhs.sa.edu.au/epsa/pages/contacts.htm South Australia

Term.Title: F 51 (Athletics) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Similar to T 51. Minimal or no movement of legs and trunk, poor or absent sitting balance, significant weakness of hands, wrist elbow (extension) and also shoulder.

Term.Title: F 53 (Athletics) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Good shoulder, elbow, wrist and finger function, limited fine grip with wasting of the muscles in the hand. Have nearly normal grip with non-throwing arm.

Term.Title: F 54 (Athletics) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Normal arm function with no trunk or leg function. Shot, Discus and Javelin. Have no sitting balance and usually hold onto part of chair whilst throwing.

Term.Title: F 55 (Athletics) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Normal arm function, partial or normal trunk function; with no leg function. Fair to good sitting balance. Eg. Bilateral amputation of both legs at level of hip joint, paraplegia.

Term.Title: F 56 (Athletics) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Normal trunk and upper limb function. Reasonable hip function, may have some knee function. Good balance and movements backwards and forwards. Eg Bilateral high above knee amputees (short stump) or low level spinal cord injury.

Term.Title: F 57 (Athletics) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: If spinal cord injury, normal upper limb and trunk function. Normal hip and knee function, affected ankle function. May have one good leg and one bad leg. Good movement of trunk backwards and forwards, usually to one side. Can rise from a sitting to a standing position with assistance during the throw. Eg. Bilateral above knee amputations (long stump) or single amputation at level of hip joint.

Term.Title: F 58 (Athletics) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Seated. Better function than F57 athletes, but not enough to stand to throw. If Spinal cord injury, normal upper limb and trunk strength, normal hip and knee function and nearly normal ankle function. Must meet minimal disability criteria.

Term.Title: Face Dodging
Term.Description: A player cradles the ball with the stick across their face in order to avoid a stick-poking defender.

Term.Title: Face Off
Term.Description: A linesman drops the puck between two opposing players who face each other in the face-off circle. Each player tries to hit or draw the puck to one of the players on his team.

Term.Title: Face Off Circles
Term.Description: There are five circles each with a radius of 15 feet, which are drawn on the ice: two in each team's defensive zone and one in the middle of the rink.

Term.Title: Face Plant
Term.Description: To fall onto one's face during a crash.

Term.Title: Facebook
Term.Description: Facebook is a social networking service and website since 2004, operated and privately owned by Facebook Inc.

Term.Title: Facemask
Term.Description: The cage like structure that is placed across the front of the helmet that players wear. Players can see out but the mask helps to protect the players face from being slammed into the ground and so protects the players face from injury.

Term.Title: Facemask Penalty
Term.Description: When a player grabs the facemask of another player.

Term.Title: Facet Joint Pain
Term.Description: The facet joints are synovial joints which help support the weight and control movement between individual vertebrae of the spine.

Term.Title: Facility
Term.Description: Permanent, semi-permanent, or temporary commercial or government property such as a stadium, track, court or club built and established for the performance of one or more specific sporting activities or functions.

Term.Title: Fact sheet
Term.Description: A summary of information about a product, service,organisation, event or topic.

Term.Title: Fade
Term.Description: By using backspin a golfer can get the ball to start to the inside and then move back outside.

Term.Title: Fadeaway
Term.Description: A fadeaway shot is a variation on a set jump shot in which the shooter attempts his shot leaning backward, creating the effect of "fading away" from his defender.

Term.Title: FAI
Term.Description: The Fdration Aronautique Internationale (FAI) - The World Air Sports Federation, was founded in 1905. FAI activities include the establishment of rules for the control and certification of world aeronautical and astronautical records. FAI establishes regulations for air sporting events which are organised by member countries throughout the world.

Term.Title: Failure of Consideration
Term.Description: The inabiity or refusal of a contracting party to perform its side of a bargain.

Term.Title: Fair Catch
Term.Description: An unhindered catch of an opponent's kick. The player wanting to make one must signal for a fair catch by waving an arm overhead while the ball is in the air. After that signal, if they gain possession of the ball it is dead immediately and opponents will receive a fifteen yard penalty for hitting them.

Term.Title: Fair Use Rule
Term.Description: A law that authorizes the use of copyrighted materials for certain purposes without the copyright owner's permission. Generally, uses intended to further scholarship, education or an informed public are considered fair use.

Term.Title: Fairlead
Term.Description: A ring, hook or other device used to keep a line or chain running in the correct direction or to prevent it rubbing or fouling.

Term.Title: Fairway
Term.Description: The grass surface running from tee to green.

Term.Title: Fakie
Term.Description: Backwards. So "riding fakie" is riding backwards.

Term.Title: Falcon
Term.Description: An instance of the ball coming into contact with a person's head.

Term.Title: Falkland Islands
Term.Description: Country code = FK

Term.Title: Fall (Sailing)
Term.Description: The part of the tackle that is hauled upon.

Term.Title: Fall (Wrestling)
Term.Description: Called when both shoulders of a wrestler are held on the mat for a few seconds since this is the length of time it will take the referee to pronounce the word tombe. After the referee says tombe he then raises his hand, looks to the judge or mat chairman for confirmation, strikes the mat with his hand and blows the whistle. The match is over.

Term.Title: Fall Back
Term.Description: When a wrestler is able to score a take down by holding the other wrestler from behind and then falling over backwards.

Term.Title: Fall Down Mark
Term.Description: A mark 11 yards (10 metres) down the track from the starting line. If a skater falls down in this first 11 yards the starter might restart the race. However, if the fall was not caused by another skater or does not interfere with another skater, the starter will most likely not restart the race.

Term.Title: Fall Line
Term.Description: The direction gravity pulls a snowboarder when they are going down a slope.

Term.Title: Fall Off
Term.Description: To change the direction of sail so as to point in a direction that is more down wind.

Term.Title: Falling
Term.Description: A common clinical sign in severe ataxia and incoordination due to any cause; A sudden drop from a relatively erect to a less erect position.

Term.Title: Falling on the Puck
Term.Description: A minor penalty, which occurs when a player other than the goalie closes their hand on the puck, deliberately falls on the puck, or gathers the puck under their body while lying on the ice.

Term.Title: Falls
Term.Description: If a skier falls on the Inrun their point total will have 20 points deducted, if they fall anywhere else on the jump they will have 12 points deducted from their total score.

Term.Title: False Attack
Term.Description: A movement to test the reflexes and reaction of an opponent.

Term.Title: False Flat
Term.Description: A low-gradient climb, usually occurring partway up a steeper climb. So-called because while it may look deceptively flat and easy especially after the steep climb preceding it, it is still a climb.

Term.Title: False Start (Athletics)
Term.Description: Moving or leaving the starting blocks or line before the gun goes off.

Term.Title: False Start (Gridiron)
Term.Description: When an offensive player moves before the ball is snapped.

Term.Title: False Start Rope
Term.Description: This is a rope that is 49 feet (15 metres) away from the starting line and if there is a false start the rope falls in the water.

Term.Title: Family name
Term.Description: That part of a name a person usually has in common with some other members of his/her family, as distinguished from his/her given names, as represented by text - AIHW

Term.Title: Fan Spiral
Term.Description: A spiral position in which the free leg is lifted, held upwards in front of the body, and lowered, in the style of an opening and closing Japanese fan.

Term.Title: Fantail
Term.Description: Aft end of the ship.

Term.Title: Fantasy Football
Term.Description: An activity or game in which the participants (often called owners or managers) each draft, on their own or with the aid of online software, a team of real-life players and then score points based on those players' statistical performance on the field.

Term.Title: Far West Academy of Sport
Term.Description: http://www.dsr.nsw.gov.au/

Term.Title: Faroe Islands
Term.Description: Country code = FO

Term.Title: Fartlek
Term.Description: A term derived from Swedish, literally meaning speed play. A fartlek is any of the several types of training during which the runner varies the pace frequently over the course of a continuous run.

Term.Title: Fast
Term.Description: Fastened or held firmly.

Term.Title: Fast Bowler
Term.Description: Fast bowling, sometimes known as pace bowling, is one of the two main approaches to bowling in the sport of cricket. The other is spin bowling. Practitioners are usually known as fast bowlers or pace bowlers although sometimes the label used refers to the specific fast bowling technique the bowler prefers, such as swing bowler or seam bowler. The main aim of fast bowling is to bowl the hard cricket ball at high speed and to induce it to bounce off the pitch in an erratic fashion or move sideways through the air, factors which make it difficult for the batsman to hit the ball cleanly.

Term.Title: Fast Bowling
Term.Description: A style of bowling in which the ball is delivered at high speeds, typically over 90 mph.

Term.Title: Fast Pitch
Term.Description: A straight pitch thrown by the pitcher as hard as possible.

Term.Title: Fast Pool
Term.Description: Refers to a pool that has all of the latest technology that will keep waves to a minimum and simply means that the swimmers can swim faster times in a fast pool.

Term.Title: Fast Twitch Fibre
Term.Description: A muscle fibre characterised by their fast contraction time, high anaerobic capacity and low aerobic capacity.

Term.Title: Fastball
Term.Description: A straight pitch thrown by the pitcher as hard as possible.

Term.Title: Fat Mass
Term.Description: The amount of fat, measured in grams, in the body.

Term.Title: Fat Side
Term.Description: Refers to the side of the ground which has more space on it.

Term.Title: Fathom
Term.Description: A unit of length equal to 6 feet (1.8 m) particularly used to measure depth.

Term.Title: Fatty Acid
Term.Description: Any of a class of aliphatic acids, especially palmitic, stearic, or oleic acid, consisting of a long hydrocarbon chain ending in a carboxyl group that bonds to glycerol to form a fat.

Term.Title: Fault (Badminton)
Term.Description: A violation of the playing rules that can happen when serving, receiving, or during play. There are service faults and general faults.

Term.Title: Fault Serve
Term.Description: An illegal serve when the ball hits the ceiling, back-wall, or two side-walls before it hits the floor. A fault can also occur when the ball fails to go over the short line.

Term.Title: FBD Insurance Ras
Term.Description: http://www.cyclesportnews.com

Term.Title: FBT
Term.Description: Fringe Benefits Tax - a tax applied within the Australian tax system by the Australian Taxation Office applied to employers who provide certain "fringe benefits" to employees.

Term.Title: Feasibility Study
Term.Description: Part of an investment decision making process, involves the examination of a particular project or business to assess its probability of operating successfully.

Term.Title: Feather (Rowing)
Term.Description: To turn the oar so that its blade is parallel with the water.

Term.Title: Featherweight Boxer
Term.Description: Featherweight boxers weigh up to 126lbs or 57.3kg.

Term.Title: Fed Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fedcup.com/en/home.aspx From 1963 to 1995 the Fed Cup was previously known as the Federation Cup.

Term.Title: Federal Golf Club
Term.Description: Canberra ACT 2601

Term.Title: Federation Cup
Term.Description: From 1963 to 1995 the Fed Cup was formerly known as the Federation Cup.

Term.Title: Federation Internationale de Roller Sports
Term.Description: International governing body for rollers sports. Originally formed in 1924 as the Federation Internationale de Patinage a Roulettes (FIPR).

Term.Title: Federation Internationale de Tir a L'Arc
Term.Description: http://www.archery.org/

Term.Title: Fee Simple
Term.Description: Full ownership rights in a piece of real estate.

Term.Title: Feed (Netball)
Term.Description: An exact pass into the shooting circle.

Term.Title: Feed Pass
Term.Description: An offensive play where one player passes the ball to a cutting teammate for a swift shot on goal.

Term.Title: Feed Zone
Term.Description: In road bicycle racing, a location along the course of a long race where team personnel hand musettes containing food and beverages to passing riders. In mountain bicycle racing, a limited section of the course in which riders may accept food from non-racing assistants. Sometimes this is combined with the technical assistance zone if one exists

Term.Title: Feeding the Scrum
Term.Description: To roll the ball into the scrum. Technically, the ball should enter the scrum via the tunnel formed by the front row forwards of the two teams binding together, with both teams able to strike for the ball, but a relaxed application of the rule is practised. The relaxed application allows players to roll the ball more directly into their team's side of the scrum thus reducing the chances of the other team successfully striking for the ball and gaining possession of it. "Feeding!" is an ironic accusation sometimes called out by spectators of a game in response to a player taking advantage of the modern application of the rule.

Term.Title: FEI Equestrian World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.feiworldcup.org/

Term.Title: Feint (Fencing)
Term.Description: A movement that is meant to deceive. It can be done with the arm, foot, leg or hand.

Term.Title: Feint Pass
Term.Description: When a player pretends to aim a pass in one direction and releases it in another.

Term.Title: Felony
Term.Description: Crime of a serious nature.

Term.Title: Female Athlete
Term.Description: An athlete who is legally defined as female within their country of representation.

Term.Title: Female Athlete Triad
Term.Description: Inter-relatedness of the three medical disorders in femaile athletes : amenorrhea, eating disorders and osteoporosis.

Term.Title: Female hyperandrogenism
Term.Description: Female or Intersex female athletes with elevated androgen production may be of concern within some competitive sports. In general, the performances of male and female athletes may differ mainly due to the fact that men produce significantly more androgenic hormones than women and, therefore, are under stronger influence of such hormones. Androgenic hormones have performance enhancing effects, particularly on strength, power and speed, which may provide a competitive advantage in sports. Within some sports and sport competitions investigations may be held to evaluate a suspected cases of female hyperandrogenism.

Term.Title: Femur Breadth
Term.Description: The distance between the medial and lateral epicondyles of the femur when the subject is seated and the leg flexed at the knee to form a right angle with the thigh.

Term.Title: Fencing World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.fencing.net

Term.Title: Fencing World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fencing.net

Term.Title: Fend
Term.Description: Fending is the action by the ball carrier of repelling a tackler using his arm. For the action to be legal, the ball carrier's arm must be straight before contact is made a shove or straight-arm smash, where the arm is extended immediately before contact or on contact, is illegal and classed as dangerous play.

Term.Title: Ferritins
Term.Description: An amber-colored, crystalline protein, found in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, that consists of apoferritin combined with a ferric hydroxide-ferric phosphate complex and that stores iron for use in metabolism.

Term.Title: Fetch
Term.Description: The distance across water which a wind or waves have traveled.

Term.Title: FFA Cup
Term.Description: Australia's premier knockout cup competition encompassing amateur, semi-professional and A-League clubs from all states and territories.
