Term.Title: FIBA World Basketball Championships
Term.Description: The FIBA World Championship is a world basketball tournament for men's national teams held quadrennially by the International Basketball Federation (FIBA). http://www.fiba.com

Term.Title: Federation Internationale de Basketball Amateur World Championships
Fiber Optic Cable
Term.Description: A cable made up of super-thin filaments of glass or other transparent materials that can carry beams of light.

Term.Title: Fiber Optic Sensors
Term.Description: A sensor that uses optical fiber either as the sensing element ("intrinsic sensors"), or as a means of relaying signals from a remote sensor to the electronics that process the signals ("extrinsic sensors").

Term.Title: Fibroblast Growth Factor
Term.Description: FGFs are a family of growth factors with members involved in angiogenesis, wound healing, embryonic development and various endocrine signaling pathways.

Term.Title: Fibromyalgia
Term.Description: Fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS or fibromyalgia) is a term used to describe a cluster of symptoms that may include widespread pain and tenderness in 'trigger points' on the body that are abnormally sore to touch.

Term.Title: FIBT
Term.Description: Federation Internationale de Bobsleigh et de Tobogganing (International Bobsleigh and Tobogganing Federation) http://www.fibt.com/

Term.Title: Federation Internationale de Bobsleigh et de Tobogganing
FIBT Bobsleigh World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.fibt.com/

Term.Title: Fiduciary
Term.Description: Institution or a person (such as a bank or executor) that is duty bound to act for the benefit of another person because it, he or she is in a position of trust or confidence.

Term.Title: FIE
Term.Description: Federation Internationale d'Escrime (International Fencing Federation) http://www.fie.ch/

Term.Title: Field (Football 7 a Side) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The field of play is roughly three quarters the size of a regular football pitch. It is a rectangular soft surface 75 metres long and 50 metres wide. For official national and international matches, the game must be played on a synthetic outdoor hockey field.

Term.Title: Field Archery
Term.Description: Use with Men's or Women's

Term.Title: Field Goal
Term.Description: A score of 3 points made by place or drop-kicking the ball through the opponent's goal other than via a kickoff or free kick following a safety.

Term.Title: Field Position
Term.Description: Refers to the place where the offense begins its offensive drive.

Term.Title: Fielding
Term.Description: Fielding in the sport of cricket is the action of fielders in collecting the ball after it is struck by the batsman, in such a way as to either limit the number of runs that the batsman scores or get the batsman out by catching the ball in flight or running the batsman out. A fielder or fieldsman may field the ball with any part of his person. However, if while the ball is in play he wilfully fields it otherwise (e.g. by using his hat), the ball becomes dead and 5 penalty runs are awarded to the batting side unless the ball previously struck a batsman not attempting to hit or avoid the ball. Most of the rules covering fielders are in Law 41 of the Laws of cricket.

Term.Title: FIFA
Term.Description: International governing body for the sport of football.

Term.Title: FIFA Confederations Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/index.html

Term.Title: FIFA Women's World Cup
Term.Description: International womens football competition contested by the national teams recognised by FIFA. The first World Cup was held in China in 1991 and has been held every four years since.

Term.Title: FIFA World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/index.html

Term.Title: FIFA World Cup
Term.Description: International football competition contested by the national teams recognised by FIFA. The first World Cup was held in Uruguay in 1930 and has been held every four years since (excepting between 1938-1950).

Term.Title: Fifth Ball Attack
Term.Description: A strategy that tries to win points on the fifth stroke. The sequence of hits would be: serve, return, well placed shot, return, kill.

Term.Title: Fifty Metre Arc
Term.Description: A line that placed 50 metres from each goal line. Because an Australian Rules Football field is oval in shape the 50 metre line is a radius. It is used as a reference point.

Term.Title: Fifty-Fifth
Term.Description: When the snowboard is slinding parallel to the coping.

Term.Title: FIG
Term.Description: Federation Internationale de Gynmastique (International Federation of Gymnastics) www.fig-gymnastics.com

Term.Title: Fight (Orienteering)
Term.Description: Vegetation that is difficult to run through or impassable (shown on the map with the darkest shade of green).

Term.Title: Orienteering Land Forms and Map Symbols
Fighting
Term.Description: Fighting can be a minor (roughing) penalty or a major penalty and a game misconduct. This is at the discretion of the Referee. A player who starts the fight will be assessed an instigating minor penalty, a major for fighting and a ten minute misconduct. Any player who is assessed a major and a game misconduct for being an instigator / aggressor of an altercation will have this recorded for statistical and suspension purposes.

Term.Title: Figure Skating rink
Term.Description: In Olympic competitions the rink is 196 feet (60 metres) long and 98 feet (30 metres) wide. In other competitions the rink will be between 183-196 feet (56-60 metres) long and 85-98 feet 26-30 metres wide.

Term.Title: Figures
Term.Description: A position where the swimmer's legs are above the water and their arms doing the propelling.

Term.Title: Fiji
Term.Description: Country code = FJ

Term.Title: FILA
Term.Description: Federation Internationale des Luttes Associees (International Federation of Associated Wrestling Styles) www.fila.com

Term.Title: File
Term.Description: A collection of related data or program records stored on some input / output or auxiliary storage medium.

Term.Title: File Format
Term.Description: The structure of a computer document that specifies how information is organized.

Term.Title: File Management
Term.Description: Creation and saving of an existing file manually or electronically.

Term.Title: Filing Failure
Term.Description: A failure by an athlete to file current and accurate whereabouts information in accordance with the rules of an IF and / or ASADA.

Term.Title: Fill the Port
Term.Description: To try and put a stone in the port, so that an opposing player can't play a stone through it.

Term.Title: FIM
Term.Description: Federation Internationale de Motocyclisme www.fim-live.com

Term.Title: FIM Speedway Motorcycling World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fim-live.com/en/

Term.Title: Fin Swimming
Term.Description: Finswimming is the progression of a swimmer using monofins or normal swimfins (called bifins or stereofins within the sport) either on the water surface or underwater, using only muscle strength. It is a discipline of underwater sports.

Term.Title: FINA
Term.Description: Federation Internationale de Natation (International Swimming Federation) www.fina.org

Term.Title: FINA 25m Swimming World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.fina.org/

Term.Title: FINA Grand Prix (Diving)
Term.Description: http://www.fina.org/

Term.Title: FINA Water Polo World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fina.org/

Term.Title: FINA Women's Water Polo World League
Term.Description: http://www.fina.org/

Term.Title: Federation Internationale de Natation Water Polo World League
FINA World Championships
Term.Description: http://www.fina.org/ The FINA World Championships or World Aquatics Championships are the World Championships for aquatic sports: diving, swimming, open water swimming, synchronized swimming and water polo. The pool swimming events are contested in a 50 m, or "long course", pool.

Term.Title: Federation Internationale de Natation Swimming World Championships
Federation Internationale de Natation World Championships
Final
Term.Description: A final is the race, match or other sporting event in which the overall winner of a competition is decided.

Term.Title: Finance 1
Term.Description: Accounting and financial software solution.

Term.Title: Financial Accounting
Term.Description: The field of accountancy concerned with the preparation of financial statements for decision makers.

Term.Title: Financial Asset
Term.Description: Economic resource.

Term.Title: Financial Guarantee Contracts
Term.Description: Under international financial reporting standards, a financial guarantee contract requires the issuer of the contract to make specific payments to the contract holder for a loss incurred by the holder if a debtor fails to pay under the terms of a debt instrument.

Term.Title: Financial Instruments
Term.Description: Either cash; evidence of an ownership interest in an entity; or a contractual right to receive, or deliver, cash or another financial instrument.

Term.Title: Financial Liability
Term.Description: A contractual obligation to deliver cash or similar to another entity or a potentially unfavorable exchange of financial assets or liabilities with another entity.

Term.Title: Financial Statements
Term.Description: Financial statements are a collection of reports about an organization's financial condition. Standard sets are balance sheets, income statements, statements of cash flows and supplementary notes.

Term.Title: Fine Orienteering
Term.Description: Precision navigation in detailed terrain usually demanding careful use of map, compass and pace counting, and usually involving short course legs.

Term.Title: Finger Roll
Term.Description: A finger roll is performed when a player shoots the ball with one hand during a layup and then lifts his fingers, rolling the ball into the basket.

Term.Title: Finish (Rowing Stroke)
Term.Description: That portion of the pull-through just as the oar is taken from the water.

Term.Title: Finish Judge (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: He is in charge of making sure the skaters finish the race in a legal manner.

Term.Title: Finish Judge (Swimming)
Term.Description: The finishing judge reports on the position (1,2,3 etc.) that the swimmers finish in.

Term.Title: Finish Symbol
Term.Description: If it shares the same location as the start, it will be a circle with a triangle inside. If its location is separate from the start, it is shown as a double circle (circle within a circle).

Term.Title: Finish Zone
Term.Description: The finish zone is the area between the Norm Point and the K point.

Term.Title: Finland
Term.Description: Country code = FI

Term.Title: FIRA
Term.Description: Federation Internationale de Rugby Amateur www.firaaer-rugby.com

Term.Title: Fireman's Carry
Term.Description: A takedown whereby a wrestler is taken over their opponent's shoulders and then is brought down to the mat.

Term.Title: Firewall
Term.Description: A software or hardware-based network security system that controls the incoming and outgoing network traffic based on applied rule set.

Term.Title: Firewire
Term.Description: A proprietary name for the internationally agreed standard IEEE1394, a high-performance interface which allows for the connection of peripherals such as modems, printers, and mass storage devices.

Term.Title: Firing Pin
Term.Description: The part of a gun's action which actually strikes the primer so as to set it off and initiate firing the cartridge's main charge of propellant.

Term.Title: Firing Point
Term.Description: The physical position from which shooting takes place.

Term.Title: Firmware
Term.Description: A microprogram stored in ROM, designed to implement a function that had previously been provided in software.

Term.Title: First Aid
Term.Description: Emergency aid or treatment given to someone injured, suddenly ill, etc., before regular Medical services arrive or can be reached.

Term.Title: First and Goal
Term.Description: When a team has the ball inside their opponent's 10-yard line and they have a first down.

Term.Title: First Base (Softball Positions)
Term.Description: First base, or 1B, is the first of four stations on a baseball diamond which must be touched in succession by a baserunner in order to score a run for that player's team. A first baseman is the player on the team playing defense who fields the area nearest first base, and is responsible for the majority of plays made at that base.

Term.Title: First Base Player
Term.Description: First base, or 1B, is the first of four stations on a baseball diamond which must be touched in succession by a baserunner in order to score a run for that player's team. A first baseman is the player on the team playing defense who fields the area nearest first base, and is responsible for the majority of plays made at that base.

Term.Title: First Base Player (Softball Player)
Term.Description: First base, or 1B, is the first of four stations on a baseball diamond which must be touched in succession by a baserunner in order to score a run for that player's team. A first baseman is the player on the team playing defense who fields the area nearest first base, and is responsible for the majority of plays made at that base.

Term.Title: First Baseman
Term.Description: First base, or 1B, is the first of four stations on a baseball diamond which must be touched in succession by a baserunner in order to score a run for that player's team. A first baseman is the player on the team playing defense who fields the area nearest first base, and is responsible for the majority of plays made at that base.

Term.Title: First Down
Term.Description: The first of a set of four downs in which the offense team needs to move the ball 10 yards closer to their own goal.

Term.Title: First Kick
Term.Description: Instantaneous velocity of vertex of head at first flexion of knee (dolphin kick) or separation of feet (flutter kick).

Term.Title: First Receiver
Term.Description: The first receiver is the name given to the first player to receive the ball off the ruck.

Term.Title: First Slip
Term.Description: In the sport of cricket, a slip fielder (collectively, a slip cordon or the slips) is placed behind the batsman on the off side of the field. They are placed with the aim of catching an edged ball which is beyond the wicket-keeper's reach. Many teams employ two or three slips (numbered from the slip fielder closest to the wicket-keeper: first slip, second slip, etc.). A floating slip is sometimes employed, usually in limited over games, who patrols an area in the slip cordon that would ordinarily be occupied by more than one fielder. The slip cordon's distance from the batsman increases with the pace of the bowler. Generally they will be marginally further away from the batsman than the wicketkeeper is. Because of the resulting geometry, spin bowlers generally have fewer slips in the cordon than a fast bowler would in an equivalent game situation. As fielding in the slips requires quick reflexes and sure hands, usually the most adept catchers in the team will make up the slip cordon. Most slip fielders are top order batsmen. Specialist slip fielders are sometimes called slippers.

Term.Title: First Stroke
Term.Description: Instantaneous velocity of vertex of head when hands part to commence stroke cycle.

Term.Title: FIS
Term.Description: Federation Internationale de Ski - includes Alpine, Nordic Combined, Cross Country, Freestyle, Ski Jumping and Snowboarding.

Term.Title: FIS Cross Country World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fis-ski.com/

Term.Title: FIS Hotham Australia New Zealand Cup (skiing)
Term.Description: http://www.mthotham.com.au

Term.Title: FISA
Term.Description: Federation Internationale des Societes d'Aviron (International Rowing Federation) www.worldrowing.com

Term.Title: FISA World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.worldrowing.com/

Term.Title: FISA World Rowing Championships
Term.Description: http://www.worldrowing.com/

Term.Title: Fiscal Year
Term.Description: Fiscal year is the twelve-month period over which an entity reports on the activities that appear in its annual financial statements.

Term.Title: Fistmele
Term.Description: The proper distance between the handle of a bow and the bow string when the bow is strung.

Term.Title: FITA
Term.Description: Federation Internationale De Tir A L'arc (International Archery Federation) www.fita.org

Term.Title: Federation Internationale de Tir a L'Arc
Fitness trainer
Term.Description: A qualified instructor that provides advice and guidance on exercise and training routines to promote increased strength, flexibility and performance.

Term.Title: FItout
Term.Description: The process of refurbishing a workplace internally. Includes painting, floor coverings, furnishings, furniture, fittings and equipment.

Term.Title: FIVB
Term.Description: Federation Internationale de Volleyball www.fivb.org

Term.Title: FIVB World Tour (Beach Volleyball)
Term.Description: http://www.fivb.ch/en/beachvolleyball/

Term.Title: Five Foot Line
Term.Description: The short, red line on the floor or side-wall that is five feet behind the short line of the service box.

Term.Title: Five Metre Scrum
Term.Description: When a scrum offence is committed within 5m of either try line, or a player carries the ball over their own try line and touches it down, the referee will award a scrum on the five metre line. This is to prevent all but the most brutal packs from driving the ball over the try line within the scrum.

Term.Title: Five-Forty
Term.Description: When a snowboarder rotates 540 degrees, a circle and a half, in the air and then lands riding fakie.

Term.Title: Five-one
Term.Description: Six player offense where a single designated setter sets regardless of court position.

Term.Title: Fixed Asset
Term.Description: Property, plant or equipment.

Term.Title: Fixed Gear Bicycle
Term.Description: A bicycle that has a drivetrain with no freewheel mechanism.

Term.Title: Fixed Term Employment
Term.Description: Fixed Term employees are engaged for either a specified period or until the happening of a specfied event that is stipulated in their employment contract.

Term.Title: Fixie
Term.Description: Slang for Fixed Gear Bicycle.

Term.Title: Fixture
Term.Description: Anything attached to a house or land which is considered a part of the property.

Term.Title: Flag (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A weighted yellow cloth thrown by a field official to indicate that a foul has been committed; the weighted red flag that an NFL head coach throws throws onto the field to alert officials that he is challenging a call on the field.

Term.Title: Flagrant Foul
Term.Description: A flagrant foul is a serious contact foul involving unnecessary and / or excessive and / or intentional contact.

Term.Title: Flail
Term.Description: When a snowboarder is riding out of control.

Term.Title: Flamingo
Term.Description: A position in which one leg is extended perpendicular to the surface with the other leg drawn to the chest and parallel to the surface and the swimmers face at the surface.

Term.Title: Flange
Term.Description: The bottom of a golf club.

Term.Title: Flanker
Term.Description: Also known as breakaways or wing forwards. They are the players wearing shirts numbers 6 & 7. They are the players with the fewest set responsibilities. The player should have all round attributes: speed, strength, fitness, tackling and handling skills. Flankers are always involved in the game, as they are the real ball winners at the breakdown, especially the number 7. The two flankers do not usually bind to the scrum in a fixed position. Instead, the openside flanker will attach to the scrum on whichever side is further from the nearer touchline, while the blindside flanker attaches themself to the scrum on the side closer to the touchline.

Term.Title: Flannels
Term.Description: The cream coloured clothing worn by a cricketer.

Term.Title: Flare
Term.Description: A hull cross section that grows wider as it rises from the waterline toward the gunwales.

Term.Title: Flat
Term.Description: A style of attacking play characterised by a lack of depth along the line of attacking players. More of the attacking team are in close proximity to defenders. The attackers look to take advantage of weaknesses created if defenders cannot organise themselves and allocate defenders to where they are needed. Weaknesses of this style of play include risk of passes being intercepted and a lack of speed in the attacking line.

Term.Title: Flat Bottom
Term.Description: The area in a half-pipe that is in-between the two opposite transitional walls.

Term.Title: Flat Pass
Term.Description: This type of pass involves the player in possession of the ball and a team mate being level when the pass is received. The player about to receive the ball may be running past the ball-carrier aiming for a gap in the defence.

Term.Title: Flat Pass
Term.Description: When a player passes the puck to a teammate along the surface of the ice.

Term.Title: Flatbed Scanner
Term.Description: A type of scanner or copier that uses a flat, glass surface for scanning documents or other objects.

Term.Title: Flatbow
Term.Description: A non-recurved bow with a rectangular cross section.

Term.Title: Flatland
Term.Description: A type of BMX course that consists of only flat land.

Term.Title: Flatliner
Term.Description: A player that hits the ball flat with no topspin.

Term.Title: Fleche
Term.Description: This is a quick running attack, which can be quite dramatic and amazing to watch.

Term.Title: Fleche Wallonne
Term.Description: http://www.cyclingfans.com/node/1853

Term.Title: Fleeing a Hold
Term.Description: A wrestler breaks off contact so his opponent is not able to get a hold.

Term.Title: Fleeing the Mat
Term.Description: A wrestler can move off the mat to get away from an attack from their opponent. This will result in a warning or in a penalty point.

Term.Title: Flemish
Term.Description: To coil a line that is not in use so that it lies flat on the deck.

Term.Title: Fletching
Term.Description: Fletching are the three or four feathers near the back of the arrow. The fletching should be tight and smooth to allow a precise flight by the arrow. Damaged fletching could hurt the trajectory of the arrow. Fletchings are also called vanes.

Term.Title: Flex (Golf)
Term.Description: The amount a club's shaft bends when it is swung.

Term.Title: Flex Point
Term.Description: The part of a club's shaft that will flex the most.

Term.Title: Flexibility
Term.Description: The range of motion about a joint, opposition or resistance of a joint to motion.

Term.Title: Flexible Boot
Term.Description: A soft boot that is flexible. It is used in freestyle and freeride snowboarding.

Term.Title: Flexible Budget
Term.Description: A flexible budget, itemizes different expense levels depending upon changes in the amount of actual revenue.

Term.Title: Flexible Work Arrangements
Term.Description: Agreed or permitted arrangements for the performance of work in ways that give employees flexibility in how, when and where the work is performed.

Term.Title: Flexion
Term.Description: The bending of a joint so that the bones forming the joint are brought closer together.

Term.Title: Flexor
Term.Description: Muscle the flexes a limb or decreases the joint angle.

Term.Title: Flexor Digitorum Muscles
Term.Description: Flex phalanges of each finger and flex hand at wrist.

Term.Title: Flexor Hallicus
Term.Description: Flexes toes and plantar flexes foot.

Term.Title: Flexor Pollicis
Term.Description: A muscle in the forearm and hand that flexes the thumb.

Term.Title: Flick (Badminton)
Term.Description: A quick wrist and forearm rotation, intended to surprise the opposition, because it changes a soft shot into a fast shot. This is used primarily on the serve and at the net.

Term.Title: Flick (Hockey)
Term.Description: When a player lifts the ball into the air with his / her stick. This stroke is used for shots on goal and for penalty shots.

Term.Title: Flight (Cricket)
Term.Description: Flight, also known as Loop, is a description of a kind of delivery in cricket, when a bowler makes the ball rise above eyeline, before it descends once again on its trajectory towards the batsman. Flight is a key weapon of spin bowlers. The term is also known as loop or giving the ball air.

Term.Title: Flight (Golf)
Term.Description: A ball while it is in the air and the direction it is going.

Term.Title: Flight (Ski Jumping)
Term.Description: When a skier jumps they lean forward and to reduce drag, the skier will have their skis form a V shape with the back of the skis together, this helps to provide lift to the skier and therefore a longer distance jumped. Once a skier has taken off from the jump, they are in the air for 2 to 3 seconds before they land.

Term.Title: Flight Phase
Term.Description: For a jumper, the period following takeoff during which the athlete enters a period of non-support.

Term.Title: Flighting
Term.Description: Flighting the ball is when a bowler in cricket deceives the batsman with subtle changes in the speed of delivery using almost identical bowling actions. This is almost always used by slow bowlers, as it requires the ball to be pushed forward or dropped short by looping the ball in the air.

Term.Title: Flinders University
Term.Description: http://www.flinders.edu.au/

Term.Title: Flip Jump (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: A toe-assisted figure skating jump that takes off from the back inside edge.

Term.Title: Flip Pass
Term.Description: When the puck is lifted in the air to go over an opponents stick in order to pass the puck to another player.

Term.Title: Flip Shot
Term.Description: A shot in which a player cups the puck in his stick then flips it with his wrists up off the ice towards the goal.

Term.Title: Flip Turn
Term.Description: When the swimmer gets near the wall and needs to turn around to start swimming back down the lane, they do a somersault, so there legs will be pointing toward the wall and they can get a powerful kick off the wall to propel them down the lane.

Term.Title: Flipper
Term.Description: The flipper is the name of a particular bowling delivery used in cricket, generally by a leg spin bowler. In essence it is a back spin ball. Squeezed out of the front of the hand with the thumb and first and second fingers, it keeps deceptively low after pitching and can accordingly be very difficult to play.

Term.Title: Float
Term.Description: Between two and eight swimmers are connected in a line horizontally and are performing on the surface of the water.

Term.Title: Float (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: A shot that looks similar to a shot that puts lots of spin on the ball, but this shot does not. It is meant to fool the other player so they will misplay the ball.

Term.Title: Floater
Term.Description: A kick which does not spin and floats through the air, or a handpass with a very high trajectory, giving opponents enough time to reach the target.

Term.Title: Floor Exercises
Term.Description: Use for: floor

Term.Title: Men's Artistic Gymnastics Commonwealth Games Events
Women's Artistic Gymnastics Commonwealth Games Events
Floorball
Term.Description: Floorball is a variant non-contact form of hockey first developed in Sweden. It is played indoors with 2 teams of 6 players.

Term.Title: Flop
Term.Description: An attempt by a player not involved in the completion of a tackle to delay the player in possession from getting to their feet quickly afterwards by falling on top of those involved. The referee can award a penalty to the attacking team when he sees this tactic.

Term.Title: Flop Style
Term.Description: Also known as the Fosbury Flop, this is a style of high jumping in which the jumper's back passes over the bar. The style was popularized by American Dick Fosbury, a gold medalist in 1968.

Term.Title: Floreat Oval
Term.Description: Floreat WA 6014

Term.Title: Flu
Term.Description: Influenza; an acute, commonly epidemic disease, occurring in several forms, caused by numerous rapidly mutating viral strains and characterized by respiratory symptoms and general prostration.

Term.Title: Fluorescein
Term.Description: An orange-red, crystalline, water-insoluble solid, C 20 H 12 O 5 , that in alkaline solutions produces an orange color and an intense green fluorescence: used to trace subterranean waters and in dyes.

Term.Title: Fluoxymesterone
Term.Description: An anabolic steroid with strong androgenic properties that has been used in the treatment of male hypogonadism, delayed puberty in males, and in the treatment of breast neoplasms in women.

Term.Title: Flush
Term.Description: Two or more pairs of flags that are placed on the ski course and they are set in a straight line.

Term.Title: Flush Deck
Term.Description: An upper deck of a vessel that extends unbroken from stem to stern.

Term.Title: Flutter
Term.Description: In head-to-head races, the coxswain may decide to call a flutter, which is essentially the six-stroke start put into the race close to the end.

Term.Title: Flutter Kicks
Term.Description: The legs move independently of each other, not in unison, in an up and down motion.

Term.Title: Fly Ball
Term.Description: A ball that is batted in a high arc, usually to the outfield.

Term.Title: Fly Ball (Baseball)
Term.Description: A ball that is batted in a high arc, usually to the outfield.

Term.Title: Fly half
Term.Description: Also referred to by a number of different names, they are the players wearing shirt number 10. This position is one of the most influential on the pitch. The fly-half makes key tactical decisions during a game. Generally a fly-half is also the goal kicker due to excellent kicking skills.

Term.Title: Fly Pattern
Term.Description: This is a pass pattern that has the receiver running fast down the sideline.

Term.Title: Fly Shot
Term.Description: A shot that is hit before it has a chance to bounce.

Term.Title: Flyer
Term.Description: In a relay race this means that the swimmer who is jumping into the pool after their partner touches base. A flyer leaves the starting block too soon, before their partner has touched the base, and the swimmers are disqualified from the race.

Term.Title: Flying Kangaroos
Term.Description: Women's Freestyle Skiing Team

Term.Title: Flying Mare
Term.Description: When a wrestler is able to grab their opponent's arm and use it as a lever to throw the other wrestler over their back.

Term.Title: Flying Shot
Term.Description: A player taking a shot or kick on the run at goal. Usually, the player will be in the air as their foot makes contact with the ball.

Term.Title: Flying Sit Spin
Term.Description: A combination movement when a jump spin is performed with the skater jumping and then going into a sitting position at the top of the jump, and they maintain this sitting position when they land.

Term.Title: Flying Spin (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: A jump that lands in a spinning position. Commonly performed flying spins include flying camel spins and flying sit spins.

Term.Title: Flying Squirrel Air
Term.Description: The first turn is a 90-degree spin in a front-side direction shifty style. Then the snowboarder bends their knees then both hands grab the heel edge and leans forward. To finish the trick the snowboarder lets go of their rear hand, and then after a brief pause they let go with the other. They then swing the board back with a 90-degree spin back or they do a front-side spin to complete the 180.

Term.Title: Flyweight Boxer
Term.Description: Flyweight boxers weigh a maximum of 112lbs or 50.9kg.

Term.Title: FMIS
Term.Description: Financial Management Information System.

Term.Title: Focus Group
Term.Description: A representative group of people questioned together about their opinions on political issues, consumer products, etc.

Term.Title: Foible
Term.Description: This is the weakest part of a sword. It is the part of the blade that is between the middle and moving forward to the point of the blade.

Term.Title: Foil
Term.Description: A thrusting sword with a flexible rectangular blade. Like the epee all of the foils touches are done with the tip.

Term.Title: Folding the Map
Term.Description: Orienteers fold their maps along the line of travel to aid concentration on the leg being run, and to facilitate thumbing their position.

Term.Title: Follow On
Term.Description: Follow-on is a term used in the sport of cricket to describe a situation where the team that bats second is forced to take its second batting innings immediately after its first, because the team was not able to get close enough (within 200 runs for a five-day match) to the score achieved by the first team batting in the first innings. In matches when each team has only one innings of batting, follow-on in such a case is obviously not applicable - it is found only in the longer (more traditional) two-innings each match.

Term.Title: Follow Through (Cricket)
Term.Description: The follow through is the motion of the bowler after releasing the ball.

Term.Title: Following Sea
Term.Description: Wave or tidal movement going in the same direction as a ship.

Term.Title: Fontainebleau Horse Trials
Term.Description: http://www.britisheventing.com/

Term.Title: Food Trick
Term.Description: Any aerial movement where the snowboarder grabs an edge of their snowboard.

Term.Title: Foot Stretcher
Term.Description: An adjustable footplate which allows the rower to easily adjust his or her physical position relative to the slide and the oarlock. The footplate can be moved (or "stretched") either closer to or farther away from the slide frontstops.

Term.Title: Football
Term.Description: Football is a sport played between two teams of eleven players with a round ball. The object of the sport is to score goals by moving the ball between the opposing teams goalposts. Football is played predominately with the feet and, aside from the goalkeepers, players are not permitted to touch the ball with their hands or arms while it is in play.

Term.Title: Football (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A football is 28 inches long, weighs 14 oz. and is made of leather and it has laces on one side. Twenty-four approved footballs can be used in each game, 12 each half.

Term.Title: Football 5-a-side (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Football 5-a-side made its Paralympic debut at the Athens Games in 2004 and is open to athletes with visual impairments. There are five players on each team and the game lasts 50 minutes. Rules are similar to the able-bodied game with a few modifications. The ball makes noise when it moves and everyone, aside from the goalkeeper, uses eye shades to ensure fairness. The goalkeeper may be sighted and act as a guide during the game. Also, the measurements on the field are smaller and there are no offside rulings. Football 5-a-side is governed by the Football Subcommittee of the International Blind Sports Federation (IBSA) using the rules of the International Federation of Associated Football (FIFA).

Term.Title: Football 7-a-side (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Football 7-a-side is a sport open to ambulant athletes with Cerebral Palsy, acquired brain injury or similar conditions. Each team of 7 players must have at least one FT5 or FT6 class athlete per team who must play throughout the match. If this is not possible, the team must play with six players. Furthermore, no more than two players from category FT8 are allowed to play at the same time.

Term.Title: Football Federation Australia
Term.Description: Established in 2004, Football Federation Australia (FFA) is the governing body for football in Australia.

Term.Title: Footballer
Term.Description: An athlete who plays Football.

Term.Title: Footchock
Term.Description: An alternate name for the cross bracing which allows a rower to secure his / her feet.

Term.Title: Footpass
Term.Description: When one player passes the ball to their teammate by kicking it to them.

Term.Title: Footplate
Term.Description: The piece of the boat to which the rower's feet are attached, either by tying their actual shoes in, or (more often) by putting their feet into a permanently attached pair of shoes.

Term.Title: Footstop
Term.Description: The shoe assembly in a shell into which each rower laces his or her feet.

Term.Title: Footwork Rule
Term.Description: Restricts movement of player in possession of the ball.

Term.Title: Footy
Term.Description: The name for Australian Football in the southern states; it refers to Rugby League football in Sydney and Brisbane. Also the name of the ball itself.

Term.Title: Footy Park
Term.Description: Football Stadium.

Term.Title: Footy Tipping
Term.Description: Form of syndicated Australian gambling competition which is based on the results of a teams' performances in a sporting competition over a season. Footy tipping is most often played based on the team results within the AFL and NRL, but may also be used for other sporting competitions or leagues.

Term.Title: Force
Term.Description: A force is any influence that causes a free body to undergo a change in speed, a change in direction, or a change in shape. Force can also be described by intuitive concepts such as a push or pull that can cause an object with mass to change its velocity (which includes to begin moving from a state of rest), i.e., to accelerate, or which can cause a flexible object to deform.

Term.Title: Force out
Term.Description: An out created when a runner is forced to advance because there is another runner behind them, although they will be thrown or tagged out. The defensive player needs only to touch the base being approached by the runner with the ball in hand to record the out.

Term.Title: Force Plate
Term.Description: A force plate is a measuring instrument that measures the ground reaction forces generated by a body standing on or moving across it, to quantify balance, gait and other parameters of biomechanics.

Term.Title: Force sensors
Term.Description: A force sensor is a transducer that converts an input mechanical force into a electrical output signal.

Term.Title: Ford Ranger Cup
Term.Description: http://cricket.com.au/

Term.Title: Fore
Term.Description: Players shout fore when a ball is headed toward another player.

Term.Title: Forecast
Term.Description: Ancipation of likely future business performance, often based on previous performance.

Term.Title: Forecheck
Term.Description: When a forward harasses the opposition in the opposition's defensive zone.

Term.Title: Foreclose
Term.Description: Termination of rights in a mortgage by taking and selling the property to pay the debt.

Term.Title: Forecourt (Badminton)
Term.Description: The front third of the court, located between the short service line forward to the net.

Term.Title: Forehand (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: To shoot the puck in a forward motion.

Term.Title: Forehand Draw
Term.Description: When the bowl is aimed to the right of the Jack, and curves to the left.

Term.Title: Forehand Drive
Term.Description: A shot that generates lots of force and speed on the ball. This drive comes from the shoulder and the player moves their paddle upward and attempts to hit the ball when it is at its highest point.

Term.Title: Forehand Push
Term.Description: This shot is used to return balls that are hit low or have a lot of backspin on them. The player, like in the backhand stroke, uses a short stroke, but this time the paddle face is open allowing some backspin to be put on the ball.

Term.Title: Foreign Currency
Term.Description: Something that is used as a medium of exchange - money - from a country other than the one in which the business is taking place.

Term.Title: Foreign Exchange
Term.Description: A form of currency used to make payments between entities located in different countries.

Term.Title: Forestays
Term.Description: Long lines or cables, reaching from the bow of the vessel to the mast heads, used to support the mast.

Term.Title: Forfeit
Term.Description: To lose or give up something as a penalty for a crime, for breach of a contract or neglect of a duty.

Term.Title: Form
Term.Description: A printed / electronic document with spaces in which to fill details or answers.

Term.Title: Form Line
Term.Description: An intermediate contour line showing distinct terrain variations, mapped as a dashed brown line.

Term.Title: Orienteering Land Forms and Map Symbols
Formation (Football)
Term.Description: How the players in a team are positioned on the pitch.

Term.Title: Formation (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A formation is the way in which the players position themselves, where they stand, what opposing player they will guard, during a play.

Term.Title: Formebolone
Term.Description: An anabolic steroid.

Term.Title: Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYROM)
Term.Description: Country code = MK

Term.Title: Formestane
Term.Description: A type I steroidal aromatase inhibitor.

Term.Title: Forms
Term.Description: Printed or typed documents with blank spaces for insertion or required or requested information.

Term.Title: Formula 1 (Motor Sport)
Term.Description: http://www.formula1.com

Term.Title: Formula Windsurfing Nationals
Term.Description: http://www.windsurfing.org/

Term.Title: Forte
Term.Description: This is the strongest part of the blade and it is the part of the blade that is used to parry with. It is that part of the blade starting about halfway and moving down to the bottom of the blade where it meets the guard.

Term.Title: Forum
Term.Description: A meeting or assembly, in person or online, for the open discussion of a particular subject.

Term.Title: Forum Sports and Aquatic Centre
Term.Description: Newcastle University NSW 2308

Term.Title: Forward (Canoe / Kayak)
Term.Description: Normal paddle stroke (paddle pulls straight through water).

Term.Title: Forward (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: A rugby league forward pack consists of players who tend to be bigger and stronger than backs, and generally rely more on their strength to fulfil their roles than play-making skills.

Term.Title: Forward Defence
Term.Description: The forward defence is one of the most commonly-used shots in cricket. Played to a good length ball, the batsman attempts to defend his wicket by smothering the ball before it has had much opportunity to spin or move off the seam. With a well-bent front knee, the shot can also help combat variable bounce. Whilst the shot is a defensive one, there can be opportunities to score from it, if the shot is particularly well-timed, or if the batsmen run a quick single.

Term.Title: Forward Lean
Term.Description: High-back soft bindings keep the snowboarders ankles bent in a forward, leaning position.

Term.Title: Forward Line
Term.Description: Consists of two wings (right and left) and a center. These three players play nearer the opponents goal and are responsible for most of the scoring.

Term.Title: Forward Pass (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A pass that touches a person, object, or the ground closer to the opponent's end line than where it was released from, or is accidentally lost during a forward throwing motion.

Term.Title: Forward Pass (Rugby)
Term.Description: It is called a throw-forward in the laws of the game. A forward pass occurs when the ball fails to travel backwards in a pass. If the ball is not thrown or passed forward but it bounces forward after hitting a player or the ground, it is not a throw-forward. If the referee deems it accidental, this results in a scrum to the opposing team, however deliberate forward passes result in the award of a penalty.

Term.Title: Forward Pocket
Term.Description: The Forward Pocket's job is to help the Full Forward. They do this by getting the Full Forward the ball and then they do whatever else they can to help them score points. The Forward Pockets are the Full Forwards linemates.

Term.Title: Forward Pockets
Term.Description: The Full-forward's linemates. They help a player to get or recover the ball in the offensive zone and assist them when they are attempting to score.

Term.Title: Forward Progress
Term.Description: The location to which a ball carrier's forward momentum carries them before they are tackled. At the end of a play, the football is spotted at the point where the ball carriers forward progress is stopped, even if they are pushed backward by the defenders.

Term.Title: Foul (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: Any infraction of the rules that will draw a penalty.

Term.Title: Foul Ball
Term.Description: A ball that lands outside the first or third base foul lines.

Term.Title: Foul Lines
Term.Description: Lines extending from home plate through 1st and 3rd base to the outfield fence and perpendicularly upwards. These actual lines are considered in play.

Term.Title: Foundation
Term.Description: Sports with a record of achieving multi-medal or consistent team medals at Olympic, Paralympic, world championships or Commonwealth Games level. These sports are expected to make the largest contribution towards Australias Winning Edge targets.

Term.Title: Founder
Term.Description: To fill with water and sink.

Term.Title: Four Foot Ring
Term.Description: The 4-foot-diameter (1.2 m) circle in the house. It surrounds the centre area called the button. It is used as a visual aid only - there is no extra score for placing a stone within it.

Term.Title: Four Nations
Term.Description: Replaces Rugby League Tri Nations series. http://www.rlfournations.com/

Term.Title: Four Nations Cup (Golf)
Term.Description: http://www.rcga.org/fournationscup

Term.Title: Four Point Landing
Term.Description: When a skier is able to plant both poles when they land after having taken off from a jump.

Term.Title: Four Point Takeoff
Term.Description: When the skier plants both poles when they take off from a mogul.

Term.Title: Fourth Down
Term.Description: The final of a set of four downs. Unless a first down is achieved or a penalty forces a replay of the down, the team will lose control of the ball after this play. If a team does not think they can get a first down, they often punt on fourth down or kick a field goal if they are close enough to do so.

Term.Title: Fourth Down Conversion
Term.Description: The act of using a fourth down play to make a first down.

Term.Title: Four-Two
Term.Description: A 6-player offensive system using four hitters and two setters.

Term.Title: Foward Somersault
Term.Description: The skier is on level ground and they put all their weight on one ski, they then lift the other ski off the ground, maintaining their balance and putting their weight on their ski poles they then lift their other ski off the ground and then they do a somersault.

Term.Title: Fox Sports
Term.Description: Fox Sports is an Australian group of sports channels owned by the Premier Media Group, which is owned by News Corp and consolidated Media Holdings.

Term.Title: Fracture
Term.Description: The breaking of a bone, cartilage, or the like, or the resulting condition.

Term.Title: Frame
Term.Description: The playing of all the bocce balls in one direction and the awarding of points. After points are awarded a new frame starts in the opposite direction. Frames are played until sufficient points are accumulated to win the game. A frame is sometimes called a Giro.

Term.Title: Frameset
Term.Description: The bicycle frame plus the front fork.

Term.Title: Framework
Term.Description: A skeletal structure designed to support something.

Term.Title: France
Term.Description: Country code = FR

Term.Title: Franchise
Term.Description: A business arrangement in which knowledge, expertise and often a trade mark or trade name is licensed to an operator, generally for an initial fee and a yearly payment.

Term.Title: Frankston Yacht Club
Term.Description: Frankston VIC 3199

Term.Title: Fraud
Term.Description: Deceit, trickery, sharp practice, or breach of confidence, perpetrated for profit or to gain some unfair or dishonest advantage.

Term.Title: Freak Ball
Term.Description: When the ball moves in an unexpected way after hitting a wall.

Term.Title: Free
Term.Description: Short for free kick.

Term.Title: Free Agent
Term.Description: When a player no longer has a contract with any one team and can sign a contract with any team that they wants or any team who wants them..

Term.Title: Free Ball
Term.Description: A ball that is passed over the net because an attack wasn't possible.

Term.Title: Free Guard Zone
Term.Description: An area after the Hog Line and in front of the house where the first two players may place their stones to block a clean shot to the house. The first two players on each team are not allowed to move the other teams stones that are in the free zone.

Term.Title: Free Hand
Term.Description: The free hand is the hand that does not have the paddle in it. The free hand throws the ball in the air when a player is serving. On a serve the free hand must stay behind the end line of the table until the player receiving the serve has returned the ball back over the net.

Term.Title: Free Hit (Cricket)
Term.Description: Free hit is a cricket terminology, relevant in one day internationals and Twenty20 matches. When a bowler bowls a front-foot no ball, in the immediate next ball, the batsman cannot be ruled out in any dismissal modes, other than run out, handling the ball, hitting the ball twice and obstructing the field. This freedom enables the batsman to play a powerful shot without the fear of getting out caught, bowled or leg before. For this reason, the delivery immediately after a front-foot no ball is called a free hit. It came into International Cricket in October 2007.

Term.Title: Free Hit (Hockey)
Term.Description: A play awarded to a team when the opposition commits any infraction outside of the shooting circle. It takes place at or near the spot of the infraction, and all opposing players must stand at least five yards away from the player taking the hit.

Term.Title: Free Kick (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A kick made to put the ball in play as a kickoff or following a safety or fair catch.

Term.Title: Free Kick (Rugby)
Term.Description: Also called short arm penalty. This is a lesser form of the penalty, usually awarded to a team for a technical offence committed by the opposing side such as numbers at the line-out or time wasting at a scrum. A free kick is also awarded for calling a mark. A team cannot kick for goal and the normal 22m rule applies for kicking for position from a free kick. A Free Kick is signalled by the referee with a bent arm raised in the air.

Term.Title: Free Leg (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: The leg that is not on the ice.

Term.Title: Free pass
Term.Description: Awarded to opposing team for penalty incurred.

Term.Title: Free Position
Term.Description: After a foul the player who has been fouled is allowed to position themselves anywhere they wish 8 metres from the crease. If the foul was a major foul all of the other players must stand at least 4 meters behind the player taking the free position. On a minor foul they are allowed to stand four meters to the side. A referee puts the ball in the head of the stick of the player taking the free position who then can pass or shot the ball or run with the ball.

Term.Title: Free Radical
Term.Description: In chemistry, radicals (often referred to as free radicals) are atoms, molecules, or ions with unpaired electrons on an otherwise open shell configuration. These unpaired electrons are usually highly reactive, so radicals are likely to take part in chemical reactions. Radicals play an important role in combustion, atmospheric chemistry, polymerization, plasma chemistry, biochemistry, and many other chemical processes, including human physiology.

Term.Title: Free Space to Goal
Term.Description: A lane to the goal within the critical scoring area. This is an imaginary lane that is drawn by two lines running from the ball to the perimeter of the goal circle.

Term.Title: Free Weights
Term.Description: weights that are not part of an exercise machine

Term.Title: Freeboard
Term.Description: The vertical distance measured from a boat's waterline to the lowest part of its gunwale.

Term.Title: Freedom of Information
Term.Description: FOI; Obtaining access to information held as records by government agencies, government ministers and other public bodies in accordance with Freedom of Information (FOI) legislation. Includes policy and procedural rules regarding Freedom of Information.

Term.Title: Freedom of Information Act 1982
Term.Description: The FOI Act was brought about to provide the public with legal access to official information as well as promote Government accountability. It also provides individuals with the right to apply for amendments to information that may be misleading or untrue.

Term.Title: Free-riding
Term.Description: Snowboarding that is done in any type of terrain.

Term.Title: Freestyle
Term.Description: The swimmer swims on their stomach, their back above the top of the water. The swimmers arms are moving in alternating strokes and the swimmers legs are going in a non-stop, flutter kick, kicking motion.

Term.Title: Swimming for the Disabled terms and techniques
Freestyle (Snowboard)
Term.Description: Snowboarding that includes tricks. The snowboarder is performing these tricks to practice them or they are, usually, performing in a competitive venue.

Term.Title: Freestyle Technique (Cross Country Skiing)
Term.Description: A skier will push the inside edge of their ski in one motion backward and outward at approximately a 45-degree angle.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Freestyle World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.fis-ski.com

Term.Title: Freestyle Wrestling
Term.Description: A type or style of wrestling where competitors can use both their arms and legs to perform holds.

Term.Title: Freewheel
Term.Description: The part of the rear gear cluster that allows a bike to coast without the pedals turning.

Term.Title: Freeze
Term.Description: A type of draw that ends up and stops right in front of and next to another rock, without moving it.

Term.Title: Freeze the Puck
Term.Description: When a player pushes the puck against the boards so that it can't be played. The goaltender can also freeze the puck in the goal crease by covering it up.

Term.Title: Fremantle Dockers
Term.Description: Australian Football League Club Team.

Term.Title: Fremantle Rowing Club
Term.Description: http://www.rowingwa.asn.au

Term.Title: French Open
Term.Description: http://www.rolandgarros.com/en_FR/index.html

Term.Title: Les Internationaux de France de Roland Garros
French Polynesia
Term.Description: Country code = PF

Term.Title: Fresh Airy
Term.Description: Missing the ball with the kick.

Term.Title: Fresh Fish
Term.Description: The backside version of a Stale Fish.

Term.Title: Fringe
Term.Description: The grass that is cut shorter then the fairway grass but is longer then the grass on the green. The fringe surrounds the green and separates it from the fairway.

Term.Title: Front and Back Formation
Term.Description: A way to position players when playing doubles. One player will line up in front of the other and the forward player has the responsibility of covering the front portion of the court area and the other player covers the back area of the court.

Term.Title: Front Court
Term.Description: The area in front of the service line.

Term.Title: Front Foot
Term.Description: The foot that is nearest the front or nose of the snowboard.

Term.Title: Front Foot Contact
Term.Description: Front foot contact is the position of the bowler at the moment when the front foot hits the ground just prior to delivering the ball. For a right-handed bowler the front foot is normally the left foot.

Term.Title: Front Hand
Term.Description: The hand that is nearest to the front or nose of the snowboard.

Term.Title: Front Layout
Term.Description: A swimmer is lying straight on the surface of the water on their stomach. The swimmers head can be either in or out of the water.

Term.Title: Front Nine
Term.Description: The first 9-holes on an 18-hole golf course.

Term.Title: Front Pike Position
Term.Description: The swimmer's head and torso are perpendicular to the surface of the water and the swimmers legs in a horizontal position to the surface of the water and on the surface of the water.

Term.Title: Front Row (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: The front row of the scrum includes the hooker with the two props on either side. All three may be referred to as front-rowers, but this term is most commonly just used for props.

Term.Title: Front Tuck
Term.Description: In a tuck position a skier does one front flip.

Term.Title: Front Walkover
Term.Description: The swimmer starts out lying flat on the surface of the water face down. The swimmer then moves into a front pike position and raises one leg and brings it completely over so their legs are doing a split. The swimmer brings the other leg over to be next to the first leg while simultaneously bring their head and torso to the surface of the water so they are now lying face up in the water.

Term.Title: Frontside
Term.Description: An air maneuver that is executed on the toeside wall of the half-pipe.

Term.Title: Frontside Handplant
Term.Description: A 180-degree handplant where the snowboarders front hand is planted on the lip of the wall of the half-pipe.

Term.Title: Frontside Mechanics
Term.Description: The movements of the running form that take place in front of the centre of mass.

Term.Title: Frontside Rotation
Term.Description: When a snowboarder rotates in the direction of their front heel.

Term.Title: Frontside Wall
Term.Description: The wall a snowboarder faces when riding straight down a half-pipe.

Term.Title: Frontstop
Term.Description: The stop mechanism on the seat slides which prevents the rower's seat from falling off the sliding tracks at the front end (towards the boat's stern) of the slide tracks.

Term.Title: Frostbite
Term.Description: Injury to any part of the body after excessive exposure to extreme cold, sometimes progressing from initial redness and tingling to gangrene.

Term.Title: Frozen Shoulder
Term.Description: Adhesive Capsulitis. Adhesive Capsulitis is the medical term for Frozen Shoulder sometimes abbreviated to FSS (frozen shoulder syndrome). This is a condition which affects the ability to move the shoulder, and usually only occurs on one side.

Term.Title: FT 5 (Football 7 a Side) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Athletes in this class generally have diplegia (both legs) or dystonia (legs affected much more than arms). During football, exertion will increase muscle tone. These players will have difficulty in turning, pivoting and stopping, usually running only short distances due to involvement in both lower limbs. Stride length is decreased with exertion.

Term.Title: FT 6 (Football 7 a Side) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Athletes in this class have athetosis or ataxia that affects all four limbs. These athletes will have trouble stopping and changing direction quickly with and without the ball. Coordination and timing problems will be seen when tracking, trapping and kicking the ball. The athlete will have difficulty dribbling or controlling the ball when running. Explosive movements will be difficult to perform.

Term.Title: FT 7 (Football 7 a Side) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: This class consists of athletes with hemiplegia (one side of body). The athletes usually walk with a limp and the arm or hand is flexed on the affected side. The other side of the athlete's body has a good functional ability. The athlete has difficulty pivoting and balancing on the impaired side and therefore often pivots on the unaffected side and may kick with the affected foot. During sprinting the athlete's affected arm muscles will have an increase in tone and a noted difference in stride.

Term.Title: FT 8 (Football 7 a Side) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The FT8 class consists of athletes with mild spasticity, athetosis, ataxia or dystonia and must meet the eligibility criteria. This athlete may appear to have near normal function when running but the athlete must demonstrate a limitation in function while performing the skills required for football.

Term.Title: Fujitsu V8 Supercars
Term.Description: http://www.v8supercars.com.au

Term.Title: Full
Term.Description: One flip with a full twist.

Term.Title: Full Court Press
Term.Description: An all-out effort to exert pressure. In basketball, full-court press is an aggressive defence strategy in which the defenders put pressure on the opposing team over the entire court, trying to disrupt their dribbling and passing.

Term.Title: Full Court Pressure Defence
Term.Description: The full-court pressure defense is a man-to-man full-court defense.

Term.Title: Full Double Full
Term.Description: Two flips with three twists, with a double flip in the second twist.

Term.Title: Full Double Full Full
Term.Description: The skier performs three flips with four twists.

Term.Title: Full Double Full Tuck
Term.Description: Three flips with three twists with two of the twists being done in the second flip.

Term.Title: Full Forward (AFL Player)
Term.Description: The Full Forward job is to score goals or behinds. He plays deep in his team's offensive zone, near the other teams goal posts. It is from this position he will try to score.

Term.Title: Full Full Full
Term.Description: Three flips with three twists.

Term.Title: Full In
Term.Description: A full twist on the first flip and then a double or triple somersault.

Term.Title: Full In Full Out
Term.Description: Two flips done with two twists.

Term.Title: Full Lay
Term.Description: Two flips in a layout position the first flip has one twist.

Term.Title: Full Nelson
Term.Description: A wrestler will pass their arms under the opponent's armpits from behind and lock their hands against the back of the opponents head.

Term.Title: Full Out
Term.Description: The skier does a double or triple somersault and does a full twist on the last one.

Term.Title: Full Time Employment
Term.Description: Employment based on a standard of 37.5 hours per week.

Term.Title: Full Time Equivalent
Term.Description: A measure of the volume of work (not people) in the organisation's workforce based on the standard measure of 1.0 unit of measure being 37.5 hours per week). The FTE measure of proportional or part time employment is obtained by dividing an employee's tot

Term.Title: Full Toss
Term.Description: A full toss is a type of delivery in the sport of cricket. It describes any delivery that reaches the batsman without bouncing on the pitch first. Full tosses are sparingly bowled deliberately, as they defeat the purpose of most types of delivery, which is to deceive the batsman by bouncing unpredictably on the pitch. They are commonly greeted with delight by a batsman, as they tend to be very easy to hit. A full toss is frequently the result of an unintentional error made while attempting to bowl a yorker, which would land around the batsman's feet.

Term.Title: Full Tuck
Term.Description: Two flips, with one of the twists done in the first flip.

Term.Title: Full Tuck Full
Term.Description: Three flips with two twists. The second flip however, does not have a twist.

Term.Title: Fullback
Term.Description: They are the player wearing jersey number 15. They act as the last line of defence against running attacks by the opposing three-quarter backs. The full back is expected to field high kicks from the opposition, and reply with a superior kick or a counterattack. The full back is sometimes the specialist goal-kicker in a team, taking penalty and conversion kicks.

Term.Title: Fullback (AFL Player)
Term.Description: The Fullback position is the furthest back on his team's defense. He tries to stop the other team from scoring and also tries to recover the ball and get it back to the offensive players on his team.

Term.Title: Fullback (Gridiron)
Term.Description: The Fullback is an offensive player. The Fullback will block and try and open up a hole in the defensive line for a running back to run through on a running play. He will also block for the quarterback during passing plays.

Term.Title: Fullback (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: Numbered 1, this position calls for all-round ball-playing ability and speed. The fullback is the last line of defence, standing behind the main line of defenders. Defensively, fullbacks must be able to chase and tackle any player who breaks the first line of defence, and must be able to catch kicks made by the attacking side.

Term.Title: Fulvestrant
Term.Description: A selective estrogen receptor down-regulator (SERD).

Term.Title: Fumble
Term.Description: A ball that a player accidentally lost possession of.

Term.Title: fun
Term.Description: enjoyment or light-hearted pleasure

Term.Title: Functional Classification 1 point (Wheelchair Basketball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players with little or no controlled trunk movement in all planes. Their balance in both forward and sideways directions is significantly impaired and they rely on their arms to return them to the upright position when unbalanced. One point players have no active trunk rotation.

Term.Title: Functional Classification 2 Point (Wheelchair Basketball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players with some partially controlled trunk movement in the forward direction, but no controlled sideways movement. They have upper trunk rotation but poor lower trunk rotation.

Term.Title: Functional Classification 3 Point (Wheelchair Basketball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players with good trunk movement in the forward direction to the floor and up again without arm support. They have good trunk rotation but no controlled sideways movement.

Term.Title: Functional Classification 4 Point (Wheelchair Basketball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players with normal trunk movement, but usually due to limitations in one lower limb they have difficulty with controlled sideways movement to one side.

Term.Title: Functional Classification 4.5 Point (Wheelchair Basketball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players with normal trunk movement in all directions who are able to reach side to side with no limitations.

Term.Title: Functions
Term.Description: Any ceremonious public or social gathering or occasion.

Term.Title: Funding Service Level Agreement
Term.Description: Funding agreements between the ASC and individual NSOs / NSODs.

Term.Title: Furazabol
Term.Description: A derivative of the anabolic steroid stanozolol.

Term.Title: Furl
Term.Description: To roll or gather a sail against its mast or spar.

Term.Title: Furosemide
Term.Description: A loop Kiuretic banned due to its allegd use as a masking agent for other drugs.

Term.Title: Fusen-gachi
Term.Description: When a judoko fails to appear for a match their opponent wins through default.

Term.Title: Futsal
Term.Description: Futsal is a form of five-a-side football that is played on an indoor pitch.

Term.Title: Futsal
Term.Description: Futsal is a variant of association football that is mainly played indoors. Futsal is the only form of indoor football or five-a-side that is officially approved by FIFA and Football Federation Australia.

Term.Title: Fybromyalgia
Term.Description: Fibromyalgia is a widespread muscular pain and fatigue condition. Pain and tenderness is felt throughout the body, not just in one specific muscle or area. The word fibromyalgia means pain in the fibrous tissues in the body. The pain originates from the muscles, tendons and ligaments which are the connective tissues in the body. Fibromyalgia is often associated with chonic fatigue, decreased pain threshold and stress.

Term.Title: Gabon
Term.Description: Country code = GA

Term.Title: Gaelic Football and Hurling Association of Australasia
Term.Description: http://www.gaelicfootball.com.au/

Term.Title: Gaelic Football World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.gaelicfootball.com.au/

Term.Title: Gain
Term.Description: To obtain as a profit.

Term.Title: Gain line
Term.Description: The gain line is an imaginary line drawn across the centre of the pitch when there is a breakdown in open play, such as a ruck, maul or scrum. Advancing across the gain line represents a gain in territory.

Term.Title: Galahs
Term.Description: Senior Men's Australian Football team

Term.Title: Gallery
Term.Description: Spectators at a tournament.

Term.Title: Gambia
Term.Description: Country code = GM

Term.Title: Game (Squash)
Term.Description: Part of a match.

Term.Title: Game Ball (Squash)
Term.Description: The state of the score when the server requires one point to win the game in progress.

Term.Title: Game Sense
Term.Description: Game Sense is an approach to coaching that uses games and game-like activities as the focus of the practice session. Game sense uses an athlete-centred approach to coaching, where participants have the opportunity to respond to challenges through activity, solve problems and contribute to what is done in a session.

Term.Title: Gap Jump
Term.Description: A jump that has a void between the takeoff and landing areas.

Term.Title: Garbage Serve
Term.Description: A half speed serve that hits about halfway up on the front wall and comes to the receiver at about shoulder height in either one of the rear court corners.

Term.Title: Garland
Term.Description: When a snowboarder turns to one side only, with downhill skidding, across the fall line. The resulting trail looks like a garland.

Term.Title: Garnishment
Term.Description: A order made by the courts that takes property from a person to satisfy a debt.

Term.Title: Garryowen
Term.Description: A Garryowen or up and under kick, is a high short punt onto or behind the defending team.

Term.Title: Gastrocnemius

Term.Title: Gastrointestinal Disease
Term.Description: Illness of, pertaining to, or affecting the stomach and intestines.

Term.Title: Gate (Rowing)
Term.Description: Bar across the top of rowlock, secured with a nut, which prevents the oar from coming out of the rowlock. Also historically used to refer to the oarlock or rowlock.

Term.Title: Generalised Anxiety Disorder
Term.Description: GAD; an anxiety disorder marked by chronic excessive anxiety and worry that is difficult to control, causes distress or impairment in daily functioning, and is accompanied by three or more associated symptoms (as restlessness, irritability, poor concentration, and sleep disturbances).

Term.Description: (G.S): Giant Slalom races differ from slalom races in that the course is longer and the gates are farther apart.

Giant Slalom (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The course is longer, there are fewer turns, and the turns are wider and smoother than the Slalom. The number of gates is determined by the vertical drop and the penalty for missing a gate is disqualification. Each athlete completes two runs on the same day on different courses. Times from the two courses are added to determine order of finish. (The ranking in the first run is the basis for the starting order in the second run, with the fastest skiing last).

Term.Title: Giant Slalom Gates
Term.Description: In Giant Slalom (G.S) the gates consist of two poles and one piece of cloth (flag) is attached to both poles, connecting the two poles. The Gates are 4 feet 11 inches tall (1.5 meters) and the Open Gate is 2 feet 6 inches wide (75 cm) and the Blind Gate is 1 foot or (30 cm) wide.

Term.Title: Gilmore's Groin
Term.Description: Gilmore's groin was first identified in 1980 as a cause of longstanding groin pain. The condition is sometimes called the Sportsman's Hernia, however there is not actually a hernia present.

Term.Title: Gimmie
Term.Description: A ball that is so close to the hole that the opposing player concedes that you will make the shot.

Term.Title: Give and Go
Term.Description: "Give and Go" is an offensive play that involves passing the ball (give) and then running (go) to an open spot to receive the ball back, usually near the basket, for an easy score.

Term.Title: Given name
Term.Description: The persons identifying name within the family group or by which the person is socially identified, as represented by text - AIHW. A person may have more than one given name.

Term.Title: Glandular Fever
Term.Description: Infectious mononucleosis (the presence of an abnormally large number of mononuclear leukocytes, or monocytes, in the blood).

Term.Description: A fighter who is especially vulnerable or susceptible to a knockout is said to have a glass jaw.
