Term.Title: Glide
Term.Description: This is when a swimmer has their arms to the side and their legs together and is not making any swimming motions. Usually done under water and at the beginning of a race.

Term.Title: Glide Technique
Term.Description: In the shot put, this is the technique employed by many throwers in which the athlete glides from the back of the ring to the front in a straight line without rotating. The glide technique is older than the spin technique, but both are still commonly used.

Term.Title: Glide Wax
Term.Description: A wax that is put on the bottom of the skies and is used to help reduce friction between the skis and the snow.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Glide Zones
Term.Description: Refers to the areas on the bottom, and in the front and back of cross-country skies. These areas allow the skier to move forward when equal weight is put on each ski.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Gliders
Term.Description: Women's Wheelchair Basketball Team

Term.Title: Gliding Federation of Australia
Term.Description: http://www.gfa.org.au

Term.Title: Global Media and Sports
Term.Description: Global Media & Sports provides advice and negotiation support to the world's leading and aspiring sports in maximizing their media rights value across their most critical international and national leagues.

Term.Title: Glove (Wheelchair Rugby) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Athletes may wear gloves to improve their grip on the ball.

Term.Title: Glucose
Term.Description: A sugar, C 6 H 12 O 6 , having several optically different forms, the common dextrorotatory form (dextroglucose, or d -glucose) occurring in many fruits, animal tissues and fluids, etc., and having a sweetness about one half that of ordinary sugar, and the rare levorotatory form (levoglucose, or l -glucose) not naturally occurring.

Term.Title: Glutamic Acid
Term.Description: An amino acid, HOOCCH 2 CH 2 CH(NH 2 )COOH, obtained by hydrolysis from wheat gluten and sugar-beet residues, used commercially chiefly in the form of its sodium salt to intensify the flavor of meat or other food. Abbreviation: Glu; Symbol: E

Term.Title: Glutamine
Term.Description: A crystalline amino acid, HOOCCH(NH 2 )CH 2 CH 2 CONH 2 , related to glutamic acid. Abbreviation: Gln; Symbol: Q

Term.Title: Gluteal Muscles Group
Term.Description: The three muscles that make up the buttocks.

Term.Title: Gluteus Maximus
Term.Description: Extend and laterally rotate thigh at hip.

Term.Title: Gluteus Medius
Term.Description: Muscles abduct and internally rotate thigh at hip: active during walking to stabilise the pelvis.

Term.Title: Gluteus Minimus
Term.Description: Muscles abduct and internally rotate thigh at hip: active during walking to stabilise the pelvis.

Term.Title: Glycaemic Index
Term.Description: GI - an index indicating the effects of various foods on blood sugar. Fast-releasing foods that raise blood sugar levels quickly are high on the index, while slow-releasing foods, at the bottom of the index, give a slow but sustained release of sugar.

Term.Title: Glycine
Term.Description: A colorless, crystalline, sweet, water-soluble solid, H 2 NCH 2 COOH, the simplest amino acid used chiefly in organic synthesis and biochemical research. Abbreviation: Gly; Symbol: G

Term.Title: Glycolytic
Term.Description: The anaerobic energy producing process that takes place in the absence of oxygen.

Term.Title: Go For Gold Sailing Regatta
Term.Description: http://www.yachting.org.au/

Term.Title: Go to the Mat
Term.Description: To engage in a wrestling bout, the mat being the surface on which the contest is fought.

Term.Title: Goal (AFL)
Term.Description: A maximum score (equivalent to 6 points) achieved by kicking the ball between the two goal-posts without it touching either post or any other player.

Term.Title: Goal (Football)
Term.Description: Physical structure on a football pitch consisting of goal posts and a goal crossbar. A standard goal is 8 foot high (2.44m) and 8 yards wide (7.32m).

Term.Title: Goal (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A surface in space marked by a structure of two upright posts 18 feet 6 inches apart extending above a horizontal crossbar whose top edge is 10 feet off the ground. The goal is the surface above the bar and between the lines of the inner edges of the posts, extending infinitely upward, centred above each end line.

Term.Title: Goal (Hockey)
Term.Description: Where a player tries to shot the ball in order to score a point for their team. The front of the goal is set on the backline or goal line and is 4 yards or 3.66 metres wide and 7 feet or 2.13 metres tall and has a frame of four goalposts, the two in front being the more important and a crossbar. The goal usually has a net on it.

Term.Title: Goal (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: A player scores a goal when he shoots the puck into the goal.

Term.Title: Goal (Rugby)
Term.Description: A goal is scored when a player kicks the ball through the plane bounded by the two uprights and above the crossbar. A drop goal or penalty goal count for 3 points and conversions count for two.

Term.Title: Goal (score) (Football)
Term.Description: Given the value of one point in a match. A goal is awarded to the attacking team when the ball has completely crossed the goal line between the goal posts and beneath the crossbar of the defending team.

Term.Title: Goal (Water Polo equipment)
Term.Description: The physical structure that defines where a score is achieved. A goal is scored after the ball passes completely over the goal line between the goal posts and under the crossbar. The goal posts are 3 metres apart and the crossbar is 0.9 metres above the water surface.

Term.Title: Goal Attack
Term.Description: The Goal Attack (GA) shares the goal shooting responsibilities with the Goal Shooter, and is allowed to move within the goal third and centre third. The Goal Attack must also work closely with the WA on the centre pass to gain possession and feed the ball to the GS.

Term.Title: Goal Cage
Term.Description: Metal grid that attaches to the front of a helmet to protect the face. Occasionally also refers to the goal.

Term.Title: Goal Circle (Hockey)
Term.Description: A half-moon shaped area in front of the goal where an offensive or attacking player must be before he can take a shot and score a goal. This area is also known as a Scoring Circle or Shooting Circle.

Term.Title: Goal Crease (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: The semi-circle shaded area directly in front of the net.

Term.Title: Goal Crease (Lacrosse)
Term.Description: A circle that is 3 metres in radius and the goal net sits inside this circle. An attacking player can never be inside the goal crease and any defending player who has the ball has 4 seconds to get rid of it or to leave the circle.

Term.Title: Goal Defence
Term.Description: The main task of the Goal Defence (GD) is to defend the attacking moves of their opponent, the Goal Attack, to prevent a goal being scored. The Goal Defence also needs to have good attacking skills, which are important for getting the ball out of the defence third, and assisting the team in attack.

Term.Title: Goal Keeper
Term.Description: The main task of the Goal Keeper (GK) is to defend the goal third to prevent the ball from making it to the goal circle, and to stop a goal being scored. Their opponent is the Goal Shooter.

Term.Title: Goal Keeper (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: This player's responsibility is to guard their team's goal.

Term.Title: Goal Kicker (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: Although any player can attempt his team's kicks at goal (penalty kicks or conversions), most teams will have specific players who will train extensively at kicking, and will often use only one player to take goal kicks during a game.

Term.Title: Goal Line (AFL)
Term.Description: A section of the boundary line that runs from one behind post to the other, at each end. All four posts (two goal posts and two behind posts) are set directly on this line.

Term.Title: Goal Line (Gridiron)
Term.Description: The line that marks where the end zone begins. The goal line is considered part of the end zone so a player with the ball scores when the ball is on, above, or over the goal line.

Term.Title: Goal Line (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: This is a red line that is painted across the ice and it marks the front edge of the goal and the puck must pass over the line completely in order for it to count as a goal. The line is 3.96 metres from the end boards. This line is also used to determine when icing has occurred.

Term.Title: Goal Line (Water Polo)
Term.Description: The line at each end of the pool crossing the front of the goal designated by a white mark on the edge of the pool. The playing area extends 0.3 metres behind the goal line which must be at least 1.66 metres from the pool wall.

Term.Title: Goal Line / Tryline
Term.Description: Two solid, straight white lines (one at each end) stretching across the entire width of the pitch passing directly through the goal posts which defines the boundary between the "field of play" and the "in-goal". As the goal line is defined as part of the "in-goal", attacking players can score tries by placing the ball with downward pressure onto the goal line itself. The base of the goal posts and post protectors are also defined to be part of the goal line. The goal line is often referred to as the "try line" though that term does not appear in the Laws of the Game.

Term.Title: Goal Line Drop Out
Term.Description: Awarded when a defending player grounds the ball in his own in-goal area, is tackled with the ball in his own in-goal area, or when a defending player plays the ball "dead" (into touch) behind his own goal line. The defending team must kick the ball from their own goal line and beneath the uprights to a minimum distance of ten metres. Note that if a player grounds the ball on his own goal line in a tackle, he is regarded as being in the field of play, and play continues. This is contrary to the definition of a try, where the goal line counts as the in-goal area.

Term.Title: Goal Posts (AFL)
Term.Description: There are two goalposts and the are 6.4 metres and they must be 6 metres tall.

Term.Title: Goal posts (Rugby)
Term.Description: H shaped goals at either end of the field. Drop goals and conversions are scored by successfully kicking the ball between the upright sections of the goal.

Term.Title: Goal Shooter
Term.Description: The main task of the Goal Shooter (GS) is to score goals. They are allowed within the goal third only and they must have good space awareness when working in confined areas with the GA. They must also be able to execute a variety of leads and movements in order to break away from the defenders.

Term.Title: Goal Square
Term.Description: An area directly in front of the goalposts. The goal square is the same width as the goal line 6.4 metres. Two lines run straight out at right angles from each of the goalposts, extending into the field for 9 metres. Another 6.4-metre line is the drawn between the end of these two lines thus forming a square. The ball is kicked out of this area after a behind has been scored.

Term.Title: Goal Umpire
Term.Description: The two umpires that are responsible for signaling when and whether a goal or a behind has been scored. If a goal has been scored then they will wave two flags and if a behind id scored they wave one flag.

Term.Title: Goalball
Term.Description: Goalball is a sport exclusively for athletes who are blind or have a visual impairment. It was invented in 1946 in an effort to rehabilitate the blind veterans from World War II and made its Paralympic debut in 1976 in Toronto. Goalball competitions are set apart from all other Paralympic events due to the unique atmosphere inside the playing venue. The object is to roll the ball into the opponent's goal while the opposing players try to block the ball with their bodies. Bells inside the ball help to orientate the players by indicating the direction of the oncoming ball. Therefore, while play is in progress, complete silence is required in the venue to allow the players to concentrate and react instantly to the ball. Goalball is played by male and female athletes with blindness / visual impairment and athletes wear blackout masks on the playing court. This allows persons with varying degrees of vision to participate together. The game consists of two halves of 10 minutes each.

Term.Title: Goalball Australia
Term.Description: http://www.goalball.com.au/

Term.Title: National Sporting Organisation for People with a Disability
Goalie (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: This player's responsibility is to guard their team's goal.

Term.Title: Goalie (Water Polo)
Term.Description: The player for each team assigned to remain directly in front of the goal to prevent the opposite team from scoring. Within the five metre area in front of his goal the goalkeeper may touch the ball with two hands, strike the ball with a clenched fist and touch the bottom of the pool (pool depth permitting). Unlike the field players he cannot cross the half-distance line. Both goalkeepers wear quartered red caps numbered "1".

Term.Title: Goalposts (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: The metal bars that frame the area to which the net is attached which rests on the centre of the goal line and between which a puck must pass to score a goal.

Term.Title: Goals (Football 7-a Side) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The goals are 5m wide by 2m high with netting.

Term.Title: Goals (Goalball) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Regulation goals measure 9 (equal to the length of the court) x 1.3m high.

Term.Title: Goat Event
Term.Description: A long-distance endurance event similar to cross-country orienteering courses. It usually has a mass start and often includes special rules such as permission to skip a control.

Term.Title: Going About
Term.Description: Changing from one tack to another by going through the wind.

Term.Description: National Basketball League Club Team

Term.Description: Australian Football League Club Team.

Term.Description: National Rugby League Club Team

Term.Description: National A-League football club team.

Term.Title: Golden Duck
Term.Description: When a batsman is dismissed by the very first ball he faces without scoring.

Term.Description: http://www.iaaf.org/

Term.Title: Golden Point
Term.Description: The golden point, a sudden death overtime system, is sometimes used to resolve drawn rugby league matches. Minor variations exist to this system. In the National Rugby League, if the scores are level at the end of 80 minutes, 5 minutes are played, the teams swap ends with no break, and a further 5 minutes are played. Any score (try, penalty goal, or field goal) in this 10 minute period secures a win for the scoring team, and the game ends at that point.

Term.Title: Golden Set
Term.Description: Winning a set without losing a point.

Term.Title: Golf Australia
Term.Description: http://www.golfaustralia.org.au/

Term.Title: Golf Cart
Term.Description: A battery powered two-passenger vehicle used to take golfers and their clubs around the course.

Term.Title: Golf course
Term.Description: The place where golf is played. Golf courses have either 9 or 18 holes.

Term.Title: Golf Croquet
Term.Description: A simplied version of croquet.

Term.Title: Golf Grand Slam
Term.Description: The US Open, British Open, Augusta (The Masters) and the PGA Championships are known as the grand slam.

Term.Title: Golf Majors
Term.Description: http://www.fourgolfmajors.com/

Term.Title: Golf World Cup
Term.Description: http://worldcup.pgatour.com/

Term.Title: Golfing World Amateur Team Championships
Term.Description: http://www.internationalgolffederation.org/

Term.Title: Gonorrhea
Term.Description: A sexualy transimitted disease; a contagious, purulent inflammation of the urethra or the vagina, caused by the gonococcus.

Term.Title: Good D
Term.Description: Good defence.

Term.Title: Good Luck Beijing
Term.Description: http://www.cycling.org.au

Term.Title: Goofy
Term.Description: This is riding with the right foot forward.

Term.Title: Googly
Term.Description: A googly is a type of delivery bowled by a right-arm leg spin bowler. It is occasionally referred to as a Bosie (or Bosey) after its inventor Bernard Bosanquet. In Australia it is commonly referred to as a wrong'un.

Term.Title: Gooseneck
Term.Description: Fitting that attaches the boom to the mast, allowing it to move freely.

Term.Title: Gout
Term.Description: An acute, recurrent disease characterized by painful inflammation of the joints, chiefly those in the feet and hands, and especially in the great toe, and by an excess of uric acid in the blood; a metabolic disease characterized by painful inflammation of certain joints, esp of the big toe and foot, caused by deposits of sodium urate in them.

Term.Title: Governance
Term.Description: Governance is the system by which organisations are directed and managed. It influences how the objectives of the organisation are set and achieved, spells out the rules and procedures for making organisational decisions and determines the means of optimising and monitoring performance, including how risk is monitored and assessed.

Term.Title: Government
Term.Description: Body of people that sets and administers public policy, and exercises executive, political, and sovereign power through customs, institutions, and laws within a state.

Term.Title: Government Loan
Term.Description: A loan subsidized by the government, which protects lenders against defaults on payments, thus making it a lot easier for lenders to offer potential borrowers lower interest rates.

Term.Title: Government regulation of gambling
Term.Description: Australia government bodies and legislation to control gambling.

Term.Title: GPS tracking device
Term.Description: A space-based global navigation satellite system (GNSS) that provides location and time information in all weather, anywhere on or near the Earth, where there is an unobstructed line of sight to four or more GPS satellites.

Term.Title: Grab
Term.Description: Another word for mark (nice grab).

Term.Title: Grab Start
Term.Description: When a swimmer reaches down and takes hold of the starting block. The swimmer will put their hands in-between their feet or to the outside of their feet and then lead forward, this type of start is meant to give the swimmer a fast start off of the blocks.

Term.Title: Grace Period
Term.Description: A time period during which you are not required to make payments on a debt. eg, most credit cards give you a grace period of 30 - 55 days before you have to pay interest on the amount of your purchases. Cash advances, however, usually have no grace period.

Term.Title: Grade 1A (Equestrian) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Riders in this class generally use wheelchair for their mobility and have impairment of all 4 limbs. They may be able to walk with an unsteady gait. However their trunk and balance are significantly impaired.

Term.Title: Grade 1B (Equestrian) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Riders in this class generally use wheelchairs for their mobility and have poor trunk balance and/ or impairment of function in all four limbs. They may have no trunk balance and good upper limb function, or have reasonable balance but a significant impairment in all 4 limbs.

Term.Title: Grade 2 (Equestrian) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Riders in this class generally use wheelchairs for their mobility, or those with significant locomotor impairments involving the trunk and with good to mild upper limb function. They may have significant arm impairment and slight leg impairment or severe impairment on one side of their body.

Term.Title: Grade 3 (Equestrian) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Riders in this class are usually able to walk without support. They have moderate impairments on one side of their body or moderate impairment in four limbs, or significant impairment in one arm. Riders in this class may need to use a wheelchair for longer distances. Riders who are completey blind compete in this class. They are required to wear blacked out glasses or a blind fold.

Term.Title: Grade 4 (Equestrian) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Impairment in one or two limbs or a vision impairment equivalent to a B2. That is from the ability to recognize the form of a hand to a visual acuity of 2/60 and / or a visual field of less than 5 degrees.

Term.Title: Graduate Certificate in Career Counselling for Elite Athletes
Term.Description: School of Sport and Science, Faculty of Workforce Development, Victoria University, PO Box 14428, Melbourne VIC 8001 www.vu.edu.au

Term.Title: Graeme Briggs Memorial Track Classic
Term.Description: http://www.athletics.com.au/

Term.Title: Grafton Stadium
Term.Description: Grafton NSW 2460

Term.Title: Grains
Term.Description: This is the standard weight measurement used in archery.

Term.Title: Grand Amplitude Hold
Term.Description: When a wrestler lifts their rival off the mat and carries them through the air and lands them in the danger position from a standing position. From the kneeling or par terre position, a grand amplitude happens when a wrestler is able to lift their opponent from the ground and cause them to land face or belly-down which is worth 3 points or in the danger position worth 5 points.

Term.Title: Grant
Term.Description: Grants are funds disbursed by one party (Grant Makers), often a Government Department, Corporation, Foundation or Trust, to a recipient, often (but not always) a nonprofit entity, educational institution, business or an individual. In order to receive a grant, some form of "Grant Writing" often referred to as either a proposal or an application is usually required.

Term.Title: Grant Deed
Term.Description: A deed containing an implied promise that the person who is transferring the property actually owns the title and that it is not encumbered in any way, except as described in the deed itself.

Term.Title: Grantor
Term.Description: Creator of a trust.

Term.Title: Grants 4 Grassroots Fund
Term.Description: The Australian Sports Foundations Grants 4 Grassroots (G4G) Fund is a newly launched small grants program which funds initiatives and programs aimed at increasing participation in grassroots and community sport. The G4G Fund was set up to support incorporated non-profit sporting clubs and organisations throughout Australia. Grants ranging from $2,500-$10,000 are made to support a variety of participation based projects such as the purchase of sporting equipment or sport development initiatives.

Term.Title: Grapevines (Figure Skating)

Term.Title: Graphic Design

Term.Title: Graphics Processing Unit
Term.Description: A single-chip processor used primarily for computing 3D functions.

Term.Title: Graphite
Term.Description: A kind of material that is used to make golf club shafts and golf club heads.

Term.Title: Grapple Tackle
Term.Description: A grapple tackle is a controversial tackling technique whereby the tackler attempts to impede the ball carrier by applying a choke hold-like manoeuvre. Although players can be penalised for its use, it is difficult to enforce.

Term.Description: GH or HGH, also known as somatotropin or somatropin, is a peptide hormone that stimulates growth, cell reproduction and regeneration in humans and other animals.

It gives the ball both high and low bounce and on occasions, the ball can sit up in a perfect catching position.

Term.Title: Haakon Flip
Term.Description: A half-pipe trick that has the rider approach the backside wall fakie and then rotating in the backside direction while at the same time going upside down.

Term.Title: Habeas Corpus
Term.Description: Latin meaning 'you have the body'. A prisoner files a petition for writ of habeas corpus in order to challenge the authority of the gaol or prison warden to continue to hold them. If the judge orders a hearing after reading the writ, the prisoner gets to argue that their confinement is illegal.

Term.Title: Habit
Term.Description: A particular practice, custom, or usage; an acquired behavior pattern regularly followed until it has become almost involuntary.

Term.Title: Hack
Term.Description: Similar to a starting block in track and field, the foothold device where the person who throws the rock pushes off for delivery.

Term.Title: Hacker

Term.Title: Haematocrit
Term.Description: The proportion of blood volume that is occupied by red blood cells. It is considered an integral part of a person's complete blood count results, along with hemoglobin concentration, white blood cell count, and platelet count.

Term.Title: Haemochromatosis
Term.Description: Inborn metabolic defect characterized by an increased absorption of iron, which accumulates in body tissues. The clinical manifestations include skin pigmentation, diabetes mellitus, enlargement of the spleen and liver, cirrhosis, heart failure, arthritis, and general weakness and lassitude.

Term.Title: Haemoglobin
Term.Description: A conjugated protein, consisting of haem and the protein globin, that gives red blood cells their characteristic colour. It combines reversibly with oxygen and is thus very important in the transportation of oxygen to tissues.

Term.Title: Haier Pulse
Term.Description: Australian Netball Club Team

Term.Title: Hail Mary
Term.Description: When a player kicks or hand passes the ball to no one in particular in the hope that it will reach a team mate.

Term.Title: Hairpin Net Shot
Term.Description: A shot made from very close to the net and is hit from below the net. The shot goes straight up it barely clears the net, and then goes straight down on the other side. Hence the name of the shot, because it looks a lot like the shape of a hairpin.

Term.Title: Haiti

Term.Title: Hajme
Term.Description: The referee's order to start fighting.

Term.Title: Haka
Term.Description: The haka is a traditional Maori dance performed by the All Blacks, the international rugby union team of New Zealand, immediately prior to international matches. It serves as a challenge to the opposing team.

Term.Title: Half (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: A flip that has a half-twist.

Term.Title: Half (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: Positioned more centrally in attack, near the forwards, they direct the ball in attack and are usually two of their team's main decision-makers.

Term.Title: Half and Half Formation
Term.Description: When playing doubles the court is divided in half from the front wall to the back wall. Each player is responsible for their half of the court.

Term.Title: Half Back (AFL)
Term.Description: The name given to the player placed in that position. Usually opposed by the half-forward.

Term.Title: Half Forward
Term.Description: The name given to the player placed in that position. Usually opposed by the half-back.

Term.Title: Half Forward Flank
Term.Description: Half Forward players attack the ball, meaning that they try and get the ball away from the other team. They also try to keep the ball in their team's offensive zone. They try to set up scoring shots and they can also attempt to score themselves.

Term.Title: Half Full Half (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: Three flips with two twists.

Term.Title: Half Half (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: Two flips and each one has a half-twist.

Term.Title: Half Half Full (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: Three flips with the first one having a half-twist, the second one having a half-twist, and the third one having a full twist.

Term.Title: Half In (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: A double or triple somersault that has a half-twist on the first flip.

Term.Title: Half Nelson
Term.Description: A wrestler will pass their arm under their opponent's armpit from behind and lock one hand against the back of the opponents head.

Term.Title: Half Out (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: A double or triple somersault that has a full twist on the first flip.

Term.Title: Half Pipe
Term.Description: A U-shaped trench with walls of the same height and size on both sides. It is used for performing freestyle tricks and it looks like a drainpipe that has been cut in half length-wise.

Term.Title: Half Randy Full (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: Three flips with five twists.

Term.Title: Half Rudy Full (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: A triple back flip, the first one has a half-twist, the second one has one and a half twists, and the third has a full twist.

Term.Title: Half time
Term.Description: The midpoint of the warmup.

Term.Title: Half Tuck Half (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: Three flips combined with two half-twists.

Term.Title: Half Volley (Racquetball)
Term.Description: When a player hits the ball right after it bounces off the floor.

Term.Title: Half Volley (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: When a player returns a shot and hits the ball right after it has bounced off the tabletop.

Term.Title: Halfback Flank
Term.Description: The Halfbacks job is to get the ball and get it back to the Center or Wings.

Term.Title: Halftime

Term.Title: Hallucinations

Term.Title: Halte

Term.Title: Halve a Hole
Term.Description: A tie.

Term.Title: Halve a Match
Term.Description: When both players have won the same number holes during the match.

Term.Title: Halyard

Term.Title: Hammer (Curling)
Term.Description: The very last stone played at the conclusion of each end.

Term.Title: Hammer (Rowing)

Term.Description: This grip is when the player has all of their fingers around the handle of the paddle and has no fingers running up the side of the paddle.

Term.Title: Hamstring Origin Tendinitis
Term.Description: Hamstring tendinitis is inflammation of the hamstring tendon as it attaches to the Ischial Tuberosity. It can follow a tear of the hamstring tendon which is poorly treated or more often is an overuse injury.

Term.Title: Hamstring Strain
Term.Description: A hamstring strain or a pulled hamstring as it is sometimes called is a tear in one or more of the hamstring muscles

Term.Title: Hamstrings

Term.Title: Hand Off
Term.Description: A move in which a player transfers the ball to another player, and the receiving player takes possession of the ball before it leaves the hands of the giver.

Term.Title: Hand on the Ice
Term.Description: When a skater swings their arm, the arm that is on the outside of the curve, to keep them from moving to the outside and to conserve speed.

Term.Title: Hand Out (Racquetball)
Term.Description: The player who is receiving the serve. Also in doubles when the serve is lost by the teams first server. The serve then goes over to their partner.

Term.Title: Hand Out (Squash)
Term.Description: Condition when a change of server occurs.

Term.Description: A half-pipe trick that has the snowboarder doing a handstand on one or both hands.

Term.Title: Hand wraps
Term.Description: Long piece (approx 1.5m) of material used to wrap the hands. The hands are wrapped prior to the gloves being put on.

Term.Title: Handball
Term.Description: A team sport in which two teams of seven players each (six outfield players and a goalkeeper) pass a ball with the aim of throwing it into the goal of the other team. A standard match consists of two periods of 30 minutes, and the team that scores the most goals wins.

Term.Title: Handball World Championships

Term.Title: Handcycle (H Classes) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: There are four divisions of riders in this class, H1-4. This class includes cyclists with spinal cord injuries, cerebral plays, amputees or other athletes with other disabilities that prevent the safe use of a conventional bicycle or tricycle.

Term.Title: Handcycling
Term.Description: A handcycle is a type of human-powered land vehicle powered by the arms rather than the legs, as on a bicycle. Most handcycles are tricycle in form, with two coasting rear wheels and one steerable powered front wheel. Despite usually having three wheels, they are also known as handbikes.

Term.Title: Handicap
Term.Description: A handicap is a numerical measure of a golfer's potential playing ability based on the tees played for a given course. It is used to calculate a net score from the number of strokes actually played during a competition, thus allowing players of different proficiency to play against each other on somewhat equal terms. The higher the handicap of a player, the poorer the player is relative to those with lower handicaps. Handicap systems are not used in professional golf.

Term.Title: Handle Steer
Term.Description: A method of steering the sled by either pulling or pushing on the handles.

Term.Title: Handled the Ball
Term.Description: Law 33 of the Laws of cricket provides that: "Either batsman is out Handled the ball if he wilfully touches the ball while in play with a hand or hands not holding the bat unless he does so with the consent of the opposing side."

Term.Title: Handover
Term.Description: Upon a team completing their set of tackles they are required to surrender possession to the opposing team.

Term.Title: Handpass
Term.Description: A player will hold a ball stationary in one hand and with a clinched fist will hit or strike the ball and send or pass it to one of their teammates.

Term.Title: Handrail

Term.Title: Hardware

Term.Title: Hat Trick (Ice Hockey)

Term.Description: Hawk-Eye is a computer system used in cricket, tennis and other sports to visually track the path of the ball and display a record of its actual path as graphic image. In some sports, like tennis, it is now part of the adjudication process. It is also able to predict the future path of a ball.

Term.Title: Head (Bowls)
Term.Description: Rolling bowls toward Jack to build up a Head, which means such bowls that have come to rest within the boundary of the Rink and have not been declared dead.

Term.Title: Head (Sailing)
Term.Description: The forwardmost or uppermost portion of the ship.

Term.Title: Head Coach (Football)
Term.Description: Known internationally as a Manager, but generally in Australia as a Head Coach, the position entails all aspects of managing a football team, including overseeing other coaches, training schedules, selecting the team and directing on field play.

Term.Title: Head Deke
Term.Description: When a player drops their head as though moving one way and quickly moves in another to fake out the opponent.

Term.Title: Head Hold
Term.Description: One wrestler is able to get one arm around their opponent's head. In a Head Hold you can only use one arm, use of both arms will result in a penalty.

Term.Title: Head Race
Term.Description: A long race in which rowers race a twisting course of about 3 miles. A race for time. The start is staggered.

Term.Title: Head Sea
Term.Description: A sea where waves are directly opposing the motion of the ship.

Term.Title: Head Up
Term.Description: An order given by the referee in the case of passive obstruction or repeated attacks by a wrestler who continuously push's their head forward.

Term.Title: Headache
Term.Description: A pain located in the head, as over the eyes, at the temples, or at the base of the skull.

Term.Title: Headcount
Term.Description: A measure of workforce size by reference to the actual number of people employed at any given point in time. This is a measure of employment that does not rely on an employees status as a full or part time employee.

Term.Title: Header
Term.Description: Use of the player's head to direct the ball.

Term.Title: Header (Sailing)
Term.Description: A change in the wind direction which forces the helmsman of a close hauled sailboat to steer away from its current course to a less favorable one.

Term.Title: Headguard
Term.Description: Equipment used during training and competition to protect the head.

Term.Title: Headset
Term.Description: The bearing system in the head tube within which the handlebars rotate.

Term.Title: Headwind
Term.Description: A wind moving the opposite direction of a sprinter or jumper during the sprint or approach. Marks set into headwinds are counted for record purposes, but setting any kind of record into a headwind is a rare occurrence.

Term.Title: Hear Footsteps
Term.Description: To believe one is under more pressure than one actually is.

Term.Title: Hearing
Term.Description: In a trial court context, a legal proceeding (other than a full-scale trial) held before a judge. A hearing is usually a proceeding before an administrative hearing officer or judge representing an agency that has the power to regulate a particular field or oversee a governmental benefit program.

Term.Title: Hearing Impaired
Term.Description: Or Deaf

Term.Title: Heat
Term.Description: A race or other sporting event that is held preliminary to a final event to reduce the number of competitors in a final competition event. Dependent on the number of competitors, the competitors who score highest or fastest proceed into the final or to a further heat. The lowest scoring or slowest competitors are eliminated from the competition event.

Term.Title: Heat Exhaustion
Term.Description: A condition characterized by faintness, rapid pulse, nausea, profuse sweating, cool skin, and collapse, caused by prolonged exposure to heat accompanied by loss of adequate fluid and salt from the body.

Term.Title: Heat Stroke
Term.Description: A disturbance of the temperature-regulating mechanisms of the body caused by overexposure to excessive heat, resulting in fever, hot and dry skin, and rapid pulse, sometimes progressing to delirium and coma.

Term.Title: Heater
Term.Description: A good fastball.

Term.Title: Heave
Term.Description: A vessel's transient, vertical, up-and-down motion.

Term.Title: Heaving To
Term.Description: Stopping a sailing vessel by lashing the helm in opposition to the sails. The vessel will gradually drift to leeward.

Term.Title: Heavy
Term.Description: A stone that has been played with too much speed or weight and therefore goes past its mark.

Term.Title: Heavy Ice
Term.Description: Ice that is playing slow.

Term.Title: Heavyweight (Rowing)
Term.Description: A rower who weighs more than the limit for lightweight rowing. Often referred to as open weight.

Term.Title: Heavyweight Boxer
Term.Description: Heavyweight boxers have no upper weight limit imposed on them, but must weigh in at 200lbs or more.

Term.Title: Heel Drag
Term.Description: Drag that is caused when a snowboarders heel hangs off the edge of their snowboard.

Term.Title: Heeling
Term.Description: Heeling is the lean caused by the wind's force on the sails of a sailing vessel.

Term.Title: Heelside
Term.Description: The edge of the snowboard nearest to the rider's heels.

Term.Title: Heelside Turn
Term.Description: When a snowboarder makes a turn on the heelside edge of the snowboard.

Term.Title: Hegemony
Term.Description: Ascendancy or domination of one power or state within a league, confederation, etc, or of one social class over others.

Term.Title: Height and Distance (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: Two of the factors that are taken into consideration as part of the jumping score.

Term.Title: Hel van het Mergelland

Term.Title: Held Ball

Term.Title: Helicopter (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: A 360-degree spin with the skier in an upright or standing position.

Term.Title: Helicopter Punt
Term.Description: A kick which gyrates flatly like the turbines of a helicopter.

Term.Title: Helm
Term.Description: A ship's steering mechanism.

Term.Title: Helmet (Cycling) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: During competition, athletes must wear a hard shell protective helmet to a recognized international standard. The helmet colour is standardized depending on the class of the athlete (red, blue, green or white).

Term.Title: Helmets (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Hard-shell helmets are required in Alpine Skiing events.

Term.Title: Helmsman

Term.Title: Help Desk

Term.Title: Hematologic Disease

Term.Title: Hemic and Lymphatic Diseases
Term.Description: Hematologic diseases and diseases of the lymphatic system collectively. Hemic diseases include disorders involving the formed elements and chemical components; lymphatic diseases include disorders relating to lymph, lymph nodes, and lymphocytes.

Term.Title: Hemophilia
Term.Description: An inherited deficiency in one of the bloods clotting factors.

Term.Title: Hemorrhage
Term.Description: Profuse discharge of blood, as from a ruptured blood vessel; bleeding.

Term.Title: Hemorrhoids
Term.Description: An abnormally enlarged vein mainly due to a persistent increase in venous pressure, occurring inside the anal sphincter of the rectum and beneath the mucous membrane (internal hemorrhoid) or outside the anal sphincter and beneath the surface of the anal skin (external hemorrhoid).

Term.Title: Hepatitis
Term.Description: Inflammation of the liver, caused by a virus or a toxin and characterized by jaundice, liver enlargement, and fever.

Term.Title: Hepatocyte Growth Factor
Term.Description: HGF is a paracrine cellular growth, motility and morphogenic factor.

Term.Title: Heptathlete
Term.Description: Track and Field athlete who competes in the Heptathlon.

Term.Title: Heptathlon (Women)
Term.Description: An athletic contest usually limited to women in which each contestant participates in the following seven track and field events: 200-metre and 800-metre runs, 100-metre hurdles, shot put, javelin throw, high jump, and long jump.

Term.Title: Herding
Term.Description: A way for a player to block the cross court passing lane and thus force their opponent to shoot a down the line pass. This makes it easier for the player doing the herding to cover the one part of the court.

Term.Title: Hernia
Term.Description: Hernias occur when part of the internal tissue (fat, muscle, intestines etc) bulge through a weakness in the overlying abdominal wall. The herniating tissues are at risk of complications such as strangulation (pinching) which can cause intestinal blockages and may cut off the blood supply which requires immediate treatment.

Term.Title: Herniated Discs
Term.Description: A condition where the cushion between a spinal vertebra is pushed out of its original location and causes pain.

Term.Title: Herpes
Term.Description: Any of several diseases caused by herpesvirus, characterized by eruption of blisters on the skin or mucous membranes.

Term.Title: Herpes Simplex Virus
Term.Description: Any of several viral diseases causing the eruption of small blisterlike vesicles on the skin or mucous membranes, especially herpes simplex or herpes zoster.

Term.Title: Herpesviridae
Term.Description: One of the major virus families, to which the herpes simplex, varicella zoster, and Epstein-Barr viruses belong.

Term.Title: Herringbone
Term.Description: When a skier is moving forward by not skiing but by stepping. The ski tips are pointed outward so the backs of the skis are close to each other. It is called herringbone because of the patter this makes in the snow.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Hervis Tour
Term.Description: http://www.uci.ch

Term.Title: Heterosexism
Term.Description: The assumption that everyone is or should be heterosexual and that heterosexuality is the only normal or natural expression of sexuality.

Term.Title: HEW Cyclassics

Term.Title: High Clear
Term.Description: A shot that is hit deep into the opposition's court, this is usually a defensive shot. It is also called a High-lift.

Term.Title: High Intensity Exercise
Term.Description: Form of strength training focusing on performing quality weight training repetitions to the point of momentary muscular failure.

Term.Title: High Line
Term.Description: The area from the middle of the chest and above.

Term.Title: High Lob Serve
Term.Description: When the ball touches the side-wall on its way into the back court but it does not come off the back-wall.

Term.Description: The elite end of NSOs operations

High Speed Cameras
Term.Description: A device used for recording fast moving objects as a photographic image onto a storage media.

Term.Title: High Stick
Term.Description: This is when a stick is carried above the height of the opponent's shoulders. A player is permitted accidental contact on an opponent if the act is committed as a normal windup or follow through of a shooting motion. But any contact made by a stick on an opponent above the shoulders is prohibited and a minor penalty will be imposed.

Term.Title: High Tackle
Term.Description: A high tackle (or head-high tackle) is a form of tackle where the tackler grasps the ball carrier above the line of the shoulders (most commonly around the neck or at the line of the chin and jaw). Executed violently or at speed, a high tackle is potentially instantly lethal and, as extremely dangerous play, high tackles are a cause for penalties, and yellow or red cards.

Term.Title: High-Back Bindings
Term.Description: Bindings with a high back support for the snowboarders ankle and lower legs.

Term.Title: Highway
Term.Description: A large groove in the bottom of a half-pipe or up a half-pipe wall.

Term.Title: Hike
Term.Description: Synonym of "snap" - the handoff or pass from the centre that begins a play from scrimmage.

Term.Title: Hill Climb (Race)
Term.Description: A short distance uphill race, usually an individual time trial over approx. 35 km.

Term.Title: Hills District Athletics Club (SA)
Term.Description: www.hillsathletics.com

Term.Title: Hilt
Term.Description: The name for the handle of a sword it is also called a grip.

Term.Title: Hinder
Term.Description: When there is interference that causes stoppage of play during a service or a rally.

Term.Title: Hip Bursitis
Term.Description: A bursa is a small sack of fluid which is usually positioned in between a bone and a muscle or tendon. The function of a bursa is to prevent friction between the bone and overlying soft tissue. The most commonly injured bursa is the trochanteric bursa. This can be injured in one of two ways, through a direct impact to the bursa, such as a fall onto the outer hip, known as traumatic bursitis. Or through repetitive friction from the overlying muscles and tendons, usually during running. This repeated friction results in the bursa becoming inflamed and swollen. Every time the tendons then rub over the bursa, this causes pain.

Term.Title: Hip n Shoulder
Term.Description: A legal bump.

Term.Title: Hip Toss
Term.Description: One attacking wrestler will be if front of the other wrestler and the attacker will grab his opponent's right arm across the front of his body. He then drops to his right knee and throw his left hip into his opponent and this throws his rival forward across his back and the attacking wrestler is then able to pin his rival.

Term.Title: Hire
Term.Description: The price or compensation paid or contracted to be paid for the temporary use of something.

Term.Title: Hiring Manager
Term.Description: Leader of the selection team and often the supervisor of the vacant position, a hiring manager is authorised by the general manager/assistant director to plan and manage all the recruitment, selection and induction process.

Term.Title: Histidine
Term.Description: An essential amino acid, C 3 H 3 N 2 CH 2 CH(NH 2 )COOH, that is a constituent of proteins and is important as the iron-binding site in hemoglobin. Abbreviation: His; Symbol: H

Term.Title: Histrionic Personality Disorder
Term.Description: A psychological disorder usually beginning in early adulthood, characterized by excessive emotional expression and attention-seeking behavior.

Term.Title: Hit (Baseball)
Term.Description: A play in which the batter safely reaches a base after hitting the ball, without aid from a fielding error or fielders choice.

Term.Title: Hit (Fencing)
Term.Description: When one fencer is able to, with an attacking movement, strike their opponent. A hit can be either on or off target.

Term.Title: Hit (Hockey)
Term.Description: When a player is able to draw his stick way back and hit the ball with a lot of force. This stroke is used to make long passes or take shots on goals.

Term.Title: Hit (Softball)
Term.Description: A play in which the batter safely reaches a base after hitting the ball, without aid from a fielding error or fielders choice.

Term.Title: Hit and Run
Term.Description: Play-action situation in which the batter must swing at the pitch while the base runner attempts to steal the base.

Term.Title: Hit Below the Belt
Term.Description: To hit an opponent below the belt is an illegal move in boxing.

Term.Title: Hit the Ball Twice
Term.Description: Law 34 of the Laws of cricket provides that the striker is out if hit the ball twice if, while the ball is in play, it strikes any part of his person or is struck by his bat and, before the ball has been touched by a fielder, he wilfully strikes it again with his bat or person, other than a hand not holding the bat, except for the sole purpose of guarding his wicket. 'Struck' or 'strike' shall include contact with the person of the striker." The bowler does not get credit for the wicket.

Term.Title: Hit the Wall
Term.Description: To completely run out of energy on a long ride.

Term.Title: Hit Wicket
Term.Description: Hit wicket is a method of dismissal in the sport of cricket. This method of dismissal is governed by Law 35 of the laws of cricket. The striker is out "hit wicket" if, after the bowler has entered his delivery stride and while the ball is in play, his wicket is put down by his bat or his person. The striker may do this whilst preparing to receive or receiving a delivery or in setting off for his first run after playing the delivery. In simple language if the striking batsman knocks the bails off the stumps or uproots the stumps, while attempting to hit the ball or take off for a run, he is out hit wicket.

Term.Title: Hitch
Term.Description: A knot used to tie a rope or line to a fixed object.

Term.Title: Hitting (Bocce)
Term.Description: Hitting or Spock - A declared underhand bowling type hard throw directly at the balls on the court to purposely hit and move an opponent's ball or the pallino. Sometimes called spocking, shooting, bombing, or raffa.

Term.Title: Hitting Alley
Term.Description: The lane the ball follows on its way to the front wall.

Term.Title: Hitting Foul Line
Term.Description: The second foul line marked on the sideboards/court surface 10 feet from each backboard behind which the bocce balls thrown hard to hit and move other bocce balls or the pallino must be released. This allows for a running delivery to gain momentum on the ball. Sometimes called the spocking, shooting, bombing, or raffa foul line.

Term.Title: Hitting the Wall
Term.Description: A condition caused by the depletion of glycogen stores in the liver and muscles, which manifests itself by sudden fatigue and loss of energy.

Term.Title: HIV AIDS
Term.Description: A disease of the immune system characterized by increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as pneumocystis carinii pneumonia and candidiasis, to certain cancers, as Kaposi's sarcoma, and to neurological disorders caused by a retrovirus and transmitted chiefly through blood or blood products that enter the body's bloodstream, especially by sexual contact or contaminated hypodermic needles.

Term.Title: Hives
Term.Description: Any of various eruptive conditions of the skin.

Term.Title: Hog Lines
Term.Description: The line which the stone must completely cross to be considered in play and the line by which the stone must be clearly and fully released by the thrower.

Term.Title: Holding (Gridiron)
Term.Description: Offensive holding is illegally blocking a player from the opposing team by grabbing and holding his uniform or body. Defensive holding is called against defensive players who hold offensive players, but who are not actively making an attempt to catch the ball (if the defensive player were to impede an offensive player in the act of catching the ball, that would be the more severe foul of pass interference).

Term.Title: Holding (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: A minor penalty which occurs when a player grabs and holds onto an opponent (or stick) with their hands or arms to impede the opponents progress.

Term.Title: Holding the Ball
Term.Description: When a player gets tackled and the umpire rules that he did not make a legitimate attempt to kick or pass the ball to a teammate, then the opposing team is awarded a free kick.

Term.Title: Hole in One

Term.Title: Home Plate
Term.Description: The fourth station to be reached by the runner. The offensive team is credited with one run every time a player safely crosses this base. A pitched ball must cross the plate when thrown by the pitchers to be credited as a strike on the batter.

Term.Title: Home Run
Term.Description: A ball hit out of the playing field in fair territory. A home run scores the batter and any base runners.

Term.Title: Home Run (Baseball)
Term.Description: A ball hit out of the playing field in fair territory. A home run scores the batter and any base runners.

Term.Title: Hook Check
Term.Description: A sweep of the stick low to the ice to take the puck from an opponents stick.

Term.Title: Hook Steer
Term.Description: A way of steering with the competitor hooking their toe under the horn of the cufin which lifts the front of the cufin and the sled goes in the direction of the lifted cufin.

Term.Title: Hooker
Term.Description: Hookers traditionally wear the number 2 shirt. The hooker is the player who is in the centre position of the front row of the scrum and who uses his /her feet to 'hook' the ball back. Due to the pressure put on the body by the scrum and the requirement to use both arms to bind to other players (and hence having no free arm to use to support or deflect bodyweight) it is considered to be one of the most dangerous positions to play. Hookers normally throw the ball in at line-outs, partly because they are normally the shortest of the forwards, but more often because they are the most skillful of the forwards.

Term.Title: Hooker (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: The hooker, numbered 9, packs in the middle of the scrum's front row.

Term.Title: Hooking
Term.Description: Using the blade of the hockey stick to trip or pull at an opposing player which is not allowed.

Term.Title: Hot Seating

Term.Title: Hurdler
Term.Description: Track and Field athlete who competes in the Hurdle race.

Term.Title: Hurdling
Term.Description: Hurdling is the sport of running and jumping over an obstacle (hurdle) at speed. The hurdles are set at different heights and distances apart depending on the event. The events are most frequently run over courses that are either 100m, 110m, or 400m in distance.

Term.Title: Hurling
Term.Description: An Irish game resembling hockey, played with a shorter stick with a broader oval blade. It is the national game of Ireland and may date back to the 2nd millennium BC.

Term.Description: Stroke variations that swimmers use to make their routine more interesting.

Term.Title: Hydrogen Ion
Term.Description: Ionized hydrogen of the form H + , found in aqueous solutions of all acids.

Term.Title: Hyperextension
Term.Description: Extension of a segment past the anatomical position.

Term.Title: Hyperglycaemia
Term.Description: An abnormally high level of glucose in the blood.

Term.Title: Hyperhydration
Term.Description: Packing the body with a greater than normal level of fluid, usually prior to the commencement of exercise; Excess water content of the body.

Term.Title: Hypernatremia
Term.Description: An abnormally high concentration of sodium in the blood.

Term.Title: Hyperthermia

Term.Title: Hypothyroidism

Term.Title: Hypotonic
Term.Description: When comparing two solutions this term refers to the one with the lower osmolarity (less concentrated); a solution of lower osmotic pressure than another solution with which it is compared.

Term.Title: Hypovolemia
Term.Description: An abnormally low blood volume.

Term.Title: Hypoxia-inducible Factors
Term.Description: HIFs are transcription factors that respond to changes in available oxygen in the cellular environment, specifically, to decreases in oxygen, or hypoxia.

Term.Title: Hypoxic Training
Term.Description: A way to help swimmers deal with a lack of oxygen. In training exercises a swimmer will swim some distance without breathing.

Term.Title: Ice Dancing
Term.Description: One part of figure skating where a couple must dance without using lifts and turns. It has three compulsory elements to it, a free dance, an original dance and two compulsory dances.

Term.Title: Ice Dancing Compulsory Dances
Term.Description: In Ice Dancing there are two compulsory dances and they are each worth 10 percent of the team's total score. All the skaters must complete the same two selected dances to the same music. Each of the dances has set rhythms and specific steps that are required be preformed in a specific way. Each team will receive one technique mark and one timing / expression mark for each of the dances.

Term.Title: Ice Dancing Free Dance
Term.Description: The final phase of the ice dancing competition. The free dance has few restrictions on it. The skaters are free to choose the tone and rhythm of their music and are given four minutes to exhibit a range of technical skills and resourcefulness using choreography that they have designed. Teams receive one technical merit mark and one presentation mark. The Free Dance counts for 50 percent of an ice dance team's total score.

Term.Title: Ice Dancing Original Dance
Term.Description: The original dance segment of ice dancing is the second of three segments and it is worth 30 percent of the team's total score. The ISU selects a piece of music and the skaters must come up with a completely original dance to perform with the music. The original dance segment lasts two minutes. The teams are judged and get one composition mark and one presentation mark.

Term.Description: A hockey rink is 61 metres long and 25.9 metres wide in the NHL. In the Olympics the rink is the same length but it is 30.5 metres wide.

Term.Title: Ice Sledge Classification (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Athletes must have a permanent impairment in the lower part of the body that means that the athlete is unable to compete in standing ice-hockey. Examples include leg amputation, spinal cord injury, cerebral palsy and significant leg length difference. Athletes are allocated a classification of E (eligible) or NE (not eligible).

Term.Title: Ice Sledge Hockey (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Ice Sledge Hockey is the Paralympic version of Ice Hockey. Since its debut on the Paralympic Programme at the Lillehammer 1994 Winter Paralympics, it has quickly become one of the largest attractions for spectators at the Winter Paralympics. It is fast-paced, highly physical and played by male athletes with a physical disability in the lower part of the body. It follows the rules of the International Ice Hockey Federation (IIHF) with modifications. Instead of skates, players use two-blade sledges that allow the puck to pass beneath. Players use two sticks, which have a spike-end for pushing and a blade-end for shooting. Ic Sledge Hockey is an 8 Team Tournament.
