Term.Description: The place kick is a kicking style commonly used when kicking for goal. It typically involves placing the ball on the ground. To keep the ball in position, a mound of sand or plastic tee is sometimes used.

Term.Title: Placebo Effect
Term.Description: A reaction to a placebo (a substance having no pharmacological effect but given merely to satisfy a patient who supposes it to be a medicine) manifested by a lessening of symptoms or the production of anticipated side effects.

Term.Title: Plain Text
Term.Description: The intelligible original message of a cryptogram, as opposed to the coded or enciphered version.

Term.Title: Plaintiff
Term.Description: A party who initiates a civil action.

Term.Title: Plan
Term.Description: Forumulating ways in which objectives can be achieved (includes determination of services, needs and solutions).

Term.Title: Planning
Term.Description: The process of formulating ways in which objectives can be achieved. Includes determination of services, needs and solutions to those needs.

Term.Title: Plans
Term.Description: Lists of steps with timing and resources, used to achieve an objective.

Term.Title: Plant (Assets)
Term.Description: the equipment, including the fixtures, machinery, tools, etc., necessary to carry on any business.

Term.Title: Plantar
Term.Description: On the sole of the foot.

Term.Title: Plantar Fascia Strain
Term.Description: The plantar fascia or arch ligament is a band that runs from under the heel to the front of the foot. A strain or rupture to this is quite common. A plantar fascia strain might result from one single traumatic incident or may gradually occur over a period of time.

Term.Title: Plantar Fasciitis
Term.Description: A painful condition caused by overuse of the plantar fascia or arch tendon of the foot. The Plantar Fascia is a broad, thick band of tissue that runs from under the heel to the front of the foot.

Term.Title: Plantar flexion
Term.Description: The movement which increases the approximate 90 degree angle between the front part of the foot and the shin, as when depressing an automobile pedal.

Term.Title: Plasma Expanders
Term.Description: A substance that is administered intravenously to increase oncotic pressure.

Term.Title: Plastron
Term.Description: This is a required protective garment that is worn under a fencer's jacket. It is usually made of Kevlar, so that it will not be penetrated.

Term.Title: Plate Binding
Term.Description: A binding that is used with hard-shell boots.

Term.Title: Platelet-derived Growth Factor
Term.Description: Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) is one of the numerous growth factors, or proteins that regulate cell growth and division.

Term.Title: Platform (Synchronised Swimming)
Term.Description: When swimmers, who are not allowed to touch the bottom of the pool, group themselves together to support or hold one swimmer on top of the water and another swimmer who will be completely out of the water, standing on the swimmer who is lying flat on top of the water.

Term.Title: Platter Lift
Term.Description: A lift which has the man holding the female skater over his head his hands holding her by the hips and the female skaters body is horizontal to the ice.

Term.Title: Play Action
Term.Description: A tactic in which the quarterback fakes either a handoff or a throw in order to draw the defense away from the intended offensive method.

Term.Title: Play by the Rules
Term.Description: Play by the Rules provides information and online learning for community sport and recreation on how to prevent and deal with discrimination, harassment and child abuse, and develop inclusive and welcoming environments for participation. A joint ASC and Government Sporting Bodies initiative. http://www.playbytherules.net.au/

Term.Title: Play the Ball
Term.Description: The play-the-ball is used to restart play in various instances during a game, but most-commonly immediately following a tackle.

Term.Title: Play. Sport. Australia.
Term.Description: Launched by the ASC in 2015, Play.Sport.Australia. is Australias national policy platform aimed at improving participation in organised sport.

Term.Title: PARTICIPATION TERMS (including Development and Sport Relations)
Player Coach
Term.Description: A member of a sports team who simultaneously holds both playing and coaching duties.

Term.Title: Playing Area
Term.Description: The playing area is 46 feet (14 metres) long and 23 (7 metres) wide with the table in the center of this area. There should be panels around the edge of the playing area and these should be approx. 30 inches (75 centimetres) high. These are to prevent a ball from going outside of the playing area.

Term.Title: Playing Areas and equipment
Term.Description: Coaches to ensure safety of playing areas and equipment.

Term.Title: Playing For Life
Term.Description: Multi-skill activities included in the Playing for Life resource kit are aimed at providing primary school aged children with games rather than drills to introduce the skills and tactics of the particular sport or structured physical activity being delivered.

Term.Title: Playing Surface
Term.Description: The surface of the tabletop should be dark green and the table is 9 feet (2.74 metres) long and 5 feet (1.52) metres wide. There is a white line that is .8 inches (2 centimetres) wide that runs around the entire edge of the table.

Term.Title: Playing Through
Term.Description: When one group of golfers is playing slower then the group behind them, golfing etiquette says you should let the faster group go ahead of the slower group.

Term.Title: PlayStation
Term.Description: A series of video game consoles created and developed by Sony Computer Entertainment.

Term.Title: Pleural cavity
Term.Description: The potential space between the visceral pleura and parietal pleura.

Term.Title: Plimsoll Line
Term.Description: A special marking, positioned amidships that indicates the draft of the vessel.

Term.Title: Plotter
Term.Description: A plotter is a computer printing device for printing vector graphics.

Term.Title: Plug In
Term.Description: A module or piece of software that can be added to a system to provide extra functions or features, especially software that enhances the capabilities of a web browser.

Term.Title: Plunger / Pressure Button
Term.Description: A device used to correct an arrow's flex at the point of release.

Term.Title: Plyometrics
Term.Description: Drills or exercises linking strength and scop of movement to produce an explosive type of movement

Term.Title: Pneumonia
Term.Description: Inflammation of the lungs with congestion.

Term.Title: Pocket (Gridiron)
Term.Description: An area on the offensive side of the line of scrimmage, where the offensive linemen attempt to prevent the defensive players from reaching the quarterback during passing plays.

Term.Title: Pocket Area
Term.Description: An area where the quarterback tries to stay when he is passing the ball. This area is a point inside the two guards and includes the tight end if he moves off the line of scrimmage to pass protect.If the quarterback is in the pocket he can't intentionally throw the ball into the ground.

Term.Title: Podium
Term.Description: The platform on which the top three competitors of an event are awarded medals or trophies. Traditionally a winner's podium has three levels indicating the winners of first, second and third place - the highest level for the competitor taking first.

Term.Title: Pogies
Term.Description: A type of mitten with holes on each end, which allow the rower to grip the oar with bare hands while also warming the hands, used frequently by rowers in colder climates.

Term.Title: Point (Sailing)
Term.Description: A unit of bearing equal to one thirty-second of a circle, i.e., 11.25. A turn of 32 points is a complete turn through 360.

Term.Title: Point (Water Polo)
Term.Description: Position on offense in the centre of the line furthest from the goal. The point player's position provides opportunities to pass to teammates and communicate among the offense

Term.Title: Point Feature
Term.Description: A feature in the terrain that only occupies a small area. Frequently mapped examples are boulders, pits and mounds, stumps, and root mounds.

Term.Title: Point Guard
Term.Description: The backcourt player who directs the team's offense.

Term.Title: Point Up
Term.Description: To change the direction of a sailboat so that it is more up wind.

Term.Title: Pointing
Term.Description: The underhand throwing action of a player to roll the bocce ball as close to the pallino as possible to score points. Throwing styles vary from player to player. Pointing is sometimes called punto, or puntata.

Term.Title: Pointing Foul Line
Term.Description: The first foul line marked on the sideboards/court surface 6 feet from each backboard behind which the pallino and bocce balls rolled for point must be released. Sometimes called the lagging, throwing, pitch, punto, or puntata foul line.

Term.Title: Points Race
Term.Description: A bunch race (maximum of 24 riders) competing over 20, 30 or 40km. Riders aim to gain points, with the highest score winning the event. Points can be scored at "Intermediate" sprints, which are usually held every 10 or 20 laps. A bonus of 20 points can also be scored by lapping the field.

Term.Title: Points Race (Men)
Term.Description: A bunch race (maximum of 24 riders) competing over 20, 30 or 40km. Riders aim to gain points, with the highest score winning the event. Points can be scored at "Intermediate" sprints, which are usually held every 10 or 20 laps. A bonus of 20 points can also be scored by lapping the field.

Term.Title: Points Race (Women)
Term.Description: A bunch race (maximum of 24 riders) competing over 20, 30 or 40km. Riders aim to gain points, with the highest score winning the event. Points can be scored at "Intermediate" sprints, which are usually held every 10 or 20 laps. A bonus of 20 points can also be scored by lapping the field.

Term.Title: Poke Check
Term.Description: A quick jab or thrust to the puck or opponents stick to knock the puck away from them.

Term.Title: Poland
Term.Description: Country code = PL

Term.Title: Pole Vault
Term.Description: A field event in which an athlete vaults over a high crossbar with the aid of a long pole.

Term.Title: Pole Vaulter
Term.Description: Track and Field athlete who competes in the Pole Vault.

Term.Title: Pole Vaulter (Heptathlete)
Term.Description: Track and Field athlete who competes in the Pole Vault.

Term.Title: Poles Outriggers (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Skiers in Alpine Skiing events use poles for propulsion and balance. The poles for Downhill and Super-G events are curved to fit around the body. Slalom poles are straight and usually have plastic guards to protect the hands from injury. Athletes in certain Paralympic classifications (e.g. single-leg amputees who ski without a prosthesis, sit-ski users) use special poles called outriggers. Outriggers have short ski blades on the end and help the skier with balance.

Term.Title: Policy
Term.Description: A definite course of action or set of principles adopted by a government or organisation formulated to determine actions and activities.

Term.Title: Poling
Term.Description: A reference to a skier using their poles to help them move along the course. Skiers also use their poles when making turns.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Polio
Term.Description: Poliomyelitis; An acute viral disease, usually affecting children and young adults, caused by any of three polioviruses, characterized by inflammation of the motor neurons of the brain stem and spinal cord, and resulting in a motor paralysis, followed by muscular atrophy and often permanent deformities.

Term.Title: Polo
Term.Description: Polo is a team sport played on horseback. The objective is to score goals against an opposing team. Players score by driving a small white plastic or wooden ball into the opposing team's goal using a long-handled mallet. The traditional sport of polo is played at speed on a large grass field up to 274 meters long by 146 meters wide, and each polo team consists of four riders and their mounts.

Term.Title: Polocrosse
Term.Description: Polocrosse is a team sport that is played all over the world. It is a combination of polo and lacrosse. It is played outside, on a field (the pitch), on horseback. Each rider uses a cane or fibreglass stick to which is attached a racquet head with a loose, thread net, in which the ball is carried. The ball is made of sponge rubber and is approximately 10.16 centimeters across. The objective is to score goals by throwing the ball between the opposing team's goal posts.

Term.Title: Polocrosse Association of Australia Inc
Term.Description: http://www.polocrosse.org.au/ PO Box 3221 EXETER NSW 2759 1300 363 722

Term.Title: Polocrosse World Cup
Term.Description: http://www.polocrosse.com/

Term.Title: Polynormande
Term.Description: http://au.eurosport.com

Term.Title: Pommel Horse
Term.Description: The pommel horse is a piece of gymnastics apparatus. Originally made of a metal frame with a wooden body and a leather cover, modern pommel horses have a metal body covered with foam rubber and leather, with plastic handles (or pommels). The composition, size, and gymnastic elements are all regulated by the Federation Internationale de Gymnastique.

Term.Title: Men's Artistic Gymnastics Commonwealth Games Events
Ponderal Index
Term.Description: Measure of leanness of a person calculated as a relationship between height and mass.

Term.Title: Pony Club Australia
Term.Description: http://www.ponyclubaustralia.com.au/

Term.Title: Riding for the Disabled Association of Australia
Pool Pattern
Term.Description: The patterns the swimmers use as they move through the water.

Term.Title: Pop Tart
Term.Description: To get air from fakie to forward in the half-pipe but without rotation.

Term.Title: Popliteal Cyst
Term.Description: In the hollow bit at the back of the knee is a bursa (a small sack of fluid used to help lubricate the joint). A fairly uncommon condition is when the back of the joint gets swollen and causes the bursa to swell also. Usually some disorder of the knee causes the synovial (lubricating) fluid within the knee joint to increase. This then spills into the bursa at the back of the knee causing it to increase in size.

Term.Title: Popliteal space
Term.Description: The space behind the knee joint.

Term.Title: Popliteus
Term.Description: Medially rotates leg on thigh.

Term.Title: Port (Rowing)
Term.Description: A sweep rower who rows with the oar on the port or left side of the boat.

Term.Title: Port (Sailing)
Term.Description: The left side of the boat.

Term.Title: Port Adelaide Power
Term.Description: Australian Football League Club Team.

Term.Title: Port Adelaide Rowing Club
Term.Description: http://portadelaiderowingclub.com/

Term.Title: Port Phillip Bay
Term.Description: Melbourne VIC 3000

Term.Title: Port Pirie Pura Light Start State Masters Games
Term.Description: http://portpiriemastersgames.com.au/

Term.Title: Port tack
Term.Description: When sailing with the wind coming from the port side of the vessel.

Term.Title: Portable and Attractive
Term.Description: Items that are valued at less than $2000, are not computer equipment or laser printers, and are an item that is desirable and easily portable.

Term.Title: Portfolio Budget Statements
Term.Description: A statement by a government department that provides additional details and explanations of the Budget and the Statement of Risks, which is included in Budget Paper.

Term.Title: Portugal
Term.Description: Country code = PT

Term.Title: Position
Term.Description: A post of employment that comprises a group of specified responsibilities, tasks and activities .

Term.Title: Position of Readiness
Term.Description: A place on the court, usually in the centre, which a player tries to return after every shot to be in a position to return the next shot.

Term.Title: Positional Jump
Term.Description: A jump for the purpose of displaying a position, such as stag jumps and split jumps.

Term.Title: Positioning
Term.Description: A defensive move to attempt to keep a rival from performing a throwing movement.

Term.Title: Possession
Term.Description: The actual physical possession, or the constructive possession (which shall be found only if the person has exclusive control over the prohibited substance or prohibited method or the premises in which a prohibited substance or prohibited method exists), provided however, that if the person does not have exclusive control over the prohibited substance or prohibited method or the premises in which a prohibited substance or prohibited method exists, constructive possession shall only be found if the person knew about the presence of the prohibited substance or prohibited method and intended to exercise control over it. Provided, however, there shall be no anti-doping rule violation based solely on possession if, prior to receiving notifi cation of any kind that the person has committed an anti-doping rule violation, the person has taken concrete action demonstrating that the person never intended to have possession and has renounced possession by explicitly declaring it to an Anti-Doping Organisation. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this definition, the purchase (including by any electronic or other means) of a prohibited substance or prohibited method constitutes possession by the person who makes the purchase.

Term.Title: Possession (Gridiron)
Term.Description: Having the ball on offense for a number of downs, ultimately resulting in either a score, a turn-over, or the end of the half; Physical control of the ball after a pass or fumble.

Term.Title: Post Danmark Rundt
Term.Description: http://paris.thover.com

Term.Title: Post Pattern
Term.Description: A passing route in which the receiver sprints 8 to 10 yards, fakes a look back at the Quarterback, then sprints deep at an angle toward the middle of the field. The opposite pattern is the flag route.

Term.Title: Post Traumatic Stress Disorder
Term.Description: A mental disorder, as battle fatigue, occurring after a traumatic event outside the range of usual human experience, and characterized by symptoms such as reliving the event, reduced involvement with others, and manifestations of autonomic arousal such as hyperalertness and exaggerated startle response.

Term.Title: Poster
Term.Description: A placard or bill posted.

Term.Title: Posterior
Term.Description: Backward.

Term.Title: Posterior Cruciate Ligament Injury
Term.Description: The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) functions mainly in preventing the tibia from traveling backwards on the femur, known as posterior drawer. It also helps to prevent the tibia from twisting outwards. Injury to the ligament leads to knee instability with the shin bone having a tendency to 'sag' backwards when the knee is bent at 90 degrees.

Term.Title: Posterior Tibial Tendon Dysfunction
Term.Description: A dysfunction of the muscle, resulting in a fallen arch, or flat feet.

Term.Title: Posterior Tibialis Tendonitis
Term.Description: An overuse injury of the tibialis posterior muscle which passes down the back of the leg and under the medial malleolus due to degeneration of the tendon rather than acute inflammation.

Term.Title: Posthumous
Term.Description: After death.

Term.Title: Postpartum Disorder
Term.Description: A major depressive episode, which occurs after having a baby.

Term.Title: Pot Lid
Term.Description: The center portion of the circle where the tees meet.

Term.Title: Potassium
Term.Description: A silvery-white metallic element that oxidizes rapidly in the air and whose compounds are used as fertilizer and in special hard glasses. Symbol: K; atomic weight: 39.102; atomic number: 19; specific gravity: 0.86 at 20C.

Term.Title: Potato Bowl
Term.Description: A badly thrown (or released) bowl that hops, skips and jumps.

Term.Title: Potential International Athlete
Term.Description: Athlete with the capability to achieve at least international class athlete status within 4-7 years. Based on US research showing that most Olympians averaged approximately 7 years of structured training (role of NESC members) before gaining national senior team selection.

Term.Title: Power
Term.Description: Rate at which work is done.

Term.Title: Power (Strength & Conditioning)
Term.Description: The ability to generate high levels of force as quickly as possible. It is a function of speed and strength

Term.Title: Power Alley
Term.Description: A cross-court hit traveling away from the spiker to the farthest point of the court.

Term.Title: Power Dribble
Term.Description: A dribble used in the low post involving a two handed, short dribble, usually in line with the middle of your body. A wide base is made with the feet, then a two handed "power dribble" is used.

Term.Title: Power Football Australia NSW
Term.Description: http://fipfa.org/

Term.Title: Power Forward
Term.Description: A basketball forward whose size and strength are used primarily in controlling play near the basket.

Term.Title: Power of Attorney
Term.Description: Authority to represent someone or act as his or her agent and conduct business in his or her name.

Term.Title: Power Output
Term.Description: The alternating-current power in watts delivered by an amplifier to a load.

Term.Title: Power Play
Term.Description: When a team has more players on the ice than the opposition.

Term.Title: Power Serve
Term.Description: A serve hit low and fast to a rear corner of the court. This is also called a drive serve.

Term.Title: Power Side
Term.Description: Refers to the side where the skier is using their pole.

Term.Title: Power Supply Unit
Term.Description: The component that supplies power to the other components in a computer.

Term.Title: Power to Mass Ratio
Term.Description: The rate of doing work expressed relative to body mass.

Term.Title: Powerbook G4
Term.Description: The PowerBook G4 is a series of notebook computers that was manufactured, marketed, and sold by Apple Computer, Inc. between 2001 and 2006 as part of its PowerBook line.

Term.Title: Powerlifting
Term.Description: Powerlifting is a strength sport that consists of three lifting disciplines: Squat, Bench press, and Deadlift.

Term.Title: Powerlifting (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Powerlifting for athletes with a disability made its first appearance in 1964 at the second Paralympic Games in Tokyo as Weightlifting. Later it changed from Weightlifting to Powerlifting. The competition is open to all athletes with cerebral palsy, spinal injuries, short stature, amputees (lower limb amputees only) and les autres who meet minimal disability criteria. Powerlifting is the ultimate test of upper body strength. Competitors must lower the bar to the chest, hold it motionless on the chest and then press it upwards to arms length with locked elbows. The bench press is the only discipline with 10 different categories based on body weight. The athletes are given three attempts and the winner is the athlete who lifts the highest number of kilograms.

Term.Title: Powerlifting Australia Ltd
Term.Description: http://www.powerliftingaustralia.com/

Term.Title: Powerplay (Rugby League)
Term.Description: Powerplay refers to the act of running the ball on the fifth tackle instead of kicking it.

Term.Title: Powerpoint
Term.Description: A Microsoft application for creating presentations, speeches, slides, etc.

Term.Title: PR
Term.Description: Personal Record.

Term.Title: Prasterone
Term.Description: An endogenous steroid hormone.

Term.Title: Praxis Sport Science
Term.Description: Praxis Sport Science is a consultancy company delivering tailored solutions to high performance sporting programs.

Term.Title: Prayer
Term.Description: A shot attempted from outside the normal range of a player usually with the clock running out.

Term.Title: Preamble
Term.Description: An introduction, introductory words or passages.

Term.Title: Precedent
Term.Description: The concept that a legal principle or form decided in an earlier instance, or case, should be used in a subsequent one.

Term.Title: Precedents
Term.Description: Judgments quoted as an authority for deciding a similar set of facts. Must come from an equivalent or higher court.

Term.Title: Precision Bearing
Term.Description: Some compasses can be used to take a precise bearing (degrees clockwise from north) which can then be followed in the terrain.

Term.Title: Preferred Lie
Term.Description: Allows a golfer to move his / her ball to the nearest point of relief, a place where the ball can be hit, that is not closer to the hole.

Term.Title: Preliminary Swings (Hammer Throw)
Term.Description: The purpose of the swings is to give the hammer momentum, establish a rhythm, start the hammer rotating in the correct plane and establish a correct balance.

Term.Title: Premenstrual Syndrome
Term.Description: A collection of physical and emotional symptoms related to a woman's menstrual cycle.

Term.Title: Preparticipation Screening
Term.Description: Coaches need to ensure that they choose activities that are appropriate for the participant's physical stature, ability, and health.

Term.Title: Prepayment
Term.Description: To pay or arrange to pay beforehand or before due.

Term.Title: Preseason
Term.Description: Games played before the official start of the season that do not count toward the final team standings.

Term.Title: Presentation
Term.Description: Any form of visual and / or verbal communication used to show or explain a topic to an audience.

Term.Title: Presentation Mark
Term.Description: The judges award points for the choreography of a routine and how well the choreography was done from a technical standpoint.

Term.Title: Presentation Packages
Term.Description: Promotional material such as leaflets, brochures, handouts, publicity material and gimmicks, distributed to promote an event or service provided by the organisation.

Term.Title: President's Junior Interstate Shield
Term.Description: http://www.tenpinevents.org.au/Records/Presidents_Shield_Games.htm

Term.Title: Press Defence
Term.Description: Defensive pressure on the attacking team by closely defending each player man to man.

Term.Title: Pressing
Term.Description: This is when one fencer is moving their blade from side to side, inviting the other fencer to attack.

Term.Title: Presumption of Fact
Term.Description: An assumption which is made in a legal case - an inference drawn from the facts.

Term.Title: Prevalence of injury and illness problems
Term.Description: Many injuries and illness do not result in loss of training or competition time. The National Injury and Illness Database has adopted the scoring system proposed by Clarsen et. al. where the proposed definition of a recordable incident (injury or illness) is inappropriate. For example, the prevalence of shoulder pain in Australian water polo players is currently monitored via weekly questionnaires based on the Clarsen method. It is expected that this method will be adopted where appropriate among NSOs into the future. The Clarsen method requires input from the athlete and where this is unobtainable it is possible to measure the prevalence of missed or modified training and competition due to injury or illness from participation records. This allows similar data to be collected without the reliance of athlete self-reports.

Term.Title: Data dictionary for the National Injury and Illness Database
Preventer
Term.Description: A sail control line originating at some point on the boom leading to a fixed point on the boat's deck or rail used to prevent or moderate the effects of an accidental jibe.

Term.Title: Price Waterhouse Coopers
Term.Description: Global professional services firm and one of the big four accountancy firms.

Term.Title: Pride Football Australia
Term.Description: Established in 2009, Pride Football Australia is an annual gay and lesbian football tournament in which teams compete for the Justin Fashanu Cup (men) and the Julie Murray Cup (women).

Term.Title: The Flying Bats Women's Football Club
Prijs Stad Roeselare
Term.Description: http://www.womenscycling.net/

Term.Title: Prima Facie
Term.Description: Latin meaning 'as it first appears' or 'at first sight'.

Term.Title: Prima Facie Case
Term.Description: A showing of sufficient evidence to initially establish a petitioner's case. If such a case is made out, the opposing party is then required to respond. If not, the case will be dismissed.

Term.Title: Prime (Fencing)
Term.Description: One of the 8 basic ways or positions to hold a weapon, and the ways in which parries are made. The name further refers to the place where the parry will be scored on the torso. Is located in the Low Lines.

Term.Title: Princeton Offence
Term.Description: The Princeton offense is an offensive basketball strategy which emphasizes constant motion, passing, back-door cuts, and disciplined teamwork.

Term.Title: Principal
Term.Description: Principal is the amount of a debt that was originally borrowed, and which remains unpaid.

Term.Title: Privacy Act
Term.Description: http://www.privacy.gov.au/law/act

Term.Title: Privacy Act 1988
Term.Description: The Privacy Act defines what is personal infomation, what can be collected, terms for use and disclosure.

Term.Title: Private Company
Term.Description: A company owned by shareholders, and which is not publicly traded on the stock exchange. Private can also mean an entity which is a non-government organisation.

Term.Title: Pro Am
Term.Description: First major tournament of each calendar year always played at Augusta National Course in Georgia.

Term.Title: Pro Jump
Term.Description: A drop on a racecourse that is between 2- to 4 foot-high.

Term.Title: Pro Rata
Term.Description: In proportion.

Term.Title: Pro shop
Term.Description: A place at a golf course where you sign up to start play, enrol in lessons and buy balls, clubs and clothing.

Term.Title: Pro-Am
Term.Description: A tournament where an amateur is the partner of a professional.

Term.Title: Probability
Term.Description: A measure of the chance of occurrence expressed as a number between 0 and 1. The extent to which an event is likely to occur.

Term.Title: Probable Cause
Term.Description: A strong reason to suspect something; reasonable grounds.

Term.Title: Probate
Term.Description: A court procedure which determines the validity of a will.

Term.Title: Probation
Term.Description: Permission which is given to a person previously convicted of a crime to stay free from prison provided he or she stays out of trouble and reports to a probation officer at predetermined intervals.

Term.Title: Probenecid
Term.Description: A uricosuric drug that increases uric acid excretion in the urine.

Term.Title: Probiotics
Term.Description: Dietary supplement used for gastro and immune protection.

Term.Title: Procedural Fairness
Term.Description: The just administration of rules that provide how parties go about enforcing their legal rights.

Term.Title: Procedure
Term.Description: A sequence of actions or instructions to be followed.

Term.Title: Procedures
Term.Description: A documented official way of doing something.

Term.Title: Proceeds
Term.Description: Something that results or accrues.

Term.Title: Processing
Term.Description: To handle (papers, records, etc.) by systematically organizing them, recording or making notations on them, following up with appropriate action.

Term.Title: Processor
Term.Description: The key component of a computer system, which contains the circuitry necessary to interpret and execute program instructions.

Term.Title: Procurement
Term.Description: The acquisition of appropriate goods or services at the best possible total cost of ownership.

Term.Title: Product
Term.Description: A thing or concept that is produced, manufactured or refined and made available for profit or non-profit distribution.

Term.Title: Product Packaging
Term.Description: A product package might include a logo or other artwork, organized text and pure design elements such as shapes and color which unify the piece.

Term.Title: Productivity
Term.Description: A measure of the activity of a business based on a comparison of input and output.

Term.Title: Professional Development
Term.Description: Skills and knowledge attained for both personal development and career advancement.

Term.Title: Professional Golf Association
Term.Description: www.pga.com

Term.Title: Professional Squash Association
Term.Description: www.psa-squash.com

Term.Title: Profit
Term.Description: Pecuniary gain resulting from the employment of capital in any transaction.

Term.Title: Program
Term.Description: A plan of action to accomplish a specified end.

Term.Title: Program (Figure Skating)
Term.Description: The various movements, including jumps and spins, that a skater or skaters perform when on the ice. When taken as a whole this is referred to as a program.

Term.Title: Prohibited List
Term.Description: The list identifying the prohibited substances and prohibited methods which is published and revised by WADA as described in Article 4.1 of the Code, as updated from time to time.

Term.Title: Project
Term.Description: A temporary individual or collaborative enterprise that is created for the purpose of delivering one or more business products according to an agreed plan or business case.

Term.Title: Project Aperio
Term.Description: Project Aperio was established by the Australian Crime Commission in February 2012 to develop a deeper understanding of the use of performance and image enhancing drugs, including the nature, extent and resulting harms of the involvement of organised crime in this market.

Term.Title: Project Manager
Term.Description: A person on a project team who has the responsibility of the planning, execution and closing of any project.

Term.Title: Project Plan
Term.Description: A formal, approved document used to guide both project execution and project control; A statement of how and when a project's objectives are to be achieved, by showing the major products, milestones, activities and resources required on the project.

Term.Title: Project Plans
Term.Description: A formal, approved document used to guide both project execution and project control.

Term.Title: Project Team
Term.Description: A team whose members are assigned to activities for a specific project. Usually project teams are only used for a defined period of time and disbanded after the project is deemed complete.

Term.Title: Projectile
Term.Description: The name given to any item coming out of the barrel of any type of gun when it is fired.

Term.Title: Projection
Term.Description: A forecast of future trends in the operation of a business.

Term.Title: Proline
Term.Description: An alcohol-soluble amino acid, C 4 H 9 NHCOOH, occurring in high concentration in collagen. Abbreviation: Pro; Symbol: P

Term.Title: Promissory Note
Term.Description: A signed document which is a promise to pay a certain amount of money either on or after a designated date, or, on demand.

Term.Title: Promoting a Bowl
Term.Description: Pushing up one of your team's bowls to a better position.

Term.Title: Promotion
Term.Description: The advancement of an employee from one position to another position or work level that is classified as a being of higher level of work value and which usually attracts higher salary is called a promotion.

Term.Title: Pronation
Term.Description: Moving the flexed forearm so that the palm of the hand is turned posterior or inferior.

Term.Title: Pronator Teres
Term.Description: Pronates forearm and hand.

Term.Title: Prone Position
Term.Description: Prone shooting is mostly for rifle and is done lying face down, supporting the upper body on the elbows.

Term.Title: Prop
Term.Description: They are the players wearing shirts number 1 & 3. The role of both the props is to support the hooker in the scrum and to provide support for the jumpers in the line-out. The props provide the main power in the push forward in the scrum. For this reason they need to be exceptionally big and strong.

Term.Title: Prop (Rugby League Player)
Term.Description: There are two props, numbered 8 and 10, who pack in to the front row of the scrum on either side of the hooker.

Term.Title: Prop DrillDance
Term.Description: Prop DrillDance is a display of dance or drill movements highlighted by clever use of props.

Term.Title: Property Management
Term.Description: The function of managing land and working, storage or living space within premises, and of acquiring, constructing, fitting out, managing, maintaining, protecting and disposing of premises.

Term.Title: Proposal
Term.Description: A business proposal is a written offer from a seller to a prospective buyer. Business proposals are often a key step in the complex sales process., whenever a buyer considers more than price in a purchase.

Term.Title: Proprietary Company
Term.Description: A company that is registered as, or converts to, a proprietary company under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth). A proprietary company must have no more than 50 non-employee shareholders.

Term.Title: Proprietorship
Term.Description: A business owned and operated by a single person.

Term.Title: Propulsion Technique
Term.Description: The different ways a swimmer will use their arms and legs to propel them through the water.

Term.Title: Prostanozol
Term.Description: An anabolic steroid designer drug which is a prodrug of the 17-demethylated analogue of stanozolol.

Term.Title: Protected Zone
Term.Description: An imaginary corridor 5 metres to either side of a player who is taking a free kick, into which no players from either team are permitted to be.

Term.Title: Protection Area
Term.Description: The area that boarders the Passivity Zone. The match will be stopped if a wrestler has part of their body is in this area.

Term.Title: Protection Devices
Term.Description: Devices that are designed to reduce injuries in specific sports. Mouthguards, appropriate footwear, protective padding, goggles, helmets, gloves, personal floating devices, hand guards, wetsuits, etc.

Term.Title: Protective Gear (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Because of the physical nature of the game, all players are required to wear a helmet with a full cage or mask as well as a protective collar or bib. Players are also encouraged to wear protective padding, including shoulder pads, shin guards, elbow pads and large padded gloves. In addition, the goalkeeper wears leg pads, body pads, a helmet with a visor and a catcher glove to protect the athlete from pucks flying up to 100 km/h.

Term.Title: Protein
Term.Description: Any of numerous, highly varied organic molecules constituting a large portion of the mass of every life form and necessary in the diet of all animals and other nonphotosynthesizing organisms, composed of 20 or more amino acids linked in a genetically controlled linear sequence into one or more long polypeptide chains, the final shape and other properties of each protein being determined by the side chains of the amino acids and their chemical attachments: proteins include such specialized forms as collagen for supportive tissue, hemoglobin for transport, antibodies for immune defense, and enzymes for metabolism.

Term.Title: Proteoglycan
Term.Description: A macromolecule composed of a polysaccharide joined to a polypeptide and forming the ground substance of connective tissue.

Term.Title: Protocol and Special Events NSW
Term.Description: The events.nsw.gov.au website is an initiative of Protocol and Special Events (PSE) in the NSW Department of Premier and Cabinet. The website has been developed to provide a comprehensive resource for organisers of events in NSW.

Term.Title: Provision
Term.Description: A clause in a legal instrument, a law, etc., providing for a particular matter.

Term.Title: Provisional Hearing
Term.Description: An expedited abbreviated hearing occurring prior to a hearing that provides the Athlete with notice and an opportunity to be heard in either written or oral form.

Term.Title: Provisional Suspension
Term.Description: An athlete or other person is barred temporarily from participating in any competition prior to the final decision at a hearing conducted under Article 17as a result of an anti-doping rule violation.

Term.Title: Proximal
Term.Description: Where the appendage joins the body.

Term.Title: Proximus Diamond Games (Tennis)
Term.Description: http://www.itftennis.com/

Term.Title: Proxy
Term.Description: Someone authorised to act on behalf of another person, a properly appointed representative or agent (generally to vote).

Term.Title: Psoriasis
Term.Description: Psoriasis is a non-contagious skin condition. It causes red, scaly patches to develop on the skin. Skin affected by psoriasis grows much quicker than normal skin.

Term.Title: Psychotic Disorders
Term.Description: A mental disorder characterized by symptoms, such as delusions or hallucinations, that indicate impaired contact with reality.

Term.Title: PT1
Term.Description: PT1 - Wheelchair users. Includes athletes with comparable activity limitation and an impairment of, but not limited to: muscle power, limb deficiency, hypertonia, ataxia, athetosis that prevent the ability to safely ride a conventional bike and run. Through classification assessment, athletes must have a score of up to 640,0 points. Athletes must use a recumbent handcycle on the bike course and a racing wheelchair on the run segment.

Term.Title: PT2
Term.Description: PT2 - Includes athletes with comparable activity limitation and an impairment of, but not limited to, limb deficiency, hypertonia, ataxia and or athetosis, impaired muscle power or range of movement that through classification assessment have a score of up to 454,9 points. In both bike and run segments, amputee athletes may use approved prosthesis or other supportive devices.

Term.Title: PT3
Term.Description: PT3 - Includes athletes with comparable activity limitation and an impairment of, but not limited to, limb deficiency, hypertonia, ataxia and or athetosis, impaired muscle power or range of movement that through classification assessment have a score from 455,0 to 494,9 points. In both bike and run segments, the athlete may use approved prosthesis or other supportive devices.

Term.Title: PT4
Term.Description: PT4 - Includes athletes with comparable activity limitation and an impairment of, but not limited to, limb deficiency, hypertonia, ataxia and or athetosis, impaired muscle power or range of movement that through classification assessment have a score from 495,0 to 557,0 points included. In both bike and run segments, the athlete may use approved prosthesis or other supportive devices.

Term.Title: PT5
Term.Description: PT5 - Total or Partial visual Impairment (IBSA/IPC defined sub-classes B1, B2, and B3): Includes athletes who are totally blind, from no light perception in either eye, to some light perception but unable to recognize the shape of a hand at any distance or in any direction (B1) and partially sighted athletes with a visual acuity of less than 6/60 vision or visual field less than 20 degrees with best corrective vision (B2-B3). A guide from the same nationality and gender is mandatory throughout the race. Must ride a tandem during the bike segment.

Term.Title: Puberty
Term.Description: The process of physical changes by which a child's body becomes an adult body capable of reproduction.

Term.Title: Public Company
Term.Description: A company can offer shares to the public and can be traded on a public exchange, such as the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX).

Term.Title: Public Domain
Term.Description: A work is in public domain when the relevant copyright has expired.

Term.Title: Publication
Term.Description: The word publication means the act of publishing, and it also means any writing of which copies are published, and any website. Among publications are books, and periodicals, the latter including magazines, scholarly journals, and newspapers.

Term.Title: Publications
Term.Description: An item that is published - issue (printed or otherwise reproduced textual or graphic material, computer software, etc.) for sale or distribution.

Term.Title: Publicly Disclose
Term.Description: To disseminate or distribute information to the general public or persons beyond those persons entitled to earlier notification.

Term.Title: Puck (Alpine Skiing) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Made of vulcanised rubber or any other approved material, the puck is 2.54cm thick, with a diameter of 7.62cm and weighs 156 to 170 grams.

Term.Title: Puck (Freestyle Skiing)
Term.Description: A tuck position where the legs pulled up to a 45-degree angle.

Term.Title: Puck (Ice Hockey)
Term.Description: The puck is made of vulcanized rubber, is one inch thick and three inches in diameter and weighs between five and one-half ounces and six ounces.

Term.Title: Puddles
Term.Description: Disturbances made by an oar blade pulled through the water.

Term.Title: Puerto Rico
Term.Description: Country code = PR

Term.Title: Pull
Term.Description: When a skater moves their skate inward toward the midline of the body. A Skater will do this when they are doing a crossover or the double push stride.

Term.Title: Pull Through
Term.Description: The portion of the stroke from the catch to the finish (when the oar is in the water). This is the propulsive part of the stroke.

Term.Title: Pulling Tricks
Term.Description: To do stunts or special moves on a snowboard.

Term.Title: Pulse Oximeter equipment
Term.Description: Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive method for monitoring a patient's O2 saturation.

Term.Title: Punch Drunk
Term.Description: Dazed, bewildered, or confused from repeated dazing blows or punches to the head over an extended period of time.

Term.Title: Punching
Term.Description: The act of marking the control card with the punchin the case of electronic timing, inserting the e-punch into the slot in the control station or "e-box."

Term.Title: Punitive Damages
Term.Description: Money awarded in a lawsuit to the plaintiff in order to punish the defendant for her or his negligent, reckless or malicious conduct. It is in addition to any actual losses suffered by the plaintiff.

Term.Title: Punt (Canoe / Kayak)
Term.Description: Tip of blade in contact with the bank or other solid obstacle.

Term.Title: Punt (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A kick in which the ball is dropped and kicked before it reaches the ground.

Term.Title: Punt Return
Term.Description: When a punt is fielded by the receiving team and advanced for better field position. The punt returner generally attempts to move the ball as far up the field as possible. Alternatively, they can signal for a fair catch or allow the ball to go into the end zone for a touchback.

Term.Title: Punter
Term.Description: A kicker who specializes in punting as opposed to place kicking.

Term.Title: Pura Cup Cricket
Term.Description: http://cricket.com.au/

Term.Title: Purchas Cup
Term.Description: Annual competition for gay and inclusive rugby teams. Established in 2004 it is named after the founder of the Sydney Convicts, Andrew Purchas.

Term.Title: Brisbane Hustlers Rugby Union Football Club
Melbourne Chargers Rugby Union Football Club
Purchase
Term.Description: To acquire by the payment of money or its equivalent.

Term.Title: Purchase (Assets)
Term.Description: To obtain in exchange for money.

Term.Title: Purchase Agreement
Term.Description: A contract for the sale and purchase of services, goods, or real estate.

Term.Title: Purchase Card
Term.Description: A range of different cards that can be presented by a cardholder to make a payment.

Term.Title: Purchase Order
Term.Description: A commercial document used to request someone to supply something in return for payment and providing specifications and quantities.

Term.Title: Purchase Requisition
Term.Description: A commercial document used to request someone to supply something in return for payment and providing specifications and quantities.

Term.Title: Purchasing
Term.Description: Purchases and installs new PCs or Laptops per year plus associated software and accessories.

Term.Title: Purpura
Term.Description: The appearance of red or purple discolorations on the skin that do not blanch on applying pressure. They are caused by bleeding underneath the skin.

Term.Title: Pursuit Event
Term.Description: A multi-event race. In this type of race a Mass Start is usually used to start the events. The winner of the first event, the Mass Start event, starts the second event first, and then the rest of the skier's start behind the winner by the amount of time they finished behind them in the first event.

Term.Title: Cross Country Skiing terms and techniques
Pursuit Races
Term.Description: Short track races. There are only two skaters in this type of race and the maximum number of laps the race can last is 10. The winner of the race is the skater with the fastest time or if one skater laps the other skater.

Term.Title: Push (Hockey)
Term.Description: This shot is to pass the ball or just as a defensive move to get rid of the ball to keep it from an opposing player and pass it a short ways to a teammate.

Term.Title: Push (Table Tennis)
Term.Description: A shot that is used to return a shot that has backspin on it or a ball that is too low or too far off the table to be able to return forcefully.

Term.Title: Push Pass
Term.Description: This type of pass is used to move the ball short distances quickly. It is called a push pass because the ball stays in contact with the stick as the ball is pushed on to another player.

Term.Title: Push Shot
Term.Description: A player picks up the ball and straightens their arm to pass the ball as opposed to bending their elbow and throwing the ball with a follow through motion.

Term.Title: Push the Ball
Term.Description: To dribble up the court quickly, usually beacuse the offense has an advantage on the fast break.

Term.Title: Pushing
Term.Description: This happens when one skater, using their hands, arms or other body parts makes contact with another skater and causes that skater to fall or lose their balance.

Term.Title: Putt
Term.Description: When a player uses a putter to hit the ball with the objective of getting the ball in the hole.

Term.Title: Putter
Term.Description: A special golf club with a very low loft that makes the ball roll along the green with top-spin.

Term.Title: Putting Green
Term.Description: The objective of the golfer when he tees off. The putting green is where the hole is located. It is recognizable by the very short grass and the flag stick, sticking in the cup or hole. Usually near the club house there are practice putting greens where players will practice putting before they tee off.

Term.Title: Pythia Cup
Term.Description: http://www.australianwaterpolo.com.au

Term.Title: QAS
Term.Description: Queensland Academy of Sport http://www.qasport.qld.gov.au/

Term.Title: Queensland. Department of National Parks, Recreation, Sport and Racing
Qatar
Term.Description: Country code = QA

Term.Title: Qatar ExxonMobil Open (Tennis)
Term.Description: http://www.qatartennis.org/

Term.Title: Qatar Total Open (Tennis)
Term.Description: http://www.qatartennis.org/

Term.Title: Qingdao International Tournament (Judo)
Term.Description: http://www.intjudo.eu

Term.Title: Qld Rowing Championships
Term.Description: http://www.rowingqld.asn.au/

Term.Title: QRL Wide Bay Rugby League
Term.Description: http://www.qrl.com.au/

Term.Title: Queensland Rugby League Wide Bay Rugby League
Quad
Term.Description: A boat for four scullers.

Term.Title: Quad Class (Wheelchair Tennis) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: Players with a permanent physical disability that results in a substantial loss of movement in one or both of their legs along with one or both of their arms. Players in the quad class must meet one of the following minimum eligibility criteria: a spinal cord injury at the C8 level or above, with associated loss of movement; arm amputation, or dysmelia; arm myopathy or muscular dystrophy; a player with functional disabilities in one or both upper extremities equivalent to the afore mentioned.

Term.Title: Quad Core
Term.Description: Four processing cores in a single chip, similar to a dual-core CPU, but has four separate processors which can process instructions at the same time.

Term.Title: Quadratus Lumborum
Term.Description: Flexes vertebral column sideways.

Term.Title: Quadriceps Contusion
Term.Description: This type of injury is very common in contact sports where the muscle is crushed against the bone.

Term.Title: Quadriceps Femoris
Term.Description: A large muscle group that includes the four prevailing muscles on the front of the thigh.

Term.Title: Quadriceps Muscle Strain
Term.Description: The quadriceps muscles are the muscles on the front of the thigh. They consist of the Vastus lateralis, Vastus medialis, Vastus intermedius and the Rectus femoris. A strain is a tear in the muscle.

Term.Title: Quadriceps Tendinopathy
Term.Description: The insertion of a muscle is its lower attachment point. The quadriceps muscles insert at the top of the patella (kneecap). This injury is an overuse injury, as the pain tends to develop gradually over a period of time, rather than at a specific point.

Term.Title: Quadriplegic Athlete
Term.Description: Athlete who has paralysis affecting all four limbs. Usually athletes must have at least a 10 per cent loss of lower limb function to qualify for wheelchair status.

Term.Title: Quadruple Jump
Term.Description: A jump with four full rotations (1440 degrees) in the air. The only quadruple jumps to have been completed in competition are the toe loop and salchow by men, and just the salchow for ladies. In a quadruple Axel, the skater would have done 4.5 revolutions (1620 degrees).

Term.Title: Qualification
Term.Description: The requirement for an athlete or team to meet a qualifying standard, or progress within an event in order to be eligible to compete in a particular competition.

Term.Title: PERFORMANCE TERMS (including Sports Science and Medicine)
Quality Assurance
Term.Description: Systematic process that is designed to ensure products / services are delivered to a quality standard. Also, certification that demonstrates compliance with established standards such as Australian (AS series) and / or international (ISO series). (http://www.smallbiz.nsw.gov.au)

Term.Title: Quality Management
Term.Description: A management system which seeks to deliver total customer satisfaction through fulfilling the customer's quality requirements while continually achieving improvement in business performance.

Term.Title: Quarte
Term.Description: One of the 8 basic ways or positions to hold a weapon, and the ways in which parries are made. The name further refers to the place where the parry will be scored on the torso. Is located in the High Lines.

Term.Title: Quarter
Term.Description: A period of play. Each game is divided into four quarters of equal length. Quarters in the AFL and other senior last 20 minutes plus time-on.

Term.Title: Quarter court
Term.Description: One half of the back part of the court which has been divided into two equal parts by the half-court line.

Term.Title: Quarterback
Term.Description: Quarterbacks are members of the offensive team and line up directly behind the offensive line. Quarterbacks are the leaders of the offensive team, responsible for calling the play in the huddle.

Term.Title: Quarterback Sneak
Term.Description: A play most commonly used in very short yardage or goal line situations. The Quarterback quickly takes the snap and runs right behind or beside the center.

Term.Title: Quarter-Pipe
Term.Description: A half-pipe with only one wall that is carved out of the snow.

Term.Title: Queen Sirikit Cup
Term.Description: http://www.queensirikitcup.org

Term.Title: Queens Counsel
Term.Description: A senior barrister.

Term.Title: Queensland Athletics Association
Term.Description: www.qldathletics.org.au

Term.Title: Queensland Athletics Championships
Term.Description: Open/U23/U20 Championships Open / U18 Track & Field Championships U23 / U20 Track & Field Championships Open/U23/U20/U18 3000m & 5000m Championships Open & U18 Championships (inc. U23 & U20 4x100 4x400 Relays) U23 & U20 Championships (inc. 4x100 & 4x400 Open Relays)

Term.Title: Queensland Firebirds
Term.Description: Australian Netball Club Team

Term.Title: Queensland International Judo Open
Term.Description: http://www.jfaq.com.au/news/queensland-international-judo-open.aspx

Term.Title: Queensland Masters Games
Term.Description: The Pan Pacific Masters Games first began on the Gold Coast in 1996 and was originally called the Queensland Masters Games. In 1998 it became the larger Asia Pacific Masters Games which were held three more times on the Gold Coast - in 1998, 2000 and 2002. The event was renamed the Pan Pacific Masters Games in 2002 to reflect growing interest from Asia, Japan, the Americas, Oceania and New Zealand.

Term.Title: Queensland Raceway
Term.Description: Cunningham Highway, Amberley QLD 4306

Term.Title: Queensland Reds (Brisbane)
Term.Description: National Super Rugby Club Team

Term.Title: Queensland Rowing Championships
Term.Description: http://www.rowingqld.asn.au/

Term.Title: Queensland Rugby League Wide Bay Rugby League
Term.Description: http://www.qrl.com.au/

Term.Title: Quick Set
Term.Description: A set (usually 2 above the net) in which the hitter is approaching the setter, and may even be in the air, before the setter delivers the ball. This type of set requires precise timing between the setter and hitter.

Term.Title: Quick Stick
Term.Description: When a player is able to take a feed pass and at almost the same time is able to shoot the ball at the opposing teams goal.

Term.Title: Quickie
Term.Description: A term used to describe a bowler of fast pace.

Term.Title: Quicktime
Term.Description: Apple Computer's standard for integrating full-motion video and digitised sound into application programs.

Term.Title: Quinbolone
Term.Description: An anabolic steroid with weak androgenic effects.

Term.Title: Quinte
Term.Description: One of the 8 basic ways or positions to hold a weapon, and the ways in which parries are made. The name further refers to the place where the parry will be scored on the torso. Is located in the High Lines.

Term.Title: Quiver
Term.Description: A container for an archer's projectiles.

Term.Title: Rabbit
Term.Description: In a non-championship race, a rabbit is a runner (often paid) who is designated to lead the race through a certain distance at a set pace. Typically, a rabbit leads for half to two-thirds of the total race distance. Rabbits are used to ensure a fast pace and to alleviate the pressure to lead from the actual competitors.

Term.Title: Race Modeling
Term.Description: A training technique that consists of rehearsing specific parts or elements of the race.

Term.Title: Race to the Sony Ericsson Championships (Tennis)
Term.Description: http://www.wtachampionships.com/page/Home

Term.Title: Racket (Wheelchair Tennis) (Paralympic Sport)
Term.Description: The first tennis rackets were wooden and strings were made of ship or ewe bowels. Tennis rackets today are made of technologically advanced material such as graphite with strings made of synthetic threads. Wheelchair tennis athletes may have a special strap wound around their hand to help them hold the racket.

Term.Title: Racquet (Badminton)
Term.Description: One main piece of equipment used by players to hit the shuttlecock. A racket will typically weigh about 3 ounces and be 27 inches or 68 cm in length. The maximum width for the head is 9 inches or 23 cm and maximum length is 11 inches or 29 cm. The frames are made of ceramic or graphite.

Term.Title: Racquetball Court
Term.Description: The place where racquetball is played. The court dimensions of which are 40 feet long by 20 feet wide by 20 feet high.

Term.Title: Radar
Term.Description: Acronym for RAdio Detection And Ranging. An electronic system designed to transmit radio signals and receive reflected images of those signals.

Term.Title: Radiale
Term.Description: The point at the upper and lateral border of the head of the radius.

Term.Title: Rail
Term.Description: A piece of wood that runs along the top or lip of a half-pipe. This can also refer to the sidewall and edge of a snowboard.

Term.Title: Rail Grab
Term.Description: The snowboarders rear hand will reach across the front of their body and grabs the toe edge in front of their front binding. The snowboarders rear leg is boned.

Term.Title: Rail Slide
Term.Description: To slide the rails of a snowboard onto something other than a flat slope.

Term.Title: Railing
Term.Description: When a Snowboarder is making fast and hard turns.

Term.Title: Rainmaker
Term.Description: A very high kick that doesn't cover much ground.

Term.Title: Raking
Term.Description: This happens during a face-off when one player who is trying to get the ball attempts to sweep it away from the other player.

Term.Title: Raloxifene
Term.Description: An oral selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has estrogenic actions on bone.

Term.Title: RAM
Term.Description: Random-access memory; computer memory available to the user for creating, loading, or running programs and for the temporary storage and manipulation of data, in which time of access to each item is independent of the storage sequence.

Term.Title: Ramsay Shield (Basketball)
Term.Description: http://www.fibaoceania.com

Term.Title: Rancho Murieta Horse Show
Term.Description: http://www.murietaequinecomplex.com/

Term.Title: Randwick Racecourse
Term.Description: Randwick NSW 2031

Term.Title: Randy
Term.Description: A flip that is done with two and a half twists.

Term.Title: Range of motion
Term.Description: Movement allowed by the body's joints and position in a particular exercise.

Term.Title: Ranking
Term.Description: Ranking determines the relative competitive position of individual atheletes or teams. Rankings are generally given by a sport's governing body based on performance results.

Term.Title: Rapid Dribbling
Term.Description: This distinct type of dribbling can only be performed while the ball is low to the ground and with little bounce. It involves slapping the ball rapidly, either with one hand or alternating between both hands, creating the necessary rhythm of slaps and bounces needed to keep the ball bouncing. Gradually increasing the strength of slaps and broadening the rhythm results in "lifting" the ball up, where a normal dribble may be resumed.

Term.Title: Ratify
Term.Description: To consent or approve in retrospect; to adopt.

Term.Title: Rating (Rowing)
Term.Description: The number of strokes executed per minute by a crew.

Term.Title: Rating of perceived exertion
Term.Description: A way of measuring physical activity intensity level. Perceived exertion is how hard you feel like your body is working. It is based on the physical sensations a person experiences during physical activity, including increased heart rate, increased respiration or breathing rate, increased sweating, and muscle fatigue. Although this is a subjective measure, a person's exertion rating may provide a fairly good estimate of the actual heart rate during physical activity.

Term.Title: Ratio
Term.Description: The proportional relationship of one thing to another.

Term.Title: Ratio (Rowing)
Term.Description: The relationship between the time taken during the propulsive and recovery phases of a rowing or sculling action.

Term.Title: Ratio Decidenti
Term.Description: The legal reasoning on which a judgment is based.

Term.Title: Raw File
Term.Description: A camera file format that has as little processing done on the data in camera.

Term.Title: RBA
Term.Description: Reserve Bank of Australia

Term.Title: RCA Championships (Tennis)
Term.Description: http://www.rcatennis.com/

Term.Title: Reaching
Term.Description: Sailing across the wind - from about 60 to about 160 off the wind.

Term.Title: Reaching Sail
Term.Description: A specifically designed sail for tighter reaching legs. Reaching sails are often used in racing with a true wind angle of 35 to 95 degrees.

Term.Title: Reactive Oxygen Species
Term.Description: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are ions or very small molecules that include oxygen ions, free radicals, and peroxides, both inorganic and organic.They are highly reactive due to the presence of unpaired valence shell electrons. ROS form as a natural byproduct of the normal metabolism of oxygen and have important roles in cell signaling. However, during times of environmental stress (such as for example, UV or heat exposure) ROS levels can increase dramatically, which can result in significant damage to cell structures. This cumulates into a situation known as oxidative stress. They are also generated by exogenous sources such as ionizing radiation.

Term.Title: Reading the Green
Term.Description: The skill of looking at the green and figuring out which way the ball will move as it goes toward the hole.

Term.Title: Readme
Term.Description: Pertaining to detailed documentation, credits, miscellaneous revision history, notes, etc. for a software program.

Term.Title: Ready About
Term.Description: A call to indicate imminent tacking.

Term.Title: Real Property
Term.Description: An estate or property consisting of lands and of all appurtenances to lands, as buildings, crops, or mineral rights.

Term.Title: Realty
Term.Description: Real property or real estate.

Term.Title: Reap
Term.Description: A move that tries to sweep a rival's legs out from under them to gain the advantage.

Term.Title: Rear Back
Term.Description: A move used by an attacking player to create space between them and their defender in an attempt to become open for a pass and subsequently attempt a shot. The attacker begins to swim toward the opponent's goal and abruptly stops and slides backward awaiting a pass from a teammate.

Term.Title: Rear Foot
Term.Description: The snowboarder's foot which is mounted closest to the tail of the snowboard.

Term.Title: Rear Hand
Term.Description: The snowboarder's hand that is closest to the tail of the snowboard.

Term.Title: Reasonable Adjustment
Term.Description: The organisation takes into account a person's disability and makes appropriate adjustments to the work environment to lessen the impact of the disability. Reasonable adjustment covers job and workplace design, provision of equipment, access to the workplace and flexible work practices.

Term.Title: Rebut
Term.Description: To counter or disprove arguments or evidence presented by the opposing side in a trial. To defeat, repel, contradict, prove otherwise.

Term.Title: Rebuttable Presumption of Law
Term.Description: A legal rule or principle that can be overturned by factual evidence.

Term.Title: Receipt
Term.Description: A written acknowledgment of having received a specified amount of money.

Term.Title: Receivables
Term.Description: Business assets in the form of obligations due from others.

Term.Title: Receiving Line
Term.Description: The line that is back five feet and parallel to the short line. It is also marked by three-inch vertical lines up the side-wall.

Term.Title: Receiving Zone
Term.Description: The part of the racquetball court that goes from the rear wall to the receiving line.

Term.Title: Reconciliation
Term.Description: The process of making consistent or compatible. (http://dictionary.reference.com)

Term.Title: Recordkeeping
Term.Description: Making and maintaining complete, accurate and reliable evidence of business transactions in the form of recorded information.

Term.Title: Records
Term.Description: Any business information that documents decisions made or actions taken in the course of conducting business on behalf of an organisation.

Term.Title: Records Management
Term.Description: Records management, or RM, is the practice of maintaining the records of an organisation from the time they are created up to their eventual disposal.

Term.Title: Recourse
Term.Description: Remedies and rights under the law.

Term.Title: Recovery (Rowing)
Term.Description: The non-work phase of the stroke where the rower returns the oar from the release to the catch.

Term.Title: Recovery (Speed Skating)
Term.Description: This is the part of the stride when the skate returns from a full extension to being under the midline of the skater's body.

Term.Title: Recovery Shot
Term.Description: To get the golf ball back into a better position after having hit it into a lousy position.

Term.Title: Recruitment
Term.Description: Gathering a pool or one or more appropriately skilled candidates.

Term.Title: Rectify
Term.Description: To order the correction of an error.

Term.Title: Rectus Abdominis
Term.Description: A paired muscle running vertically on each side of the anterior wall of the abdomen.

Term.Title: Rectus Femoris
Term.Description: Extend leg at knee and flex thigh at hip.

Term.Title: Rectus Femoris Rupture
Term.Description: The rectus femoris muscle is one of quadriceps muscles. It goes from the hip to the knee and can be used to straighten the knee or lift the knee up. This muscle can rupture or become inflamed at the upper part. The main cause of this is overuse through kicking or explosive movements as in sprint starts.

Term.Title: Recurve Bow
Term.Description: This is the only type of bow that is allowed in Olympic competition. They are usually made of three pieces, the riser and two limbs, which are made of layered, laminated carbon.

Term.Title: Recycle
Term.Description: Recycling involves processing used materials into new products to prevent waste of potentially useful materials.

Term.Title: Red and Black Bloc
Term.Description: Supporter group for the Western Sydney Wanderers Football Club

Term.Title: Red Card (Football)
Term.Description: An ejection from the game for a serious foul or by having two yellow cards.

Term.Title: Red Card (Hockey)
Term.Description: A card that referees pull out of their pocket when a player is guilty of an intentional foul, such as deliberate body contact or verbal abuse of officials. The result of a red card is the penalized player being ejected from the game and suspended for her team's next game.

Term.Title: Red Card (Rugby)
Term.Description: In International matches, Red cards are shown to players who have been ordered off, which results in the player being removed from the game without being replaced. Players are usually ordered off for serious foul play, for violent conduct or for committing two offences resulting in cautions (yellow cards). Red cards are also commonly used in non-international matches in precisely the same manner as in International matches but there is no regulation requiring their use. (i.e. in a domestic match, a referee may dismiss a player without actually displaying a red card.)

Term.Title: Red Card (Volleyball)
Term.Description: A severe penalty in which an official displays a red card. The result of a red card may be a player is disqualified, the team loses the serve, or the team loses a point. A red card may be given with or without a prior yellow card as a warning; it is up to the officials discretion.

Term.Title: Red Card (Water Polo)
Term.Description: Shown by a referee to signify that a player or coach has been excluded for misconduct and is required to leave the playing area immediately and cannot return to the game.

Term.Title: Red Flag (Gridiron)
Term.Description: A weighted red marker thrown onto the field by a coach to tell the officials that he wants a certain play reviewed. Sometimes referred to as "challenge flag."

Term.Title: Red Flag (Water Polo)
Term.Description: A red flag is used by officials at the scorer / timekeeper's table to signal when a player has received three exclusion fouls and must sit out the rest of the game.

Term.Title: Red Line
Term.Description: The line that runs across the rink and divides the rink in half. This line runs through the centre face off circle.

Term.Title: Redlake cameras
Term.Description: High speed high resolution digital camera.

Term.Title: Redundancy
Term.Description: The termination of an employee's empoyment when the employer no longer requires the job performed by the employee to be performed by anyone. The employee becomes surplus to the operational requirements of the organization.

Term.Title: Reentrant
Term.Description: A small, relatively shallow valley running down a hillside, where water could flow. On a map, the contour lines point uphill where a reentrant occurs.

Term.Title: Orienteering Land Forms and Map Symbols
Reeve
Term.Description: To thread a line through blocks in order to gain a mechanical advantage.

Term.Title: Referee
Term.Description: A referee is the official person responsible for presiding over a game, match or bout and enforcing the rules of the sport. In different sports the official may also be known as an Umpire, Linesman or Judge. Within some sports there may be more than one presiding Referee.

Term.Title: Referee (Tennis)
Term.Description: A tennis Referee is an off-court official. The Referee assures that the overall competition is fair and played following the rules and regulations related to that competition. The Referee supervises all aspects of play during a competition including the conduct of players, coaches, spectators, etc. Where the Chair Umpire has the final say on issues relating to on-court activities, the Referee ensures the rules of tennis are properly enforced and acts as the final authority on all questions relating to ther rules of Tennis. For instance when it is the players opinion that the Chair Umpire misinterprets a rule, they have the right to appeal to the Referee. Referees duties also include, but are not limited to, the making of the draw according to the competitions regulations and the scheduling of the matches to be played.

Term.Title: Reference data
Term.Description: Data describing a physical or virtual object and its properties.

Term.Title: Data dictionary for the National Injury and Illness Database
Reflex
Term.Description: An automatic response induced by stimulating a receptor.

Term.Title: Reflex Bow
Term.Description: A form of bow in which the entire length of the handle and arms curve away from the archer.

Term.Title: Regatta
Term.Description: A series of boat races.

Term.Title: Regions Morgan Keegan Championships (Tennis)
Term.Description: http://www.memphistennis.com/home

Term.Title: Registered Testing Pool
Term.Description: The pool of top level Athletes established separately by each IF and National Anti-Doping Organisation who are subject to both In-Competition and Out-of-Competition Testing as part of that IFs or National Anti-Doping Organisations test distribution plan. Each IF shall publish a list that identifi es those Athletes included in its Registered Testing Pool either by name or by clearly defined, specific criteria.

Term.Title: Registrar
Term.Description: The principal administrative officer of a court.

Term.Title: Registry
Term.Description: A database used by Microsoft Windows to store configuration information about the software installed on a computer.

Term.Title: Regular
Term.Description: When a snowboarder is riding with the left foot forward.

Term.Title: Regular Season
Term.Description: The portion of the season that is scheduled ahead-of-time excluding any bowl game, conference championship, or playoff games.

Term.Title: Rehabilitation
Term.Description: Rehabilitation of individuals to the best possible level of physical, mental, emotional, social or vocational wellbeing through education and / or therapy.

Term.Title: Rehydration
Term.Description: To restore moisture or fluid to something dehydrated.

Term.Title: Reimbursement
Term.Description: To make repayment to for expense or loss incurred. (http://dictionary.reference.com)

Term.Title: Related Party
Term.Description: Parties are considered to be related if one party directly or indirectly has the ability to control or jointly control the other party or exercise significant influence over the other party in making financial and operating decisions.

Term.Title: Relative Bearing
Term.Description: A bearing relative to the direction of the ship.

Term.Title: Relay (Swimming)
Term.Description: When four different swimmers are on a team and swim in the same race, one right after the other.

Term.Title: Relay Exchange
Term.Description: The exchange made between members on a relay team, which would be one swimmer who is in the water and the next swimmer who is on the starting block. In an ideal exchange the swimmer in the water will touch the touch pad and the swimmer on the blocks will be ready to jump off the starting block.

Term.Title: Relay Zone
Term.Description: On a short track oval there are 4 relay zones that are marked off my two blue lines at the borders of the zone and by a red line running through the middle of the zone. Relays can take place in any one of the four zones between the blue lines. But when there are 3 laps or less left in the race then the pass off must be between the first blue line and the red line.

Term.Title: Release (Rowing)
Term.Description: At the end of the drive portion of the stroke. It is when the oar blade(s) is removed (or released) from the water.

Term.Title: Release (Water Polo)
Term.Description: To break free from a defender to receive a pass.

Term.Title: Relief Pitcher
Term.Description: The pitcher replacing the starting pitcher. The relief pitcher can win, lose, save, or not be involved in the games final score.

Term.Title: Remedy
Term.Description: Redress; make up for a wrong.

Term.Title: Remuneration
Term.Description: Payment; The complete pay package awarded employees on an annual basis, including all forms of money, benefits, services, and in-kind payments.

Term.Title: Repair
Term.Description: To restore to sound condition after damage or injury; fix.

Term.Title: Repeal
Term.Description: Cancellation of a statute or part of a statute or act.

Term.Title: Repechage
Term.Description: A practice in some sporting competitions that allows athletes or teams who failed to win heats or to meet qualification (by the smallest margin) to continue to the next round of the competition.

Term.Title: Repechage (Rowing)
Term.Description: The second chance race given to those crews which fail to qualify for the finals from an opening heat. Rep qualifiers move onto semi-finals or finals depending on the number of entries. Used in international racing.

Term.Title: Repetition (Strength & Conditioning)
Term.Description: Number of times a movement is repeated within a single exercise set.

Term.Title: Repetition maximum
Term.Description: The maximum load that a muscle group can overcome for a given number of repetitions before fatigue prevents further muscle action. The 10 RM, for example. is the maximum load that can be overcome for 10 repetitions.

Term.Title: Repetitive Strain Injury
Term.Description: RSI: an injury of the musculoskeletal and nervous systems that may be caused by repetitive tasks, forceful exertions, vibrations, mechanical compression (pressing against hard surfaces), or sustained or awkward positions.

Term.Title: Replace
Term.Description: To provide a substitute or equivalent in the place of.

Term.Title: Replacement
Term.Description: Substitute

Term.Title: Report
